PREFACE 
    This volume, as originally published, constituted the first revision and codification of the general ordinances of the City of Liberty, Missouri, since 1931. It contained the Charter and such of the ordinances of a general and permanent nature passed on or before December 31, 1963, as were found desirable for retention, except those expressly saved from repeal by the Adopting Ordinance. 
    The Code, as now supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including the ordinance indicated on the page of instructions for handling supplemental pages. 
    The ordinances were codified, edited and indexed by the Editorial Staff of Michie City Publications Company under the supervision of Chas. W. Sublett, Stephen C. Willard and M. Paul Cook. 
    The publishers wish to express their appreciation for the cooperation of all the city officials and employees during the preparation of this publication. Particular acknowledgment is due the Honorable Wesley M. Smith, Mayor, Mr. Gary C. Clifton, City Attorney, and Mr. Charles S. Anderson, City Administrator, for their assistance during the progress of the work. 
    A feature to which the attention of the user is directed is the arrangement of the chapters in alphabetical order. Attention is also directed to the analysis preceding each chapter which, in many instances, will serve as an index within itself. The general index, carried at the end of the Code, has been carefully prepared and should serve as an accurate medium for locating the individual sections of law within the Code. In the footnotes appearing throughout the Code will be found references to the Charter and the applicable state law. These notes also contain cross references to other and related provisions in the City Code. By reference to the historical citations, appearing at the end of each section, the user will be able to ascertain the ordinance from which the present section has been derived. 
    It is a recognized fact that if any Code is to accomplish its intended purpose it must be kept up to date by means of an adequate supplemental service. Accordingly, the publishers point out the advisability and necessity of keeping this Code current. 
    The new City Code is presented to the officials and citizens of the City of Liberty, Missouri, in the belief that it will merit their approval. 
Michie City Publications Company 
Charlottesville, Virginia 
    Commencing with the publication of Supplement No. 14 in 1980, supplementation of the Code has been provide by Municipal Code Corporation of Tallahassee, Florida. The Code has been republished by Municipal Code Corporation in 2002 with the inclusion of ordinances received for codification subsequent to Supplement No. 37 to the 1964 publication. 
    The page numbering system used in the republication of this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
Charter CHT:1 Charter Comparative Table CHTCT:1 Code CD1:1 Code Appendix CDA:1 Code Comparative Table CCT:1 Code Index CDi:1  
    The republication of the Code was under the direct supervision of Robert S. Hornyak, Editor, and credit is gratefully given to the members of the publisher's staff for their able assistance throughout the project. 
ORDINANCE NO. 2933 
ENTITLED AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE 
LIBERTY CITY CODE 
    BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of the City of Liberty, Missouri, as follows: 
SECTION I 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of the City of Liberty, Missouri" and be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as "Liberty City Code." 
SECTION II 
    In the construction of this Code and of all other ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless it shall be otherwise expressly provided in any section or ordinance, or unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council, or unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Chief Administrative Officer. Wherever the words "chief administrative officer" appear in this Code, they shall mean the city administrator. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Liberty, Missouri. 
    City Council. The words "city council" or "the council" shall mean the city council of Liberty. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day: and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that shall be excluded. 
    County. The words "the county" shall mean the County of Clay, State of Missouri. 
    Gender. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the masculine, females as well as males, and associations and bodies corporate as well as individuals, shall be deemed to be included. 
    Joint authority. Words importing joint authority to three or more persons shall be construed as authority to a majority of such persons. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Number. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the singular number, the plural and separate matters and persons and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include a corporation, firm partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit as well as individuals. It shall also include an executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed according to law. Whenever the word "person" is used in any section of the Code prescribing a penalty or fine, as to partnerships or associations, the word shall include the partners or members thereof, and as to corporations, shall include the officers, agents or members thereof who are responsible for any violation of such section. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and tangible and intangible personal property. 
    Public way. The words "public way" shall include any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare. 
    Real Property. The terms "real property," "premises," "real estate" or "lands" shall be deemed to be co-extensive with lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall, may. The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean that portion of the street between the curb line and the adjacent property line which is intended for the use of pedestrians, including sidewalks over private property where curb line and property line are the same. 
    Signature. Where the written signature of any person is required, the proper handwriting of such person or his mark shall be intended. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Missouri. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean and include any public way, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley or other public thoroughfare, and each of such words shall include all of them. 
    Tangible personal property. "Tangible personal property" shall include goods, chattels and all personal property, except intangible personal property. 
    Tenant, occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Writing. The words "writing" and "written" shall include printing, lithographing or any other mode of representing words and letters. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year, unless otherwise expressed, and the word "year" shall be equivalent to the words "year of our Lord." 
    All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. 
SECTION III 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such section, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of "The Code of the City of Liberty, Missouri," shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
SECTION IV 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of the Code shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code since the same would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional or invalid phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
SECTION V 
    Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be repealed or modified, either expressly or by implication, by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an ordinance thus repealed or modified shall continue in force until the ordinance repealing or modifying the same shall go into effect unless therein otherwise expressly provided; but no suit, prosecution, proceeding, right, fine or penalty instituted, created, given, secured or accrued under any ordinance previous to its repeal shall in anywise be affected, released or discharged, but may be prosecuted, enjoyed and recovered as fully as if such ordinance or provisions had continued in force, unless it shall be therein otherwise expressly provided. 
SECTION VI 
    When an ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall itself be repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it be expressly so provided and such former ordinance, clause or provision is set forth at length. 
SECTION VII 
    This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage by the city council and approval by the mayor. 
    PASSED by the city council this 8th day of September, 1969. 
/s/ Wesley M. Smith 
MAYOR 
ATTEST: 
/s/ Betty J. Bell 
City Clerk 
APPROVED by the mayor this 8th day of September, 1969. 
/s/ Wesley M. Smith 
Mayor

PART I - THE CHARTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The City of Liberty operates under a special charter, approved by the state of Missouri on March 28, 1861. Thus, Liberty is a special charter city as that term is defined by RSMo 81.010. Such Special Charter, as amended, is set forth in this volume, as approved by the state of Missouri, except for certain editorial changes such as the employment of uniform capitalization, supplying catchlines and frontal analysis. 

ARTICLE I. - INCORPORATION; FORM OF GOVERNMENT; POWERS; WARDS 
Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Missouri, as follows: 

Section 1. - Incorporation. 
    All that district of country contained within one mile square, of which the court house of Clay County, in the City of Liberty, is the center, the sides of the square being respectfully parallel to the corresponding sides of said court house, shall be and the same is hereby erected into a city, by the name of "The City of Liberty," and the inhabitants thereof are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic by the name and style of "The Mayor, Councilmen and Citizens of the City of Liberty"; and by that name they and their successors forever, shall have perpetual succession, shall sue and be sued, implead and be impleaded, defend and be defended, in all courts of law and equity, and in all actions whatsoever; may contract and be contracted with; may purchase, receive and hold property, real and personal, within said city, and may sell, lease or dispose of the same for the use and benefit of the city; and may purchase, receive and hold property, real and personal, beyond the limits of the city, to be used as cemetery grounds for the use of the city, or for the establishment of a hospital for the reception of persons infected with contagious or other diseases, or for the erection of a poorhouse and farm, or work house, or house of correction; and may sell, lease or dispose of such property for the benefit of the city; and may do all the acts as natural persons; they may have and use a common seal, and may break, alter, change and make a new seal at pleasure. 
Section 2. - Wards. 
    The City of Liberty hereby created, as soon as may be, shall be divided into six wards, by the present council of said city, so as to include, as near as may be, the same number of free white male inhabitants in each ward; and the city council shall have power to alter or change the boundaries of said wards from time to time as they may see fit, or to increase or diminish the number of said wards, having a regard to the number of free white male inhabitants as aforesaid, so that each ward shall have, as aforesaid, as near as may be, an equal number of male inhabitants. 
ARTICLE II. - THE COUNCIL 

Section 1. - Number; election. 
    The corporate powers of the inhabitants hereby incorporated under the name and style of the mayor, councilmen, and citizens of the city of Liberty, shall be vested in and expressed by a city council, said city council to consist of one member from each ward, and one at large, to be elected by a general ticket by the registered qualified voters of said city of Liberty, on the first Tuesday in April, 1919, and every two years thereafter. 
    (Section as amended by Session Acts 1927, Page 357). 
Section 2. - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be a member of the city council unless he be a citizen of the State of Missouri, over the age of twenty-one years, and shall have resided within the city limits two years next preceding his election, and be a bona fide resident of the ward for which he is elected, and a registered qualified voter of said city. 
    (Section as amended by an act approved March 25, 1868, Session Acts 1868, p. 219). 
Section 3. - Effect of moving from ward. 
    If a councilman shall, after his election, remove from the ward from which he was chosen, his office shall be thereby vacated. 
Section 4. - President pro tempore. 
    The council, in the absence of the mayor, shall elect one of their number to be president pro tem of the council; and the president pro tem thus elected shall, during the absence from the city of the mayor, or a vacancy in the office, or of the inability of the mayor to serve, perform all duties of mayor. 
Section 5. - Elected officers. 
    At the annual election of members of the city council as aforesaid, the registered qualified voters of said city shall elect a city attorney, city treasurer, city constable, and a city clerk, and auditor, who shall respectively hold their offices until their successors are duly elected and qualified; and provided further, that no person is eligible to any office within the city who is not a registered qualified voter of said city. 
    (Section as amended by Session Acts 1927, page 357). 
Section 6. - Judges of elections; contested elections. 
    The mayor and the city council shall be the judge of all election returns and qualifications of such mayor, members of the city council, and other city officers, and shall determine contested elections. 
Section 7. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the city council shall constitute a quorum to do business; but a smaller number may meet and adjourn from day to day, and may compel the attendance of absent members, in such manner and under such penalties as the council may prescribe. 
Section 8. - Rules of procedure; expulsion of members. 
    The council may determine the rules of their proceedings, punish their members for disorderly conduct, and with the concurrence of two-thirds of all the members elected, expel a member, but not the second time for the same offense. 
Section 9. - Journal. 
    The mayor and council shall keep a journal of their proceedings; and the yeas and nays of the members on any question shall, at the desire of any member present, be entered on the journal. 
Section 10. - Eligibility of mayor or councilmen for other office. 
    Neither the mayor or any member of the council shall, during the time for which he or they are elected, be appointed to any office under the provisions of this act unless a petition to that effect be signed by the qualified voters of the city. 
Section 11. - Vacancies. 
    All vacancies that occur in the council shall be filled in such manner as shall be provided by ordinance. 
Section 12. - Affidavit as to residence. 
    Every member of the council, before entering upon the duties, shall, in addition to the oath of office hereinafter required, make affidavit that it is his bona fide intention to reside within the ward for which he was elected, during the term for which he was elected; and such oaths shall be in lieu of and shall dispense with an analogous provision, hereinafter provided to other officers of the city in their oaths of office. 
Section 13. - Tie vote in election of mayor or councilmen. 
    Whenever there shall be a tie in the election of members of the council, the judges of election shall certify the same to the mayor, or person exercising the duties of mayor, who shall immediately thereupon issue his proclamation, stating such facts, and ordering a new election; and if such tie shall occur upon any election for mayor, such judges of election shall certify same to the city council, and such council, after qualification, shall elect between such candidates having an equal number of votes; and in the further event that neither of such candidates for mayor shall receive a majority of the votes of said council, a new election for mayor shall be ordered by said city council, within a period and upon notice to be prescribed by ordinance. 
Section 14. - Meetings. 
    There shall be stated meetings of the council once in every calendar month, at such time and place as the council may designate, and other and further meetings of said council may be convened by the mayor, or the person in discharging the duties of mayor, at any time in his discretion; provided always, that said mayor and council may adjourn any meeting from day to day, or to any time within said calendar month. 
Section 15. - Entering ayes and nays under certain conditions. 
    Upon the passage of all and every bill appropriating money, imposing taxes, or increasing, lessening or abolishing licenses, or borrowing money, the ayes and nays shall be entered upon the journals, upon the motion of the mayor, or any member of the council present. 
Section 16. - Majority vote required in certain cases. 
    A majority of all members of the council shall be necessary to pass any tax bills, or bills appropriating any sum amounting to one hundred dollars, or any other bill or bills involving the like amount in anywise increasing, affecting or diminishing the city revenue. 
ARTICLE III. - LEGISLATIVE POWERS 

Section 1. - Enumerated. 
    The city council shall have power within the city, by ordinance: 
    1st.-To levy and collect taxes, not exceeding one and one-quarter per centum per annum, upon the assessed value of all property made taxable by law for state and other purposes, and also to provide for the collection of the same by the sale of all real estate and personal estate within the city, in such manner as this act or the council of said city by ordinance shall provide. 
    2nd.-To borrow money upon the credit of the city, upon the votes of two-thirds of the members of the council. 
    3rd.-To appropriate money and provide for the payment of the debts, appropriations, contracts, liabilities and expenses of the city. 
    4th.-To make regulations to guard against and prevent the introduction of contagious and infectious diseases into the city, and to make quarantine laws for that purpose, and enforce the same within five miles of the city. 
    5th.-To establish hospitals, employ physicians, attendants, and procure drugs and medicines, and to make regulations for the government and care thereof. 
    6th.-To make regulations to secure the general health of the inhabitants, and to abate, prevent and remove nuisances. 
    7th.-To provide the city with water by digging wells, making cisterns, improving springs and creeks, and erecting and providing pumps on the streets, avenues and sidewalks within the boundaries of the city, for the convenience of the inhabitants thereof. 
    8th.-To create, open, abolish, alter, widen, extend, establish, grade, pave or otherwise improve, and to clean, macadamize and keep in repair all streets, avenues, lanes and alleys within the city, with the express restriction that the council shall not establish or open any street, lane, avenue or alley through any property, which has not been laid out by the owner or owners thereof in town lots, and a plat thereof filed according to law, unless by the written consent of the owners of such property: provided, always that the council may by ordinance require the owners of such property, when laid out into lots or out-lots, to have the streets, lanes, avenues or alleys to correspond as nearly as may be with the streets, lanes, avenues or alleys in the city; and no such street, lane, avenue or alley shall be opened, located or altered, unless such city council shall pay the owner of such real estate such damages as may be found due such proprietor, to be ascertained by a jury of twelve men, or by any other provisions as the council may by ordinance prescribe, or by other legal proceedings. 
    9th.-To establish, erect and keep in repair bridges, culverts and sewers, and to regulate the use of the same. 
    10th.-To establish, support and regulate the night watch and patrol. 
    11th.-To erect market houses, establish markets and market places, and provide for the government of the same. 
    12th.-To provide for the erection of all needful buildings for the use of the city. 
    13th.-To provide for inclosing and improving any real estate belonging to the city. 
    14th.-To license, tax and regulate auctioneers, grocers, merchants, retailers, dramshop keepers, ordinaries, taverns, druggists and apothecaries. 
    15th.-To license, tax, regulate, restrain and suppress hawkers, peddlers, shows, theatricals and other performances and exhibitions. 
    16th.-To license, tax and suppress, prohibit and restrain gaming and gambling houses, keepers of billiard tables, nine or ten-pin alleys. 
    17th.-To provide for the extinguishment of fires, to organize and establish fire companies, and to provide necessary and suitable engines, hose, buckets, ladders, fire-hooks and other apparatus; and also to regulate the erection of wooden buildings, in any part of the city; to regulate and prevent the carrying on of any business, pursuit or manufactory of a character to cause or produce fires, or prejudicial or injurious to the health of the inhabitants, and to compel the owners of houses and other buildings to have scuttles upon such houses or buildings, and stairs or ladders leading to the same. 
    18th.-To regulate and order the cleaning of chimneys, and to fix the flues thereof; to regulate the storage of gunpowder, tar, rosin, pitch, hemp, cotton and all other combustible materials, and to regulate the use of lamps and lighted lamps and candles in all stables, shops and other places; to remove or prevent the construction of any fireplace, stone hearth, chimney, oven, boiler, kettle, or apparatus used in any house, building, manufactory or business which may be adjudged dangerous in causing or promoting fires; to prohibit under suitable penalties, the firing of firecrackers or other squibs, and the discharging of fire arms; to direct the construction of deposits for ashes; and to enter into at reasonable hours, or to appoint one or more officers, at reasonable times, to enter into and examine all out-houses, lots, yards, enclosures, and outbuildings of every description, in order to see if such places or buildings are in a dangerous, unhealthy or offensive state, and to cause such as may be found by verdict of a jury to be dangerous, unhealthy or offensive, to put in a safe, healthful and secure condition. 
    19th.-To provide for the inspection and weighing of hay, the storing and measuring of charcoal, stone-coal, fire-wood and other fuel to be used in the city. 
    20th.-To regulate the inspection of butter, lard and other provisions, vending of meat, poultry, butter, meat, eggs and fruits, and suppress huckstering within market hours. 
    21st.-To provide for taking an enumeration of the inhabitants of the city. 
    22nd.-To provide for the election of all elective city officers, and provide for the removing from office any person holding an office created by this act or by ordinance, not otherwise provided for. 
    23rd.-To provide for the appointment of all officers, servants and agents of the corporation not otherwise provided for; to fix the compensation of the city officers, and regulate the fees of all jurors, witnesses and others for services rendered under this act or any ordinance. 
    24th.-To regulate the police of the city; to impose fines, forfeitures and penalties for the breach of any ordinance; and to provide for the recovery and appropriating such fines and forfeitures and the enforcement of such penalties. 
    25th.-To erect a work house and a house of correction, and provide for the regulation and government thereof. 
    26th.-To levy and collect a poll tax not to exceed two dollars upon every free male person over eighteen years of age, who shall have resided six months within the city. 
    27th.-To remove all obstructions from the sidewalks, and provide for the construction, grading, paving and repairing of all sidewalks, and for the cleaning of the same, and of the gutters, at the expense of the owners of the ground fronting thereon. 
    28th.-To prevent and restrain any riot, noise, disturbance or disorderly assemblage in any street, house or place in the city. 
    29th.-To prevent and remove all obstructions in and upon all streets, lanes, avenues and alleys, established by law or ordinance. 
    30th.-To have and exercise complete and perfect control over any commons of the city, and all the property belonging to the city, real and personal, whether lying in or beyond the limits of the corporation created by this act, and the same to lease, sell, transfer and dispose of, either absolutely or with limitation, to any person or persons whatsoever. 
    31st.-To make such general rules, regulations, bylaws, and ordinances for the purpose of maintaining the peace, good government and order of the City of Liberty, and the trade and manufactures, thereof, as the city council may deem expedient, and for that purpose may make and enforce any ordinance or ordinances for the apprehension and holding in custody of all or any offenders against the laws of said city, until the said offender or offenders can be brought to proper trial, and may enforce the observance of all laws, rules, regulations, bylaws and ordinances which may be passed by said city council under this act, by inflicting penalties upon any person or persons for the violation of any ordinance or law. 
    32nd.-To make all ordinances, subject to the restrictions in the last preceding subdivision of this section specified, which shall be necessary and proper for carrying into effect the powers vested by this act in the corporation, the city government or any department or office thereof. 
    33rd.-That all taxation laws passed by the city council, other than those applying to hucksters, menageries, circuses, concerts, theatricals, exhibitions and similar amusements, billiard table keepers, and the retail trade in spirituous liquors, whether the same is to be drunk at the place sold or not, and whether the same is sold by grocer, druggist, merchant, dramshop keeper, hotel or tavern keeper, shall be based upon the ad valorem principle, and no other occupation, business or pursuit, other than those herein designated, shall be taxed by such council, but in lieu thereof, the amount of capital employed in such business, pursuit, profession or occupation shall be taxed at the same rates that other property real and personal is taxed by law or ordinance. 
    34th.-No money shall be drawn from the city treasury except in pursuit of an ordinance or resolution of the city council, regularly passed at a regular or special meeting of the council. 
    35th.-Every ordinance or resolution passed by the city council shall be signed by the mayor or president pro tem of the council, and attested by the clerk of the city council before it shall have or take effect; provided, however, that, if the mayor shall neglect or refuse to sign such resolution, order or ordinance within two (2) months after it shall have been passed by the city council, then the same is become as valid as if it had received the approval of the mayor and attestation of the city clerk; and in the event that the mayor shall veto any measure whatever passed by the city council the same may be passed over his veto, by a vote of two-thirds of the whole council. 
    36th.-The style of the ordinances of the city shall be: "Be it ordained by the city council of the City of Liberty." 
    37th.-All ordinances passed by the city council, within thirty (30) days after they become laws, shall be published in pamphlet form, or in some newspaper printed in the City of Liberty, in the discretion of the city council; but the failure to publish any ordinance within the time specified in this section, shall not render void or affect the validity of any such ordinance, unless such delay may cause such ordinance to act retrospectively on the rights of individuals. 
    38th.-All ordinances of the city may be proved by the seal of the present city corporation, and when such ordinance or ordinances have been published by authority of the corporation, they shall be received as evidence in all courts and places, without further proof. 
(Ord. No. 4918, 1-28-85, approved 4-2-85) 
Section 2. - Bonded indebtedness. 
    Not less than four-fifths of the taxes levied and collected annually upon the property of the inhabitants of said city shall constitute a special tax to be applied toward the payment of the bonded indebtedness of said city or the interest thereon, and shall be paid in current funds or coupons of the bonds of said city, passed due, or maturing during the current fiscal year. 
Section 3. - Payment of current expenses. 
    The balance of the taxes so levied and collected, and not applied to the payment of the bonded indebtedness of said city, shall be applied to the payment of the current expenses of said city, as the council thereof may direct. 
(Article 3 amended by act approved March 14, 1874, Session Acts 1874, p. 337.) 
(For additional powers of City of Liberty, see RSMo 71.010 et seq; 81.010 et seq., 85.005 et seq., 86.010 et seq., 87.005 et seq., 88.010 et seq., 89.010 et seq., 90.010 et seq., 91.010 et seq., 94.340 et seq., 95.115 et seq., 99.010 and 100.010 et seq.) 
ARTICLE IV. - EXECUTIVE AND MINISTERIAL OFFICES 

Section 1. - Mayor-Election; term of office. 
    The chief executive officer of the city shall be the mayor, who shall be elected by the registered qualified voters of the city, at each election for city officers, and shall hold his office for two years and until his successor is elected and qualified; provided, that any election to fill a vacancy shall only be for the remainder of the time for which his predecessor was elected. 
    (Section as amended by Session Acts of 1927, page 357). 
Section 2. - Same-Qualifications. 
    No person shall be mayor, who at the time of his election is not possessed of the qualifications for a city councilman, or who holds any lucrative office under the authority of the United States. 
Section 3. - Same-City council to decide election in certain cases. 
    If two or more persons shall have an equal number of votes for mayor, or if the election shall be contested, the city council elected for the same term shall decide the election by a vote. 
Section 4. - Same-Vacancy. 
    Whenever a vacancy shall happen in the office of mayor, it shall be filled by election in such time and manner as the city council by ordinance may provide. 
Section 5. - Same-Removal. 
    The mayor may be removed from office for any misdemeanor by a vote of two-thirds of the whole council. 
Section 6. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The mayor shall act as president of the city council, and shall have power to nominate, and by and with the consent of the city council, appoint all city officers not ordered by this act appointed or elected. He shall take care that the ordinances of the city are duly enforced, respected, and observed within the city; he may remit fines, punishments, forfeitures, and penalties accruing or imposed for the violation of any law or ordinance of said city, by and with the consent of the city council; he may fill all vacancies which may occur in any elective office other than a member of the city council, until the same be filled by election, and in any other office until the end of the next session of the city council which may happen after the vacancy occurs; he shall, from time to time, give to the city council information relative to the state of the city, and shall recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall deem expedient for the advantage of the city. The mayor, while presiding in the city council, shall have no vote on any measure or question except there be a tie, in which case he shall give the casting vote. 
    (Section as amended by an act approved March 25, 1868, Session Acts 1868, p. 219.) 
Section 7. - Same-Authority to call special meetings. 
    The mayor may call special meetings of the council by proclamation or by written notice, or by verbal notice to members of the council. 
Section 8. - Same-Same-Purpose to be stated. 
    Whenever a special meeting of the council shall have been called by the mayor, he shall state to them, when assembled, the cause for which they have been convened. 
Section 9. - City recorder. 
    The city recorder shall be ex officio clerk of the city council, and in addition to the duties imposed upon him by this act, shall perform such other duties as recorder or clerk as the city council, by ordinance, may prescribe. 
Section 10. - Authority of city council to designate elective officers. 
    The city council may by ordinance provide for the election of officers of said city, not herein made elective by the qualified voters of said city. 
Section 11. - Duties of clerk of city council. 
    It shall be the duty of the clerk of the city council to keep a journal of the proceedings of the council; to record in a separate book all ordinances or resolutions appropriating money; to keep a record of all the official acts of the mayor, and, when necessary, to attest the same. He shall keep and preserve in his office the common seal of the city, and all records, public papers and documents not properly belonging to any other office. 
Section 12. - Duties of city treasurer. 
    It shall be the duty of the city treasurer to receive and keep the money of the city, and to pay out the same on warrants drawn by the mayor, or other officer authorized by ordinance to draw them; and to perform such other duties as the council prescribe. 
Section 13. - City constable. 
    The city constable shall, within the city, possess the same powers, perform the same duties, and receive the same fees and compensation, as the constable of Liberty township for similar services. He shall execute and return all process to him directed, whether issued by the mayor, recorder or any member of the city council, or by any justice of the peace, where such justice is authorized to issue process under this act or any ordinance of the city. He shall also be ex officio collector of the city taxes. He shall attend each meeting of the city council, and perform such services as the council may require of him. He shall have power to arrest all offenders against the law or any ordinance of the city, and secure or hold in custody the same, until he, she or they can be brought to proper trial. 
Section 14. - Mayor, etc., to reside in city. 
    The mayor and all other officers of the city shall reside within the city limits during their continuance in office. 
Section 15. - City recorder. 
    The recorder of the city shall be a resident of the city, and shall possess the same qualifications as mayor of the city and the city council, and shall hold his office one year, and until his successor is duly elected and qualified. Such recorder shall be removed from the office in the same manner as the mayor. He shall have the same jurisdiction as justices of the peace. He shall have exclusive jurisdiction over all cases arising under any ordinance of the city; subject, however, in all cases to an appeal to the circuit court of Clay county; and every such appeal shall be granted as in this act expressed. He shall have power to take and certify, under the sale of the city, the acknowledgment of deeds, conveyances and all other instruments of writing requiring authentication. He shall be authorized to administer oaths or affirmations, and take depositions; and such deeds, conveyances and all other instruments may be recorded in any county in this state, and may be read in any court or place of this state as evidence, without further authentication. He shall be entitled in all cases to the same fees which are now or may be hereafter allowed to justices of the peace for similar services, which shall be taxed and collected as other costs by fee bill or execution. 
Section 16. - City attorney. 
    The city attorney shall have resided six months within the city next prior to his election, and shall be a licensed lawyer, admitted to practice at the bar of the Clay county circuit court. He shall at all times give legal advice to any officer of the city, shall prescribe the forms of deeds and other instruments of writing in which the city is interested or a party, and shall perform such other duties as the city council may by ordinance direct and prescribe. 
Section 17. - Absence, etc., of city recorder. 
    In the event of the absence, sickness, removal or other inability of the recorder to act, any justice of the peace, residing within the limits of the city, shall have power to issue all process in, and to hear, try and determine all cases properly recognizable before the recorder; and if no justice of the peace resides within the city, then any justice of the peace within and for Liberty township shall be possessed with the same powers herein granted to justices residing in said city. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTIONS 

Section 1. - When held. 
    A general election of all the officers of the corporation required to be elected by this act, or by any ordinance of the city, shall be holden on the first Monday of April in each year, unless otherwise provided by ordinance. 
Section 2. - Manner of conducting generally. 
    At all elections for city officers the voters shall vote by ballot, and the manner and place of holding such elections shall be regulated by ordinance of the city subject to the registration and election laws of the state. 
    (Section as amended by act approved March 25, 1868, Session Acts 1868, at p. 219.) 
Section 3. - Judges. 
    Three judges of election, who shall be registered qualified voters, and two clerks, shall be appointed by the city council, unless otherwise provided for by the registration law of the State of Missouri, and they shall take an oath or affirmation to faithfully discharge their duties, according to law, as judges and clerks aforesaid. They shall open their poll books at nine o'clock in the morning, and keep them open until six o'clock in the afternoon, when they shall close the same, and proceed forthwith to ascertain and certify the result of the election in the presence of so many candidates or other persons who may deem proper to be present; provided, there shall not be less than three others present at any count. 
    (Section as amended by act approved March 25, 1868, Session Acts 1868, at p. 219). 
Section 4. - Holding elections in grogshop, etc., prohibited. 
    No election shall be held in a grogshop or other place where intoxicating liquors are vended. 
Section 5. - Qualifications of voters. 
    All qualified voters of the State of Missouri, who shall have resided within the city sixty days next preceding any election, shall be qualified voters at said election. 
    (Section as amended by Section RSMo 10178 929. See also RSMo 115.133) 
Section 6. - Opening and closing polls, etc. 
    Elections for city officers shall not be continued for longer than one day, and during that day the polls shall not be closed longer than two hours, between the time of opening and closing the same finally. 
Section 7. - Special elections. 
    Special elections shall be held under such regulations as may be provided by ordinance. 
ARTICLE VI. - OPENING AND WIDENING STREETS 

Section 1. - Grading, etc., streets. 
    It shall not be lawful for the city council to grade, pave or macadamize any street, lane or avenue not opened or established according to law. It shall be lawful, nevertheless, for the city council to order the owners of ground fronting on any private alley to keep the same clean, and if necessary thereto to direct him to pave the same. 
Section 2. - Eminent domain-Generally. 
    When it is necessary to take private property for opening, widening, altering or extending any public street, lane or avenue, the corporation shall make a just compensation therefor to the person whose property is so taken; and if the amount of such compensation cannot be agreed upon, the recorder shall cause the same to be ascertained by twelve disinterested freeholders of the city. 
Section 3. - Same-Ascertainment of benefits. 
    In opening, altering, widening, extending alleys through blocks or squares of the city, the same proceedings shall be had in case of opening, widening, altering or extending public streets, lanes or avenues, with the addition that the jury will ascertain the amount of benefit that will accrue to the person whose property is so taken, and those who may have petitioned for the opening, widening, etc., of such alleys. 
Section 4. - Petition by abutting property owners to open, etc., streets, etc. 
    When the owners of the major part of the front of all property on the street, lane, avenue or alley proposed to be opened, widened or extended, shall petition therefor, the mayor and city council may open, widen, alter or extend such street, lane, avenue or alley, upon conditions to be prescribed by ordinance, but no compensation shall be in such case made to those whose property shall be taken for opening, widening, altering or extending such street, lane, avenue or alley, who have petitioned for the same; nor shall there be any assessment of benefit or damages that may accrue thereby to any of the petitioners. 
Section 5. - Jurors to establish damages, etc., in eminent domain proceedings-Generally. 
    All jurors empaneled to inquire into the amount of benefit or damage which shall happen to any owner of property proposed to be taken for opening, widening, altering or extending any street, lane, avenue or alley, shall first be sworn to that effect, and shall return to the mayor their inquest in writing, signed by each juror. 
Section 6. - Same-Authority of mayor to set aside, etc. 
    The mayor shall have power, for good cause shown, within ten days after any inquest shall have been returned to him as mentioned in the preceding section, to set the same aside, and cause new inquest to be made. 
Section 7. - Same-Authority of mayor, etc., to enforce payment for benefits. 
    The mayor and city council shall have power, by ordinance, to enforce the payment of all sums which a jury shall declare to be the amount of benefit accruing to the owners of the property upon any alley which shall be opened, widened, altered or extended, if the owner be one of the petitioners for opening, widening, altering or extending such alley. 
Section 8. - Special tax for paving, etc. 
    The mayor and city council shall have power, by ordinance, to levy and collect a special tax of the holders of any lots on any street, lane, avenue or alley, according to the respective fronts owned by them for the purpose of paving or grading such street, lane, avenue or alley: provided always, said tax shall not exceed one per centum; nor shall the grading or paving be done at the expense of the owners of the lots fronting on the street, lane, avenue or alley, unless a petition for such grading and paving, signed by the owners of the major part of the ground fronting thereon, be presented for such purpose. 
Section 9. - Redemption of property sold for taxes. 
    The city council shall have power, by ordinance, to direct the manner in which any property, real or personal, advertised for sale or sold for taxes, general or special, or for the cost of any improvement done or ordered to be done by authority of the corporation, may be redeemed. 
Section 10. - Assessment of open, etc., land. 
    Lands within the limits of the city, which have not been laid off into blocks or lots, shall not be taxed or assessed otherwise than by the acre as agricultural or waste land, and shall continue to be so taxed or assessed until laid off into blocks or lots by the owners thereof, respectively, and the owners of such lands, in laying off the same into blocks or lots, shall so arrange the streets that they shall correspond with previously established streets of the city. 
Section 11. - Lot, etc., owners to keep street, etc., clean. 
    The city council shall have power, by ordinance, to compel all occupants of house or houses, fronting on any street, lane or avenue, to keep the part of the street, lane or avenue immediately in front of their houses clean of all trash and rubbish; and where the street, lane or avenue immediately in front of any house is macadamized or paved, to keep the same clear of all mud or dirt. 
ARTICLE VII. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Section 1. - Annual financial statement. 
    The city council shall cause to be published at the end of each fiscal year, a full, complete and detailed statement of all moneys received and expended by the corporation during the preceding fiscal year, and what account received and expended, classifying each receipt and expenditure under its appropriate head. 
Section 2. - Effect of prior ordinances, etc. 
    All ordinances and resolutions now in force in the City of Liberty, previous to the passage of this act, and not inconsistent with this act, shall remain in full force until altered, modified or repealed by the city council under the provisions of this act, and all officers elected in pursuance of any law or ordinance of the corporation of the City of Liberty, previous to the passage of this act, and now in office, shall so remain in office until the time for which they were elected expires. 
Section 3. - Style of law suits. 
    All suits, actions and prosecutions instituted, commenced or brought by the corporation hereby created, shall be instituted, commenced and prosecuted in the name of "Mayor, Councilmen and Citizens of the City of Liberty." 
Section 4. - Rights of prior corporation. 
    All actions, fines, taxes, penalties and forfeitures which have accrued to the corporation, or the "Mayor, Councilmen and Citizens of the City of Liberty," under their corporation previous to the passage of this act, and the ordinances or bylaws of said corporation, for the receiving of which no suit or action at law shall have been commenced or instituted, shall be and the same is hereby vested, and may be prosecuted for, by the corporation hereby created. 
Section 5. - Status of law suits instituted by prior corporation. 
    All suits or action at law for the recovery of any fines, taxes, penalties or forfeitures arising under the present corporation of the City of Liberty, or under any ordinance, law, or bylaws thereof, instituted or pending in any court in the name of the "Mayor, Councilmen and Citizens of the City of Liberty," and not prosecuted to final judgment, shall not thereby abate or be discontinued in consequence of the passage of this act, but the same shall be in everywise proceeded with by the corporation hereby created in such manner, with same power, as the corporation hereby repealed. 
Section 6. - Property, etc., of prior corporation. 
    All property, real, personal and mixed, and choses in action, heretofore belonging to the City of Liberty, or to the mayor, councilmen, and citizens of said city, in their corporate capacity, shall be and the same is hereby declared to be vested in the corporation hereby created. 
Section 7. - Obligations of prior corporation. 
    All debts, obligations and contracts due from, entered into, or incurred by the present corporation of the City of Liberty, or the mayor, councilmen and citizens thereof, in their corporate capacity, shall be fully paid, satisfied and fulfilled by the corporation hereby created, as fully, to all intents and purposes, as the said corporation hereby repealed, and are liable for and bound to discharge the same. 
Section 8. - Prior acts, etc. 
    This charter shall not invalidate any act or acts done by the present corporation of the City of Liberty, or any officer thereof, nor divest them of any right that may have accrued to them prior to the passage of this act. 
    (Repealed by act approved March 25, 1868, Session Acts 1868, at p. 219.) 
Section 9. - Charter as a public act. 
    This act is hereby declared to be a public act, and may be read in evidence in all courts of law or equity in this state, without further proof. 
Section 10. - Persons exempted from road work, etc. 
    All persons living within the limits of the City of Liberty are hereby exempted from working upon any road without and beyond the boundaries of said city, and from paying any fine or penalty to be applied to employ any laborers, or furnish means or provide materials to work or be used upon any road beyond the limits of said city. 
Section 11. - General penalty. 
    Any person who shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay any fine or cost imposed by judgment of the municipal court upon conviction of misdemeanor, or of any installment thereof, shall be proceeded against in like manner and be subject to orders of court in the same manner as is provided by the laws of the State of Missouri with respect of such default for a fine is imposed upon conviction of a misdemeanor under the laws of the State of Missouri relating to offenses against the peace and dignity of the state, including enforcement of payment and collection authorized by state law with respect to State offenses constituting misdemeanors. (Ord. No. 4918, 1-28-85, approved 4-2-85) 
Section 12. - Misdemeanors. 
    The city council shall, by ordinance, prescribe in what a misdemeanor in said City of Liberty shall consist, or what shall constitute the same. 
Section 13. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall terminate on the day preceding the second Monday in March of each year; and such period of termination of said fiscal year may be altered or changed by the city council by ordinance. 
Section 14. - Publication of ordinances. 
    (Repealed by an act approved March 21, 1865, Session Acts 1865, at p. 421, which enacts a new section as follows: 
    "There shall be a digest of the ordinances of the city which are of a public or general nature published in a newspaper or in pamphlet form, or in both, as often as the city council shall deem necessary, and that a like digest of all ordinances shall be made within five (5) years from the passage of this amendatory act, and a like digest every ten (10) years thereafter.") 
Section 15. - Delinquent officers. 
    The city council shall provide by ordinance for the collecting from any delinquent officer of the city any revenue, money, or property improperly detained or not accounted by such officer; and may provide the penalty or punishment of such delinquency or failure to account for such money or property. 
Section 16. - Issuance of scrip, etc. 
    The city council, or any officer or department thereof, shall not have power to issue any bills, scrip, or paper of any description whatever, to circulate as currency or representative thereof; but any warrant, note, or draft, obligation and bond of the city may be transferred and made transferable by a proper endorsement of the holder, under such restrictions and regulations as the city council may prescribe. 
Section 17. - Redemption of property sold for taxes. 
    Whenever any real estate shall have been advertised for sale, or shall have been sold, for the payment of any fine, judgment, penalty, forfeiture, or taxes, in consequence of the failure of the owner thereof to do any duty by ordinance prescribed, such owner or owners, whether resident or nonresident of said city, may within two (2) years after such sale, redeem the same by paying to the purchaser thereof the full amount of said purchase money and all taxes subsequently paid thereon, together with all cost, and the full value of any useful or necessary improvement made thereon by such purchaser, to be assessed by a jury of twelve (12) householders before the recorder of said city, together with one hundred (100) per centum on the original amount of purchase money paid therefor by each purchaser. 
Section 18. - Certificate of purchase of real estate sold for taxes, etc.-Generally. 
    Any purchaser of any real estate sold for the nonpayment of any fine, judgment, penalty, forfeiture, or taxes, or in consequence of the failure of the owner thereof to do some duty by ordinance imposed, upon the payment to the treasurer of the corporation hereby created of the purchase money thereof shall receive of and from such treasurer a certificate of the payment of the amount of purchase money, describing such real estate by lot and number upon the recorded plat of the Town of Liberty, or by metes and bounds thereof, and briefly describing the judgment, penalty, forfeiture, tax, or improvement, for the nonpayment of which the same was sold, together with the date of each sale; which certificate shall be countersigned by the mayor of said city, under the seal of the city. 
Section 19. - Same-Failure of owner to redeem, within two years. 
    Any holder of such certificate, after the lapse of two (2) years from the date, (if the owners of such real estate shall have failed, neglected, or refused to redeem the same in the manner thus prescribed), upon the production of such certificate at any regular session of the city council, and upon said council, or a majority of them, be satisfied by the affidavit of such purchaser, or otherwise, that the said owner has failed to redeem the real estate therein described, within two (2) years after the sale of such real estate and the date of such certificate, such purchaser shall receive a deed of conveyance from the said corporation, conveying to such purchaser the real estate described in such certificate. 
Section 20. - Same-Deed of conveyance. 
    The deed of conveyance above described shall be made and executed by the mayor of the City of Liberty in the name of said city, and shall recite the judgment, penalty, forfeiture, or neglected improvement, together with the law and ordinance under which the same was sold; the advertisement for sale, and the time, place, and terms of sale; the consideration, the certificate granted by the treasurer, and the failure to redeem; and shall convey the premises as described in such certificate by the operative words, "assign, transfer, convey, and confirm" to such purchaser, and his or her heirs and assigns forever. Such conveyance shall be signed by said mayor and attested under the seal of said corporation, and shall be acknowledged before any officer, other than the recorder of said city, authorized to take acknowledgments of instruments of writing conveying real estate under the laws of the State of Missouri. 
Section 21. - Same-Same-Effect. 
    Such deed of conveyance so executed and acknowledged shall vest in such purchaser all the right, title and interest, estate and property of the previous owners of such real estate, and shall be admitted in evidence in any court within this state in any suit or action at law or in equity, as evidence of title, without further proof. 
Section 22. - Right of heirs, etc., to redeem property sold for taxes, etc. 
    The owners of any real estate sold under the provisions of this act, or his widow, executor, administrator, or heirs, may, within any time within two (2) years after such sale, redeem the same in and after the same manner in which the owner, had he lived, might redeem the same; and upon said payment, shall receive from said council, attested by mayor or under the seal of said city, a quietus to the title thereto, conforming as near as may be, to the quietus granted by the State of Missouri under analogous circumstances; and such quietus shall fully vest all the title to such real estate in the original owners. 
Section 23. - Disposition of surplus money from sale of real estate for taxes, etc. 
    All surplus money received by the corporation hereby created, arising from the sale of any real estate, over and above the amount due for taxes, penalties, forfeitures, fines, judgments and costs, shall be paid into the city treasury; and the owner of such real estate at the time of such sale, or his legal representatives, may apply to the city council for such surplus, who shall issue a warrant on the city treasurer in favor of the owner of such real estate at the time of such sale, or his representatives, for such amount paid into the treasury for his use. 
Section 24. - Prosecutions for misdemeanors. 
    All prosecutions for misdemeanors shall be instituted before the recorder, or other officer having jurisdiction thereof, as is in this act herein expressed and provided. 
Section 25. - Pre-emptory challenges. 
    All persons charged with a misdemeanor shall be entitled to four (4) pre-emptory challenges, and the city attorney shall be entitled to two (2) pre-emptory challenges. 
Section 26. - Punishment for misdemeanor. 
    All persons charged with and convicted of a misdemeanor for violation of a city ordinance shall be punished as provided by ordinance, but not to exceed a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
    (As amended by act approved March 25, 1868, Session Acts 1868, p. 219; Ord. No. 4918, 1-28-85, approved 4-2-85) 
Section 27. - Appeals to county court from judgment of recorder-Generally. 
    The true intent and meaning of this act is, that an appeal shall be allowed to the Clay County circuit court, from the final judgment of the recorder or other officer having jurisdiction of the subject matter (other than contempt of court), or from the finding of any jury within the time prescribed by this act, any law or usage or any provision or construction of this act to the contrary notwithstanding. 
Section 28. - Same-Procedure. 
    Whenever an appeal shall have been allowed to the Clay County circuit court, from the verdict or finding of any jury, or from the judgment or finding of the recorder or any officer having jurisdiction under this act, such appeal, if involving a charge of misdemeanor, shall be tried by circuit court, by a jury of six (6) men, or by the judges of the circuit court; and such misdemeanor shall be punished in the manner and according to the provisions of this act, and the ordinance of the city council governing such original trial, not inconsistent or repugnant to the same, any law or usage to the contrary notwithstanding; and if such appeal be taken from the judgment of the recorder or other officer having jurisdiction under this act, or from the finding of a jury, in any action brought to recover any tax, fine, penalty and forfeiture, other than a misdemeanor for the breach of any law, ordinance or bylaw of said city, such action shall be tried before such circuit court as appeals of justices of the peace, and shall be governed and determined in all respects and particulars as nearly as may be, according to such existing laws, ordinance or bylaw of the City of Liberty, and the provisions thereof, before such recorder or other officer having jurisdiction upon such original trial, any law or usage to the contrary notwithstanding. 
Section 29. - Charges for misdemeanors-Generally. 
    That all charges of misdemeanors, and all statements of cause of action occurring under any law, ordinance or bylaw of the City of Liberty, inflicting any fine, penalty, forfeiture or tax, shall be filed before the recorder or other officer having jurisdiction under this act, before the said officer or officers can hear, adjudge and determine the same, and such charge or statement shall describe such course of action, and the particular law, ordinance or bylaw under which the same occurred, in plain and intelligible language, expressed in writing and signed by the city attorney, in such manner as to render the same a clear and perfect statement of the cause of action. 
Section 30. - Same-Procedure for arrest, etc. 
    Upon filing the statement of the cause of action hereinbefore provided, the officer having jurisdiction of such cases shall immediately issue his warrant to the constable of the city, or of the Township of Liberty, or any sheriff of Clay County, commanding him to forthwith apprehend the person or persons charged with any offense or misdemeanor in the charge or statement filed with such officer as aforesaid, and bring the same before such officer issuing the warrant, (or any other having jurisdiction under this act), forthwith, to be dealt with according to law. The warrant above provided shall be under the hand of such officer issuing the same, and have affixed thereto the common seal of the city. If deemed necessary and proper by city council, the statement of the cause of action shall also contain the proper warrant as aforesaid, for the arrest of any person charged with any misdemeanor or other offense against the laws of the city; but when such warrant is incorporated in said charge or statement, the same shall be attested by the city attorney, and signed by the recorder or other officer having jurisdiction of same with the common seal of the city affixed thereto. 
Section 31. - Same-Same-Prerequisites to fair trial. 
    When such warrant is served on any person or persons charged with any misdemeanor or other offense against the city, such person or persons so served shall have time given them by the officer before whom they are brought, to procure counsel, witnesses and other things requisite for a fair and impartial trial. 
Section 32. - Same-Same-Witnesses. 
    In all trials before the recorder or other officer having jurisdiction, arising under this act, such officer shall have as full and as perfect power in the subpoenaing of witnesses and compelling the attendance thereof, and inflicting penalties for the refusal of any witnesses to attend a trial when subpoenaed, as any court of law or equity in this State is possessed of; and the mode and manner of subpoenaing witnesses by such officer shall be regulated by ordinance of the city council. 
Section 33. - Same-Same-Continuance. 
    No suit instituted before the recorder or other officer, for the recovery of any fine, tax, penalty or forfeiture for the breach of any city law, bylaw or city ordinance, shall be continued by such recorder or other officer, even upon good cause shown, for a longer time than two days at any one time; continuances shall be at the cost of the party applying therefor, unless otherwise ordered by the officer granting the same. 
Section 34. - Holding certain suits under advisement. 
    No suit or action for the recovery of any fine, tax, forfeiture or penalty arising under this act, shall, after the hearing of the same, be held under advisement by any officer before whom the same is tried for a longer time than one hour. 
Section 35. - Time within which appeals to be taken, etc. 
    All appeals from the verdict of any jury or rendition of any judgment, by and before the recorder or other officer under this act, shall be taken by plaintiff or defendant within ten days after such finding or judgment; and the affidavit and bond, and other matters connected with such appeal, shall conform in all respects as near as may be to the laws of this State regulating appeals from judgments rendered by justices of the peace to the circuit court. 
Section 36. - Proceedings before recorder-Generally. 
    The practice and proceedings before the recorder under this act, for the recovery of any fine, tax, forfeiture or penalty for the breach of any bylaw or ordinance of the city, (unless when otherwise expressly provided), shall conform in all respects, as near as may be, to the laws of this State regulating justices' courts. 
Section 37. - Same-Imprisonment. 
    In all cases where a judgment shall be rendered by the recorder or other officer having jurisdiction under this act for the recovery of any fine, tax, penalty, forfeiture or costs, for the breach of any law, bylaw or ordinance of the City of Liberty, or upon the verdict or finding of a jury, and such verdict, finding or judgment, or any part thereof, involves the imprisonment of the defendant, it shall be the duty of said recorder or other officer to forthwith order such defendant into the custody of the city constable or other officer, and to issue a mittimus or commitment, committing such defendant to the common jail of Clay county; and such defendant shall, from the making of such order, or the issue of such commitment, remain in safe custody, unless discharged by the taking of an appeal as hereinbefore provided, or discharged by due course of law. 
Section 38. - Execution of orders, etc., within county. 
    The city constable or other officer entrusted with the execution of any command, power or trust under this act, shall execute such command, power or trust, in any part of Clay county. 
Section 39. - Qualifications of jurors. 
    In selecting jurors to try any case arising under this act, it shall be lawful to select any person or persons qualified to act as jurors under the laws of this State, whether the same reside within the city limits, or in the county of Clay. 
Section 40. - Elections as to regulating dramshops, etc. 
    The city council shall have power at any time to order an election to test the sense of the qualified voters residing within the limits of the City of Liberty, upon the subject of licensing groceries, dramshops, taverns and inns, for the purpose of vending, at retail, spirituous or vinous liquors, or either of the above named houses, and also on the subject of licensing billiard tables within the limits of the city; such elections shall be governed by such rules, and conducted in such manner, as the city council may provide. 
Section 41. - Repealed. 
    (Repealed by act approved March 25, 1868, Session Acts 1868, at p. 219.) 
Section 42. - Right of General Assembly to alter, etc., city charter. 
    The General Assembly of the State of Missouri may at any time alter, repeal or amend this charter. 
Section 43. - Repeal of inconsistent acts. 
    All acts or parts of acts, contrary or inconsistent with the provisions of this act, or within provisions thereof, be and the same are hereby repealed. 
Section 44. - Transmittal of true copy of city charter. 
    It shall be the duty of the Secretary of State of Missouri, within six (6) days after this act is approved by the governor, or otherwise becomes a law, to transmit a true copy thereof, certified under the seal of the State of Missouri, to the clerk of the county court of Clay County. 
Section 45. - Effective date. 
    This act shall take effect and be in force from and after the day of its passage. 
    Approved March 28, 1861. 
    I hereby certify the above copy of a law, entitled "An act to incorporate the City of Liberty," is a true copy of the original roll of said law as now on file in this office. 
(SEAL) 
In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my name and affixed the seal of office. Done at this office the 2nd day of May, A.D. 1861. 
B.F.Massey, 
Secretary of State
