Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of the City of Liberty, Missouri" and be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as "Liberty City Code." 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction.[1] 
    In the construction of this Code and of all other ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless it shall be otherwise expressly provided in any section or ordinance, or unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council, or unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Chief administrative officer. Wherever the words "chief administrative officer" appear in this Code, they shall mean the city administrator. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Liberty, Missouri. 
    City council. The words "city council" or "the council" shall mean the city council of Liberty. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that shall be excluded. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.040. 
    County. The words "the county" shall mean the County of Clay, State of Missouri. 
    Gender. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the masculine, females as well as males, and associations and bodies corporate as well as individuals, shall be deemed to be included. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.030. 
    Joint authority. Words importing joint authority to three or more persons shall be construed as authority to a majority of such persons. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.050. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.020(10). 
    Number. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the singular number, the plural and separate matters and persons and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.030. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include a corporation, firm partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit as well as individuals. It shall also include an executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed according to law. Whenever the word "person" is used in any section of this Code prescribing a penalty or fine, as to partnerships or associations, the word shall include the partners or members thereof, and as to corporations, shall include the officers, agents or members thereof who are responsible for any violation of such section. 
State Law reference- See RSMo, 1.020(11). 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.020(14). 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and tangible and intangible personal property. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.020(15). 
    Public way. The words "public way" shall include any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare. 
    Real property. The terms "real property," "premises" "real estate" or "lands" shall be deemed to be co-extensive with lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.020(16). 
    Shall, may. The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean that portion of the street between the curb line and the adjacent property line which is intended for the use of pedestrians, including sidewalks over private property where curb line and property line are the same. 
    Signature. Where the written signature of any person is required, the proper handwriting of such person or his mark shall be intended. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Missouri. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean and include any public way, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley or other public thoroughfare, and each of such words shall include all of them. 
    Tangible personal property. "Tangible personal property" shall include goods, chattels and all personal property, except intangible personal property. 
State Law reference- For state law definition of "personal property", see RSMo 1.020(12). 
    Tenant, occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Writing. The words "writing" and "written" shall include printing, lithographing or any other mode of representing words and letters. 
State Law reference- See RSMo,  1.020(21). 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year, unless otherwise expressed, and the word "year" shall be equivalent to the words "year of our Lord." 
State Law reference- See RSMo 1.020(10). 
    All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Construction of statutes generally, see RSMo 1.010-1.210. 

Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such section, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of "The Code of the City of Liberty, Missouri," shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-4. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code since the same would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional or invalid phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
Sec. 1-5. - Repeal of ordinance not to affect liabilities, etc. 
    Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be repealed or modified, either expressly or by implication, by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an ordinance thus repealed or modified shall continue in force until the ordinance repealing or modifying the same shall go into effect unless therein otherwise expressly provided; but no suit, prosecution, proceeding, right, fine or penalty instituted, created, given, secured or accrued under any ordinance previous to its repeal shall in anywise be affected, released or discharged, but may be prosecuted, enjoyed and recovered as fully as if such ordinance or provisions had continued in force, unless it shall be therein otherwise expressly provided. 
Sec. 1-6. - Repeal not to revive former ordinance. 
    When an ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall itself be repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it be expressly so provided and such former ordinance, clause or provision is set forth at length. 
Sec. 1-7. - Cross reference notations on amended or repealed ordinances to contain number of ordinance affecting amendment or repeal. 
    Whenever any ordinance is amended or repealed, a notation on the ordinance amended or repealed shall be made giving the number of the ordinance amending or repealing such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2422,  1) 
Sec. 1-8. - Ordinances to be presented at two city council meetings before passage; exceptions. 
    All ordinances, except ordinances relating to appropriations, shall be presented at two separate city council meetings before being passed by the city council; provided, that the provision of this section may be waived by the unanimous consent of all council members present at any meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2423,  1, 2) 
Sec. 1-9. - Self-preemption. 
    No provision of the Liberty City Code shall apply to any circumstance in which such application shall be unlawful under superseding federal or state law and furthermore, if any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this Code is now or in the future superseded or preempted by state or federal law or found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unauthorized, such provision shall be automatically interpreted and applied as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 10832,  II, 12-11-17) 
Sec. 1-10. - Enforcement; attorneys' fees. 
    The city shall be entitled to enforce any provision of this Code through all remedies lawfully available, and any person determined to have violated the terms of this Code shall further be liable to pay the city's costs and attorneys' fees in enforcing such Code provisions. Additionally, any user of city services, rights-of-way, or other city facilities or property, shall, as a condition of such use or continued use, to the full extent permissible by law, be liable to pay the city's costs and attorneys' fees incurred in enforcing any lawful requirement applicable to such use, whether arising in contract, statute, ordinance, or other enforceable duty as to such use. 
(Ord. No. 10831,  III, 12-11-17) 
Sec. 1-11. - Violation; remedies; unauthorized holdover. 
    Any person who fails to hold and maintain a current and valid agreement with the city to use the city's land or facilities has no right to holdover and shall be subject to the provisions and city remedies of this section in addition to all other remedies and penalties as may otherwise exist in applicable law. Any claimed holdover right shall be deemed void and terminated upon expiration of a valid use agreement unless the city has affirmatively in writing authorized the holdover, or as otherwise may be required by law. Where a rights-of-way use agreement, lease, or other agreement for use of public land or facilities expires, and in addition to any penalties or other requirements therein, the licensee during any period without a valid agreement shall or during any period of unauthorized use shall: (1) indemnify the city from any liability arising from the use, (2) pay any damages and costs of the city from such use, including attorney fees incurred in enforcing this ordinance, and (3) make payment of compensation in the amount of two (2) times the monthly rent of the last expired agreement, if a holdover, and two (2) times the market rental value reasonably determined by the city, if no prior agreement, until a valid agreement is executed with the city or the attachments and/or use is fully removed, the property restored and all obligations to the city satisfied. Unless otherwise provided in an unexpired agreement, Licensee shall also be responsible for interest on all amounts owed and at a rate of one and one-half (11/2) per cent per month. Nothing in these provisions, remedies or compensation requirements, or acceptance or enforcement thereof by the city, shall be deemed to accept or authorize any use of public property without a required agreement, or after the expiration of such agreement, or otherwise in violation of applicable requirements. 
(Ord. No. 10831,  III, 12-11-17) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Secs. 2-1-2-103 were adopted by Ord. No. 3636 on March 8, 1976. 
Cross reference- Court, fines and imprisonment, Ch. 10; elections, Ch. 11; finance, Ch. 13; taxation, Ch. 27. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City seal established. 
    There shall be a common seal of the city. 
Sec. 2-2. - Description of the seal. 
    The device of the common seal shall be a representation of the goddess of liberty, standing upon a rock and holding in her right hand a staff, supporting a cap, with a scroll of parchment in her left hand, partly unrolled, whereon is inscribed the word "Liberty" in Roman capitals; and encircled around the device with the following words in Roman capitals: "City of Liberty, Missouri," which seal shall be circular and not to exceed two inches in diameter. 
Sec. 2-3. - Seal kept by city clerk. 
    The city clerk shall be the keeper of the common seal of the city, and custodian of said seal. 
Sec. 2-4. - Affixing seal. 
    The common seal shall be affixed to all the official certificates or documents of the City of Liberty required by this Code. 
Sec. 2-5. - City limits. 
    A showing of the limits of the city shall be maintained on an up-to-date map located in the department of community development. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY OFFICERS 

Sec. 2-6. - City council, number of members. 
    There shall be elected two (2) council members from each ward in the city who shall hold office for a term of four (4) years; provided, that at the general city election on April 6, 1971, there shall be elected one council member from each ward, who shall serve for a term of four (4) years, and at the next city general election on April 4, 1972, there shall be elected one council member from each ward who shall serve for a term of one year, after which election there shall be elected at each succeeding general city election for municipal officers, one council member from each ward who shall serve for a term of four (4) years. 
Sec. 2-7. - Council regular meetings. 
(a)  Time. The city council shall hold regular meetings on the second and fourth Mondays of each month, at 7:00 p.m.; provided, however, that when the day fixed for any regular meeting of the council falls upon a day designated by law as a legal or national holiday, such meeting shall be held at the same hour on the next succeeding day not a holiday, unless otherwise provided by the council. 
(b)  Place. All regular meetings of the council shall be held in the council chamber of the City Hall unless otherwise designated by the mayor and city council. 
Sec. 2-8. - Council special meetings. 
    The mayor shall call special meetings of the council whenever, in his opinion, the public business may require it, by proclamation, or verbal or written notice to all members of the council at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of a scheduled special meeting, with publication of said notice to appear in at least one newspaper of general distribution within the City of Liberty. 
Sec. 2-9. - Adjourned meetings of council. 
    Any meeting of the city council may be continued or adjourned from day to day, or for more than one day, but such adjourned meeting must be reconvened prior to the next regular scheduled meeting thereafter. 
Sec. 2-10. - Council agenda. 
    The city administrator shall be responsible for the preparation of the agenda and it should be delivered to the mayor and council at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to each council meeting. 
Sec. 2-11. - Presiding officer of council. 
    The mayor shall act as presiding officer of the city council. The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at regular and special meetings of the council. He shall state every question coming before the council, announce the decision of the council on all subjects and decide all questions of order and procedure, unless overruled by a two-thirds majority vote of the council. In the event of the absence of the mayor, the president pro tem of the council shall preside at city council meetings. 
Sec. 2-12. - Call to order of council. 
    The presiding officer shall take the chair at the hour appointed for the meeting and shall call the council to order. 
Sec. 2-13. - Roll call of council. 
    Before proceeding with the business of the council, the city clerk or deputy shall call the roll of members, and the names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. 
Sec. 2-14. - Council quorum. 
    A majority of the members of the council shall constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting of the council. No action shall be valid unless a majority in attendance shall vote in favor of such action, except as may be provided in other ordinances requiring a larger favorable vote for adoption. 
Sec. 2-15. - Council order of business. 
    Meetings of the council shall be open to the public except for executive sessions as authorized by state statute. The order of business shall be as follows: 
(1)  Call to order. 
(2)  Invocation. 
(3)  Roll call. 
(4)  Approval of minutes of previous meetings. 
(5)  Citizens' participation. 
(6)  Swearing-in ceremony (if any). 
(7)  Meeting schedule. 
(8)  Consent agenda. 
(9)  Public hearings (if any). 
(10)  Ordinances, contracts and resolutions. 
(11)  Other business. 
(12)  Miscellaneous matters from city administrator. 
(13)  Miscellaneous matters from mayor and city council. 
(14)  Adjournment. 
(Ord. No. 5549,  1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 2-16. - Reading of council minutes. 
    Unless a reading of the minutes of a council meeting is requested by a member of the council, such minutes may be approved without reading if the members of the council have been previously furnished with a copy thereof. 
Sec. 2-17. - Council rules of debate. 
(a)  Getting the floor. Every member desiring to speak shall address the chair, and, upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine himself to the question under debate. 
(b)  Interruptions. A member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it be to call him to order by the presiding officer, or as herein otherwise provided. If a member, while speaking, be called to order, he shall cease speaking until the question of order be determined, and, if in order, he shall be permitted to proceed. 
(c)  Motion to reconsider. A motion to reconsider any action taken by the council shall be made either immediately during the same session, or at a recessed or adjourned session thereof. Such motion must be made by one of prevailing side, but may be seconded by any member, and may be made at any time and have precedence over all other motions or while a member has the floor; it shall be debatable. 
(d)  Request for remarks to be entered in minutes. A council member may request of the presiding officer the privilege of having an abstract of his statement on any subject entered into the minutes. 
(e)  Entering synopsis of debate in minutes. The city clerk may be directed by the presiding officer to enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming regularly before the council. 
Sec. 2-18. - Addressing the council. 
    Any person desiring to address the council shall first secure the permission of the presiding officer; provided, however, unless the mayor rules otherwise, persons shall address the council only when the order of business moves to: 
(1)  Citizens' participation, for matters not shown on the published agenda; and 
(2)  Any item shown on the published agenda which is applicable to their purpose for wishing to address the council. 
Preference shall be given to persons who have notified the deputy city clerk in advance of their desire to address the council. 
Sec. 2-19. - Manner of addressing the council; time limit. 
    Each person addressing the council shall approach the podium, give his name and address in an audible tone of voice for the record, and shall limit his address to an announced time limit. No person, other than the mayor and council and the person having the floor, shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, either directly or through a member of the council, without the permission of the presiding officer, provided that a majority vote of the council may overrule the presiding officer. 
Sec. 2-20. - Abstaining from voting. 
    Unless a member of the council states that he is abstaining, his failure to vote shall be recorded as a vote with the majority. Any member of the council shall abstain from voting due to a stated conflict of interest. 
Sec. 2-21. - Council decorum. 
(a)  Responsibility of council members. While the council is in session, the members must preserve order and decorum, and a member shall, neither by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the council nor disturb any member while speaking or refuse to obey the orders of the council or presiding officer, except as otherwise herein provided. 
(b)  Persons addressing the council. Any person making personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks, or who shall become boisterous while addressing the council shall forthwith, by the presiding officer or by a majority vote of the council, be barred from further audience before the council, unless permission to continue be granted by a majority vote of the council. 
Sec. 2-22. - Enforcement of council decorum. 
    The presiding officer may designate a sergeant-at-arms of the council meetings, who shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer, or enacted by a majority vote of the council, for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the council meetings. 
Sec. 2-23. - Council members' protests against council action. 
    Any council member shall have the right to have the reasons for his dissent from or protest against any action of the council entered on the minutes. 
Sec. 2-24. - Ordinances, resolutions, motions, and contracts. 
(a)  Every motion, resolution and ordinance shall be reduced to writing before the vote is taken thereon, and upon consideration of passage of every ordinance appropriating money, imposing taxes, or increasing, lessening or abolishing licenses, or borrowing money, the "Ayes" and "Nays" shall be called and recorded. 
(b)  Introducing for Passage or Approval. 
(1)  Ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects requiring action by the council must be introduced and sponsored by the mayor or a member of the council, except that the city administrator may present ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects to the council, and any council member may assume sponsorship thereof by moving that such ordinances, resolutions, matters, subjects be adopted; otherwise, they shall not be considered. 
(2)  All proposed ordinances shall be given a document number by the city clerk and shall be adopted by reference to the document number and an ordinance number. 
(3)  All ordinances except ordinances relating to appropriations shall be presented at two (2) separate city council meetings before being adopted by the city council; provided that such provision may be waived by the unanimous consent of all council members present at any meeting. Ordinances not relating to appropriations or considered on first reading shall be passed to second reading. 
(4)  The style of ordinances shall be: "Be it ordained by the city council of the City of Liberty, Missouri, as follows:" 
(5)  The city clerk shall note the passage and effect of any ordinance on prior ordinances modified, amended or repealed. 
(Ord. No. 8821,  I, 5-9-05) 
Sec. 2-25. - Council reports, ordinances and resolutions filed with city clerk. 
    All reports, ordinances and resolutions shall be filed with the city clerk and entered on the minutes. 
Sec. 2-26. - Adjournment of council. 
    A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
Sec. 2-27. - Affidavits by council members prerequisite to office. 
    The members of the city council in addition to the affidavit required by the Charter of the city shall, before entering upon the duties of their offices, respectively, make affidavits under oath that they will support the Constitutions of the United States and of the State of Missouri, and that they will, to the best of their skill and ability, diligently and faithfully, without partiality or prejudice, discharge the duties of their offices according to the Constitution and laws of said state. 
Sec. 2-28. - Affidavits by ministerial officers other than council members. 
    All ministerial officers of the city, other than members of the city council, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices shall, respectively, make affidavit under oath that they will support the Constitutions of the United States and of the State of Missouri, and that they will, to the best of their skill and ability, diligently and faithfully, without partiality or prejudice, discharge the duties of their offices according to the Constitution and laws of this state; and that it is their bona fide intention to reside within the city for the term of office for which they are elected or appointed. 
Sec. 2-29. - Code of ethics. 
(a)  Mission statement. The proper operation of a democratic government requires that public officers be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made within the proper channels of governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, a code of ethics for all public officers is hereby adopted. The purpose of this code is to establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all public officers of the city by setting forth those acts or actions that are not reasonably compatible with the best interests of the city and by directing disclosure by such public officers of interest in matters affecting the city. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Business entity means any corporation, limited liability company, general or limited partnership, sole proprietorship (including a private consulting firm, person, entity or operation), joint venture, unincorporated association or firm, institution, trust, any combination of individuals and/or artificial entities, foundation, or other organization, whether or not organized for profit. 
(2)  Confidential information means all information which is: (i) specifically identified and termed as being confidential, (ii) communicated orally or in writing, and (iii) of such a nature that it is not, at the time of such communication, a matter of public record or public knowledge. For purposes of this section, the phrase "public record" shall be deemed to refer to all written information, documents, and other matter to which the public has a right of access under the Missouri Sunshine Law (RSMo 610.010 et seq.) or under any other state or federal statutes pertaining to open records, and the phrase "public knowledge" shall refer to information which is reasonably available to members of the public. 
(3)  Gift means any item or thing which has a reasonable value exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) and which is given or received without the substantially contemporaneous exchange of an item or thing of reasonably equivalent value. The term shall not include the solicitation, acceptance, receipt, or regulation of political campaign contributions regulated in accordance with provisions of federal, state or local laws governing campaign finances, provided however, for the purpose of this section, the term "gift" as contained in this section shall not be interpreted to mean: 
a.  A non-pecuniary award publicly presented to a public officer in recognition of public, educational, charitable or religious service, or 
b.  Gifts to public officers from their family members. 
(4)  Interest means direct or indirect pecuniary or material benefit accruing to a public officer as a result of a contract, transaction, zoning decision, or other matter which is or may be the subject of an official act or action by or with the city except for such contracts, transactions, zoning decisions or other matters which by their terms and by the substance of their provisions confer the opportunity and right to realize the accrual of similar benefits to all other persons and/or property similarly situated. For the purpose of this section, an interest in a matter shall be attributed to the public officer if the interest in the matter is held by: 
a.  The public officer's spouse or dependent children; 
b.  Any business entity with whom the public officer shall have a substantial contractual relationship; 
c.  Any business entity in which the public officer is an officer, director, member, partner, agent, trustee, manager, fiduciary or employee; and 
d.  Any business entity in which the public officer controls or owns, directly or indirectly: 
1.  More than five (5) percent of the legal or beneficial ownership; or 
2.  An interest having a reasonable value equal to or exceeding fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). 
(5)  Official act or action means any legislative, administrative, appointive or discretionary act of any officer of the city or any agency, board, committee or commission thereof. 
(6)  Public officer means any person holding a position, by election or appointment, in the service of the municipality, whether paid or unpaid, and a member of any board, committee, or commission thereof. The phrase shall include, by way of illustration and not of limitation, the mayor, members of the city council, auditor, treasurer, constable, city clerk, all members of all boards and commissions, members of ad hoc task forces and committees, municipal judge, city attorney (prosecutor). However, and notwithstanding any provisions of this section to the contrary, the phrase "public officer" shall not include or be applicable to full-time paid employees of the city. 
(7)  Substantial contractual relationship means a contractual relationship, either orally or in writing, in which the public officer will or reasonably expects to receive financial benefits equal to or exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) in any calendar year, provided however, a commercially reasonable loan made to a public officer in the ordinary course of business by an institution which is authorized by the laws of this state or of the United States to engage in the making of such loans shall not be deemed to create an interest in violation of this ordinance, and provided further, a reasonable commercial contractual obligation, even though greater in value than five hundred dollars ($500.00), shall not be deemed to create an interest in violation of this section. 
(c)  Conflicts of interest. 
(1)  Interest in contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter. No public officer, having the power or duty to perform an official act or action related to a particular contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter which is or may be the subject of an official act or action of the city, shall: 
a.  Participate in or attempt to influence, either directly or indirectly, any official act or action in relation to such contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter in which he or she has any interest except as otherwise stated in this section; or 
b.  Take any official act or action on any matter relating to a business entity in which the public officer shall have an interest; or 
c.  Represent, advise or appear on behalf of, whether paid or unpaid, any person involved in any such contract, transaction, zoning decision, or other matter, except as otherwise stated in this section; or 
d.  Have solicited, accepted or granted a gift from or to a person involved in such contract, transaction, zoning decision, or other matter, except as otherwise stated in this section. 
(2)  Appearances. No public officer shall appear on behalf of any private person or business entity, other than for himself or herself or for his or her spouse or for his or her minor children, before any city agency or municipal court. 
a.  Provided however, a member of the city council may, without compensation (except where compensation is provided by the city to all council members similarly situated), appear before city agencies on behalf of his or her constituents in the course of performing his or her duties as a representative of the electorate or in performing his or her public or civil obligations; 
b.  Provided further, no provision hereof shall preclude a public officer from making an appearance before any city agency in representation of a business entity in which such public officer has a substantial ownership interest so long as the public officer discloses, to the city agency, his or her ownership interest in the business entity at the inception of such appearance; 
c.  Provided further, no provision hereof shall preclude a public officer from making an appearance before any city agency in representation of a not-for-profit entity or association in which such public officer is an officer or board member so long as the public officer discloses, to the city agency, his or her relationship to the not-for-profit entity at the inception of such appearance; 
d.  Provided further, no public officer shall take any official act or action on any matter on which he has made an appearance, as permitted above, except as to members of the city council in acting in their official capacity as permitted in subsection (c)(2)a. hereinabove. 
(3)  Disclosure of interest in legislative action. Any public officer who has an interest in any proposed legislation before the council shall disclose the nature and extent of such interest on the public record. In addition, such public officer shall fully comply with the personal financial disclosure requirements as adopted by the city. 
(4)  Public contracts. Notwithstanding the prohibitions in subsection (c)(1) hereinabove, a public officer may enter into a contract with the city if: 
a.  The contract is awarded through a process of public notice and competitive bidding, and 
b.  The contract is with a division or agency over which the public officer has no functions requiring the exercise of discretion. 
(5)  Disclosure of confidential information. No public officer, with respect to any contract, transaction, zoning decision, or other matter which is or may be the subject of an official act or action of the city, shall, without proper legal authorization, disclose confidential information concerning the property, government, or affairs of the city, or use such information to directly or indirectly advance the financial or other private interest of the public officer. 
(6)  Public property. Elective and appointive officers shall not use city-owned vehicles, equipment, materials or property for personal convenience or profit, except when such services are available to the public generally or are provided as municipal policy for the use of officials in the conduct of official business. 
(7)  Special treatment. No elective or appointive officer, acting in his or her official capacity, shall grant a special consideration, treatment or advantage to any citizen beyond that which is reasonably available to other citizens similarly situated, provided however, no provision hereof shall be deemed to prohibit members of the council from addressing and seeking to redress grievances of their constituents as part of their essential legislative function. 
(8)  Canvassing elected public officers. 
a.  No person shall wilfully canvass any member of the city council, directly or indirectly, in order to obtain preferential consideration for employment in the municipal service. Any person who shall so canvass one or more council members for such preferential consideration shall, upon determination that such prohibited canvassing has occurred, be thenceforth disqualified from consideration for employment. 
b.  Elected public officers shall not recommend any individual for city employment, promotion in city employment or release from city employment, except where such recommendation is a part of the elected public officer's official function or except where otherwise permitted by this code. 
(9)  Later case interest. No public officer shall, for a period of one year after the termination of service with the city, appear before any board, commission, committee or agency of the city in relation to any case, proceeding or application or contract in which he or she personally participated during the period of his or her service or which was under his or her active consideration. 
(d)  Board of ethics. 
(1)  Creation of board. There is hereby created and established a board of ethics ("board") which shall consist of five (5) residents of the city to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
a.  The board shall elect one of its number who shall serve as chairperson. 
b.  The members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
c.  The term of each member of the board shall be for five (5) years, provided, however, the terms of the initial members of the board shall be staggered for terms of one, two (2), three (3), four (4) and five (5) years, respectively. 
d.  A quorum of the board shall be three (3) members. 
e.  The vote of a majority of a quorum shall be deemed the official act of the board. 
f.  Meetings of the board may be called by the chairperson or by any two (2) members, and not less than seven (7) days' advance notice of a meeting shall be given to each of the members with respect to any such meeting, provided however, attendance of such meeting by a member shall be a waiver of the requirement that such member be given notice of same. 
g.  In addition to seeking the advice of the city counselor as hereinafter provided, the board may retain independent legal counsel to assist and advise the board regarding rendition of advisory opinions, interpretation of this section, investigation of alleged violations of this section and the applicability of this section to any factual pattern. 
(2)  Duties of board. The duties of the board shall be to generally: 
a.  Investigate violations of this section as hereinafter provided; and 
b.  To render advisory opinions as hereinafter provided. 
(3)  Advisory opinions. The board shall have the power to render advisory opinions with respect to this section and its application to specific factual patterns. 
a.  Advisory opinions shall be requested by formal written request of a public officer in such form and format as the board shall reasonably prescribe from time to time. The requesting public officer shall have the opportunity to present his or her interpretation of the facts at issue, and of the applicability of provisions of this ordinance, prior to rendition of the advisory opinion which has been requested. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the board shall have the power to issue advisory opinions upon its own initiative and without formal request by any public officer. 
b.  Prior to rendering an advisory opinion, the board may seek the advice and assistance of the city counselor. 
c.  An advisory opinion, until amended or revoked, shall be binding upon the city, the city council and the board in any subsequent action or matter concerning the public officer who solicited such advisory opinion and who acted thereon in good faith, provided however, such advisory opinion shall not have such binding effect in the event any material facts, upon which the advisory opinion was predicated, were untrue, omitted or misstated. 
d.  An advisory opinion of the board shall be deemed a public record which shall be available for inspection by the public, provided however: 
1.  The name of the public officer requesting the advisory opinion, as well as the names of any person or business entity mentioned in the advisory opinion, shall be deemed confidential information and shall not be disclosed by the board unless the public officer waives such confidentiality or unless the board determines that the public officer requesting the advisory opinion has failed to act in good faith in requesting same or has failed to act in conformity with the advisory opinion or unless the identity of the person requesting, or persons affected or to be affected by, the advisory opinion is required to be disclosed by law. 
2.  If the board shall seek advice from the city counselor prior to rendition of an advisory opinion, the board may, at its option, disclose to the city counselor the identity of the public officer requesting the advisory opinion and may, at its option, disclose to the city counselor the names of any person or business entity who or which may be ultimately mentioned in the advisory opinion. 
e.  In order to prevent undue delay in the governance of city government, the board shall promptly consider and issue advisory opinions as requested by public officers. 
(4)  Investigation of violations. The board shall have the general power to investigate any alleged violation of this section and all public officers shall fully cooperate with any such investigations. Any person who believes that any public officer has violated any provision of this section shall have the right to file a complaint with the board, which complaint shall be in such form and of such content as the board shall prescribe. The board shall, upon conclusion of its investigation, report its findings and recommendations to the city council. The board may retain independent legal counsel to assist and advise the city council regarding interpretation of this section and the operation and/or effect of this section to any factual pattern. 
(e)  Consequence of violations. 
(1)  If the board shall determine that any contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter directly or indirectly resulted from an act or action in violation of this section, the city council may, at its option, void, reverse or nullify such resulting contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter. 
(2)  If the board shall determine that any contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter directly or indirectly resulted from an act or action in violation of this section, the city council may (at its option and after considering the interests of the city as well as the interests of third parties who have in good faith relied upon the validity of such contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter), bring a civil action at law or in equity for a judgment enjoining any violation of the provisions of this section or requiring relinquishing of any prohibited interest or voiding of any such contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter. If the city council, after considering the interests of the city as well as the interests of third parties who have in good faith relied upon the validity of such contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter, shall not seek to invalidate such contract, transaction, zoning decision or other matter, the city council may, notwithstanding, direct that a civil action be commenced, maintained and prosecuted to completion against the public officer violating this section so as to recover all damages accruing to the city as a direct or indirect result of the violation of this section by such public officer. 
(3)  A knowing and wilful violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by a jail term of not more than ninety (90) days, or both. 
(f)  Distribution of the code of ethics section. The city clerk shall cause a copy of this section to be distributed to every public officer within thirty (30) days after enactment. Each public officer elected or appointed or engaged thereafter shall be furnished a copy of this section (and any amendments with respect thereto) before entering upon the duties of office. 
(g)  Severability. If any provision of this section is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, or if the application of this section to any person or circumstances is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect the other provisions or applications of this section which can be given effect without the invalid or unconstitutional provision or application. 
(Ord. No. 6809,  I, 4-11-94; Ord. No. 7670,  II, 7-13-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6809,  1, adopted April 11, 1994, amended  2-29 to read as herein set out. Former  2-29 pertained to similar subject matter and carried no history note. 
Sec. 2-30. - Salaries of elective officers set by council; monthly payment of salaries. 
    The city council shall fix the salary of all elective officers of the city before the close of the time for filing for the next term of office of the elective officials, and such salary shall not be changed during the term for which any city officer shall be elected. 
    All officers who receive a certain salary per month shall be paid such salary each month, the same to be appropriated at the regular monthly meeting of the city council. 
    Effective upon the expiration of the current and present term of the current and present incumbent of the office of city clerk, all salary and compensation to any person holding said office is hereby eliminated, and none shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 4591,  1, 1-10-83) 
Editor's note- Inclusion of  1 of Ord. No. 4591 as the third paragraph of  2-30 has been at the discretion of the editor, since 4591 did not specifically amend the Code. 
Sec. 2-31. - Reimbursement of officers for expenses. 
    Elective and appointive officers and employees of the city shall receive their actual and necessary expenses incurred in performance of their duties of office.

DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-41. - Defined. 
    In all cases where the context will authorize or allow such construction, the terms "city recorder," "recorder," "city clerk," "clerk" and "clerk of the city council," wherever they may appear in the general statutes of the state, the special Charter of the city as amended, this Code or other ordinances, resolutions and motions of the city council; and any and all documents, instruments, regulations and papers in the files or possession of or executed by or directed to any or all officials, servants or agents of the city in any and all capacities, shall be construed to be synonymous terms equivalent in meaning, and to refer to, designate and describe a single officer of the city, which officer shall be the officer referred to by the words "a clerk" in Section 81.070 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
Sec. 2-42. - Qualifications for office; term. 
    A city clerk shall be elected at each general election in the city and shall possess the same qualifications for office as those prescribed for council members and shall hold office for a term of two (2) years and until a successor is elected or appointed and qualified. 
Sec. 2-43. - Death, removal or resignation. 
    In the event of the death, removal or resignation of the city clerk, a successor shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council for the unexpired term. 
Sec. 2-44. - Duties. 
    The city clerk shall take the official minutes of all regular and special city council meetings; which minutes shall be reviewed, typed and distributed by the office of the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 4220,  1, 4-7-80; Ord. No. 4237,  1, 5-12-80) 
Sec. 2-45. - Oath of office. 
    The city clerk, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take the oath of office prescribed by ordinance. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY TREASURER 

Sec. 2-46. - Qualifications. 
    A city treasurer shall be elected at each general election in the city who shall possess the same qualifications for office as those prescribed for council members. 
Sec. 2-47. - Death, removal or resignation. 
    In the event of the death, removal or resignation of the city treasurer, a successor shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council for the unexpired term. 
Sec. 2-48. - Oath and term of office. 
    The city treasurer, before entering upon the office, shall take the oath of office prescribed by ordinance. The city treasurer shall hold the office for a term of two (2) years from the date of the election, unless sooner removed by the city council, and until the successor has been elected and qualified. 
ARTICLE IV. - APPOINTIVE OFFICERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor,  2-49-2-51 have been designated as Div. 1, "Generally." 

Sec. 2-49. - Administrative policy and procedures officers. 
(a)  Perform duties. Each officer shall perform all duties required of his office by state law, City Charter, ordinance of the city and such other duties not in conflict herewith as may be required by the mayor and city council. 
Sec. 2-50. - Department heads. 
(a)  The heads of departments shall be immediately responsible to the city administrator for the effective administration of their respective departments and all activities assigned thereto. 
(b)  The heads of departments shall keep informed as to the latest practices in their particular field and shall inaugurate, with the approval of the city administrator, such new practices as appear to be of benefit to the service and to the public. 
(c)  The heads of departments shall submit monthly and annual reports of the activities of their departments to the city administrator in such form as he may require. 
(d)  The heads of departments shall establish and maintain a system of filing and indexing records and reports in sufficient detail to furnish all information necessary for proper control of departmental activities and to form a basis for the periodic reports to the city administrator. 
(e)  The heads of departments shall have power, in conjunction with the city administrator, to appoint and remove, subject to the personnel classification system regulations for personnel, all subordinate employees of the city under their supervision. 
(f)  The heads of departments shall be responsible for the proper maintenance of all city property and equipment used in their departments. 
(g)  The heads of departments shall be residents of the city during their term in office and shall be registered voters of the City of Liberty, Clay County. 
Sec. 2-51. - Departments. 
    Each department shall cooperate with other departments and furnish, upon the direction of the city administrator, any other department such service, labor and materials as may be requisitioned by the head of such department, and as its own facilities permit, through the same procedure and subject to the same audit and control as other expenditures are incurred. 
DIVISION 1A. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor, Div. 1 has been redesignated as Div. 1A. 

Sec. 2-52. - Office created. 
    The office of city administrator is hereby established. 
Sec. 2-53. - Appointment. 
    The city administrator shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-54. - Removal. 
    The city administrator may be removed from office by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-55. - Qualifications; residency requirements. 
    The city administrator shall be appointed solely on the basis of his knowledge of city government and his administrative skills and ability. He shall reside within the city during his tenure in office. 
Sec. 2-56. - Powers and duties. 
(1)  Duties. 
(a)  Administrative office. Except as otherwise specified by ordinance or by the state statutes, the city administrator shall coordinate and generally supervise the operation of all departments of the city. 
(b)  Purchasing. The city administrator shall be the purchasing agent for the city and all purchases amounting to less than seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) shall be made under his direction and supervision, except in the event of an emergency, when the administrator may authorize contracts of up to twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), in accordance with all approved purchasing policies and procedures. 
(c)  Budget. He shall be the budget officer of the city and shall assemble estimates of the financial needs and resources of the city for each ensuing year and shall prepare a program of activities within the financial power of the city, embodying in it a budget document with proper supporting schedules and analyses to be proposed to the mayor and city council for their final approval. 
(d)  Financial reports. He shall make monthly reports to the mayor and city council relative to the financial condition of the city. Such reports shall show the financial condition of the city in relation to the budget. 
(e)  Annual report. Prepare and present to the mayor and city council an annual report of the city's affairs, including a summary of reports of department heads and such other reports as the mayor or city council may require. 
(f)  Personnel system. He shall act as the personnel officer of the city and shall recommend an appropriate position classification system and pay plan to the mayor and city council. He shall advise and recommend to the mayor and city council concerning the appointment or dismissal of department heads, and further, after consultation with department heads, shall approve pay plans and position classification system. He shall, in conjunction with the appropriate department head, have the power to appoint and remove, subject to personnel system regulations for personnel, all subordinate employees of the city. 
(g)  Policy formulation. He shall recommend to the mayor and city council adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the city or for the improvement of administrative services. 
(h)  City council agenda. He shall submit to the mayor and city council a proposed agenda for each city council meeting at least forty-eight (48) hours before the time of the council meeting. 
(i)  Boards and committees. He shall work with all city boards and committees to help coordinate the work of each. 
(j)  Attend council meetings. He shall attend all meetings of the city council, and shall be responsible for the minutes of each council meeting and shall deliver such minutes to the deputy city clerk for safekeeping. 
(k)  Miscellaneous. He shall perform any other duties or functions prescribed by the mayor or by the city council. 
(2)  Powers. 
(a)  Generally. He shall have the power to coordinate the work of all the departments of the city, and at times of an emergency, shall have authority to assign the employees of the city to any department where they are needed for the most effective discharge of the functions of city government. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. The city administrator shall establish such rules and regulations as are necessary or expedient for the conduct of city departments. 
(c)  Investigate and report. Have the power to investigate and to examine or inquire into the affairs or operation of any department of the city under his jurisdiction, and shall report on any condition or fact concerning the city government requested by the mayor or city council. 
(d)  Coordinate officials. The city administrator shall have the power to overrule any action taken by a department head, and may supersede him in the functions of his office. 
(e)  Appoint administrative committee. He shall have the power to designate from the administrative service such committees and the officers thereof as he shall find necessary for the proper consideration of administrative problems. 
(f)  Appear before the city council. He shall have the power to appear before and address the city council at any meeting. 
(g)  Superseding actions of mayor or city council. At no time shall the duties or powers of the city administrator supersede the action by the mayor and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 6691,  1, 10-25-93; Ord. No. 7294,  1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 2-57. - Bond. 
    The city administrator shall, before entering the duties of his office, give a good and sufficient surety company bond to the city, duly approved by the city, duly approved by the city counselor, and conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of his duties, and for proper application and payment of all money or property coming into his hands by virtue of his office. Such surety bond shall be in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and the premium for such bond shall be paid by the city. 
DIVISION 1B. - ASSISTANT CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-58. - Office created. 
    The appointive office of assistant city administrator is hereby created. 
Sec. 2-59. - Appointment. 
    The assistant city administrator, upon recommendation of the city administrator, may be appointed by the mayor and by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-60. - Removal. 
    The assistant city administrator, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be removed from office by the mayor and by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-61. - Qualifications. 
    The assistant city administrator shall be appointed solely on the basis of his knowledge of city government and his administrative skills and abilities. He shall possess qualifications equivalent to those of the city administrator and he shall reside within the city during his time in office. 
Sec. 2-62. - Accountability, responsibilities and duties. 
    The assistant city administrator shall be immediately accountable and responsible to the city administrator for the effective performance of his office. He shall serve as acting city administrator during the absence of the city administrator and the duties and responsibilities for the office of assistant city administrator shall be assigned by the city administrator. 
DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT 

Sec. 2-63. - Office created. 
    The appointive office of director of community development is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 5103,  1, 2-17-86) 
Sec. 2-64. - Appointment. 
    The director of community development, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be appointed by the mayor and by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5103,  1, 2-17-86) 
Sec. 2-65. - Removal. 
    The director of community development, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be removed from office by the mayor and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5103,  1, 2-17-86) 
Sec. 2-66. - Qualifications. 
    The director of community development shall be selected and appointed with primary consideration given to known and demonstrated ability and judgment as a manager and as administrator, with sufficient knowledge and experience of technology to procure, perceive and evaluate technical consultation and advice by qualified professionals as they relate to the operation of the department. 
(Ord. No. 5027,  1, 8-26-85; Ord. No. 5103,  1, 2-17-86) 
Sec. 2-67. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The director of community development shall be immediately accountable and responsible to the city administrator for the effective performance of his office and the administration of the community development department. 
(b)  The director of community development shall supervise the personnel and operations of the community development department. 
(c)  The director of community development shall recommend to the city administrator the necessary types and number of personnel position classifications to carry out the responsibilities of the department. After the annual review and approval of the position classification plan by the city council, the authorized positions for the department shall be filled and administered in accordance with the personnel regulations. 
(d)  The director of community development shall execute all duties and responsibilities pertaining to the community development department as may be specified in other sections of the Code and administrative regulations which shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  City planning; 
(2)  Inspection of all dangerous buildings and enforcement of applicable ordinances; 
(3)  Administration of housing programs; 
(4)  Enforcement of zoning ordinances; 
(5)  Enforcement of all occupational licenses; 
(6)  Other responsibilities as may be assigned by the city administrator. 
(e)  The director of community development is designated as the health officer of the city, but before undertaking any action in discharge of his duties as such under the Liberty City Code, shall report to the Clay County Health Center such information as he may have to suggest action, and as said health center or state department of public health and welfare, division of health, shall assume jurisdiction thereof, the city health officer shall defer to those agencies for handling and resolution of the matter. If, however, the city health officer shall determine that such county and state agencies reject assumption of such jurisdiction, he shall then proceed under the provisions of the Liberty City Code. It is intended that the functions of the city health officer are secondary, and that primary responsibility for inspection and enforcement of appropriate rules, regulations and statutes governing the conduct of those agencies shall be the primary authority in such matters relating to their function and including food establishments and restaurants. 
(Ord. No. 4524,  1, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 5103,  1, 2-17-86)

DIVISION 4. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCE 

Sec. 2-73. - Office created. 
    The appointive office of director of finance is hereby created. 
Sec. 2-74. - Appointment. 
    The director of finance, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-75. - Removal. 
    The director of finance, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be removed from office by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-76. - Qualifications. 
    The director of finance shall be appointed solely on the basis of his knowledge of municipal finance, experience and administrative ability. 
Sec. 2-77. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The director of finance shall be immediately accountable and responsible to the city administrator or the assistant city administrator as may be assigned, for the effective performance of his office and the administration of the finance department. 
(b)  The director of finance shall supervise the personnel and operations of the finance department. 
(c)  The director of finance shall recommend to the city administrator the necessary types and number of personnel position classifications to carry out the responsibilities of the department. After the annual review and approval of the position classification and pay plan by the city council, the authorized positions for the department shall be filled and administered in accordance with the personnel regulations. 
(d)  The director of finance shall execute all duties and responsibilities pertaining to the finance department as may be specified in other sections of the Code and administrative regulations which shall include, but are not limited to the following: (1) general accounting; (2) cost accounting; (3) billing; (4) investment management; (5) grants management; (6) inventory control/purchasing; (7) budget management; (8) payroll; (9) water meter reading; (10) data processing; (11) collection of revenue; (12) disbursement of funds; (13) cemetery records; (14) municipal court administration; (15) other responsibilities as may be assigned by the city administrator. 
Sec. 2-78. - Bond required. 
    The director of finance shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, give a good and sufficient surety company bond to the city, duly approved by the city, duly approved by the city counselor, and conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of his duties, and for proper application and payment of all money or property coming into his hands by virtue of his office. Such surety bond shall be in the amount of $10,000 and the premium of such bond shall be paid by the city. 
Sec. 2-79. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-80. - Audit of city funds required. 
    An annual audit of all city funds shall be conducted by a certified public accountant firm.

DIVISION 6. - DEPUTY CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-88. - Office created. 
    The office of deputy city clerk of the city council is hereby created as an appointive office and hereinafter referred to as deputy city clerk. 
Sec. 2-89. - Appointment. 
    The deputy city clerk, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-90. - Qualifications. 
    The deputy city clerk shall be a regular employee of the city, a notary public commissioned for the county. The appointment shall be based upon the skill and ability of the individual to competently carry out the day-to-day duties of the office of the city clerk as outlined in section 2-66. 
Sec. 2-91. - Duties. 
    The deputy city clerk shall work under the direct supervision of the city administrator and shall be available and competent to carry out such duties of the office of the city clerk as keeping and maintaining all official documents of the city, which shall include ordinances, resolutions, contracts, agreements, licenses, deeds, insurance policies, minutes of the city council, election results, historical material, correspondence and other material which is of a general and long-term nature regarding the government of the city. The deputy city clerk shall also be responsible for supervision and administration of all city elections, and shall perform other services of a clerical nature as directed. The deputy city clerk is hereby authorized to sign and attest all official documents and affix the seal of the city and to perform all other acts and functions of such clerk, in the absence of the city clerk from the premises of the City Hall, when so directed by the city administrator or the mayor. 
Sec. 2-92. - Oath; term of office. 
    The office of deputy city clerk shall be filled when an individual has been appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council and has taken an oath of office as a civil officer. The duly appointed and sworn deputy city clerk shall remain in office unless and until the individual is terminated as a regular employee of the city.

Sec. 2-99. - Appointment. 
    The police chief, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-100. - Removal. 
    The police chief, upon recommendation by the city administrator, may be removed from office by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
Sec. 2-101. - Qualifications. 
    The police chief shall be appointed solely upon the basis of his technical knowledge, experience and administrative ability. 
Sec. 2-102. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The police chief shall be immediately accountable and responsible to the city administrator for the effective performance of his office and the administration of the police department. 
(b)  The police chief shall supervise the personnel and operations of the police department. 
(c)  The police chief shall recommend to the city administrator the necessary types and number of personnel classifications to carry out the responsibilities of the department. After the annual review and approval of the position classification and pay plan by the city council, the authorized positions for the department shall be filled and administered in accordance with the personnel regulations. 
(d)  The police chief shall execute all duties and responsibilities pertaining to the police department as may be specified in other sections of the Code and administrative regulations which shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The preservation and protection of the person and property of all citizens; 
(2)  The maintenance of peace and order, the prevention and detection of crime, and enforcement of the municipal ordinances of the city; 
(3)  Cooperation with county and state officers for the preservation of peace and order and the prevention and detection of crime; 
(4)  Coordination and implementation of traffic safety programs in conjunction with the departments of community development and community maintenance; 
(5)  Animal control and disposal; 
(6)  Parking control; 
(7)  Other responsibilities as may be assigned by the city administrator. 
Sec. 2-103. - Commission, powers, authority to make arrests. 
    All police officers, upon being first duly sworn and commissioned, shall be peace officers, and as such conservators of the peace, and shall have the power to restrain and detain citizens; to issue warnings and citations; to make arrests as authorized under the Constitution and law of the United States, the State of Missouri, the ordinances of the city; and to execute lawful warrants and criminal process directed to officers of this city.

Sec. 2-103.2. - Appointment. 
    The director of parks and recreation, upon recommendation by the park and recreation board in conjunction with consultation with the city administrator, may be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council 
(Ord. No. 4031,  1, 11-20-78) 
Sec. 2-103.3. - Removal. 
    The director of parks and recreation, upon recommendation by the park and recreation board in conjunction with consultation with the city administrator, may be removed from office by the mayor by and with the consent of the city council.

Sec. 2-103.4. - Qualifications.

(a)  The director of parks and recreation shall be immediately accountable and responsible to the city administrator for the effective performance of his office and the administration of the park department.

(e)  The director of parks and recreation shall execute all duties and responsibilities pertaining to the development and implementation of a comprehensive park and recreation program for the City of Liberty and any and all duties and responsibilities pertaining to the park and recreation department as may be specified in other sections of the Code and administrative regulations which shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Preservation, maintenance and improvement of all park property and facilities within the city limits of the City of Liberty; 
(2)  General management of the parks and recreation department, its personnel, its planning, implementation and supervision of all recreational programs which are conducted under the auspices of the park and recreation department; 
(3)  Liaison between the parks and recreation board and the mayor and city council and the city administrator, and other responsibilities as may be assigned by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 4031,  1, 11-20-78)

DIVISION 10. - ATTORNEY AND CITY PROSECUTOR[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4061,  2, adopted Jan. 8, 1979, enacted Div. 10,  2-103c-2-103f, which the editor has redesignated as  2-103.11-2-103.14, to preserve Code format. 
Cross reference- Municipal court, Ch. 10; duties of city prosecuting attorney relative to municipal court,  10-10. 

Sec. 2-103.11. - Appointment; term of office; qualifications. 
    Pursuant to RSMo 81.140, an attorney and city prosecutor shall be appointed to office by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. The term of the attorney and city prosecutor shall be for two (2) years from July 1, 1999, and for subsequent four-year terms thereafter. The term of the attorney and city prosecutor shall extend until a new appointment is made. The term is subject to earlier termination for cause by action of the city council, provided that said attorney and city prosecutor shall have the right to a public hearing if so requested before the city council to show cause why the term should not be terminated. No person shall be appointed to the position of attorney and city prosecutor unless that person shall have been a resident of the City of Liberty no less than six (6) months next preceding the appointment, and in addition thereto, shall be a member in good standing of the state bar, admitted to practice before all of the courts of the state. Said attorney and city prosecutor shall be considered holding part-time employment, and as such may accept, within the requirements of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Missouri Supreme Court Rule 4, other employment not in conflict with the duties as such officer. 
(Ord. No. 4061,  2, 1-8-79; Ord. No. 7458,  I, 4-28-97; Ord. No. 7830,  I, 6-28-99) 
Sec. 2-103.12. - Vacation of office. 
    The attorney and city prosecutor shall have vacated his office upon the occurrence of any one of the following: 
(a)  Upon his removal of his residence from within the city limits of the City, Clay County, Missouri; or 
(b)  Upon his being disbarred from the practice of law within the State of Missouri; or 
(c)  Upon the acceptance, election or appointment to any other office of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, or to an elective office of any other municipality, any county, state or the federal government, except that of notary public, unless the acceptance, election or appointment of such office shall have been previously disclosed and approved by the mayor and city council. 
(d)  Upon expiration of his term as defined in section 2-103.11 of this division; or 
(e)  Upon termination for cause subject to the provisions of section 2-103.11 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 4061,  2, 1-8-79; Ord. No. 6247,  1, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 7830,  II, 6-28-99; Ord. No. 7830,  II, 6-28-99) 
Sec. 2-103.13. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the attorney and city prosecutor appointed under this division to prosecute the violations of the ordinances of the City of Liberty before the judge of the municipal court or before the associate circuit judges or circuit judges hearing violations of the city's ordinances. The attorney and city prosecutor shall perform such other duties as he shall be directed to perform by action of the mayor and city council. He shall deliver to his successor in office all books, papers, records and property pertaining to his office as attorney and city prosecutor. 
(Ord. No. 4061,  2, 1-8-79) 
Sec. 2-103.14. - Absence, disability, disqualification, etc. 
    Whenever in any cause coming before the municipal court, the attorney and city prosecutor shall, by reason of temporary absence, sickness or otherwise, be unable to attend any session of the municipal court on the trial of any cause; or whenever the attorney and city prosecutor shall have been engaged or retained as attorney or counselor in any cause in which the city is interested on behalf of the party opposed to the city, or shall have a professional or personal conflict of interest, he shall inform the mayor thereof. In each such case, the mayor shall thereupon employ some attorney to act as attorney and city prosecutor pro-tempore for the city in the prosecution of such cause. 
(Ord. No. 4061,  2, 1-8-79) 
Sec. 2-103.15. - Legal service providers. 
    The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, may from time to time appoint one or more legal service providers to serve the legal service needs of the City of Liberty. Any legal service provider appointed shall serve pursuant to the terms of a written agreement approved by the city council. Any such agreement shall be with an attorney or a firm of attorneys licensed to practice law. 
(Ord. No. 7830,  III, 6-28-99) 
Secs. 2-103.16-2-103.20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - MUNICIPAL JUDGE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4059,  2, adopted Jan. 8, 1979, adopted Div. 9,  2-103a, 2-103b, which the editor has redesignated as Div. 11,  2-103.21, 2-103.22, to preserve Code format. 
Cross reference- Municipal judge, powers and duties generally,  10-5. 

Sec. 2-103.21. - Appointment; term of office; qualifications. 
    The judge of the municipal court of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, shall be known as a municipal judge of the Seventh Judicial Circuit, shall have been a resident of the City of Liberty no less than six (6) months next preceding the appointment, and in addition thereto, shall be a member in good standing of the state bar, admitted to practice before all of the courts of the state. The municipal judge shall be appointed to the position by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. The term of the municipal judge shall be four (4) years, from July 1 of 1999 and for subsequent four-year terms thereafter. The term of the municipal judge shall extend until a new appointment is made. The municipal judge may not hold any other office in city government; however, the municipal judge shall be considered holding a part-time position, and as such may accept, within the requirements of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Missouri Supreme Court, Rule 2, other employment. 
(Ord. No. 4059,  2, 1-8-79; Ord. No. 7458,  I, 4-28-97; Ord. No. 7830,  IV, 6-28-99) 
Sec. 2-103.22. - Vacation of office. 
    The municipal judge shall have vacated his office upon the occurrence of any one of the following: 
(a)  His removal from office by the State Commission of Retirement, Removal and Discipline of Judges, as provided in Missouri Supreme Court Rule 12; or, 
(b)  Upon attaining his seventy-fifth birthday; or 
(c)  Upon being disbarred from the practice of law within the State of Missouri; or 
(d)  Upon his removal of his residence from within the city limits of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri; or 
(e)  Upon his acceptance, election or appointment to any other office of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, or as a judge of any other court whatsoever; or 
(f)  Upon expiration of his term of office as defined in Section 2-103.21 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 4059,  2, 1-8-79)
