DIVISION 7. - PRESERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference- Historic district review commission (Unified Development Ordinance),  30-20 et seq. 

Sec. 2-131. - Composition; qualifications; appointment. 
    The city preservation and development commission shall be composed of seven (7) members, all of whom shall be residents of the city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4813,  2, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 2-132. - Terms of office; vacancies. 
    The members of the preservation and development commission shall hold office as follows: Two (2) members for a term of one year; two (2) members for a term of two (2) years and three (3) members for a term of three (3) years. Following the original staggered terms, each member shall be appointed for three (3) years; provided, however, that any member appointed to fill a vacancy caused by any reason other than normal termination shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 4813,  2, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 2-133. - Meetings; organization; quorum. 
    The city preservation and development commission shall meet at least annually and more often as necessary at the call of the chairperson or by written notice to members, by any three (3) members at least three (3) days in advance. A chairperson and vice-chairperson will be elected from the membership at the first commission meeting and thereafter annually. The minutes of each meeting shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. Four (4) members shall constitute a quorum and no action of the commission shall be binding unless authorized by a majority of the commission. The commission shall have power to make rules and regulations for the proper conduct of its business. 
(Ord. No. 4813,  2, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 2-134. - Duties generally. 
    The commission shall act as an educational and advisory group to the mayor, council, other city boards and commissions, and the general public with respect to the preservation of the community's architectural, cultural and historical resources and the role of these resources in promoting the community's economic health and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 4813,  2, 6-25-84) 
DIVISION 8. - LIBERTY COMMISSION ON AGING 

Sec. 2-135. - Establishment; composition; qualifications; terms of office. 
    The Liberty Commission on Aging (LCOA) is established consisting of nine (9) members, all to be citizens and residents of the city and each to serve for a period of three (3) years with the exception of the initial board. The initial board shall be structured as follows: The chairperson and two (2) members shall hold three-year terms, three (3) members shall hold two-year terms, and three (3) members shall hold a one-year term. 
(Ord. No. 4815,  1, 6-25-84; Ord. No. 4858,  1, 9-24-84) 
Sec. 2-136. - Appointment; compensation; organization; vacancies. 
    All appointments to the LCOA shall be made by the mayor and approved by the city council as required by state law. Each member shall serve until his successor is duly appointed and qualified, and shall receive no compensation. The mayor shall name a chairperson for the first year, after which the members shall appoint a chairperson from within their own ranks on a yearly basis. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as regular appointments and any person so appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term. The LCOA will, upon convening, create and adopt its own bylaws, rules and regulations for its guidance, to be submitted for council approval. Amendments in the bylaws will be handled in the same fashion. 
(Ord. No. 4815,  1, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 2-137. - Duties generally. 
(a)  The LCOA shall prepare an annual budget for aging services which they shall submit for city council approval. It shall be responsible for developing and maintaining an aging network in Liberty, including scheduling of events and referral activity, developing cooperative programs with interested local civic groups and institutions, advocating superior service to local aged; provided, however, that any and all such responsibilities which require the expenditure of funds, execution of contracts, or regulations which must be enacted by ordinance shall be referred to the mayor and city council for consideration and appropriate action. 
(b)  Matters pertaining to park facilities and scheduling shall be approved by the parks and recreation director and/or the park board. 
(Ord. No. 4815,  1, 6-25-84) 
Cross reference- Director of parks and recreation,  2-103.1 et seq.; park board,  2-110 et seq. 
Sec. 2-138. - Aging services coordinator. 
    The staff representation of the LCOA shall be the aging services coordinator a city employee under the parks and recreation department. The coordinator shall serve as a liaison between the LCOA and the director of parks and recreation and between the LCOA and the city council. Minutes of all LCOA sessions shall be filed with the parks and recreation director and with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 4815,  1, 6-25-84) 
Secs. 2-139-2-148. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - LIBERTY SISTER CITY ADVISORY COMMISSION[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 5286,  1, adopted Feb. 9, 1987, amended Ch. 2, Art. V, by adding a new Div. 9 thereto, designated  2-139-2-143. In order to conform to Code format and to provide for future amendments and additions to Div. 8, the editor, at his discretion, has renumbered these new sections as  2-148-2-153. 

Sec. 2-149. - Establishment; composition; qualifications. 
    The Liberty Sister City Advisory Commission shall be established and composed of nine (9) members, all of whom shall be residents of the city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5286,  1(2-139), 2-9-87) 
Sec. 2-150. - Terms of office. 
    Each member of the Liberty Sister City Advisory Commission shall serve for a period of three (3) years, with the exception of the initial board. The initial commission shall be structured as follows: The chairperson and two (2) members shall hold three-year terms, three (3) members shall hold two-year terms, and three (3) members shall hold a one-year term. 
(Ord. No. 5286,  1(2-140) 2-9-87) 
Sec. 2-151. - Appointment; compensation; organization; vacancies. 
    All appointments to the Liberty Sister City Advisory Commission shall be made by the mayor and approved by the city council as required by state law. Each member shall serve until his successor is duly appointed and qualified, and shall receive no compensation. The mayor shall name a chairperson for the first year, after which the members shall appoint a chairperson from within their own ranks on an annual basis. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as regular appointments, and any person so appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term. The Liberty Sister City Advisory Commission, upon convening, shall create and adopt its own rules and regulations for its guidance and shall have the authority to amend those rules and regulations by a majority vote of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 5286,  1(2-141), 2-9-87) 
Sec. 2-152. - Duties generally. 
    The Liberty Sister City Advisory Commission shall work to promote activities between Liberty citizens and Liberty's sister city. It shall be responsible for coordinating events and activities designed to involve all segments of Liberty's population in the Sister City program. The commission is also responsible for making policy recommendations to the city council regarding Liberty's Sister City program. 
(Ord. No. 5286,  1(2-142), 2-9-87) 
Sec. 2-153. - Staff representation. 
    A representative from the city staff shall be assigned to the Liberty Sister City Advisory Commission to provide administrative assistance and project coordination. Said representative shall be appointed by the city administrator. A meeting summary of all Liberty Sister City Advisory Commission sessions shall be prepared by the staff representative and filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 5286,  1(2-143), 2-9-87) 
Secs. 2-154-2-163. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - LIBERTY COMMUNITY CHRISTMAS TREE ADVISORY COMMISSION[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 5314, adopted April 27, 1987, amended Ch. 10, Art. V by adding a new Div. 10,  2-144-2-148. At the editor's discretion, and in order to conform to Code format, these new provisions have been redesignated as  2-164-2-168. 

Sec. 2-164. - Establishment; composition; qualifications. 
    The Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission shall be established and composed of nine (9) members, all of whom shall reside within the area designated by the Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5314,  1(2-144), 4-27-87; Ord. No. 5563,  1, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 5755,  1, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 6220,  1, 9-23-91; Ord. No. 9621,  I, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-165. - Terms of office. 
    Each member of the Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission shall serve for a period of three (3) years, with the exception of the initial board. The initial commission shall be structured as follows: the chairperson and three (3) members shall hold three-year terms, three (3) members shall hold two-year terms, and three (3) members shall hold a one-year term. 
(Ord. No. 5314,  1 (2-145), 4-27-87; Ord. No. 5563,  1, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 5755,  1, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 9621,  I, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-166. - Appointment; compensation; organization; vacancies. 
    All appointments to the Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission shall be made by the mayor and approved by the city council as required by state law. Each member shall serve until his successor is duly appointed and qualified, and shall receive no compensation. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as regular appointments, and any person so appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term. For 1989 the mayor will appoint a chair and vice-chair. In the following years, the vice-chair will succeed the chair and the mayor will appoint a new vice-chair. The Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission, upon convening, shall create and adopt its own rules and regulations for its guidance and shall have the authority to amend those rules and regulations by a majority vote of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 5314,  1 (2-146), 4-27-87; Ord. No. 5563,  1, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 5755,  1, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 9621,  I, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-167. - Duties generally. 
    The Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission shall work to address the needs of the community's disadvantaged during the Christmas season, and at other times of the year as deemed appropriate. The commission shall promote involvement in their effort by all segments of the community. The commission is also responsible for making policy recommendations to the city council regarding their efforts. 
(Ord. No. 5314,  1 (2-147), 4-27-87; Ord. No. 9621,  II, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-168. - Staff representation. 
    A representative from the city staff may be assigned to the Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission to provide administrative assistance and project coordination. Said representative shall be appointed by the city administrator. A meeting summary of all Liberty Community Christmas Tree Advisory Commission sessions shall be prepared by the staff representative and filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 5314,  1(2-148), 4-27-87; Ord. No. 9621,  I, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-169. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - CITY TREE BOARD 

Sec. 2-170. - Composition and appointment. 
    The city tree board shall be composed of five (5) members, all of whom shall be residents of the city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 8755,  I, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 2-171. - Terms of office; vacancies. 
    The members of the city tree board shall hold office as follows: The terms of the five (5) persons to be appointed by the mayor shall be three (3) years except that the term of two (2) of the members appointed to the first board shall be one (1) year, and the terms of two (2) members of the first board shall be two (2) years. Each member shall serve until his successor is duly appointed and qualified, and shall receive no compensation. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as regular appointments, and any person so appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 8755,  I, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 2-172. - Meetings; organization; quorum. 
(a)  The tree board shall make rules and regulations for the proper conduct of business. At the first regular meeting of the board, a chairperson to conduct the business of the board and a vice-chairperson to conduct its business in the absence of the chairperson shall be chosen by the board from among its membership. Each term of each officer shall be for one (1) year. At the first regular meeting of each new calendar year, a chairperson and vice-chairperson shall be chosen. A recording secretary shall be chosen who shall be responsible for recording the proceedings of the meeting and maintaining its record on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(b)  Three (3) members of the tree board shall constitute a quorum, and no action of the board shall be binding unless authorized by a majority of the members present and voting at a regular meeting or any special meeting called by the chairperson, where a quorum is present. 
(c)  The tree board shall hold meetings, no less than four (4) times per calendar year, to discuss business. These meetings shall be held at the discretion of the chairperson and shall be open to the public. The chairperson or any two (2) members of the board may call a special meeting as needed. 
(Ord. No. 8755,  I, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 2-173. - Duties generally. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the city tree board to study, investigate, advise, report, or develop any plan or program which is determined to be necessary or advisable for the care, selection, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal, or disposition of trees and other woody vegetation located in public parks, on other city-owned or maintained grounds, or on public land adjacent to all city streets. Such a plan will be presented to the city council and upon its acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive tree plan for the City of Liberty, Missouri. The board shall review annually and update, if needed, the comprehensive city tree plan. The board, when requested by the city council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report, and recommend upon any special matter of question within the scope of its work. 
    It shall also be the purpose of the tree board to assist in securing the cooperation of the residents of Liberty in a coordinated and planned program of tree protection and planting on public and private property. 
(Ord. No. 8755,  I, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 2-174. - Interference with city tree board and city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree board, the city or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the caring for, planting, cultivating, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees or park trees, as authorized in this chapter or Chapter 28A. 
(Ord. No. 8755,  I, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 2-175. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall commit, assist in, or allow the existence of any violation of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided in section 22-70 of the Liberty City Code. For each and every day that a violation continues, it shall be deemed a separate offense, and punishable as a separate misdemeanor upon conviction. 
(Ord. No. 8755,  I, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 2-176. - Review by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city tree board. 
(Ord. No. 8755,  I, 12-13-04) 
DIVISION 12. - LIBERTY ARTS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-177. - Commission established; purposes. 
    There is hereby established a Liberty Arts Commission to plan, promote and encourage programs to further public awareness of, accessibility to, participation in, and support for the artistic and cultural development of the city. 
(Ord. No. 8961,  I, 3-27-06) 
Sec. 2-178. - Composition and appointment. 
    The Liberty Arts Commission shall be composed of eleven (11) members, all of whom shall be residents of the city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. Members shall have significant knowledge or demonstrated interest in one or more areas of the arts, including music, dance, literature, visual arts, theater, folk arts, media design and arts education. One (1) member shall be a liaison from the city council who shall serve as a full voting member of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 8961,  I, 3-27-06; Ord. No. 8990,  I, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 2-179. - Terms of office; vacancies. 
    The members of the Liberty Arts Commission shall hold office as follows: The term of each member shall be three (3) years, except that the terms for those initially appointed to the commission shall be structured as follows: three (3) members shall hold a three-year term; four members shall hold a two-year term; and four (4) members, including the city council member, shall hold a one-year term. Each member shall serve until his successor is duly appointed and qualified, and shall receive no compensation. Following appointment, the city council member shall serve the term to which appointed or so long as qualified to serve. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as regular appointments, and any person so appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 8961,  I, 3-27-06; Ord. No. 8990,  II, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 2-180. - Meetings; organization; quorum. 
(a)  The Liberty Arts Commission shall make rules and regulations for the proper conduct of business, and shall have the authority to amend those rules and regulations by a majority vote of the commission. The members shall appoint a chairperson and vice-chairperson from their own ranks on an annual basis. Each term of each officer shall be for one (1) year. At the first regular meeting of each new calendar year, a chairperson and vice-chairperson shall be chosen. 
(b)  Five (5) members of the arts commission shall constitute a quorum, and no action of the commission shall be binding unless authorized by a majority of the members present and voting at a regular meeting or any special meeting called by the chairperson, where a quorum is present. 
(c)  The Liberty Arts Commission shall hold regular meetings, no less than once per calendar year, to discuss business. These meetings shall be held as established by the commission and shall be open to the public. The chairperson or any two (2) members of the board may call a special meeting as needed. 
(Ord. No. 8961,  I, 3-27-06) 
Sec. 2-181. - Duties generally. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the Liberty Arts Commission to act in an advisory capacity to the city council in all matters pertaining to the arts and cultural environment of the city; to hold regular public meetings and maintain a written record of its proceedings; to work with area agencies on broad community issues in which a cultural perspective is relevant and desirable; and to engage in comprehensive planning and initiation of programs for the cultural development of the city. 
(Ord. No. 8961,  I, 3-27-06) 
Sec. 2-182. - Staff representation. 
    A representative from the city staff shall be assigned to the Liberty Arts Commission to provide administrative assistance and project coordination. Said representative shall be appointed by the city administrator. A meeting summary of all Liberty Arts Commission sessions shall be prepared and filed in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 8961,  I, 3-27-06) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses and occupations generally, Ch. 7; licenses, Ch. 18; driving under the influence of liquor or drugs,  20-4; intoxicated persons,  22-15; possession of alcoholic beverages in parks,  22A-5. 
State Law reference- Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.010 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - NONINTOXICATING BEER 

Sec. 3-1. - Defined. 
    Nonintoxicating beer is defined and declared to be beer having an alcoholic content of not less than one-half of one per cent by volume, nor exceeding three and two-tenths (3.2) per cent by weight. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  2) 
Sec. 3-2. - Applicability of article. 
    All beverages having an alcoholic content of less than one-half of one per cent by volume shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  2) 
Sec. 3-3. - Purchase, etc., by minors. 
    No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall purchase or attempt to purchase or have in his possession any non-intoxicating beer or beer of any alcoholic content whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 2039,  2) 
Cross reference- Sale of alcoholic beverages to minors,  3-31; purchase of intoxicating liquor by minors,  3-23; open house parties,  3-61; parent or guardian to appear for minor,  22-34. 
Sec. 3-4. - License-Required. 
    No person shall manufacture, brew, sell or expose to sale in the city nonintoxicating beer in any quantity, without first procuring a license therefor from the [deputy] city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  1) 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 18; license fee for malt liquor containing alcohol not in excess of five per cent,  3-15. 
Sec. 3-5. - Same-Fees. 
    For a license required by section 3-4 there shall be paid to and collected by the [deputy] city clerk annual charges as follows: 
(a)  For a license authorizing the manufacture and sale by the manufacturer of nonintoxicating beer brewed or manufactured in this city, three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00). 
(b)  For a license authorizing the sale of nonintoxicating beer for consumption on the premises where sold, thirty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($37.50). 
(c)  For a license authorizing the sale of nonintoxicating beer by grocers and other merchants and dealers, for sale in the original package, which is defined as any package containing three (3) or more standard beer bottles, direct to the consumer not to be opened or consumed on the premises where sold, and not for resale, twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. 1546,  1; Ord. No. 1649,  1) 
Sec. 3-6. - Same-Qualifications. 
    No person shall be granted a license under the terms of this article unless such person is of good moral character and no person shall be granted any license whose license as a dealer in or manufacturer of nonintoxicating beer has been revoked by any city, county, state or federal agency in the United States. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  3; Ord. No. 2876,  1) 
Sec. 3-7. - Same-Application; contents; issuance; hearing upon denial. 
(1)  Application for license required by section 3-4 shall be made in writing, describing the premises wherein operation thereunder is to be carried on, and to which said premises such license, if issued, shall be limited, and describing the class of license applied for as classified in section 3-5. Such application shall be made in the name of the person and signed by the manager in charge of the place of business for which such license is desired, and which manager shall at all times possess the qualifications set out in section 3-6. 
(2)  No manager, principal or employee of any such licensee shall perform any act in the manufacture, distilling, sale or exposition for sale of any nonintoxicating beer in his capacity as such manager or employee until such licensee for the premises and the individual, whether manager or employee, shall also have obtained a license under section 3-39. 
(3)  Such application, when completed, shall be presented to the deputy city clerk. Any applicant, by signing an application form, shall consent to an investigation of all matters relevant to the qualifications of the applicant and, if advised of any contrary information or question with respect thereto, shall furnish full, accurate and verified information with respect to any deficiency of which applicant is advised. Upon completion of investigation, if applicant meets all requirements set forth in Chapter 3, Article III for the issuance of such license, the deputy city clerk shall issue the same which shall describe therein the identity of the applicant and the location of the premises for which the same is issued. 
(4)  If such license shall be denied by the deputy city clerk, upon written request the applicant shall be given a hearing before the city council for reconsideration thereof. At such hearing it shall be the burden of the applicant to show that the applicant meets all requirements and conditions for the issuance of such license and to establish such as a fact by proper evidence. Neither the deputy city clerk nor any other officer or agency of the city shall be required to prove any deficiency found, but the same shall be heard, if offered, in consideration of the evidence proffered by the applicant. As it finds the facts to be, final determination shall be made by the city council as to the issuance of such license. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  3, 4; Ord. No. 4624,  1, 2, 3-28-83) 
Sec. 3-8. - Same-Term; proration; transferability, etc.; display. 
    Each license granted as provided in this article shall be for a term ending on the thirtieth day of June next succeeding the granting thereof and may be prorated for a period of not less than three (3) months on payment of the proper annual license fee. No such license shall be transferable or assignable, and may be revoked for cause as herein provided. The privileges granted by such license shall be exercised by the licensee only in the premises described in the application therefor and no license shall be granted for more than one place of business to any one licensee. Such license shall be displayed to public view in the premises by the licensee at all times during the term thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  5) 
Sec. 3-9. - Same-Revocation; public hearing. 
    The city council may in its reasonable discretion and for cause, which shall include, but not be limited to one or more violations of this article, revoke any license granted hereunder, first having given such licensee not less than ten (10) days' notice in writing, which notice shall contain therein the grounds for such revocation and shall command such licensee to be present at a meeting of the city council, to be held at a time and place stated, and to show cause, if any, why such license should not be revoked. 
    Such notice shall be served by the city constable [chief of police] by delivering a copy thereof to such licensee or to any person or employee in charge of the premises described in the application for such license. 
    The licensee may be represented by counsel and present evidence on the part of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  6) 
Sec. 3-10. - Intoxicating liquor not to be kept by or sold to licensees. 
    No person holding a license under this article to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail, shall have, or keep or secrete in or about the premises described in and covered by his license any intoxicating liquor of any kind or character, nor shall any manufacturer or wholesale distributor sell intoxicating liquor containing alcohol in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) per cent by weight to any retail distributor holding a license or permit for the sale of intoxicating beer only. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  7) 
Sec. 3-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4393, adopted July 13, 1981, repealed  3-11, which regulated days and hours of sale of nonintoxicating liquor, and which derived from Ord. No. 1546,  8 and Ord. No. 2183,  1. 
Sec. 3-12. - Right of city to recover fees by legal action. 
    The amount of the license fee for a period of one year, as provided by this article, may be recovered of any person attempting to engage in any business authorized to be licensed by this article, without first procuring such license, by civil action as is now provided in the cases of action by individuals for the recovery of debt. Such action shall be brought in the name of "the mayor, councilmen [council members] and citizens of the City of Liberty" and this remedy shall be in addition to and not in lieu of other remedies provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1546,  9) 
ARTICLE II. - INTOXICATING LIQUOR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Driving under the influence of liquors or drugs,  20-4. 

Sec. 3-13. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Caterer: Any person who, having a licensed premise, furnishes provisions and service for use at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location other than the licensed premises. 
    Intoxicating liquor: Alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented malt or other liquors or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous or fermented, and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes containing in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) per cent of alcohol by weight. 
    Light wine: Any alcoholic beverage manufactured from grapes, berries and other fruits or vegetables containing not in excess of fourteen (14) per cent alcohol by weight. 
    Malt liquor: Intoxicating liquor manufactured from pure hops or pure extract of hops or pure barley malt or wholesome grains or cereals and wholesome yeast and pure water. 
    Wine: A vinous liquor produced by fermentation of juices of grapes, berries, or other fruits or a preparation of certain vegetables by fermentation, and containing not in excess of twenty-two (22) per cent alcohol by volume. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  15; Ord. No. 8527,  I-A, 6-9-03) 
State Law reference- Definition of intoxicating liquor, RSMo 311.020. 
Sec. 3-14. - License-Required. 
    No person shall manufacture, distill, sell or expose for sale in the city intoxicating liquor in any quantity, without first procuring a license therefor from the city recorder [deputy city clerk]. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  1) 
Sec. 3-14.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4234,  1, adopted April 28, 1980, repealed  3-14.1, relative to licenses for alcoholic beverages based on population growth, derived from Ord. No. 2900,  2; Ord. No. 3037,  2; and Ord. No. 3599,  1, adopted Nov. 24, 1975. 
Sec. 3-15. - Same-Fees. 
    For a license required by section 3-14, there shall be paid to and collected by the city recorder [deputy city clerk] annual charges as follows: 
(a)  For the sale of malt liquor containing alcohol not in excess of five (5) per cent by weight and light wine, by the drink, for consumption on the premises where sold, the sum of fifty-two dollars and fifty cents ($52.50). 
(b)  For manufacturing or distilling intoxicating liquor, the sum of three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00). 
(c)  For the sale of all intoxicating liquor at retail in the original package, the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(d)  For the sale of malt liquor containing alcohol in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) per cent by weight and not in excess of five (5) per cent by weight and light wine, by grocers and other merchants and dealers for sale in the original package, which is hereby defined as any package containing three (3) or more standard beer bottles, direct to consumers, not to be opened or consumed on the premises where sold and not for resale, the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(e)  For sale of intoxicating liquor, by the drink at retail, for consumption on the premises of any restaurant bar described in the application, between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and midnight on Sunday, by applicant meeting the requirements of and in compliance with the "Sunday sale" or "restaurant bar" statute of the State of Missouri, RSMo 311.097, and additional fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) per year. 
(f)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor, by the drink at retail, for consumption on the premises, the sum of four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) per year. 
(g)  For the Sunday sale of all intoxicating liquor at retail in the original package, the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(h)  For the Sunday sale of all intoxicating liquor, by the drink, for consumption on the premises for any charitable, fraternal, religious, service or veteran's organization which has obtained an exemption from payment of federal income taxes as provided in section 501(c)(3), 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), 501(c)(7), 501(c)(,8), 501(c)(10), 501(c)(19), or 501(d) of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended, which possesses a license which allows the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises, the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) per year. 
(i)  For the sale of malt liquor not in excess of five (5) per cent by weight by grocers and other merchants and dealers for sale in the original package direct to consumers, not to be opened or consumed on the premises where sold and not for resale, including sales of malt liquor at retail on Sunday, the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(j)  For the sale of malt liquor not in excess of five (5) per cent by weight at retail by drink for consumption on the premises where sold, including sales of malt liquor at retail on Sunday, the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
    The fee charged in this section shall be in addition to all other license fees and other taxes, and should any license be revoked, no part of the fee therefor shall be returned. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  1, 14; Ord. No. 1545,  1, 2; Ord. No. 1648,  1; Ord. No. 4395,  1, 7-13-81; Ord. No. 6093,  1, 2-11-91; Ord. No. 7062,  1, 6-12-95; Ord. No. 8527,  I-B-I-D, 6-9-03; Ord. No. 8690,  I, 6-28-04) 
State Law reference- City authorized to collect fees for licenses issued to manufacturers, distillers, etc., RSMo 311.220. 
Sec. 3-16. - Same-Qualifications. 
    No person shall be granted a license under this article authorizing the sale of any intoxicating liquor, unless such person is of good moral character. No person shall be granted any license whose license as a dealer in or manufacturer or distiller of intoxicating liquor has been revoked by any city, county, state or federal agency in the United States, or who has been convicted, since December 5, 1933, of the violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor, or who employs or has associated with him in his business as such dealer, any person whose license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violating the provisions of any law since December 5, 1933. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  2) 
Sec. 3-17. - Same-Application; contents; issuance; hearing upon denial. 
(1)  Application for license required by section 3-14 shall be made in writing, describing the premises wherein operation thereunder is to be carried on, and to which said premises such license, if issued, shall be limited, and describing the class of license applied for as classified in section 3-15. Such application shall be made in the name of the person and signed by the manager in charge of the place of business for which such license is desired, and which manager shall at all times possess the qualifications set out in section 3-16. 
(2)  No manager, principal or employee of any such licensee shall perform any act in the manufacture, distilling, sale or exposition for sale of any intoxicating liquor in his capacity as such manager or employee until such licensee for the premises and the individual, whether manager or employee, shall also have obtained a license under section 3-39. 
(3)  Such application, when completed, shall be presented to the deputy city clerk. Any applicant, by signing an application form, shall indemnify the City of Liberty from any liability, attorney fees, costs and expenses incurred as a result of any patio operation, and shall consent to an investigation of all matters relevant to the qualifications of the applicant and, if advised of any contrary information or question with respect thereto, shall furnish full, accurate and verified information with respect to any deficiency of which applicant is advised. Upon completion of investigation, if applicant meets all requirements set forth in Chapter 3, Article III for the issuance of such license, the deputy city clerk shall issue the same which shall describe therein the identity of the applicant and the location of the premises for which the same is issued. 
(4)  If such license shall be denied by the deputy city clerk, upon written request the applicant shall be given a hearing before the city council for reconsideration thereof. At such hearing it shall be the burden of the applicant to show that the applicant meets all requirements and conditions for the issuance of such license and to establish such as a fact by proper evidence. Neither the deputy city clerk nor any other officer or agency of the city shall be required to prove any deficiency found, but the same shall be heard, if offered, in consideration of the evidence proffered by the applicant. As it finds the facts to be, final determination shall be made by the city council as to the issuance of such license. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  2, 3; Ord. No. 2087,  1; Ord. No. 4624,  3, 4, 3-28-83; Ord. No. 9338,  I, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 3-18. - Same-Term; proration; transferability, etc.; display. 
    Each license granted under this article shall be for a term ending on the thirtieth day of June next succeeding the granting thereof and may be prorated for a period of not less than three (3) months on payment of the proper proportion of the annual license fee. No such license shall be transferable or assignable, and [any license] may be revoked for cause. The privileges granted by such license shall be exercised by the licensee only in the premises described in the application therefor and no license shall be granted for more than one place of business to any one licensee. Such license shall be displayed to public view in the premises by such licensee at all times during the term thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  4) 
Sec. 3-19. - Same-Revocation; public hearings. 
    The city council may, in its reasonable discretion and for cause, revoke any license granted, first having given such licensee not less than ten (10) days' notice in writing, which notice shall contain the grounds for such revocation and shall command such licensee to be present at a meeting of the city council, to be held at a time and place stated, and to show cause, if any, why such license should not be revoked. Any license shall be automatically revoked when the licensee shall not have operated, or caused to be operated, the business, and such business has been closed to the public for a period of ninety (90) days consecutively; provided, that notice must be given to the licensee ten (10) days prior to revocation of the license, and he may then appear before the city council to show cause, if any, why such license should not be revoked. Such notice shall be served by any duly commissioned officer of the city, or by certified mail, to such licensee or to any person or employee in charge of the premises described in the application of such licensee for such license. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  5; Ord. No. 3289,  1) 
Sec. 3-20. - Same-Premises; operations restricted thereto. 
    The premises licensed under this article shall be on a single undivided tract or parcel of land and no products or materials to be used in the manufacture of intoxicating liquor and no intoxicating liquor to be used in or arising out of the business of such licensee as a manufacturer or distiller of or dealer in intoxicating liquor shall be stored, housed, kept or deposited at any place in the city, except on such premises. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  3) 
Sec. 3-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4393, enacted July 13, 1981, repealed  3-21, which regulated days and hours of sale of intoxicating liquor. The repealed section derived from the ordinances listed below: 
Ord. No. Sec. Ord. No. Sec. 1523 8 2181 1 1545 3, 4 3025 1  
Sec. 3-22. - Sale in other than original package prohibited; exceptions. 
    No licensee, licensed to sell intoxicating liquor by this article, shall sell or expose for sale any intoxicating liquor in any quantity, other than malt liquor containing alcohol not in excess of five (5) percent by weight, unless the same is contained in the original package, which package shall not have been broken or opened, and the licensee shall not suffer or permit the same to be opened on his premises. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  8) 
Sec. 3-23. - Purchase, etc., by minors. 
    No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall purchase or attempt to purchase or have in his possession any intoxicating liquor of any alcoholic content whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 2039,  1) 
Cross reference- Purchase of nonintoxicating beer by minors,  3-3; sale of alcoholic beverages to minors,  3-31; open house parties,  3-61. 
Sec. 3-24. - Drinking in public; possession of open container in motor vehicle. 
(a)  No person shall drink or display any intoxicating liquor while in or on any street, park, public place or parking area to which the public has access in the city except as permitted by city ordinance or resolution. 
(b)  No person, while an occupant of any motor vehicle upon any street, park, or parking area to which the public has access, shall have in possession or within range of immediate access any open container, can or bottle containing alcohol in any percentage, and no such person while such occupant shall consume any such beverage containing alcohol. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  9; Ord. No. 5584,  1, 8-8-88; Ord. No. 7770,  I, 3-22-99; Ord. No. 9338,  I, 7-14-08) 
Cross reference- Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages in parks,  22A-5. 
Sec. 3-25. - Sales to wholesalers or distributors and vice versa. 
    No manufacturer, distiller, distributor or wholesaler of intoxicating liquor or agent or employee thereof shall sell or offer for sale any intoxicating liquor in any quantity to any person not a licensee under the provisions of this article, but no license shall be required of any wholesaler or distributor for the sale of intoxicating liquor at wholesale to any licensee hereunder, except such license as is now required by the terms and provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  10) 
Sec. 3-26. - Prescription sales. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as limiting a druggist in the exercise of his business in compounding medicines or dispensing intoxicating liquor under prescription from a licensed physician. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  11) 
Sec. 3-27. - State and federal stamps prerequisite to possessing, selling, etc.; exception. 
    No person shall possess, sell or expose to sale any intoxicating liquor in any quantity, other than to sell or offer for sale malt liquor containing alcohol not in excess of five (5) percent by weight, by drink for consumption on the premises, unless the same is contained in an original package which shall have been labeled and stamped as is provided by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  13) 
Sec. 3-28. - Keeping premises; view of interior of premises to be unobstructed. 
    No licensee holding a license under this article authorizing the sale of intoxicating liquor shall suffer or permit the premises described in the application for such license to assume or acquire the appearance of what is commonly known as a "saloon" and no such licensee may erect or maintain on any such premises any blinds, screens, swinging doors, curtains or any other thing in or on such premises that will obstruct or obscure the interior thereof from public view. 
(Ord. No. 1523,  12) 
Sec. 3-29. - Right of city to collect fees by legal action. 
    The amount of such license fee for a period of one year, as provided by section 3-15, may be recovered of any person, attempting to engage in any business authorized to be licensed without first procuring such license, by civil action as is now provided in the cases of action by individuals for the recovery of debt. Such action shall be brought in the name of "the mayor, councilmen [council members] and citizens of the City of Liberty" and this remedy shall be in addition to and not in lieu of other remedies provided in this article. 
(1523,  18) 
Sec. 3-30. - Compliance with chapter. 
    No intoxicating liquor shall be manufactured, distilled, sold or exposed for sale in the city except as is expressly authorized under the provisions of this article. 
    All licensees under this article shall conform and adhere to the liquor laws of the state and the rules and regulations of the supervisor of the department of liquor control of the state at all times and specifically pertaining to the rules and regulations controlling the window displays, advertising signs, and visibility of the premises to the public. 
(1523,  6, 16; 1858) 
Sec. 3-30.5. - Limited licenses for temporary events and caterers' permits. 
    "Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, a limited license may be issued as set out below. 
(1)  Temporary event retail selling of intoxicating liquor by the drink. 
a.  A temporary license may be issued only to a church, school, civic, service, fraternal, veteran, political or charitable club or organization to allow the sale of intoxicating liquor at a picnic, bazaar, fair or similar gathering within the city for a period of not more than five (5) days by any such organization herein described. 
b.  An application for such temporary license, when completed, shall be presented to the deputy city clerk. Any applicant, by signing an application form, shall indemnify the City of Liberty from any liability, attorney fees, costs and expenses incurred as a result of any temporary event operation, and shall consent to an investigation of all matters relevant to the qualifications of the applicant and, if advised of any contrary information or question with respect thereto, shall furnish full, accurate and verified information with respect to any deficiency of which applicant is advised. Upon completion of investigation, if applicant meets all requirements set forth in the applicable sections of the City Code of Ordinances for the issuance of such license, the deputy city clerk shall present the same to the city council for consideration. For purposes of this temporary liquor license, "premises" shall be defined as that portion of property serving as the event area, on which intoxicating liquor is sold or consumed. 
c.  The applicant must provide written permission from the property owner to occupy and dispense liquor on the premises during the license period. In instances where the event is to occur on public property, the city may, at its discretion, substitute other city documents to meet this requirement. Should the event be proposed to take place outdoors, the applicant shall send a letter addressed to the owner or occupant of all properties within one hundred eighty-five (185) feet of the event location postmarked at least seven (7) days prior to the city council's consideration of the application, notifying them of the proposed event and the time and place of the council meeting at which the application will be considered. A copy of this letter must also accompany the application. Additional information necessary for presentation of the application to city council, including but not limited to a map of the location of the event; a complete description of the event; and a security plan, if appropriate, shall accompany the application. 
d.  The applicant must provide a valid certificate of general liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Missouri for the event premises, said proof of insurance to be filed with the city clerk's office providing for such general liability insurance in limits as established by the city. If such liability insurance shall terminate, or be cancelled, such license shall be immediately suspended, and not reinstated until such insurance has been further effected and policy or certificate thereof so filed. 
e.  Said license shall be issued upon approval by city council and the applicant providing proof to the deputy city clerk that a liquor license has been issued to the applicant by the State of Missouri. 
f.  No applicant shall sell intoxicating liquor at a picnic, bazaar, fair or similar gathering without first obtaining a temporary liquor license from the city. 
g.  The applicant shall comply with all applicable city codes and ordinances pertaining to this event and license. The applicant shall also comply with any applicable county and state laws governing such activity. 
h.  A license under the terms of this section shall be issued to qualified applicants who fully comply with the applicable provisions of this and other chapters, provided the proposed event does not adversely impact the public health, safety, comfort or general welfare, and upon payment of a license fee to the office of city clerk in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each calendar day or fraction thereof for which the license is issued. 
(2)  Caterer's permit. 
a.  A temporary permit to caterers or other persons holding licenses from this city or any other governmental subdivision in the State of Missouri to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail pursuant to the provisions of this chapter who furnish provisions and service for use at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location other than the licensed premises, effective for a period not to exceed seventy-two (72) consecutive hours, which shall authorize the serving of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption. A fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be paid to the City of Liberty for each calendar day, or fraction thereof, for which the permit is issued; 
b.  All applicable provisions of this chapter shall extend to such premises and shall be in force and enforceable during all the time that the permittee, or any agent, servant, employee, or stock are in such premises; 
c.  Any caterer who possesses a valid liquor license from the city may deliver alcoholic beverages, in the course of a catering business, within the city without obtaining a permit. 
(Ord. No. 8527,  I-E, 6-9-03; Ord. No. 9338,  I, 7-14-08) 
ARTICLE III. - SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES TO MINORS AND CERTAIN OTHER PERSONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7080,  1, adopted July 17, 1995, amended the Code by adding sections designated as  3-25-3-28. In order to avoid conflicts in section numbering, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 7080 as Art. III,  3-31-3-34. Formerly Art. III was reserved. 
Cross reference- Purchase of nonintoxicating beer by minors,  3-3; purchase of intoxicating liquor by minors,  3-23; open house parties,  3-61; intoxicated persons,  22-15. 

Sec. 3-31. - Sale of alcoholic beverages to minors. 
    No licensee, or his employee shall sell, vend, give away, or otherwise supply any intoxicating or nonintoxicating liquor in any quantity whatsoever to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(Ord. No. 7080,  1, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 3-31.1. - Purchase or possession by minors. 
(a)  No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall purchase or attempt to purchase or have in such person's possession intoxicating liquor, non-intoxicating beer, or beer of any alcoholic content whatsoever (hereinafter identified as "liquor). 
(b)  For purposes of this section, "possession" shall mean such person has physical control over or is in close proximity to a container that has or recently had intoxicating liquor in it; or by speech, manner, appearance, behavior, lack of coordination, or other observable condition, demonstrates that such person is under the influence of intoxicating liquor, non-intoxicating beer, or beer of any alcoholic content whatsoever; or a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall be presumed to be under the influence of liquor as set forth in this section if such person has a blood alcohol content, as determined by chemical analysis performed in accordance with methods approved by the Missouri State Department of Health and Senior Services, of two-hundredths (0.02) percent or greater. 
(c)  For purposes of prosecution under this section, a manufacturer-sealed container describing that there is intoxicating liquor or beer therein need not be opened or the contents therein tested to verify that there is intoxicating liquor or beer in such container. The alleged violator may allege that there was not intoxicating liquor or beer in such container, but the burden of proof of such allegation is on such person, as it shall be presumed that such a sealed container describing that there is intoxicating liquor or beer therein contains intoxicating liquor or beer in accordance with RSMo 311.325 or non-intoxicating beer in accordance with RSMo 312.407. 
(d)  Violation of any provision of this section is a misdemeanor and on conviction therefore a person shall be punished as prescribed by section 22-70 of the Liberty Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 9214,  I, 10-22-07) 
Sec. 3-32. - Sale of alcohol to certain persons. 
    No licensee, or his employee shall sell, vend, give away, or otherwise supply intoxicating or nonintoxicating liquor in any quantity whatsoever to any person intoxicated or appearing to be in a state of intoxication, or to a habitual drunkard. 
    No person shall procure for, sell, give away, or otherwise supply intoxicating or nonintoxicating liquor to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, or to any intoxicated person, or to a habitual drunkard; provided, however, that nothing in sections 3-31 through 3-33 shall apply to the supplying of intoxicating and nonintoxicating liquor to a person by that person's parent or guardian, or for medical purposes only, or to the administering of such to any person by a duly licensed physician. 
(Ord. No. 7080,  1, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 3-33. - Enforcement of liquor laws. 
    The police department shall enforce all municipal ordinances pertaining to the sale, distribution, possession, and consumption of alcoholic beverages under this chapter. Pursuant to this responsibility the police department may engage in covert enforcement activities involving sworn officers, underage operatives and informants in controlled situations to develop probable cause for arrests. In such cases the police department, nor its agents, will be deemed in violation of any provisions of this chapter, including section 3-23 purchase, etc. by minors. 
(Ord. No. 7080,  1, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 3-34. - Penalty provisions. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of sections 3-31 through 3-32 of the Liberty City Code constitutes an offense, is unlawful and constitutes a misdemeanor, and any person found guilty of violating these provisions shall be assessed a penalty of a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 7080,  1, 7-17-95) 
Secs. 3-35-3-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PERMIT TO SELL OR SERVE ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 3-39. - Required. 
    No person shall sell, serve or in any way dispense any intoxicating liquors or intoxicating beer or nonintoxicating beer in any place licensed in the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, to sell intoxicating liquor or intoxicating beer or nonintoxicating beer without first obtaining a permit issued by the deputy city clerk. Persons involved in the dispensing and/or sale of intoxicating liquor and non-intoxicating beer by the drink under a temporary event license, without pay, are exempt from the requirement to obtain a liquor dispensing permit if they meet appropriate age and other requirements. 
(2436,  1; Ord. No. 3924,  1, 2-27-78; Ord. No. 8527,  I-F, 6-9-03) 
Sec. 3-40. - Application; investigation of applicant; fee. 
    Every applicant for such permit shall provide his/her Missouri driver/non-driver license (or federal government issued photo identification). If applicant holds an out-of-state driver's license they must also provide the corresponding out of state driver's record. Applicants shall execute and fully complete an application provided by the city including disclosure of all the information required on the application form. Any applicant shall, by signing the application form, consent to an investigation of the record of the applicant with reference to convictions of crimes. The applicant will complete a State of Missouri Request for Criminal History Check which will be submitted to the state by the city with the applicant's payment of the required state fee. In addition, the applicant shall pay a fee based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(2436,  2, 4; Ord. No. 3924,  2, 2-27-78; Ord. No. 4298,  2, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 7507,  I, 7-28-97; Ord. No. 8624,  I, 12-15-03; Ord. No. 8624,  I, 12-15-03; Ord. No. 10344,  I, 2-23-15; Ord. No. 10632,  I, 10-10-16) 
Sec. 3-41. - Issuance generally; contents. 
(a)  Temporary approval. If the applicant meets the general requirements set forth in this article for the issuance of a permit, a sixty (60) day temporary permit shall be approved by the deputy city clerk, and a permit shall be issued stating the name, age, address, the expiration date of said permit, signed by the deputy city clerk. 
(b)  Full term approval. When the city receives the criminal records report from the state, if there are not entries that would prevent the issuance of a permit as outlined in section 3-42 below, the deputy city clerk will issue a three (3) year permit. 
(c)  Reconsideration upon initial disapproval. If such permit shall be denied by the deputy city clerk, upon written request the applicant shall be given a hearing before the city council for reconsideration thereof. At such hearing it shall be the burden of the applicant to show that the applicant meets all requirements and conditions for the issuance of such permit and to establish such as a fact by proper evidence. Neither the deputy city clerk nor any other officer or agency of the city shall be required to prove any deficiency found, but the same shall be heard, if offered, in consideration of the evidence proffered by the applicant. As it finds the facts to be, final determination shall be made by the city council as to the issuance of such permit. 
(2436,  5; Ord. No. 3924,  3, 2-27-78; Ord. No. 4800,  1, 5-29-84; Ord. No. 7507,  I, 7-28-97; Ord. No. 10344,  II, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 3-42. - Issuance to certain persons prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  Issuance of liquor dispensing permits: 
(1)  No permit shall be issued to any applicant under this article who shall have been convicted of a liquor, or controlled substance, related felony. 
(2)  No permit shall be issued to any applicant under this article who shall have been convicted since the ratification of the twenty-first amendment to the Constitution of the United States, of a violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor. 
(3)  No permit shall be issued to any applicant under this article who shall have been convicted during the two (2) years next before the date of application of any misdemeanor offense relating to liquor or controlled substances, other than those set out in subsection (2) above (to illustrate-D.W.I., etc.) 
(4)  The deputy city clerk may issue a temporary ninety-day permit to any applicant under this article who shall have been convicted during the period of not less than two (2) years nor more than five (5) years next before the date of application of any misdemeanor offense relating to liquor or controlled substances, other than those set out in subsection (2) above. During said ninety-day period, if an investigation by the police department of the record of the applicant reveals no further arrests for offenses relating to liquor or controlled substances (except as set out in subsection (2) above), the deputy city clerk may issue a full term permit. If the investigation of the applicant's record reveals such arrests, the procedure shall be as listed in this section concerning applicants under formal charge. 
(5)  Any applicant who shall be currently under formal charge for any offense listed in this section, but who meets all other requirements under this article for such permit, may be issued a probationary permit subject to dismissal or adjudication of such charge. Such probationary permit shall be automatically revoked and become invalid upon conviction under any such charge. If such charge is dismissed or applicant discharged as not guilty, said applicant shall be eligible for a full term permit. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued to any person who is under the age of twenty-one years of age, except that in any place of business licensed in accordance with section 3-4 or section 3-14 of the Code of the City of Liberty, Missouri, where at least fifty (50) per cent of the gross sales made consists of goods, merchandise or commodities other than intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer in the original package, persons at least eighteen (18) years of age may stock, arrange displays, operate the cash register or scanner connected to a cash register and accept payment for, and sack for carry-out, intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer. Delivery of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer away from the licensed business premises cannot be performed by anyone under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(c)  Persons eighteen (18) years of age or older may, when acting in the capacity as a waiter or waitress, accept payment for or serve intoxicating liquors in places of business which sell food for consumption on the premises if at least fifty (50) per cent of all sales in those places consists of food; providing that nothing in this section shall authorize persons under twenty-one (21) years of age to mix or serve across the bar intoxicating beverages. 
(3816; Ord. No. 3924,  4, 2-27-78; Ord. No. 4800,  2, 5-29-84; Ord. No. 10344,  III, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 3-43. - Term; grounds for revocation. 
    The initial temporary permit issued pursuant to this article shall expire sixty (60) days next following the date of the issuance of such permit. Such permit shall be revoked upon information from the state that would prohibit issuance as described in subsection (a) of section 3-42 of this article. 
    Regular permits issued pursuant to this article shall expire three (3) years next following the date of the issuance of the temporary permit. Such regular permit shall be automatically revoked and voided upon final conviction of any charges described in subsection (a) of section 3-42 of this article. 
(2436,  6; Ord. No. 3924,  5, 2-27-78; Ord. No. 7507,  I, 7-28-97; Ord. No. 10344,  IV, 2-23-15) 
Secs. 3-44-3-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 3-61. - Open house parties prohibited when alcohol or illegal drugs are possessed or used by minors. 
(a)  Definitions. Unless the provisions explicitly state otherwise, as used in this section, the following terms and phrases shall have the meanings hereinafter designated: 
(1)  Alcoholic beverage. Any alcoholic liquor as defined now and hereafter by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. Currently, "alcoholic liquor" is defined by RSMo 311.020. 
(2)  Control. Any form of authority, regulation, responsibility or dominion, including a possessory right. 
(3)  Drug. A controlled substance as defined and described now or hereafter by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. Currently, controlled substances are defined and described by RSMo 195.005-195.425 of the Revised Statues of Missouri (Chapter 195). 
(4)  Minor. A person not legally permitted by reason of age to possess, consume, or purchase alcoholic liquor as described now or hereafter by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(5)  Open house party. A social gathering at a residence or premises of persons in addition to the owner or those with rights of possession or their immediate family members. 
(6)  Residence or premises. A motel room, hotel room, home, apartment, condominium, or other dwelling unit, including the curtilage of a dwelling unit, or a hall, meeting room, or other place of assembly, whether occupied as a dwelling or specifically for social functions, and whether owned, leased, rented, or used with or without compensation. 
(b)  Prohibited activities. No person who is the owner in possession, a tenant or sub-tenant, or has temporary charge of any residence or premises, shall allow an open house party to take place at the residence or premises if any alcoholic beverage or drug is possessed or consumed at the residence or premises by any minor where the person knew or reasonably should have known that any alcoholic beverage or drug was in the possession or being consumed by a minor at the residence or premises and where the person failed to take reasonable steps to prevent the possession or consumption of the alcoholic beverage or drug at the residence or premises. 
The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  The consumption, use or possession of a drug by a minor pursuant to a lawful prescription for each drug. 
(2)  Religious observance or prescribed medical treatments. 
(3)  The possession by a minor of alcoholic beverages or lawfully prescribed drugs incidental to the lawful employment of such minor. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 7984,  I, 4-10-00) 
Sec. 3-61.1. - Refusal to disperse upon police order. 
    Liberty Police Officers are authorized to order those attending an open house party to disperse. It shall be unlawful for any person not domiciled at the site of the open house party to fail or refuse to leave the premises immediately after being told to leave by a Liberty Police Officer. 
    Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, may be punished as prescribed in section 22-70 and pay court costs. 
(Ord. No. 9552,  I, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 3-62. - Registration of alcohol sold in kegs at the point of sale within the city limits. 
(a)  Definitions. Unless the provisions explicitly state otherwise, as used in this chapter, the following terms and phrases shall have the meanings hereinafter designated: 
(1)  Keg. Any container capable of holding four (4) gallons or more of beer, wine, or intoxicating liquor which is designed to dispense beer, wine, or intoxicating liquor directly from the container for purposes of consumption. 
(2)  Registration seal. Any document, stamp, declaration, seal, decal, sticker, or device approved by the city which is designed to be affixed to kegs and which displays a registration number and such other information as may be prescribed by the city. 
(3)  Licensee shall mean any person holding a license within the city to sell beer, wine, or intoxicating liquor. 
(b)  Registration declaration/seal requirement. No licensee shall sell or transfer control of any beer, wine, or intoxicating liquor in a keg unless such licensee shall have first registered the transaction on a form prescribed by the city, obtained the written declaration of the purchaser as required herein, and affixed a registration seal on the keg at the time of sale. 
(c)  Registration declaration. Each licensee, prior to making a sale or transfer of a keg, shall obtain from the purchaser a written declaration stating the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the purchaser, verified by valid identification as determined by rules and regulations promulgated by the city. 
(2)  The type of identification presented by the purchaser. 
(3)  A statement signed by the purchaser indicating that the purchaser is twenty-one (21) years of age or older, does not intend to allow persons under twenty-one (21) years of age to consume the alcoholic beverages purchased, that the purchaser acknowledges the penalty for providing alcohol to minors is a fine up to five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such tine and imprisonment, and that the purchaser will not remove or obliterate the keg registration tag affixed to the keg or allow its removal or obliteration. 
(d)  Keg returns-Procedure to be followed by licensee. When a registered keg is returned to the licensee, the registration seal shall be removed or obliterated and note of such action shall be made on the registration records of the licensee. 
(e)  Violations. It shall be a violation of this section for any person, except as provided above: 
(1)  To fail to register a keg in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(2)  To remove, alter, deface, or obliterate any registration seal affixed to a keg, except that disposing of empty kegs made of disposable packaging shall not constitute a violation. 
(3)  To allow any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to consume alcoholic beverages in a keg; and 
(4)  If under twenty-one (21) years of age, to consume alcoholic beverages purchased in a keg. 
(f)  Seizure or forfeiture of keg. If any person is in possession of a keg used for containing beer, wine, or intoxication liquor in violation of this ordinance, then the keg and its contents shall be subject to seizure or forfeiture by officers of the city's police department. 
(g)  Responsibility to maintain records. Every licensee shall maintain a complete and accurate record of all registration forms and other documentation of the sale of kegs at the place of business designated in the permit for a period of one year. Such records regarding keg sales shall be open to inspection by the city or other law enforcement officers at a reasonable date and time. 
(h)  Penalty. Any person who violates the terms of this section shall, upon conviction, thereof be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(i)  Severability. If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase in this section(s) or any part thereof, is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by a court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of this section(s) or any part thereof. The city council hereby declares that it would have passed the ordinance which adopted this chapter and each section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase in this chapter or any part hereof irrespective of the fact that one or more other sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases be declared unconstitutional. 
(Ord. No. 8527,  I-G, 6-9-03) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes:

No. 6535,  3, adopted Feb. 22, 1993; Ord. No. 6598,  1, adopted May 24, 1993; Ord. No. 6710,  1, adopted Dec. 22, 1993; Ord. No. 8624,  II, adopted Dec. 15, 2003; Ord.
