ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adequate care means normal and prudent attention to the needs of an animal, including wholesome food, clean water, shelter and health care as necessary to maintain good health in a specific species of animal. 
    Adequate food means the provision at suitable intervals of a quantity of wholesome foodstuffs, suitable for the species and age, sufficient to maintain a reasonable level of nutrition in each animal, all of which foodstuffs is served in a safe receptacle, dish or container. 
    Adequate shelter means a structurally sound, properly ventilated, sanitary, dry and weatherproof shelter suitable for the species, age and condition of the animal, which is free of litter or hazardous substances and objects, contains clean and dry bedding material and which provides access to shade from direct sunlight and regress from exposure to inclement weather conditions. The shelter shall have at a minimum a floor, walls with an opening suitable for the size of the animal and a roof. Unacceptable shelter includes but is not limited to barrels, pipes, crates, cardboard boxes, pet carriers and tarpaulins. 
    Adequate water means the continual access to a supply of clean, fresh, unfrozen, potable water provided in a sanitary manner suitable for the species, condition and age of the animal in sufficient amounts to maintain good health in the animal. Such water shall be provided in a secure manner so that the container cannot be overturned. 
    Animal shall include livestock, creatures, fowl, dogs or cats. 
    Animal control authority means the animal control division of the department of administration of the city. 
    Animal control officer means any person employed by the animal control authority to enforce this chapter. 
    Approved vaccine means all vaccines licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture. 
    At large shall mean: 
(1)  To be freely roaming on the private property of another without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property or to be freely roaming on any public property, street or highway without consent of the public entity in control of the property, street or highway. 
(2)  Every dog, when on any street, alley, park, school ground or other public place in the city, which is not attached to a leash, no greater than 6 feet in length, the other end of which is securely held by a person. 
(3)  When a dog is unrestrained, and not under control of the owner, on private property within the city; and, when conditions are such that the dog can leave the premises on its own volition, the dog shall be deemed running at large. 
    Body harness means, a set of straps that extend around the chest and mid-section of the dog's body, so as to not tighten around the dog's neck when the dog pulls on the end of a tether. 
    Creature means a domesticated animal used as a household pet such as a hamster, gerbil or similar animal. 
    Dog means any member of the canine family. 
    Dogfighting paraphernalia means any instrument used to train animals, promote fights or observe, participate in or wager on any dog or animal fights including but not limited to treadmills, catmills, exercise wheels, hides or other material used as hanging devices to strengthen or condition dogs; collars, leashes, chains, and other devices used to exercise or restrain fighting dogs; wooden sticks or handles used to pry open dogs' jaws; magazines, photographs, film, videotapes, or writings that depict or promote dogfighting or training or conditioning of dogs for dogfighting; any still cameras or movie or video cameras used to record dogfighting activity; all portable carrying cases and pens; antibiotics, drugs, or vitamins used to treat injured dogs or to enhance their performance; needles and syringes used for the administration of such drugs; suture kits and other veterinary supplies; weapons, handguns, shotguns, or rifles used to protect the premises upon which illegal dogfighting occurs; computers and computer diskettes or other removable media containing information related to dogfighting; registration papers or other materials showing written materials showing ownership of pit bull dogs or other fighting dogs, including bills of sale, pedigrees, breeding records, and veterinary records; any dogfighting records, including name and telephone number lists of persons suspected of being dogfighters; any awards, trophies, plaques, or ribbons promoting or relating to dogfighting; any constructed enclosures or components of any pits or arenas used for the purpose of dogfighting or training dogs for fighting; any carpeting or other materials used on the floor of such pits; weight scales; any washtubs, buckets, pails, and sponges used to wash dogs; cash, currency and financial instruments; any rules, contracts, or other written agreements concerning the fighting of dogs. 
    Domesticated means trained or adapted for use in a human environment. 
    Euthanize means to put to death in a humane manner. 
    Exposed to rabies means when bitten by, or fought with, or has come in close contact with an animal showing symptoms of rabies. 
    Fowl means domesticated chickens, guineas, geese, ducks, turkeys or other domesticated bird. 
    Harbor means to feed or shelter an animal at the same location for three (3) or more consecutive days. 
    Hearing examiner means the chief of police, or his designee, as appointed by the city administrator. 
    Impound means to apprehend, catch, trap, net or, if necessary, euthanize any animal by the animal control authority or its agent. 
    Impounding facilities means any premises designated by the city for the purpose of impounding and caring for all animals found in violation of this chapter. 
    Livestock means domestic animals, such as swine, horses, mules, asses, sheep, goats, cattle, ostriches or emus. When these terms are used herein it shall include any related member of the species whether specifically mentioned or not. 
    Non-choke-type collar means, a collar that, when worn by a dog, does not constrict or choke the dog, when the dog pulls or extends the attached tether. 
    Owner means any person owning, keeping or harboring a dog. 
    Poultry means domestic fowl such as chickens, turkeys, guineas, ducks or geese. 
    Registration and vaccination means the procedure of vaccinating for rabies and issuing an identification number and an appropriate certificate. These words shall be interchangeable. 
    Tag means any object which bears a registration number and the words "registered and vaccinated for rabies," in the shape and color recognized by the National Association of State Public Health Veterinarians which has been issued by a veterinarian. 
    Tether means a rope, chain, or cable that is attached to a dog's collar or harness for purposes of restraining the dog. 
    Veterinarian means any veterinarian holding a current state license. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-2. - Minimum fine for certain violations; reckless owners. 
(a)  Any person who has violated provisions of this chapter more than three (3) times in an 12-month period shall be fined a minimum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the fourth offense and four hundred dollars ($400.00) for the fifth offense and each offense thereafter occurring during an 12-month period (violations one through three (3) are subject to fines according to City Code). In addition to the fine, such person shall pay for all costs of keeping the animal. All such animals shall be disposed of by the city in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 4-27 if the person charged fails to pay the minimum fine assessed by the court plus the costs of keeping the animal as set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  It is hereby found and declared that certain persons have committed either such severe or repeated violations of this chapter that they are reckless owners, and a judgment of the hearing examiner shall include revocation of the person's right to own, harbor or possess animals (with the type or types of animal to be determined by the hearing examiner) for a specified amount of time. 
(1)  Definition. A person may be found to be a reckless owner if: 
a.  The person has been convicted of one or more violations of this chapter on three (3) separate occasions within a 24-month period; or 
b.  Sufficient proof is presented that the person is guilty of animal cruelty under section 4-5; 
c.  The person owns, harbors or possesses a dog that has been determined to be dangerous and has not complied with the subsequent requirements of this chapter; or 
d.  The person owns, harbors or possesses a dog that has been accused of attacking a domestic animal or biting a person, and the owner, harborer, or possessor of such a dog fails to surrender the dog to the animal control authority or fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any person to violate any restriction imposed by this section after a person has been declared a reckless owner by order of the municipal court or by order of the hearing examiner. 
(3)  Upon the filing of the affidavit of the animal control officer, or of his designee, with the municipal prosecutor alleging a person is a reckless owner, and upon the motion of the prosecutor, the judge of the municipal court may order any of the following: that all domestic animals owned, possessed, or controlled by the person be seized and impounded during the pendency of charges and appeal and not be released while the charges or appeal are pending without order of the municipal judge, upon the recommendation from the hearing examiner. 
(4)  Administrative process. 
a.  The city may at any time initiate an administrative hearing in writing to determine if a person is a reckless owner pursuant to this chapter. If an animal is being held pursuant to a municipal court order because its owner is an alleged reckless owner, the owner of the animal may request an administrative hearing in writing to the deputy city clerk. The hearing shall be held within twenty-five (25) days of the request unless continued based upon a showing of good cause. The hearing examiner shall take evidence and determine if the facts support a finding that the person is a reckless owner. If the hearing examiner finds the person to be a reckless owner, an order shall be entered consistent with the remedies set forth in this section. No penalty provided for in section 1-7 shall be imposed by the hearing examiner. The hearing examiner shall not be a judge of the municipal court. 
b.  Upon entry of such declaration and order, unless a review of such order is filed in accordance with this section, such reckless owner shall be required to surrender any or all of his or her animals to the animal control authority within twenty-four (24) hours, as ordered by the hearing examiner. Failure to surrender such animals is a criminal violation of this act that shall result in prosecution as well as immediate impoundment by the animal control authority upon issuance of a warrant of the municipal court for the authority to seize the animals. Such surrendered or impounded animals shall immediately become the property of the animal control authority and be disposed of pursuant to section 4-27 after the expiration of the appeal period. 
(5)  Administrative review. Any party aggrieved by an administrative decision pursuant to subsection (4) may appeal by filing a request for review with the Circuit Court of Missouri, 7 th Judicial Circuit. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for a reckless owner to fail to surrender any or all animals, as ordered by the hearing examiner, within twenty-four (24) hours or to subsequently own, possess, or have control over any animal for a period of twenty-four (24) months from the date of entry of the declaration and order. 
(7)  Criminal process. Any person found guilty of a violation by a Judge of the municipal court shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by section 22-70, and each and every instance of violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-3. - Limitation on number of cats or dogs kept as pets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a public nuisance for any person or occupier of land to own, keep or harbor more than a maximum total of four (4) dogs or cats, or in any combination thereof, over the age of four (4) months, except as a kennel regulated by the Unified Development Ordinance of the City of Liberty or when such owner or occupier of land resides on a tract of ground that is at least forty (40) acres or larger. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, or harbor more than one dangerous dog within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-4. - Placing poison so as to constitute hazard to humans or animals. 
    No person shall feed or place so as to constitute a direct or obvious hazard to man or animal or shall offer or tempt any dog or pet animal with any liquid, meat or food product which shall: 
(1)  Cause prostration, convulsion, pain or suffering as a prelude to death; 
(2)  Cause death; or 
(3)  Be proven to be toxic or lethal in the amount present to any man or domestic animal by competent medical or veterinary authority. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-5. - Care of animals. 
(a)  The owner of an animal shall provide it with humane shelter from heat, cold, rain, wind and snow, and shall give it food and water adequate to keep the animal in good health and comfort. Dog houses and kennels shall be soundly constructed, dry and provided in cold weather with clean bedding. If any person shall torture, torment, deprive of necessary sustenance, cruelly beat, mutilate, cruelly kill or overdrive any animal, or shall unnecessarily fail to provide the same with proper food, drink, shelter or protection from the weather, or shall cruelly work or drive same when unfit for labor, or cruelly abandon the same to die, or shall carry or cause the same to be carried on or in any vehicle or otherwise in an unnecessarily cruel or inhuman manner, he shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. All animals shall be given opportunity for daily exercise, and shall be provided by their owners with veterinary care when needed, and with kindly treatment. No owner shall permit a dog to habitually bark, howl, or in other ways be a public nuisance. No owner of any other species of animal shall permit it to become a public nuisance. An owner shall keep his animal under restraint at all times. Any animal not under restraint is subject to impoundment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to confine any animal in a motor vehicle or extension of said motor vehicle (i.e. attached trailer, etc.), under weather or other conditions that endanger its life. Whenever an animal is found to be in such circumstances that the animal control officer or a police officer determines to be endangering to the animals life, an animal control officer and or a police officer, is authorized to enter such vehicle or extension of said motor vehicle (i.e. attached trailer, etc.) and remove the animal for impoundment, at the expense of the owner/operator. The City of Liberty shall in no way be financially or legally liable for damages caused as a result of removal of the animal by the above defined City of Liberty officials, under conditions that endanger the animal's life. A prominent written notice shall be left on or in the vehicle advising that the animal has been removed under the authority of this section and impounded in accordance with this section. 
(c)  Any person found guilty of a violation prescribed in this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by sections 4-2(a) and 22-70, and each and every instance of violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-6. - Search and seizure warrants. 
(a)  The judge of the municipal court, upon application of the city prosecutor or legal service provider upon a showing that there is probable cause to believe that a violation of section 4-2, 4-5, 4-8 or 4-30 exists, and that there is probable cause to believe that evidence of such violation may be found at a specified location, may issue a search and seizure warrant, which shall be served only by an animal control officer in the company of a uniformed officer of the city police department. The warrant shall specify what animals, domesticated or wild, dogfighting paraphernalia and any other living or deceased creatures that may be seized, and shall specify the location of any animals and paraphernalia to be seized. 
(b)  The judge of the municipal court shall upon issuance of a search and seizure warrant under this section order the animal control officer to: 
(1)  Use reasonable care to care for and maintain the animals seized pursuant to the authority granted by this section free of charge to their owner for a period of two (2) weeks or upon a disposition of any municipal court proceedings filed under section 4-5, whichever is sooner; 
(2)  Return to the municipal court for further instructions concerning the disposition of any animals seized pursuant to the authority granted by this section if the animals have not been returned to their rightful owner at the end of two (2) weeks; and 
(3)  Seek the permission of the municipal court before euthanizing or giving up for adoption any animals seized pursuant to the authority granted by this section. 
(c)  Upon an owner's being found guilty of a violation of section 4-5, the municipal court shall require that the owner pay a reclamation fee of such amount as established by ordinance from time to time, plus any other license fees or immunization costs imposed under this chapter. Failure or refusal to pay such fees shall constitute abandonment of any ownership rights to the seized animal, and the judge shall immediately order the animal's disposal. 
(d)  The judge of the municipal court, in exercising authority granted in this section relative to the disposition of impounded animals, may authorize disposal pursuant to section 4-27. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-7. - Possession, display or sale of wild animals. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, possess, display or offer for sale any wild animal within the city. For the purpose of this section, the term "wild animals" shall include but not be limited to dangerous, zoonotic or exotic carnivorous animals and bats, nonhuman primates, dangerous or poisonous reptiles, foxes, raccoons, skunks, opossums and turtles, or any wild animal crossbred to domestic dogs or cats. 
(b)  Exception. This section shall not apply to common carriers transporting wild animals for hire in the usual course of their business, or to wild animals kept for exhibition purposes by circuses, zoos, scientific or educational institutions, research laboratories or veterinary hospitals, in accordance with state regulations. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-8. - Fighting animals. 
(a)  No person shall cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, cockfight or other combat between animals or between animals and humans; and any animal so used shall be seized, impounded and promptly humanely euthanized. In addition, no person shall place or attempt to place an animal in an enclosure or in any other place for the purpose of fighting or combat. No person shall attend such unlawful exhibition or be umpire, judge or spectator at such exhibition. 
(b)  No person shall train a dog to fight in the City of Liberty. Additionally, no person shall keep or harbor a dog that has been trained to fight. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-9. - Keeping poultry generally. 
    Regulated by city zoning regulations and section 30-80.7, "accessory uses, residential", keeping of livestock. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-10. - Keeping of livestock generally. 
(a)  No person shall keep, except as permitted by city zoning regulations, on any premises occupied by him under his charge or control any horses, mules, swine, cattle, goats, sheep, ostriches, emus or other animals in a pen or enclosure so that an offensive, disagreeable or noxious smell or odor shall arise therefrom. 
(b)  Livestock shall be provided with adequate care as outlined in section 4-5 and shall not be allowed to run at large, and when legally kept must be restrained in a manner and by such means as will prevent such animals from escaping, straying or running at large. Gates used to restrain livestock shall be kept closed with a chain and padlock to minimize vandalism. Each time that livestock are found running loose or not kept as required by this section is a violation. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-11. - Riding, etc., horses, etc., on sidewalks or pavements. 
    No person shall ride, drive or lead any horse, mare, mule, stallion, gelding or other animals upon any of the sidewalks or pavements within this city unless done as part of a licensed sight-seeing business, or temporary event license, as authorized by City Code. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-12. - Emergency impoundment of animals. 
(a)  Animals may be impounded during an investigation for possible violations of RSMo 578.012, or section 4-5, for failure to provide adequate care to animals. 
(b)  If the owner or person in control of an animal is arrested, is deceased or is otherwise incapacitated, the animal may be taken into protective custody if no responsible party can be found to take control of the animal. 
(c)  In the event any dog or other domesticated animal shall bite, injure or attack any person, the owner or harborer of such animal shall take such animal to the city animal shelter or to a licensed veterinarian for observation (rabies quarantine). 
(d)  Dogs not licensed pursuant to this article, or found not under restraint, or abandoned, may be picked up and impounded by any police officer or animal control officer. Impoundment may be in the city animal shelter or a licensed veterinary hospital. 
(e)  Any animal impounded under this section shall be disposed of pursuant to subsection 4-6(d). 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-13. - Impoundment fees. 
    Fees for the impoundment of animals shall be as established by ordinance from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-14. - Animal bites generally. 
    No person, whether an owner or other person having immediate charge or custody of an animal, shall suffer, allow or permit such animal to bite a human being or another animal, or fail to prevent such animal from biting a human being or another animal. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS AND CATS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-16. - Vaccination. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor or own a dog or cat within the city, until and unless such person has the dog or cat vaccinated for rabies and secures a rabies vaccination certificate from any veterinarian who holds a current license from the state. Owners of dogs shall also secure a tag of registration vaccination issued from such veterinarian which shall be displayed on the dog for which it was issued. Owners of cats shall also secure a tag of registration, however, the tag shall not be required to be displayed on the cat, provided the owner of the cat shall be required to retain at all times a copy of the vaccination certificate or the tag. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-17. - License required. 
    No person shall own, keep or harbor any dog over the age of four (4) months within the city limits unless such dog is licensed as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-18. - License application. 
(a)  Written application for a license shall be made to the city's finance department or to any duly licensed veterinarian practicing within the city limits and shall state the name, address and telephone number (if any) of the owner and the name, breed, color, sex and any distinguishing marks on the dog. 
(b)  The license fee shall be paid to the city's finance department or duly licensed veterinarian as the case may be at the time of making application. If said application is made to a duly licensed veterinarian in the city, then such veterinarian may add one dollar ($1.00) to the license fee to be retained by him as compensation for his service; the veterinarian shall remit the license fees for the application to the city on a month-to-month basis; provided that no application shall be received nor any license issued unless a signed certificate from a veterinarian shows that such dog has been inoculated against rabies. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-19. - License fees; penalty for failure to pay when due. 
(a)  The yearly license fees shall be five dollars ($5.00) for a sterilized dog; ten dollars ($10.00) for an unsterilized dog. 
(b)  All licenses shall be issued for one year beginning the first day of the month that the animal is vaccinated for hydrophobia and rabies. The owner shall apply for the license within thirty (30) days of the date of the vaccination. If the application is made after thirty (30) days the appropriate license fee shall be increased by fifty (50) per cent. A person who becomes a new owner of a dog shall apply for a license within thirty (30) days of acquiring the animal. Failure to apply for a license within the thirty (30) days will result in the license fee being increased by fifty (50) per cent. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-20. - Issuance of tags; attachment of tags to collar; lost, etc., tags; transferability of licenses. 
(a)  The city's finance department or licensed veterinarian shall issue a receipt and a numbered, metallic or plastic tag. The city's finance department shall issue to the veterinarian tags and records as needed, and the veterinarian shall return all unused tags to the city's finance department on December thirty-first of each year. The city shall maintain for three (3) years two (2) records of such receipts and tags; one arranged alphabetically by name of owner and other arranged numerically by tag numbers. Such records shall be open to public inspection at all business hours. 
(b)  The owner shall keep on the dog, at all times when the animal is not inside a private building, a collar or harness, and the tag issued by the city shall be affixed to the collar or harness in such a manner that the tag can be easily seen. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-21. - Proper enclosure and location to confine a dog (pens, kennels, structures, and fencing). 
(a)  All fences constructed for the purpose of containing animals as provided in this chapter shall be composed of either posts and rails, posts and palings, posts and wire, or posts and boards and shall be at least three and one-half (31/2) feet in height, or higher if necessary to prevent the escape of the animal. All posts shall be set firmly into the ground, not more than eight (8) feet apart, with rails, palings, wire or boards securely fastened thereto and placed a proper distance apart so as to resist the animals the fence is meant to contain. Fences composed of woven wire, wire netting or wire mesh shall be of sufficient closeness of mesh density, as to contain the intended animals. 
(b)  If the dog is not under supervision while remaining in the yard of any property, the dog must be securely confined by enclosed fencing or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, kennel, structure, or run. Such fencing or pen, kennel, structure, or run must be suitable for preventing the animal from escaping. A locked pen, structure, or run must have minimum dimensions of five (5) feet by ten (10) feet and must have secure sides and a secure top. If it has no bottom secured to the sides, the sides must be embedded into the ground no less than two (2) feet. The enclosure must also provide protection from the elements for the dog. The exterior boundary of which pen shall not be closer than twenty-five (25) feet at the nearest point to the dwelling of another, a church, as school or a place of business of another. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-22. - Tethering dogs. 
    Any dog permitted to be kept within the city shall not be left unattended and chained, tied, fastened or otherwise tethered to any stationary or inanimate object as a means of confinement and restraint to property. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-23. - Restraint. 
    When not confined to residential property, the owner or keeper of a dog shall keep his dog under restraint at all times, on a leash no longer than six (6) feet in length. It shall be unlawful for any person owning, controlling, harboring, possessing, or having the management or care of any dog to permit such dog to run at large. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-24. - Duty to possess means of removal; disposal. 
    It shall be the duty of each person who owns, possesses or controls a dog to immediately remove and properly dispose of any feces left by his/her dog on any sidewalk, street, public area or private property, not owned by the person. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-25. - Female dogs in heat. 
    The owner shall confine any female dog in heat within a building, in such a manner that the animal will not be accessible to other dogs except for planned breeding, and will not attract males of the species. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-26. - Impoundment. 
    Dogs not licensed pursuant to this article, or found not under restraint, or abandoned, may be picked up and impounded by any police officer or animal control officer. Impoundment may be in the city animal shelter or a licensed veterinary hospital. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-27. - Redeeming of impounded dogs. 
(a)  Identifying the owner. If the animal wears a license tag or if the owner can by any other reasonable means be identified and located, the owner shall be notified by the animal control officer as soon as possible that the animal has been impounded. Animals that have not been vaccinated or if no evidence of vaccination is present will be vaccinated before release. 
(b)  Failure of owner to redeem. If an animal is not redeemed by the owner within five (5) days after impoundment, the animal may be disposed of in one of the following ways, but no other ways: (1) release for adoption by a new owner who shows evidence of ability and intention to provide the animal with an appropriate home and humane care and further agrees to have said animal sterilized; (2) release to city approved rescue organization, provided the organization agrees to have the animal sterilized and indemnify and hold harmless the city from any and all liabilities that might arise from such transaction; (3) euthanasia, using a method approved by the Humane Society of the United States. 
(c)  Fees. An owner redeeming an animal from impoundment shall pay a fee before the animal is released. Fees for impoundment, adoption, disposal of dogs and cats and cremation are based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. Such fees shall be paid to the animal control officer or shelter attendant on duty at the shelter. The animal control officer or shelter attendant shall issue a receipt for all monies collected and be responsible for securing the monies collected each day and depositing said money with the city finance department, according to written procedures. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-28. - Refusal to deliver dog or cat to animal control officer. 
    No person shall refuse to deliver up to the animal control officer his dog or cat when requested to do so, under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-29. - Keeping of pit bull dogs prohibited. 
(a)  Prohibition; definition. It shall be unlawful to keep, harbor, own or in any way possess within the corporate limits of the City of Liberty, Missouri, any pit bull dog; provided, that pit bull dogs residing in the city on the date of passage of this section may be kept within the city subject to the standards and requirements herein set forth. "Pit bull dog" is defined to mean: 
(1)  The bull terrier breed of dog; 
(2)  Staffordshire bull terrier breed of dog; 
(3)  The American pit bull terrier breed of dog; 
(4)  The American Staffordshire terrier breed of dog; 
(5)  Dogs of mixed breed or other breeds than above listed which breed or mixed breed is known as pit bulls, pit bull dogs, or pit bull terriers; 
(6)  Any dog which has the appearance and characteristics of being predominantly of the breeds of bull terrier, Staffordshire bull terrier, American pit bull terrier, American Staffordshire terrier; any other breed commonly known as pit bulls, pit bull dogs or pit bull terriers, or a combination of any of these breeds. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  II, 1-22-18) 
DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS DOGS 

Sec. 4-30. - Dangerous dogs. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to own, harbor or possess a dangerous dog, except as allowed by the provisions of this section. 
    The municipal court judge or hearing examiner may declare a dog dangerous: 
(1)  When evidence shows an attack or bite to a human is a Level 4 or higher on the Dunbar scale, set forth in section 4-31; or 
(2)  When evidence shows an attack upon another domestic animal is a Level 4 or higher on the Dunbar scale, and a pattern of vicious behavior such as habitually snapping, charging, growling, or otherwise manifests a disposition to bite, attack or injure any person or domestic animal or pet if afforded the opportunity, or if in the judgment of the court or administrative tribunal it causes any person to have a reasonable fear of immediate serious physical injury; or 
(3)  When evidence shows an attack or bite to a human is less than a Level 4 on the Dunbar scale and pattern of vicious behavior such as habitually snapping, charging, growling, or otherwise manifests a disposition to bite, attack or injure any person, domestic animal or pet if afforded the opportunity, or if in the judgment of the court or administrative tribunal it causes any person to have a reasonable fear of immediate serious physical injury. 
(4)  Has been previously found to be dangerous by another entity and the owner or keeper received notice of such. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to violate any restriction imposed by this section after a dog has been declared a dangerous dog by order of the municipal court or by order of the hearing examiner. 
(c)  Upon the filing of the affidavit of the animal control officer, with the municipal prosecutor alleging the dog is a dangerous dog, and upon the motion of the prosecutor, the judge of the municipal court may order any of the following: that the dog be seized and impounded, that the dog be impounded past the rabies observation period, or that the dog be impounded during the pendency of charges and appeal and not be released while the charges or appeal are pending, without order of the municipal judge, upon the recommendation from the hearing examiner. 
(d)  Administrative process. 
(1)  The city may at any time initiate an administrative hearing in writing to determine if a dog is dangerous pursuant to this chapter. If a dog is being held pursuant to a municipal court order as an alleged dangerous dog, the owner of the dog may request an administrative hearing in writing to the deputy city clerk. The hearing shall be held within twenty-five (25) days of the request unless continued based upon a showing of good cause. The hearing examiner, as appointed by the city administrator, shall take evidence and determine if the facts support a finding that the dog is dangerous. If the hearing examiner finds the dog to be dangerous, an order shall be entered consistent with the remedies set forth in this section. No penalty provided for in section 22-70 shall be imposed by the hearing examiner. The hearing examiner shall not be a judge of the municipal court. 
(2)  Any dog declared dangerous by the hearing examiner may be ordered humanely euthanized upon the expiration of the appeal period. 
(3)  Any dog declared dangerous by the hearing examiner and not ordered euthanized and as a condition of residing within the corporate limits of the city shall be required to meet the following mandated restrictions: 
a.  Microchip. That a microchip has been placed into the dog by the animal control authority for the purpose of registering such dog with the city. The microchip shall contain the owner's, keeper's or harborer's generated and assigned "dangerous dog registration number" and such other information as required pursuant to the rules and regulations of the city. The animal control authority shall keep records of the microchip placement and of the registration number. 
It shall be a violation of this Code for a microchip to be removed unless it is for a medical reason and then only by a licensed practicing veterinarian. The animal control authority must be notified immediately of said removal. 
b.  The dog shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked kennel or cage. The kennel or cage shall be the size appropriate to the size of the dog kept therein (minimum dimensions of five (5) feet by ten (10) feet) and shall provide adequate ventilation, shade from the sun, and protection from the elements. In the event of a dispute over the appropriate size, the guidelines of the state department of agriculture regulations for animal care facilities shall apply. The kennel or cage must be constructed with nine-gauge steel chain link. Such kennel or cage must have secure sides, a secure top, and secure bottom or floor attached to the sides, or the sides must be embedded in the ground. In addition, the kennel or cage must have a double-blind entrance and must be locked with a key or combination lock when such dog is within the structure. Any such kennel or cage must be located at least twenty-five (25) feet from the nearest point to the dwelling of another, a church, a school or a place of business of another and must comply with all zoning and building regulations of the city. 
1.  Notice. A conspicuous notice, which shall be at least two (2) feet by three (3) feet, posted at the place of confinement and on the premises stating "dangerous dog" in at least two-inch block letters and contain the international symbol for danger, as to warn the public of the nature of the dog therein confined. 
2.  No dangerous dog shall be confined by an electronic fence or an electric collar. Electronic collars may not be used to control a dangerous dog when it is off the owner's, keeper's, harborer's or maintainer's property. 
3.  No dangerous dog may be kept on a porch, patio, or in any part of a house or structure that would allow the dog to exit such structure on its own volition. In addition, no dangerous dog shall be kept in a house or structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen doors are the only barrier preventing the animal from exiting the structure. 
c.  No person shall permit a dangerous dog to go outside its kennel, cage, or secure structure unless that person is age eighteen (18) or older, that person has the dog securely leashed to a buckle collar and on a leash no longer than six (6) feet in length, and that person has physical control of the dog. Such dog shall not be leashed to inanimate objects such as trees, posts and buildings. Additionally, such dog on a leash outside the dog's kennel, cage, or secure structure must be muzzled by a humane muzzling device sufficient to prevent the dog from biting persons or other animals. 
d.  The dog shall not be allowed by remedy to be removed from the city to a location outside of the city limits, unless ordered by the municipal judge. 
e.  Any dog declared dangerous by the hearing examiner cannot be sold, given away, or ownership otherwise transferred without the expressed permission of the animal control authority. 
f.  Sterilization. That the dog has been sterilized by a licensed veterinarian and proof of such has been provided to the animal control authority. Sterilization must be completed prior to the release of the dog to the owner, keeper or harborer from impoundment due to rabies quarantine or immediately following the quarantine period, if animal is to be confined to owner's premises. 
Exceptions: 
1.  The dog is under eight (8) weeks of age; 
2.  The dog cannot be spayed or neutered without a high likelihood of suffering serious bodily harm or death due to a physical abnormality. A veterinarian must certify such condition and determine the time frame after which the dog can be spayed or neutered. 
g.  For a dangerous dog, a policy of liability insurance issued by an insurer authorized to do business in the state in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00), insuring the owner or keeper for personal injuries inflicted by the dog. An insurance policy issued to satisfy the insurance requirements of this section shall provide for written notice to the city within thirty (30) days of cancellation, reduction of limits, or termination of coverage. 
h.  Licensure required. Other than when a commissioned police officer is using a dog for law enforcement or when a dog is being held in quarantine pursuant to law by a licensed veterinarian, no person shall own, keep, harbor or allow to be upon any premises occupied by him or her or under his or her charge or control a dangerous dog without first having obtained a license within thirty (30) days of the date of declaration provided for by this section. 
1.  Licensure. The owner, keeper, or harborer of a dangerous dog shall obtain a dangerous dog license from the animal control authority for any such dog. 
i.  Licensure fees. The owner, keeper, or harborer shall pay the fee for such dangerous dog license in the amount set forth in this section. In addition, the owner, keeper, or harborer of such dog shall pay an annual renewal fee for such license in the amount set forth in this subsection. Annual renewal of any license shall be conditioned on compliance with the requirements of this section. The animal control authority is authorized to pro rate the license fee for the remainder of the first year during which an animal becomes subject to the registration requirements, of this section. 
ii.  Licensure information. The owner, keeper, or harborer of a dog that is subject to a dangerous dog license shall furnish the following information along with the appropriate license fee: (1) the animal's age, weight, coloring, breed, and any other special identifying characteristics; (2) two (2) three-inch by five-inch color photographs of the animal; (3) proof of current rabies vaccination for the animal; (4) a certification under penalty of perjury that the animal has not been previously found to be a potentially dangerous or dangerous dog by any other jurisdiction; and (5) a certification under penalty of perjury that the animal has not been removed from another jurisdiction to avoid any penalties arising from the animal's previous status. 
iii.  Licensure fee amounts. The license fee for each dangerous dog to be licensed pursuant to this section is two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). The annual renewal fee for each dangerous dog licensed pursuant to this subsection is one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). 
2.  Issuance of certificate of registration. A certificate of registration for a dangerous dog shall be issued by the city upon a showing of compliance with the requirements of this article: 
i.  Microchipped; 
ii.  Secure enclosure and posted notice; 
iii.  Sterilization; 
iv.  Liability insurance; and 
v.  Dangerous dog license. 
i.  Age violation. It is a violation of this chapter for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to own, keep, harbor or maintain control of a dangerous dog, within the city limits. 
j.  Refusal or failure to comply with any of the mandated or hearing examiner-ordered restrictions or authorized inspection shall constitute a violation of this Code and, in addition, shall be considered as justifiable grounds for the hearing examiner to order further restrictions or euthanization of the dog. 
(5)  Any party aggrieved by an administrative decision pursuant to subsection (d) may appeal by filing a request for review with the Circuit Court of Missouri, 7 th Judicial Circuit. 
(6)  Criminal process. Any person found guilty of a violation prescribed in subsection (a) or (b) by a judge of the municipal court shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by section 22-70 and each and every instance of violation shall be a separate offense. A judge of the municipal court shall not impose any penalty listed in subsection (d). 
(7)  Any dog maintained and utilized by any governmental law enforcement agency shall not be considered a dangerous dog so long as it is maintained and utilized for law enforcement purposes. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-31. - Dunbar scale. 
(a)  Level 1. Obnoxious or aggressive behavior but no skin-contact by teeth. 
(b)  Level 2. Skin-contact by teeth but no skin-puncture. However, may be skin nicks (less than one-tenth ( 1/10 ) of an inch deep) and slight bleeding caused by forward or lateral movement of teeth against skin, but no vertical punctures. 
(c)  Level 3. One to four (4) punctures from a single bite, which may have lacerations in a single direction, caused by victim pulling hand away, owner pulling dog away, or gravity (little dog jumps, bites and drops to floor). 
(d)  Level 4. One to four (4) punctures from a single bite, with deep bruising around the wound (such as when a dog held on and bore down) or lacerations in both directions (such as when a dog held on and shook its head from side to side). 
(e)  Level 5. Multiple-bite incident with at least two (2) Level 4 bites or multiple-attack incident with at least one Level 4 bite in each. 
(f)  Level 6. Victim dead. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-32. - Reserved 
ARTICLE III. - RABIES CONTROL 

Sec. 4-33. - Rabid animals. 
(a)  Every rabid animal, or animal exposed to rabies, shall be immediately confined by the owner, who shall promptly notify a police officer or the animal control officer. The owner shall surrender such animal for quarantine in the city animal shelter or a licensed veterinary hospital; provided that if the owner elects to place the animal in a hospital he shall be responsible for all costs. The animal may be quarantined a maximum of ten (10) days, but shall be released earlier if certified by a licensed veterinarian to be free of rabies. 
(b)  No person shall euthanize a rabid animal, or an animal exposed to rabies; nor remove such an animal from the city, without permission from the animal control authority, except when it is necessary to euthanize such animal to prevent it from escaping or from biting any other animal or person. 
(c)  The body of any animal having been exposed to rabies prior to death shall be surrendered by the owner upon demand of the animal control authority. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-34. - Impoundment of animal when person bitten. 
    In the event any dog or other domesticated animal shall bite, injure or attack any person, the owner or harborer of such animal shall take such animal to the city animal shelter or to a licensed veterinarian for observation. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-35. - Animal to be released when there is no evidence of rabies. 
    If, within such period of observation, such animal or dog does not develop or manifest evidence of hydrophobia, or rabies, or other disease communicable to human beings, such animal may be redeemed by the owner upon the payment of boarding fees as determined by the animal control authority or veterinarian. All animals under clinical observation for rabies must fulfill all other conditions of this chapter prior to release. At the time of the biting, a summons shall be issued to the owner if in violation of any other parts of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-36. - When animal to be confined on owner's premises. 
    If it be the judgment of a licensed veterinarian that confinement in the pound, or veterinarian hospital, would prove to be detrimental to the health of such dog or animal, then same shall be confined by the owner, keeper or harborer upon his premises; provided, that such owner, keeper or harborer shall deliver such dog or animal to such veterinarian for examination every other day during such observation period. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-37. - Disposition of diseased animals. 
    It is further provided that if such dog or animal does manifest symptoms of disease, as heretofore referred to, as determined by the animal control officer or veterinarian, if it is then determined the dog or other animal shall be euthanized, the head and brain of such animal shall then be delivered to the Missouri Division of Health laboratory in Jefferson City, Missouri, for examination. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-38. - General quarantine of animals. 
    When the animal control officer shall deem it necessary because of the prevalence of rabies among the animal population of the city, county or state, strict quarantine may be placed on any species or breed of animal in any designated area of the city. This proclamation shall be construed to mean that all dogs, cats or other animals shall be confined in the owner's home or tied up or placed on a leash and under the direct physical control of a person at least eighteen (18) years of age. Violation of this regulation shall be a misdemeanor. Any dog, cat or other animal found otherwise during such a quarantine shall be impounded. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-39. - Entry on private property by animal control and public safety officers. 
    The animal control officer or their designee shall have the right of entry to any property or premises for the purpose of examining and impounding any animal involved in a bite or scratch or exposed to or exhibiting clinical symptoms of rabies; provided, however, if time and circumstances warrant, the animal control officer may apply to the municipal court for a search warrant for the purpose of seizing the animal which warrant shall be issued upon a showing that a person has been bitten or scratched by an animal and there is probable cause to believe that the animal is being harbored at the location, specified in the search warrant. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Sec. 4-40. - Exemption for police dogs. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any federal, state or local law enforcement agency or dog used by or belonging to such agency, provided that such dog shall be vaccinated for rabies as required by this article, and the dog's handler shall have proof of such vaccination in his possession for display as may be required. Also, at any time such dog is off its leash or otherwise at large, it shall be under the control of or in the performance of functions of duties for a law enforcement officer or handler acting on behalf of a law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  I, 1-22-18) 
Secs. 4-41-4-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VIOALTIONS; PENALTY 

Sec. 4-90. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. The punishment shall be that provided by the City of Liberty with respect to misdemeanors generally. 
(Ord. No. 10856,  III, 1-22-18)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, adopted Sept. 8, 2003, repealed former Art. I,  6-2-6-10, in its entirety which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the following: 
Ord. No. Section Date 3913 2  1-23-78 4296 2, 4 10-27-80 4941 1  3-25-85 5705 1  2-27-89  

Sec. 6-1. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase in this chapter or any part thereof, is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by a court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of this chapter or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-2. - Permit-Required. 
    Except as stated below, no person, firm, corporation, public utility or government agency shall erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, remove, improve, excavate for, convert or demolish any building, structure, sidewalk, driveway or utility in the city, nor do any electrical, plumbing, or mechanical installations, nor alter or make any additions to existing installations or cause the same to be done, without first obtaining a permit for such work from the building inspection division. 
    Exceptions: 
(1)  In cases of substantial emergency, the person doing said work or causing said work to be done might proceed with the work and file application for a permit within seventy-two (72) hours after commencement of emergency work. The emergency shall be considered to exist only in those situations wherein life, health, safety, and property will be adversely affected if work is not commenced immediately. 
(2)  Installations on property owned, used and operated by the United States government, the State of Missouri, or Clay County, Missouri. 
(3)  A permit shall not be required for the construction, removal, modification, alteration, maintenance or repair of the operation of public utility generation facilities used by such utilities duly franchised or authorized as such in the city when the work is done under their own supervision and by their own employees. 
(4)  A permit shall not be required for ordinary repairs, maintenance or minor alterations. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-3. - Fees. 
    Permit fees shall be based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
    Where work for which a permit is required is started or commenced without obtaining a permit, the fee shall be doubled, but the payment of such doubled fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of the Liberty City Code in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties as prescribed in section 6-8. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-4. - Inspections. 
(1)  Generally. No further work shall be done on any part of the building or structure beyond the point indicated in each successive inspection without first obtaining the written approval of work done from the building official or his authorized agent. Such written approval shall be given only after an inspection has been made of each successive step in the construction. 
    Where any framing members or utilities are to be concealed from view by the construction of a building, the person making the installation shall notify the building official or his authorized agent and such items shall not be concealed until the work has been inspected and approved. 
    Exception: If the building official or his authorized agent fails to make an inspection within twenty-four (24) hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, or holidays, of the agreed-upon time for such inspection and further delay would cause danger to public safety or undue hardship to the permit holder. 
    Where the concealment proceeds continuously during construction of a building, the person installing the work shall give due notice, and inspections shall be made periodically at the discretion of the building official or his authorized agent. 
    There shall be a final inspection and approval of every building, structure or utility when completed and ready for occupancy. 
(2)  Re-inspection fees. Permit fees provide for original progress inspections only. Where additional inspections are made necessary by incomplete or faulty work or because of incorrect address given or because the building is not accessible, no fee shall be charged for the first re-inspection; however, a fee shall be charged for each additional re-inspection based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. This fee shall be paid by the permittee before another inspection can be requested. 
(3)  Amusement rides. The design, materials, construction and operation of amusement park structures shall be such as to provide adequate safety to the public and shall be approved by the building official or his authorized agent, who may require such tests as he finds necessary to establish the safety of such structures during their erection and subsequent operation. 
    Any person applying to the city for a license to operate an amusement park, show or carnival shall apply to the building official or his authorized agent for inspection of all amusement rides to assure compliance with state statutes and accepted standards of safety. Permission to operate shall not be issued until the inspection has been made and all rides have been approved and where a required certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
    The building official or his authorized agent shall inspect amusement rides annually. Fees for required annual inspections of licensed amusement parks and carnivals shall be based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
    The owner or operator in control of an amusement ride shall promptly inform the building official, or his authorized agent, of damage to equipment, malfunction of equipment or negligence on the part of personnel in charge of an amusement ride, any of which has caused or could cause injury to the public, and shall afford the building official or his authorized agent every facility for investigating accidents, conditions or damage resulting therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-5. - Use of explosives or blasting agents; permits. 
(1)  No person shall handle, discharge, fire or otherwise use any explosive or blasting agent within the city limits without first obtaining a permit from the city. The cost of this permit shall be based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. The city shall not issue a permit to use explosives without first being presented an approved blasting insurance policy in the amount of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). The policy may be used to cover any given contract but shall not be used for more than one contract. 
(2)  Any person wishing to use explosives in the city shall, after compliance with subsection (1) of this section, give the department of public works at least twenty-four (24) hours' notice prior to discharging any explosive or blasting agent. 
(3)  Any person wishing to use explosives in the city shall, after compliance with subsections (1) and (2) of this section, give personal notice, within an area, in writing, to such property owners designated by the building official or his agent. 
    Any person who fails to comply with this section shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70 for each time explosives are discharged. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-6. - Craftsman's license-Required. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or company that installs, remodels, rebuilds, or repairs electrical work, plumbing work, or mechanical (heating and air conditioning) work within the city shall first obtain a craftsman's license. A firm, partnership, corporation or company may only acquire a craftsman's license if a natural person associated with such entity completes the necessary proficiency examination. A craftsman's license may not be transferred. A license issued to a firm, partnership, corporation or company shall be in effect only so long as such approved individual is still associated with said entity. If the individual is no longer so associated, the craftsman's license shall immediately become null and void. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-6.1. - Exceptions. 
    Provisions of this article and other articles of the codes requiring employment of licensed mechanics, craftsmen or engineers shall not apply to maintenance or operation of equipment and accessories used for operations, production or processing by public utilities, government agencies, manufacturing or processing plants or commercial enterprises which maintain a regular maintenance and operating staff supervised by a registered professional engineer or by an operating engineer certified by the city. However, work under such supervision shall be performed to comply in all respects with all applicable provisions of the articles of the codes, including provisions for permits and inspections as required by the city. 
    Any permit required by the Liberty City Code may be issued to any person to do any work required by this chapter in a single-family dwelling used exclusively for living purposes, including the usual accessory building and quarters in connection with such building. Any person fully qualified under the provisions of this chapter, who is the bona fide owner and occupier of any such dwelling and accessory buildings and quarters, may be issued a permit for work on said dwelling and accessory buildings and quarters, provided that said owner shall personally purchase all materials and shall personally perform all labor in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-6.2. - Qualifications. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or company requiring a craftsman's license shall make application to the building official and shall undergo a reasonable proficiency examination of his appropriate skill, upon payment an examination fee based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-6.3. - Fees. 
    Craftsman's license fees shall be based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. Said licenses shall be due July 1 of each year and shall be reduced to not less than the renewal fee January 1 of the current licensing year. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-7. - Excavations and unfinished building allowed to hold water no longer than one week. 
    Any excavation or unfinished building shall not be allowed to hold water for more than one week next following the end of precipitation. This requirement shall be in addition to other requirements of the Liberty City Code. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-8. - Penalty. 
    It is a misdemeanor for any person, firm, corporation, public utility, or government agency to violate, omit, neglect, or refuse to comply with, or resist enforcement of, any provisions of this code or Chapter 6 of the Liberty City Code. Any such person, firm, corporation, public utility, or government agency found in violation of this code or Chapter 6 of the Liberty City Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70 for each violation. Each day in which such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 6-9. - Board of appeals. 
    Unless an appeal procedure is otherwise specifically provided, appeals shall be to the board of appeals. In order to determine the suitability of alternate materials and type of construction and to provide for reasonable interpretations of the provisions of the codes herein unless otherwise specified by this chapter, appeals may be taken to the board of appeals established under Chapter 6, section 6-38, of the Liberty City Code. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-A, 9-8-03)

ARTICLE VI. - HOUSE MOVING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4482,  1, adopted Feb. 22, 1982, repealed former Art. VI,  6-19-6-25, as derived from  2 of Ord. No. 3913, adopted Jan. 23, 1978, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Art. VI,  6-19-6-25e. In order to preserve Code format, the editor has renumbered  6-25a-6-25e as 6-25.1-6-25.4. 
Cross reference- Raising, lowering or removing telephone wires,  7-6; injury to trees or city property,  22-30; injury to utility poles,  22-53; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 6-19. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. "Shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Applicant means any person making application for a permit. 
    Building or structure means an assembly of materials forming a construction for occupancy or use including houses, buildings or any other structures, but excluding mobile homes or trailers mounted on wheels or trucks for movement or transfer. 
    City is defined as the City of Liberty, Missouri. 
    Permittee means any person obtaining a permit as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-20. - Moving permit required. 
    No person shall move any building or structure having a total floor area of two hundred (200) or more square feet upon, across or over any highway, street, alley or sidewalk in the city without first obtaining a permit to do so, issued by the chief building official. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-21. - Application for permit; fees. 
    All applications for permits to move buildings or other structures described in sections 6-19 and 6-20 shall be made to the chief building official and such application shall state or include by attachment and be in compliance with the following: 
(a)  The intended use of the building or structure after moving. 
(b)  The dimensions of the building or structure as to length; height at its highest point when loaded for moving; width. 
(c)  A definitive description of the building or structure proposed to be moved giving present street number, construction materials, dimensions in square feet, number of rooms and condition of exterior and interior. 
(d)  A plot plan to scale with legal description of the lot to which the building is to be moved, giving the lot number, block number and subdivision, or record if located within the city. 
(e)  The day and hour when the moving is to commence and length of time required for the move. If a variance is sought for a move not to be completed within the daylight hours of a single day other than Saturday or Sunday for the reason that such is not feasible, the application shall state the facts constituting such reason with adequate evidence thereof attached. The building inspector, upon adequate showing, may grant such variance which shall not be effective unless set out in the permit. 
(f)  The names or location of highways, streets, alleys or sidewalks over, along or across which the building or structure is proposed to be moved. 
(g)  The application shall be made not less than seven (7) calendar days prior to the intended commencement of the moving and shall be accompanied by a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(h)  The application must include copies of prior written notice of such application, with copy thereof, that has been delivered by the applicant to each of the owners of adjacent lots and to the owners of wired or other facilities, whenever the movement will affect or cross wiring for the public utilities, cable television, traffic-control devices, or the crossing of any railroad located within the city limits, should such a permit be issued. 
(i)  The applicant for the building or structure to be moved shall file with the application sufficient evidence that all taxes and any city charges against the owner are paid in full. The applicant shall furnish a certificate of public liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Missouri, and in which the city is named as co-insured, for personal and property damage exempting and saving harmless the city in a minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) injury each person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each occurrence, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) property damage before a permit shall be issued. 
(j)  The applicant, if also the owner, shall include statement of ownership, and if not, the owner shall attach a written statement or bill of [sale signed and acknowledged by the owner, or other sufficient] evidence that he is authorized by the owner to move the building or structure. 
(k)  The applicant shall obtain a permit from the state if a state highway is involved and a copy shall be supplied to the chief building official. 
(l)  The application shall have attached thereto a written statement specifically identifying the persons or contractor intended to physically accomplish the move, including a description of the equipment and of the experience and qualifications of the same in the performance of such a moving operation. Such person or contractor shall be named in the permit and such permit shall not authorize any moving operation by anyone not so named therein. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-22. - Bond or letter of credit required. 
    Before such permit is issued, applicant shall file with the chief building official a bond executed by the applicant as principal, with corporate surety authorized to do business in the State of Missouri, in the amount of five thousand ($5,000.00), wherein the city is named as obligee, or, in lieu thereof, an irrevocable letter of credit issued to the city by a bank with place of business located in Clay County, Missouri, in like amount, either of such to be in form approved by the city counsellor of the city, and each of which shall be conditioned as follows: 
(a)  That principal shall pay any and all damages, costs or expenses, resulting from the moving operation, and including full compensation for any injury to any property, public or private, related to the moving operation, whether caused by a principal, or agent thereof, or his servant, employee, workman, contractor or subcontractor. 
(b)  That principal will indemnify and protect the city from any and all liability related to or resulting from the move and including any cost of defense of any claim therefor, or cost or expense of enforcement of or recovery under the terms of the bond or letter of credit. 
(c)  That said move, once begun, shall proceed continuously without interruption until completed, including removal of rubbish and materials and fill or excavation and placing of premises from which the structure is moved in safe and satisfactory condition within five (5) days from time of move. 
(d)  That in the event of any failure to fully comply with this Code, including any cessation or interruption of the moving operation before completion thereof, the city, at the election of the chief building official, but without requirement therefor, may proceed by use of city personnel, or by contractor selected by it, to the completion of the move as provided by the permit, at the cost or expense of the permittee, including compensation for the time and services of city personnel, and recover all of the same, including enforcement and expense of recovery hereunder, from any and all of the principal, surety on the bond, or bank issuing such letter of credit. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-23. - Duties of building inspector; issuance of permit. 
(a)  Inspection. The chief building official shall inspect the building or structure and the applicant's equipment to determine whether the standard for issuance of a permit is met and issue or deny such permit. 
(b)  Standards for issuance. The chief building official shall refuse to issue a permit if he finds: 
(1)  That any application requirement or any fee, deposit, insurance or bond requirement has not been complied with. 
(2)  That the building or structure is of such size and of such construction or in such a state of deterioration, disrepair or is otherwise so structurally unsafe that it cannot be moved without endangering persons or property within the city. 
(3)  That the building or structure is structurally unsafe or unfit for use for the purpose stated when moved, if the removal location is in the city. 
(4)  That the equipment to be used is unsafe and that persons and property would be endangered by its use. 
(5)  That the zoning ordinance or any other ordinances would be violated by the location and use of the building or structure at the location intended. 
(6)  That for any reasonably ascertainable reason, persons or property in the city would be endangered by the moving of the building or structure. 
(7)  That any weight, length, width or other restriction imposed upon the use of the public or private roadways within the city limits by either city traffic ordinances or state statutes would be violated. 
(c)  Claim on bond or letter of credit. After the building or structure has been moved, the chief building official shall furnish the applicant a written statement of all expenses and damages sustained by the city in removing, repairing and replacing all property belonging to the city and of all material used in the removal and replacement together with a statement of all damages caused to or inflicted upon property, both private and public, for information as to such claim against the bond or letter of credit. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-24. - Duties of permittee. 
    Every permittee under this article shall: 
(a)  Move only over designated streets. Move a building or structure only over streets designated for such use in the written permit. 
(b)  Complete move in daylight. Begin and complete the move within the daylight hours of a single day other than Saturday and Sunday unless variance is granted by the chief building official and set out in the permit. 
(c)  Notify of revised moving time. Notify in writing, both the chief building official and the police department at least forty-eight (48) hours before the move of a desired change in moving date and hour and route of move as proposed in the application, and such change must be approved by the chief building official before becoming effective. 
(d)  Notify of damage. Notify the chief building official in writing of any and all damages done to public or private property within twenty-four (24) hours after the damage or injury has occurred. 
(e)  Use of warning devices at night. If any of the move is at night, it shall be the duty of any person moving any such building or structure mentioned in sections 6-19 and 6-20 upon or across any street, alley or sidewalk or other public place in the city to display red lanterns or other warning devices used in compliance with city ordinances or state statutes thereon in such a manner as to show the extreme height and width thereof from thirty (30) minutes after sunset to thirty (30) minutes before sunrise; shall at all times erect and maintain barricades across the street in such manner as to protect the public from damage or injury by reason of removal of the building or structure; and shall have sufficient escort as provided by city ordinance, state statutes or as determined as necessary for the public safety by the chief of police. 
(f)  Not leave debris. No building or structure or any part of any building or structure being moved shall be left deposited or remain in any parkway, street or on the dedicated right-of-way between the curb and the front property line of any lot. 
(g)  Comply with governing law. Comply with the building code, fire zone, zoning ordinances and all other applicable traffic ordinances and laws upon relocating the building or structure in the city or when moving the same through the city. 
(h)  Clear old premises. Remove all rubbish and materials and fill in excavations to existing grade at the original building or structure site so that the premises are left in a safe and sanitary condition within five (5) days from the date of the move. 
(i)  Remove service connections. A reasonable time before beginning the move notify all utilities having service connections within the building or structure or along the route of moving and otherwise located within the city limits as to any facilities and services to the general public which may be affected by the movement of the building or structure. Copies of notification and evidence of delivery shall be furnished to the building inspector. 
(j)  Comply with codes. Comply with all building codes of the city within sixty (60) days after the physical move is made. 
(k)  Comply with other regulations. Comply with the regulations and specifications contained in such permit granted by the building inspector [building official] to such permittee. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-25. - Enforcing officers. 
    The chief building official, chief of police and the city engineer and other appropriate officers of the city shall enforce and carry out the requirements of this article as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-25.1. - Permittee liable for expense above deposit. 
    The permittee shall be liable for any expenses, damages, costs in excess of deposited amounts of securities, and the city counsellor shall prosecute an action against the permittee in a court of competent jurisdiction for the recovery thereof, including cost and fees for services in such recovery. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-25.2. - Permit time limitation. 
    Permits issued under and pursuant to this article shall be valid for a maximum term of sixty (60) days from date issued. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-25.3. - Proper foundation. 
    No building shall be moved to any lot unless and until a proper and suitable foundation or basement has been previously constructed on such lot upon which such building will be permanently placed, unless waived by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 6-25.4. - Violation; penalty. 
    The violation of this article is a misdemeanor and any person convicted thereof shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70 for each such offense. Each day any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4482,  1, 2-22-82; Ord. No. 5705,  1, 2-27-89) 
ARTICLE VII. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS CODE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 21. 

Sec. 6-26. - Purpose of article.
