    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation which is owner, occupant, operator or agent of a dwelling unit or rooming unit to violate, disobey, omit, neglect or refuse to comply with, or to resist enforcement of any of the provisions of this code or chapter and any such person, firm or corporation who shall have received an order or notice of an alleged violation of this code or chapter shall have committed a misdemeanor, and such person, firm or corporation shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or serve not less than one or more than fifteen (15) days in jail, or both, for each day such alleged violation continues after expiration of the specified reasonable consideration period provided herein and provided that no such penalty shall be applicable while a reconsideration, hearing or appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction is pending under the provisions of this code or chapter. 
(Ord. No. 5321,  1(15), 5-26-87) 
Sec. 6-75. - Collection and dissemination of information. 
    The director of community development is hereby authorized to collect and disseminate information concerning techniques of maintenance, repair and sanitation in housing, and concerning the requirements of this code and applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 5321,  1(16), 5-26-87) 
Sec. 6-76. - Appeals. 
(a)  There is hereby created a residential rental occupancy code board of appeals consisting of five (5) members and two (2) alternates, the composition and appointment of which is hereinafter provided. 
    The purpose of this board is to provide for reasonable interpretations of the code and to consider requests from persons subject to requirements of this code for appropriate waivers from strict compliance. 
(b)  Any decision of the director of community development in the enforcement of the residential rental occupancy code may be appealed to the board. This appeal must be made within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice of violation and must be submitted in writing, specifying the grounds therefor. 
    An appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed, except in the case of an emergency as described in Section 6-77. 
(c)  The board of appeals shall adopt reasonable rules and regulations for the conduct of its meetings and investigations, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the director of community development. All decisions and findings shall become part of the public record. 
(d)  The board of appeals shall fix a time for the hearing of the appeal within five (5) days of receipt of the request, as well as due notice to the parties of interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. In the hearing of appeals before the board, all testimony, objections thereto and rulings thereof shall be recorded. Upon the hearing before the board, any person may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(e)  At such a hearing, the applicant shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why such notice or order should be modified, extended, withdrawn or a variance granted. 
(f)  The board of appeals, by a majority vote, may sustain, modify or withdraw the notice or order. In granting an extension or variance of any notice or order, the board of appeals shall observe the following conditions: 
(1)  The board of appeals may grant an extension of time for the compliance of any order or notice for not more than eighteen (18) months subject to appropriate conditions and provided that the board of appeals makes specific findings of fact based on evidence relating to the following: 
a.  That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in carrying out the strict letter of any notice or order; and 
b.  That such an extension is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this code in securing the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  The board of appeals may grant a variance in a specific case and from a specific provision of this code subject to appropriate conditions and provided the board of appeals makes specific findings of fact based on evidence related to the following: 
a.  That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in carrying out the strict letter of any notice of order; 
b.  That the effect of the application of the provisions would be arbitrary in the specific case; 
c.  That an extension would not constitute an appropriate remedy for these practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships and this arbitrary effect; and 
d.  That such variance is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this code in securing the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(g)  The composition and appointment of the board of appeals shall be as follows: 
(1)  Composition. The board of appeals shall consist of five (5) members and two (2) alternates. Attendance of four (4) members or alternates shall be considered a quorum. At least one member shall be a person who is knowledgeable of the construction field. The director of community development shall be an ex officio member and shall act as secretary to the board. 
(2)  Appointment. Members and their alternates shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. The term of office shall be for five (5) years, excepting that the membership of the first board appointed shall serve, respectively, for terms of one member and one alternate for one year; one member and one alternate for two (2) years; one member for three (3) years; one member for four (4) years; and one member for five (5) years. Thereafter, members and alternates shall be appointed for terms of five (5) years each. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term only. Members or alternates may be removed for cause by the mayor and city council upon written charges and after a public hearing. 
(h)  No member of the board shall vote on any matter in which he has a direct or financial interest. 
(i)  All decisions of the board shall be by a majority vote of the attending members or their alternates; provided, that a quorum is present. All decisions of the board shall be in writing and shall be filed with the deputy city clerk with a copy to the appellant and the director of community development. All decisions of the board shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 5321,  1(17), 5-26-87; Ord. No. 7670,  III, 7-13-98) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions,  2-103.51 et seq. 
Sec. 6-77. - Emergencies. 
(a)  Whenever, in the judgment of the director of community development, an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, safety or welfare, an order may be issued, without a hearing or appeal, directing the owner, occupant, operator or agent to take such action as is appropriate to correct or abate the emergency. If circumstances warrant, the director of community development may act to correct or abate the emergency. 
(b)  The owner, occupant, operator or agent shall be granted a hearing before the residential rental occupancy code board of appeals on the matter upon his request, as soon as practicable, but such appeal shall in any case stay the abatement or correction of such emergency. 
(Ord. No. 5321,  1(18), 5-26-87) 
Secs. 6-78-6-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - LAWN SPRINKLER SYSTEMS 

Sec. 6-101. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth next to them. 
    City right-of-way. Any land over which the City of Liberty has a right to allow the public or the city's agents to pass. For purposes of this article and the release for lawn sprinkler system in the City of Liberty right-of-way document specified hereunder, the definition of right-of-way set forth above shall apply whether the city's legal interest in the land is in fact a right-of-way, an easement, a license or a fee simple interest. 
    Lawn sprinkler system. Any system, wholly or partly affixed or buried beneath the ground surface, by which water is transported through pipes or hoses to sprinkler heads designed to spray water over the surrounding vegetation. A system meets this definition if either the transmission pipes and hoses or the sprinkler heads are beneath the ground surface. 
(Ord. No. 7560,  I, 11-10-97; Ord. No. 10013,  I, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 6-102. - Permit required. 
    No lawn sprinkler system shall be constructed within the City of Liberty in such a manner that any sprinkler head or other component part is located on city right-of-way until the owner of the land to be benefitted by the system shall have first obtained a lawn sprinkler system permit. 
(Ord. No. 7560,  I, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 6-103. - Permit application. 
    The process for obtaining a lawn sprinkler system permit is as follows: 
(1)  The landowner shall complete an application for lawn sprinkler system permit, right-of-way permit, and a release for lawn sprinkler system in the City of Liberty right-of-way document which shall be available in the office of the chief building official. 
(2)  The landowner shall then submit the application to the chief building official along with the release for lawn sprinkler system in the City of Liberty document. 
(3)  The city engineer shall review the right-of-way permit, and the chief building official shall review the lawn sprinkler system permit and release for lawn sprinkler system in the City of Liberty document to determine the following: 
a.  That the application and release for lawn sprinkler system in the City of Liberty right-of-way document refer to the same property. 
b.  That the application identifies all recorded owners of the property. 
c.  That the proposed installation presents no threat to public safety. 
d.  That the proposed installation presents no threat of damage to existing facilities of the city, the city's lessees or those to whom the city has granted easements or licenses. 
e.  That if anyone other than the landowner proposes to install the system, then that person or firm is properly licensed under state law and local ordinance. 
(4)  If the chief building official finds that the applications meet the requirements set forth in paragraph (3), then the chief building official shall issue to the landowner a lawn sprinkler system permit, and the city engineer shall issue a right-of-way permit. 
(Ord. No. 7560,  I, 11-10-97; Ord. No. 10013,  I, 1-28-2013) 
Editor's note- The forms for permit applications and the release and indemnification document have not been set out herein but are available in the office of the city engineer. 
Sec. 6-104. - Limitations on permits. 
    The granting of a permit pursuant to this article shall create no easement, license or other right in the landowner, other than the limited permissive use of the city's right-of-way. It shall be a condition of every permit that the landowner shall expressly release, indemnify and hold harmless the City of Liberty, and its employees, agents, contractors, lessees, licensees and permittees on city's right-of-way, from any and all liability, claims, suits or demand, whatsoever, which they or others may now have or which may hereafter have arising out of the placement of sprinkler heads or related components in city right-of-way, including but not limited to any damage done to the landowner's sprinkler system as a result of any activities of the city or its employees, agents, contractors, lessees, licensees and permittees, and any damage which the landowner may do to any existing facilities on the city's right-of-way in the course of installing landowner's lawn sprinkler system. 
(Ord. No. 7560,  I, 11-10-97) 
ARTICLE XII. - INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9996,  I, adopted Dec. 17, 2012, deleted the former Art. XII,  6-105, 6-105.1 and enacted a new Art. XII as set out herein. The former Art. XII pertained to the International Building Code and derived from Ord. No. 8569,  I-C, 9-8-03. 

Sec. 6-105. - Adopted. 
    The provisions of the International Building Code, 2012 edition, including appendix as reference, is for all intents and purposes incorporated in this chapter as though more fully set out herein, except as stated below, and is hereby adopted as the official building code of the city, and all provisions thereof shall be in full force and effect in this city in the form of that particular and specific printed volume to be permanently retained as a part of the official records of this city on file in the office of the deputy city clerk and to be construed, applied and enforced, as modified and supplemented as follows: 
(a)  As modified by other provisions of Chapter 6, Article XII of the Liberty City Code. 
(b)  All portions of said International Building Code identified as exclusions below are not so included herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 9996,  I, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-105.1. - Revisions. 
    The following shall be included as a revision to the building code adopted in section 6-105: 
(a)  Section 105.2 "Work Exempt from Permit". Buildings item #2; shall be revised to read "Fences shall not be over 6 feet high". 
(Ord. No. 9996,  I, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-105.2. - Exclusions. 
    The following shall be excluded from the building code adopted in section 6-105: 
(a)  Section 113, "Board of Appeals". 
(Ord. No. 9996,  I, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-105.3. - Miscellaneous building regulations. 
(a)  Tower structures . Unless otherwise provided by law or variance, the following additional requirements shall apply to the construction, alteration or maintenance of towers: 
(1)  Definition. For purposes of this section, the term "tower" shall mean a permanent structure, having a total height in excess of fifty (50) feet measured from the ground and having one or more legs designed for the support of one or more sign, antenna, light, wind turbine, solar array or other object but excluding buildings serving other purposes and meeting the building requirements for all purposes. A tower shall not include existing electric utility poles installed by a provider holding a certificate of convenience from the Missouri PSC and installed consistent with industry practice and in conformance with all otherwise applicable federal, state, and local requirements. 
(2)  Safety fall zone required . All portions of any tower including related structures, fences, and walls (except for parking associated with the wireless facility) shall be separated from any public rights-of-way, sidewalk or street, alley, parking areas, playground, or other building, and from the property line of any adjacent property at least a distance equal to the height of the tower. Towers shall be reasonably designed to reduce the potential damage to persons or property from falling ice or equipment from the tower or from wind damage or structural failure. 
(3)  Safety fencing . In addition to other applicable requirements, the tower and any appurtenances shall be safely maintained and fenced or otherwise secured to prevent unauthorized access or climbing of the tower. Barbed, electrified, or razor wire is prohibited. Tower legs shall be of monopole design without use of lattice or guy wire support and be engineered and designed with sufficient depth, counter-weight, and other mechanisms to address wind-loading and other failure risks under all reasonably anticipated conditions and circumstances. 
(4)  Structural analysis. Before any modifications or alterations to an existing tower may be approved, a sealed structural analysis from a certified engineer must be submitted to the city as part of any application to alter or modify the same. 
(5)  Lighting. For safety concerns, towers shall not be lighted unless required by the FAA or other state or federal agency with authority to regulate, in which case a description of the required lighting scheme will be made a part of the application to install, build, or modify the tower. 
(6)  Storm water control. Any new tower or modification thereto shall be required to be reviewed for storm water control and shall comply with any storm water control requirements. All towers constructed within a designated floodplain or floodway shall comply with all state, local, and federal requirements and obtain all necessary permits. 
(7)  Paved access. To ensure access to property to address any safety concerns on which the tower is located, paved access to the tower and related facilities must be provided and maintained at all times that such tower and/or related facilities are located on the property. 
(8)  Incorporation. All requirements in article XII of the Liberty City Code shall apply to the construction, modification, and maintenance of each tower and are reincorporated herein as building code requirements to the extent permitted by law. 
(9)  Abandonment bond. Any tower not operated for a period of six (6) months or more, shall be deemed abandoned and the director shall cause notice of such determination to be sent and request for removal within a reasonable time not to exceed ninety (90) days. If a tower is abandoned, it shall be removed at the owner's expense. Failure to comply with this provision shall constitute a public nuisance and building code violation that may be remedied by the city at the tower or property owner's expense. Any applicant for a new tower shall place a bond or other security with the city prior to any final approval to ensure abandoned towers can be removed. The bond or security shall be in the form and amount approved by the director. The amount of the bond shall be determined by the director to satisfy the requirements hereof with regard to the specific tower to which it would apply based on the estimated total cost of removal of that tower. 
(b)  Appeals . Appeals by any aggrieved person of a final action of any city officer, employee, board, commission, or the city council that are claimed by an aggrieved person to be unlawful or an unconstitutional taking of property without compensation shall be to the board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 10831,  II, 12-11-17) 
ARTICLE XIII. - INTERNATIONAL RESIDENTIAL CODE 

Sec. 6-106. - Adopted. 
    The provisions of the International Residential Code, 2012 edition, including appendix as reference, is for all intents and purposes incorporated in this chapter as though more fully set out herein, except as stated below, and is hereby adopted as the official residential code of the city, and all provisions thereof shall be in full force and effect in this city in the form of that particular and specific printed volume to be permanently retained as a part of the official records of this city on file in the office of the deputy city clerk and to be construed, applied and enforced, as modified and supplemented as follows: 
(a)  As modified by other provisions of Chapter 6, Article XIII of the Liberty City Code. 
(b)  All portions of said International Residential Code identified as exclusions in section 6-106.3 below are not so included herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-C, 9-8-03; Ord. No. 9996,  I, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-106.1. - Additions. 
    The following shall be included as an addition to the residential code adopted in section 6-106: 
(a)  Appendices: A, B, C, E, G, J, and N. 
(b)  Section R310.1, "Emergency Escape and Rescue Required", exceptions: 
(1)  Exception 2: Except where sleeping rooms are created, emergency escape and rescue openings need not be increased in existing basements undergoing interior finish renovation. 
(c)  Section R405.1, "Foundation Drainage", exceptions: 
(1)  Exception 2: A filter membrane is not required where the gravel or crushed stone drain extends at least eighteen inches (18") above the top of the footing, or where the perforated pipe is covered with at least (18") inches of washed gravel or crushed stone. 
(d)  Section 1102.2.9, "Slab-on-grade Floors", exceptions: 
(1)  Exception 1: Insulation at the interface between the foundation wall and slab may be omitted. 
(e)  Section M1602.2, "Prohibited Sources (Return Air)", exceptions: 
(1)  Item #4, Exception #2, Closets with a minimum floor area of 24 square feet and minimum interior dimension 4 feet, and that are conditioned by a source of supply air. 
(f)  Section P3105.4, "Floor Drains". A floor drain (where used as such) need not be vented, provided it is within 25 feet of a three-inch stack or horizontal drain which has at least a three-inch diameter vent extension through the roof. 
(g)  Section E3902.2, "Garages and Accessory Building Receptacles", exceptions: Receptacles utilizing the provisions of the exception shall be permanently marked to indicate "Type of Equipment No GFCI Protection". 
(1)  A dedicated receptacle supplying only a garage door opener. 
(2)  A dedicated single receptacle supplying only a refrigerator and/or freezer. 
(h)  Section E3902.5, "Unfinished Basement Receptacles", exceptions: Receptacles utilizing the provisions of this exception shall be permanently marked to indicate "Type of Equipment No GFCI Protection". 
(1)  A dedicated single receptacle supplying only a permanently installed fire alarm or burglar alarm system. 
(2)  A dedicated single receptacle supplying only a sump pump. 
(3)  A dedicated single receptacle supplying a refrigerator and/or freezer. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-C, 9-8-03; Ord. No. 9996,  I, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-106.2. - Revisions. 
    The following shall be included as a revision to the residential code adopted in section 6-106: 
(a)  Section R313 "Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems". A builder of a one or two family dwelling or townhouse shall offer to any purchaser on or before the time of entering into the purchase contract the option, at the purchaser's cost, to install or equip fire sprinklers in the dwelling or townhouse. The purchaser shall have the right to choose or decline to install a fire sprinkler system. This notification requirement is provided in accordance with, and shall expire in conjunction with, Missouri Statue (RSMO 67.281). 
(b)  Section R315.3 "Carbon Monoxide Alarms In Existing Dwellings", exceptions: 
(1)  Work involving the exterior surfaces of dwellings, such as the replacement of sheathing, or the addition of a window, porch, deck, are exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(2)  Installation, alteration or repairs of plumbing or mechanical systems are exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Section R303.4 "Mechanical Ventilation". Where the air infiltration rate of a dwelling unit is less than 3 air changes per hour when tested with a blower door at a pressure of 0.2 inch w.c. (50 Pa) in accordance with Section N1102.4.1.2, the dwelling unit shall be provided with whole-house ventilation in accordance with Section M1507.3. 
(d)  Section R404.4 "Retaining Walls". Retaining walls that are not laterally supported at the top and that retain in excess of 48 inches (610 mm) of unbalanced fill, that support a surcharge, are adjacent to a public right-of-way shall be designed to ensure stability against overturning, sliding, excessive foundation pressure and water uplift. Retaining walls shall be designed for a safety factor of 1.5 against lateral sliding and overturning. 
(e)  Section R602.6.1, Figure R602.1, "Drilling and notching of top plate". When piping or ductwork is placed in or partly in an exterior wall or interior load-bearing wall, necessitating cutting, drilling, or notching of the top plate by more than 50 percent of its width, a galvanized metal tie of not less than 0.054 inch think (1.37 mm) (16) gauge and 1 1/2 inches (38 mm) wide shall be fastened across and to the plate at each side of the opening with not less than four 10d nails at each side, or equivalent (or as required by the product listing, evaluation report, or manufacturer's instruction, where applicable). The metal tie must extend a minimum of 6 inches past the opening. Reference Figure R602.6.1. 
(f)  Section R801.3, "Roof Drainage". All dwellings shall have a controlled method of water disposal from roofs that will collect and discharge all roof drainage to the ground surface at least 3 feet from foundation walls or to an approved drainage system. 
(g)  Table N1102.1.1, "Building Thermal Envelope". Under Climate Zone 4, amend the following item: "Wood Frame Wall R-Value 13 (Remainder of table unamended.) 
(h)  Table N1102.1.3, Building Thermal Envelope", Under Climate Zone 4, amend the following item: "Wood Frame Wall U-Factor 0.082 (Remainder of table unamended.) 
(i)  Table N1102.4.1.1, "Air Barrier and Insulation Installation". Under "Walls", amend first sentence to read: "Corners and headers shall be sealed and the junction of the foundation and sill plate shall be sealed." Under "Fireplace, delete: "Fireplaces shall have gasketed doors." (Remainder of table unamended.) 
(j)  Section N1102.4.1.2, "Testing". Building leakage testing shall be conducted where required by the building official. Where required by the building official, the testing shall be conducted by an approved third party. A written report of the results of the test shall be signed by the party conducting the test and provided to the building official. Testing shall be performed at any time after creation of all penetrations of the building thermal envelope. Effective January 1, 2014, the building or dwelling unit shall have an air leakage rate of not exceeding 5 air changes per hour when tested with a blower door at a pressure of 0.2 inches w.g. (50 Pascal). 
(k)  Section N1103.2.3, "Building Cavities", (Mandatory). Building framing cavities used as ducts or plenums shall be sealed to prevent leakage through the thermal envelope. 
(l)  Section P3114.3, "Air Admittance Valve". Where permitted shall read: "For certain unique situations for which conventional venting is not feasible, individual vents, branch vents, circuit vents and stack vents shall be permitted to terminate with a connection to an air admittance valve at the discretion of the building official." 
(m)  Section R501.3 "Fire Protection of Floors". Floor assemblies constructed of an open web truss, not required elsewhere in this code to be fire-resistance rated, shall be provided with a 1/2 inch gypsum wallboard membrane, 5/8 inch (16mm) wood structural panel membrane, or equivalent on the underside of the floor framing member. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-C, 9-8-03; Ord. No. 9996,  I, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-106.3. - Exclusions. 
(a)  Section R112," Board of Appeals". 
(b)  Section E4002.14, "Tamper-Resistant Receptacles". 
(c)  Section 715, "Backwater Valves" Reference City Code section 29-47.23. 
(Ord. No. 8569,  I-C, 9-8-03; Ord. No. 9996,  I, 12-17-2012)

Chapter 7 - BUSINESSES AND OCCUPATIONS GENERALLY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; food establishments, Ch. 15; places of recreation and amusement, Ch. 16; collection of solid waste,  17-3.1 et seq.; licenses, Ch. 18; solicitors and canvassers, Ch. 24; taxicabs and other vehicles for hire, Ch. 28. 

ARTICLE I. - EXCHANGE TELEPHONE SERVICE 

Sec. 7-1. - Annual license tax required. 
    Every person, firm, company or corporation now or hereafter engaged in the business of furnishing exchange telephone service in the city shall pay the city, as an annual license tax, six (6) per cent of the gross receipts derived and collected from its or their customers located within the city, and any services there provided, except such receipts as represent charges for message rate roll, or long distance service, charges for exclusive interstate service of any kind, charges for Morse, telegraph, television or radio program transmission facilities, or for other services furnished exclusively and permanently in connection with services extending beyond the boundaries of the city, charges for the billing and collecting for telegrams, charges for the sale of and advertising in telephone directories, charges for the rental of plant facilities or other property not currently used by any such company in furnishing its telephone services, and charges which combine both receipts which are herein taxed and which are herein excepted in all cases in which the demonstrable cost to any such telephone company, in making a separation between the revenues taxed and those excepted, shall exceed the evident revenue to be derived therefrom by the city hereunder. 
(2146,  1; 3063,  1) 
Sec. 7-2. - Basis of tax; quarterly returns. 
    The license tax required by section 7-1 shall be computed upon a quarter-annual basis to be due and payable to the city on or before the fifteenth day of March, June, September and December, respectively, of each year, based upon actual or estimated gross receipts collected during the preceding period of two (2) calendar months, ending respectively on the last days of February, May, August and November, plus the gross receipts estimated to be collected during the month in which the quarter-annual tax payment to the city is due. Such quarter-annual tax payment to the city based on estimated gross receipts shall be corrected to reflect actual gross receipts by adjusting the next succeeding quarter-annual tax payment to the city without penalty. 
(2146,  2; 3063,  2; 3082,  1; Ord. No. 4427,  1, 9-28-81) 
Sec. 7-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4427, adopted Sept. 28, 1981, repealed former  7-2 and 7-3 which pertained to payment and due date of the exchange telephone service tax and enacted new provisions as  7-2. Reserved  7-3 formerly pertained to due date of the tax and derived from Ord. No. 2146,  2. 
Sec. 7-4. - Tax in lieu of other charges; exception. 
    The payments required by section 7-1 shall be in lieu of all other excises, charges, exactions, rentals, fees, impositions or other license or occupation taxes which the city may be authorized to impose upon any such person licensed hereunder, but nothing contained in this section shall be construed to exempt any such person from any general or special ad valorem tax imposed upon the public generally by the city. 
(2146,  3) 
Sec. 7-5. - Right to trim trees. 
    The right is granted to all persons licensed under this article to trim trees, brush or hedges upon and overhanging the streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the city, so as to prevent such foliage from coming in contact with telephone wires and cables, all of such trimming to be done under the supervision and direction of the governing body of the city or of any city official to whom such duties have been or may be delegated. 
(2146,  5) 
Sec. 7-6. - Removing, raising or lowering wires. 
    All such persons, firms, companies or corporations mentioned in section 7-1 on the request of any person shall remove, or raise or lower its wires temporarily to permit the moving of houses or other bulky structures. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the party or parties requesting such raising or lowering of wires, and payment in advance may be required. Not less than 48 hours' advance notice shall be given to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(3063,  3) 
Cross reference- House moving, 6-19 et seq. 
ARTICLE II. - AMUSEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Places of recreation and amusement, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 7-7. - Amusements defined. 
    Amusements, as governed under the authority of this article, shall be defined as: Street exhibitions, fortune tellers, pistol galleries, shooting galleries, palmists, equestrian performances, menageries, boxing and sparring exhibitions, street fairs, circuses and carnivals. 
(3654; Ord. No. 8485,  I, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 7-8. - Licensing and regulation; approval of the city council required. 
    No amusement, or place of amusement, as defined in section 7-7, shall commence operation, or operate, within the City of Liberty before or until the owner or manager of such amusement or place of amusement has applied to the office of the city clerk for a license to operate such amusement or place of amusement. Said application shall be presented to the city council at a regular meeting, provided that the application may be presented at a special meeting, if the city council so designates. 
    The applicant, or applicants, shall be present in person at the meeting when said application is considered by the city council. If the applicant, and the amusement or place of amusement to be licensed, meet all the requirements as set forth in section 7-8.1 of this article, the city council may issue a license for operation until June 30 of the year in which such license is issued, or June 30 of the next year, if the license is issued after July 1 but prior to January 1. All licenses issued under this article are subject to the fee schedule in section 18-16 of this Code, and must be renewed annually, or as otherwise provided in section 18-16 of this Code. Non-profit organizations shall be exempt from the license fee. 
(3654) 
Sec. 7-8.1. - Qualifications of applicant; standards of amusements or place of amusement. 
(a)  No license shall be issued to any applicant, or applicants, under this article who shall have been convicted of any drug or narcotics related offense during the five (5) years immediately prior to the date of application, or who shall be currently under formal charges or indictment for any such offense; nor who shall have been convicted during the five (5) years immediately prior to the date of application of any felony offense involving minors or any offense involving contributing to the delinquency of minors, or who shall be currently under formal charges or indictment for any such offense. Applicants who do not meet these requirements shall have the privilege of making a written request for an appearance before the city council for the purpose of making a personal plea for consideration, and the council, within its sound discretion, may issue a probationary license upon a showing of good cause. If applicant is not the manager, the manager shall be required to meet all requirements of this subsection. 
(b)  No license shall be issued for any amusement or place of amusement which shall not, if located within a building, comply with all the requirements of the city building, fire, life safety, electrical, mechanical and plumbing codes. Such compliance shall be certified by the city building inspector and the city fire prevention officer. 
(c)  No license shall be issued for any amusement or place of amusement located in the out-of-doors, or in any kind of temporary structure, unless such amusement or place of amusement shall meet the following criteria: 
(1)  If located in one location for more than one day, separate public restroom facilities shall be provided for males and females which shall be approved by the city building inspector. 
(2)  If rides or gaming devices of any kind are a part of the amusement, all such rides or gaming devices shall be certified to be safe electrically, mechanically and physically by the city building inspector and the city fire prevention officer. 
(3)  If such amusement, or place of amusement, is located within any temporary structure, such structure shall be certified by the city building inspector and the city fire prevention officer to meet the requirements of the Code of the City of Liberty relating to fire and fire exits, electrical and mechanical safety, and must meet all the applicable requirements of the city life safety code, as well as all applicable requirements of the city zoning ordinance. 
(4)  If such amusement, or place of amusement, is located within the City of Liberty on a temporary basis, a bond shall be provided to the office of the city clerk which will insure repair of any damage to property, private or public, and that the area used will be left in essentially the way in which it was found. 
(5)  A license shall not be issued until a policy or valid certificate thereof, of public liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Missouri, shall be filed with the city clerk's office providing for such public liability insurance in limits of not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) property damage, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) bodily injury to any one person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury in any one occurrence. If such liability insurance shall terminate, or be cancelled, such license shall be immediately suspended, and not reinstated until such insurance has been further effected and policy or certificate thereof so filed. 
(d)  If food service is to be provided in conjunction with any such amusement or place of amusement, whether temporary or permanent, such service shall be inspected by an agent of the Missouri division of health and be certified by such agent as meeting the minimum requirements of RSMo ch. 196 relating to food service in public establishments. 
(e)  Any such amusement, or place of amusement, whether temporary or permanent, must meet all the applicable requirements of the zoning ordinance of the City of Liberty. 
(3654) 
Sec. 7-8.2. - Transferability; revocation and/or suspension of license; suspension of employee. 
(a)  Any license issued under this article shall not be transferable, either to any person or persons, or any other location that specifically approved by the city council. 
(b)  Any license issued under this article may be suspended and subject to possible revocation upon a showing in any municipal, magistrate or circuit court of probably cause leading to formal charges, or indictment by a grand jury, of the applicant, manager, owner or part owner of the establishment so licensed, for any felony offense or any offense described in section 7-8.1, subsection (a) of this article. The suspension shall be lifted upon dismissal of such charges, acquittal in a court of law, or, in the case of a manager, upon the installation of a new manager who meets the requirements of licensure under this article. 
(c)  Any employee of any amusement or place of amusement who shall be charged or indicted under the provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall be suspended pending final action in the case. 
(d)  Upon conviction for any felony offense or any offense as described in section 7-8.1, subsection (a) of this article, of the applicant, owner or part owner of any amusement or place of amusement licensed under this article, the license shall be revoked, provided that said applicant, owner or part owner shall be notified either in person or by registered mail of said revocation and shall have thirty (30) days to appeal such revocation before the city council. The city council shall have the power to reconsider such revocation, if appeal be made within the thirty (30) days, and upon a showing of good cause may issue a probationary license for continuation of the operation for up to ninety (90) days under good behavior. A second conviction under this section shall be cause for immediate mandatory revocation. 
(3654) 
Sec. 7-8.3. - Hours of operation limited. 
    Amusements and places of amusement, as defined in section 7-7 of this article, shall limit operation on Sunday through Thursday to the hours of 10:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m., provided that during the months of June, July, and August the hour for closing may be extended to be 11:00 p.m.; on Friday from 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight; and on Saturday and holidays from 9:00 a.m. to 12:30 a.m. Theatrical productions may continue until the specific production in progress is completed and must close immediately thereafter. Saturday hours shall apply to legal holidays. 
(3708) 
Sec. 7-9. - Penalties. 
    Any individual, or group of individuals, corporation or partnership which shall open any amusement or place of amusement without first complying with the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor to be punished as prescribed in section 22-70 and every day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(3654) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4956, adopted April 22, 1985, provided that the penalty set out in  22-70 was to supersede and amend all previously enacted ordinances for which the penalty was a fine not exceeding $90.00. Therefore, the section above has been editorially changed to provide a reference to  22-70. 
ARTICLE III. - CIGARETTES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7330,  I, adopted Oct. 14, 1996, amended  7-10, 7-11 and 7-13-7-25 of Art. III with new provisions as set out herein. Former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the following ordinances: 
Ord. No. Section Date 1740 2, 5, 6 8-14 2680 2, 3 3310 2, 10 4300 2, 4 10-27-80  

Sec. 7-10. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
(a)  Cigarette means a roll of tobacco or any substitute thereof wrapped in paper and used for smoking. 
(b)  Consumer means a person who comes into possession of tobacco for the purpose of consuming it, giving it away or disposing of it in any way. 
(c)  Dealer means any person dealing directly with the manufacturer of cigarettes in their purchase and in the business of selling cigarettes as a first seller. 
(d)  First seller means and includes all persons who make the initial or first sale or distribution of cigarettes within the city. 
(e)  Package means the individual package, box or other container from which sales of cigarettes are normally made or intended to be made. 
(f)  Person means any individual, partnership, society, association, joint stock company, corporation, estate, receiver, trustee, assignee, referee or other person acting in a fiduciary or representative capacity, whether appointed by a court or otherwise, or any combination of individuals. 
(g)  Retailer includes persons other than a dealer or wholesaler as defined in this section, who is engaged in the business of selling cigarettes at retail, who shall sell or offer for sale cigarettes, irrespective of quantity, number of sales, giving the same away or exposing the same where it may be taken, or purchased, or otherwise acquired. 
(h)  Sale means any transfer of title or possession or both, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatsoever, for a consideration, or any agreement therefor. 
(i)  Vending machine operator includes all persons engaged in the distribution or sale of cigarettes by means of coin-operated vending machines. 
(j)  Wholesaler includes persons whose principal business is that of a wholesale jobber and who is known to the trade as such, who sells cigarettes for only the purpose of resale or giving them away, or exposing the same where they may be taken or purchased or otherwise acquired by the retailer. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-11. - License required. 
    Every wholesale dealer, jobber, retail dealer or other person engaged in selling cigarettes or offering, delivering, or displaying the same for sale within the city shall procure an occupation license for each place of business that is to be used for the sale or distribution of cigarettes within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 7-12 was repealed by  1 of Ord. No. 3310. 
Sec. 7-13. - Tax levy. 
    Every dealer, wholesaler, or retailer engaged in the business of selling cigarettes or offering or displaying the same for sale within the city shall pay to the city finance director an occupation tax at the rate of three dollars ($3.00) per thousand for all cigarettes sold or offered or displayed for sale. This tax shall be paid but once, as provided for in Section 7-14 and only by the dealer selling cigarettes or displaying or offering them for sale. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-14. - Payment of tax required. 
    The tax described in section 7-13 shall be paid by the dealer, wholesaler, or retailer as defined in section 7-10, selling cigarettes or offering them for sale. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-15. - Monthly payment. 
    It shall be the duty of every dealer or wholesaler, as defined in Section 7-10, selling, offering or displaying for sale any package of cigarettes, to remit the monthly cigarette tax reporting form and full payment by the fifteenth day of each following month. The cancelled check, accompanied by the monthly cigarette tax reporting form, shall be proof of payment. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-16. - Rules and regulations-Records. 
    For the purpose of enabling the finance director to enforce the terms of this ordinance, the following provisions are enacted: 
(a)  Each dealer in the city and those wholesalers and retailers as defined in section 7-10 shall procure and retain invoices showing the amount and value of the shipment of cigarettes received by him, the date thereof and the name of the shipper, and shall retain this invoice for a period of three years subject to the use and inspection of the finance director. 
(b)  All dealers, wholesalers and retailers as defined in section 7-10 shall maintain and keep for a period of three (3) years such other records of cigarettes received, sold or delivered within the city as may be required by the finance director. 
(c)  The finance director or his duly authorized representatives are authorized to examine the books, papers, invoices and other records, stock of cigarettes in and upon any premises where they are placed, stored or sold, and equipment of any such dealer, wholesaler, or retailer pertaining to the sale and delivery of cigarettes taxable under this article. 
(d)  To verify the accuracy of the occupation tax imposed and assessed by this article, each person, as defined in section 7-10, is directed and required to give to the finance director or his duly authorized representatives, the means, facilities and opportunity for such examinations as are herein provided for and required. 
(e)  In addition to the powers herein granted to the finance director, he is authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations relating to the delegation of his powers to a deputy or other employee of his office and any other matter or thing pertaining to the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(f)  Cigarette tax reporting information received from the State of Missouri shall be held in confidence and used solely for verifying cigarette tax payments. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-17. - Refunds. 
    The finance director is authorized to adopt, prescribe and promulgate rules and regulations including a monthly cigarette tax reporting form with regard to the presentation and proof of claim for refunds and credits as he may deem advisable. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-18. - Oaths and subpoenas. 
    The finance director or his employees or agents duly designated and authorized by him shall have power to administer oaths and take affidavits in relation to any matter or proceedings in the exercise of their powers and duties under this article. The finance director shall have power to subpoena and require the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers and documents to secure information pertinent to the enforcement of this article and to examine them in relation thereto. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-19. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating this article by failing to file the report and make the payment provided for in Section 7-14 hereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), may be imprisoned for not more than ninety (90) days, may have their occupation license revoked or be punished by any combination thereof. Failure to file each monthly report and make each monthly payment shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-20. - Forfeiture of merchandise. 
    Any person that sells cigarettes either in a store or through a vending machine without the payment provided for in section 7-14, shall forfeit as contraband, all such cigarettes found to be in violation of this article. The city shall have the right to sell such contraband at public auction and retain the proceeds. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-21. - Dealers outside city. 
    Any dealer whose place of business is outside the corporate limits of the city shall be bound by all of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Sec. 7-22. - Severability clause. 
    The provisions of this article shall be severable. In the event that any provision of this article is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional, the remaining provisions of this article are valid unless the court finds the valid provisions of this article are so essentially and inseparably connected with, and so dependent upon, the void provision that it cannot be presumed that the city council would have enacted the valid provisions without the void ones or unless the court finds that the valid provisions, standing alone, are incomplete and incapable of being executed in accordance with the legislative intent. 
(Ord. No. 7330,  I, 10-14-96) 
Secs. 7-23-7-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OIL STATIONS, ETC. 

Sec. 7-26. - License required. 
    Every person owning or operating an oil station or engaged in the business of selling or offering for sale, gasoline, benzine, naphtha and oil and every person storing the same in quantities in excess of ten (10) gallons, and every person transporting the same over the streets, alleys and other public places of the city for the purpose of storage or sale, within the city, shall procure a license therefor. 
(R.O. 1931,  477; Ord. No. 1603,  1) 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 18. 
Secs. 7-27, 7-28. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - PUBLIC DANCES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Places of recreation and amusement, Ch. 16; license fees for dance halls and dance houses,  18-16 of this Code. 

Sec. 7-57. - Applicability of article. 
    Any dance held in the city for which admission tickets are sold shall be subject to the provisions of this article. The city council may waive the provisions of this article in the cases of dances sponsored by nonprofit or charitable groups, when the proceeds from the sale of admission tickets is to be used for some charitable purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  1) 
Sec. 7-58. - Compliance with article required. 
    No dance covered by this article shall be held without complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  8) 
Sec. 7-59. - License-Required; application. 
    The sponsor of any dance covered by this article shall make application in writing to the city clerk for a license to conduct such dance at least ten days prior to the date of such dance. Such application shall give the name of the person or persons, or organization, sponsoring such dance, the location, the date, the hours during which such dance shall be held and the names of the six persons over twenty-one who will be present as required in section 7-64. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  2) 
Sec. 7-60. - Same-Investigation of applicant. 
    Such application shall be referred by the city clerk to the chief of police who shall make an investigation of the person or persons sponsoring such dance, or if sponsored by an organization or corporation, the officers thereof. He shall also cause investigation to be made of the location of such dance. If the chief of police be satisfied that the person or persons sponsoring such dance, or the officers of the sponsoring group, are of good moral character without felony convictions, and if satisfied that the location is adequate to protect the health and safety of the persons attending such dance, he shall return such application to the city clerk with his approval noted thereon. If not satisfied, the chief of police shall note his disapproval and reasons therefor on such application and return it to the city clerk. The city clerk shall thereupon notify the applicant of the disapproval of such application. The applicant may then appeal to the city council. The council shall thereupon hear the facts and may then issue, or refuse to issue, a license for the conduct of such dance. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  4) 
Sec. 7-61. - Same-Fee-To accompany application. 
    A fee of thirty dollars shall accompany each application, and a separate application shall be submitted for each day on which a dance is to be held. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  3) 
Sec. 7-62. - Same-Same-Refund. 
    In the event a license is refused, the application shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  5) 
Sec. 7-63. - Same-Issuance. 
    In the event such application is approved, a license for the conduction of such dance shall be issued by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  6) 
Sec. 7-64. - Minimum number of adults required to be present. 
    At the dance so licensed, the sponsor shall provide at least six persons over the age of twenty-one (21) years, who shall be present during all of the time the dance is in progress and shall be charged with the duty of maintaining order at the location of the dance, including the immediate area around the place where the dance is conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  7) 
Sec. 7-65. - Violations. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2506,  9) 
Cross reference- General penalty, see  10-1 of this Code.

ARTICLE IX. - GAS COMPANIES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2244 granted the Gas Service Company a 20-year franchise on May 17, 1963. Ord. No. 4651,  1, adopted June 1, 1983, continued the gross receipts tax imposed by the earlier ordinance. Section 2 of Ord. No. 4651 enacted a new Art. IX, to which the editor has assigned section numbers 7-65.5-7-65.10. 

Sec. 7-65.5. - Gross receipts tax imposed. 
    Any gas company in the business of operating an artificial or natural gas distribution system consisting of pipe lines, mains and conduits, shall pay to the city a sum equal to five (5) per cent of its gross receipts from the sale of gas for domestic and commercial purposes within the city. 
(Ord. No. 4651,  2(1), 6-1-83) 
Sec. 7-65.6. - What constitutes domestic and commercial sales. 
    Domestic and commercial sales shall be considered as sales made other than on special contracts providing for standby fuel and interruption of service at any time demands of domestic and commercial consumers may so require. 
(Ord. No. 4651,  2(2), 6-1-83) 
Sec. 7-65.7. - Incremental schedule of tax on certain sales. 
    As to all sales of gas not considered to be domestic and commercial sales within the definition of section 7-65.6, the gas company shall pay a tax of a sum equal to five (5) per cent of the gross receipts for all sales of gas delivered by it to its customers for such sale but not to exceed, as to each of such customers, limits in the amount of such tax stated as follows: 
(a)  Five hundred dollars ($500.00) per month for the period beginning November 1, 1983, and ending December 31, 1984. 
(b)  Five hundred fifty dollars ($550.00) per month during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 1985, and continuing thereafter with an increase of fifty dollars ($50.00) in such monthly limit in each calendar year beginning January 1 of each calendar year during a period of time ending December 31, 1994, upon which last date such stated limit shall expire. 
(Ord. No. 4651,  2(3), 6-1-83; Ord. No. 4706,  1, 10-31-83) 
Sec. 7-65.8. - Monthly reports. 
    Each gas company operating such gas distribution system shall, on or before the last of each calendar month, report such gross receipts in writing delivered to the director of finance of the city, and covering the period of the calendar month next preceding (ending with the last meter reading preceding the last day of said month) and at the time of making such report shall pay to the city, delivered to said director of finance, the tax above provided, which shall be charged to the operating expenses of the gas company. 
(Ord. No. 4651,  2(4), 6-1-83) 
Sec. 7-65.9. - Tax in lieu of occupation, license taxes. 
    Such tax is levied as an occupation and license tax for the privilege of engaging in such business and shall be in lieu of all other such taxes, but not including property taxes upon the property of such gas company subject to tax by the city on an ad valorem basis. 
(Ord. No. 4651,  2(5), 6-1-83) 
Sec. 7-65.10. - Applicability to franchise holders. 
    Any gas company engaged in the business described in section 7-65.5 hereof and holding a franchise granted by the city to operate such business in the city, which franchise provides for the payment of a fee based on gross receipts, shall be governed by the provisions of said franchise ordinance during the period for which the franchise is effective and shall be exempt from the provisions hereof during such period. 
(Ord. No. 4651,  2(6), 6-1-83)
