Sections 7-135-7-138 respectively pertained to rules of construction, severability, inclusion in the Code and repeal of conflicting ordinances and have not been set out herein. Section 7-139 provided for an effective date of Jan. 1, 2002. 
Cross reference- Adequate public facilities,  32-1, et seq. 

Sec. 7-125. - Findings. 
    The city council of the City of Liberty (hereinafter the "council") finds and declares that: 
(1)  New growth and development in the city has resulted, and will continue to result in increased use, burden and demand on the existing arterial roadways of the city, and will require arterial roadway system improvements to add capacity and to complete the roadway network as established in the city's major street improvement plan; 
(2)  The council finds and declares that it is in the public interest to impose a roadway development tax on building contractors who construct buildings and improvements that generate new traffic, in the form of a license tax surcharge, for the purpose of generating revenue, and that this is a fair way to allocate the cost of necessary arterial roadway system improvements to developments that create the need for these improvements; and 
(3)  The council has determined that the most fair, equitable and uniform method to calculate the license tax surcharge is to base it on the number of vehicle trips generated by the development during the afternoon time period (p.m. peak hour) when traffic volume on the adjacent roadways is highest. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01) 
Sec. 7-126. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to generate revenue, which shall be used to pay for arterial roadway systems throughout the city, including, but not limited to, the design, construction, and reconstruction of roadways, bridges, interchanges and related improvements in the city and the acquisition of all necessary rights-of-way, through the imposition of a roadway development tax in the form of a license tax surcharge on building contractors who construct buildings and improvements that generate new traffic, which license tax surcharge shall be imposed based on the additional vehicle trips generated by any development activity during the afternoon time period (p.m. peak hour) when traffic volume on the adjacent roadways is highest. 
(b)  By adoption of this article, the city council intends to: 
(1)  Impose a license tax surcharge upon all building contractors that apply for a building permit for development resulting in additional vehicle trips that is in addition to normal building permit costs and to the annual business license tax paid by building contractors; 
(2)  Authorize the license tax administrator to create administrative guidelines to implement this article; 
(3)  Establish an administrative review and appeal procedure to ensure that the license tax surcharge shall be imposed and collected in accordance with this article, the City Charter and all applicable laws; 
(4)  Establish a license tax review committee to monitor the license tax surcharge and to make recommendations annually to the city council regarding any amendments to this article, administrative guidelines, the roadways to be constructed from the license tax revenues, and any other matter related to the imposition, collection and use of the license tax proceeds. 
(5)  Create an economic incentive for development of a certain magnitude in terms of dollars invested, number of new employees and wages paid to those employees; and certain types of science and technology/office development to locate and expand in the city, consistent with the Economic Development Component of Blueprint for Liberty, as amended, and the Economic Development Incentives Policy, as amended. 
(c)  By adoption of this article, the city council does not intend to impose a regulatory fee or other exaction pursuant to the general police powers of the city or to regulate construction, growth or development within the city. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 9798,  I, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7-127. - Authority. 
    In the creation of the license tax, the city is exercising its constitutional home rule power pursuant to Article VI, Sec. 19(a) of the Constitution of the State of Missouri, including, but not limited to, the authority granted in Article III of the Special Charter of the City of Liberty; and the authority granted in Article X, Sec. 22 of the Constitution of the State of Missouri; and all other powers derived from the Constitution and the laws of the State of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01) 
Sec. 7-128. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Area of building means the total floor area of a building measured by square feet. 
    Building means any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. 
    Building contractor means a person that builds a building. 
    Building permit means the permit required for new construction and additions pursuant to the most recent version of the uniform building code as adopted by chapter 6, article II of the Liberty City Code, as amended. 
    City administrator means the city administrator or his or her designee. 
    Developer means a person who engages in development. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved land, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavating or drilling operations. 
    Development agreement means any written agreement between the city and a developer relating to development of identified tract(s) of land. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms constituting all or part of a dwelling and which are arranged, designed, used, or intended for use exclusively as a single housekeeping unit for one family, and which include cooking, living, sanitation, and sleeping facilities. 
    Full-time employee means an employee of the company that is scheduled to work an average of at least thirty-five (35) hours per week for a twelve-month period. 
    Roadway development capital improvements plan means the map and associated tabular data showing roadways to be improved by building contractor license tax revenues as adopted by the city council. 
    License tax means the surcharge to the annual business license tax imposed upon a building contractor pursuant to this article. 
    License tax administrator means the city administrator or his or her designee. 
    License tax rate means a measurement of the rate of tax to be paid by building contractors according to land use categories, as established by resolution of the city council. 
    Non-residential means created or used for any purpose other than residential uses or purposes. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, trust, incorporated or unincorporated association, marital community, joint venture, governmental entity, or other entity or group of persons however organized. 
    P.m. peak hour means the hours between 4:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. during the weekdays, Monday through and including Friday, at which the average traffic volume is highest. 
    Public body means agencies of the federal or state government, or a political subdivision of the state. 
    Redevelopment means the demolition of one or more buildings and the subsequent construction of one or more new buildings on the property. 
    Residential means primarily created or used for a dwelling for one or more persons. 
    School district means a public school district of the State of Missouri. 
    Structure means anything erected, the use of which requires more or less permanent location on the ground, or attached to something having permanent location on the ground. 
    Vehicle trip means a single or one-direction vehicle movement with either the origin or the destination (exiting or entering) at the subject building. For trip generation purposes, the total trip ends for a building over a given period of time are the total of all vehicle trips entering plus all the vehicle trips exiting a site during a designated time period. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 9798,  II, 10-24-2011) 
Sec. 7-129. - Applicability. 
(a)  This article shall apply to development requiring a building permit and resulting in additional vehicle trips. Additional vehicle trips shall be calculated during the p.m. peak hour. As used in this section, additional vehicle trips shall mean vehicle trips that add to the total volume on city arterial roadways resulting from new development. 
(b)  This article shall not be applicable to building permits otherwise necessary for: 
(1)  Room additions, remodeling, rehabilitation or other improvements to an existing structure, provided that there is no increase in the number of dwelling units for residential use or in the amount of square footage for non-residential use; or 
(2)  Rebuilding or replacement of a damaged, destroyed, demolished or removed structure, whether voluntary or involuntary, provided that there is no increase in the number of dwelling units for residential use or in the amount of square footage for non-residential use, that there is no change of use that would generate more peak hour vehicular traffic than the previous use, and that the rebuilding or replacement occurs no later than ten (10) years after the damage, destruction, demolition or removal of the previous structure. 
(c)  Credits. Any credit granted under this article shall reduce the total license tax owed by a building contractor. 
(1)  Upon submission of a proper application, a building contractor shall be granted a full credit in the amount of the license tax imposed pursuant to this article by the license tax administrator for: 
a.  Development requiring a building permit and resulting in additional vehicle trips, which is constructed by, or by a building contractor on behalf of, a person that has entered into a development agreement with the city, executed and dated prior to the effective date of this article, provided that the development agreement contains a specific clause that provides that the person shall not be subject to further financial participation towards ultimate major street costs, other than as specifically provided for in the development agreement and a development qualifying for this credit shall be entitled to this credit, other provisions of this section notwithstanding; or 
b.  Development requiring a building permit and resulting in additional vehicle trips for which the developer has entered into a development agreement with the city, wherein the developer is required to construct any arterial street to comply with the city's Adequate Public Facilities Ordinance, chapter 32 of the City Code, provided that such credit does not exceed the projected total roadway development tax that would be assessed for the entire development; or 
c.  Development requiring a building permit and resulting in additional vehicle trips, that is constructed on a lot for which a final plat was finally approved by the appropriate approving authority and recorded on or before January 1, 2002, and for which a complete building permit application, as determined by the building official, is submitted on or before January 1, 2004; or 
d.  Development requiring a building permit and resulting in additional vehicle trips constructed by, or by a building contractor on behalf of, a public body for its governmental use; or 
e.  Development by, or by a building contractor on behalf of, a school district of the state that requires a building permit and results in additional vehicle trips; or 
f.  Development requiring a building permit and resulting in additional vehicle trips that is constructed by, or by a building contractor on behalf of, a person that is not subject to any federal, state or local taxes, including federal, state and local sales, income, personal property, real property, use, earnings, excise or license taxes. The burden of proof shall be on the building contractor claiming this credit to demonstrate to the license tax administrator, by clear and convincing evidence, that the development being constructed by, or by a building contractor on behalf of, a person claiming such credit is exempt from all federal, state and local taxes as described in this subsection. 
(2)  Upon submission of a proper application, a building contractor may be granted a credit, in an amount as indicted herein below, against the license tax imposed pursuant to this article by the license tax administrator for the following types of development: 
a.  Enhanced benefit credit. In an amount of seventy-five (75) per cent credit against the license tax imposed, for businesses that hire at least fifty (50) full-time employees as a result of the establishment of a new manufacturing and industrial business, results in an investment of at least six million dollars ($6,000,000.00), is locating within the designated priority area, and the average wage of all new full-time employees exceeds seventy-five (75) per cent of the county average wage as published by Missouri Department of Economic Development (DED). In addition, the city council may, in its sole discretion, grant an enhanced benefit credit of up to one hundred (100) per cent of the license tax imposed, if, as a result of establishment of a new manufacturing and industrial business, that business hires more than eighty (80) full-time employees, results in an investment of at least six million dollars ($6,000,000.00), is locating within the designated priority area, and the average wage of all new full-time employees exceeds seventy-five (75) per cent of the county average wage as published by Missouri Department of Economic Development (DED). 
b.  Science and technology/office economic benefit credit. In an amount of one hundred (100) per cent economic benefit credit for businesses that: 
1.  Is a science, research technology, or engineering based business that is related to agricultural, biological, life sciences, informational technology, or engineering research, or is a class A office building of at least three (3) or more stories; 
2.  Is located within a designated priority area, as identified in the economic development policy in effect at that time, as that policy is amended by the city council from time to time; 
3.  Hires at least thirty (30) new full-time employees to Liberty as a result of the business or project; 
4.  The average wage of all new full-time employees exceeds the county average wage as published by Missouri Department of Economic Development (DED); and 
5.  Results in investment of at least six million dollars ($6,000,000.00). 
(3)  Upon submission of a proper application for a credit, a building contractor shall be granted a partial credit from the license tax imposed pursuant to this article by the license tax administrator for: 
a.  Utilization of a currently underutilized existing building. As used in this subsection, underutilized means not fully occupied or not used to full capacity. The credit shall be granted only for the number of vehicle trips that were generated by the previously underutilized facility during the p.m. peak hour; or 
b.  Change of use within an existing building, except that a change of use from a residential use to a non-residential use shall not be granted a credit. The credit shall be granted only for the number of vehicle trips that were generated by the building during the p.m. peak hour prior to the change in use. 
(4)  In the event that a building is transferred by a person who receives a credit to a person who is not eligible for a credit under this ordinance, within a period of one year from the date of the issuance of the building permit, the transferee shall be required to pay the tax imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 8296,  I, 1-7-02; Ord. No. 9798,  III, 10-24-2011) 
Sec. 7-130. - Assessment and collection of the license tax. 
(a)  Upon submission of a building permit application, the license tax administrator shall: 
(1)  Determine the applicability of this article to the development for which the building permit is submitted; 
(2)  If this article is not applicable, the license tax administrator shall notify the applicant in writing of its inapplicability, and the city shall process the building permit application in accordance with applicable city ordinances and regulations; 
(3)  If this article is applicable, the license tax administrator shall calculate and assess the license tax in accordance with this article. The applicable license tax shall be calculated pursuant to section 7-131 of this article. The calculation and assessment shall be completed within three (3) days of submission of a building permit, unless the applicant is notified otherwise in writing by the license tax administrator. 
(b)  The imposition of the license tax pursuant to this article does not alter, negate, supersede or otherwise affect any obligations relating to roadway improvements imposed on a development, including, but not limited to, the city county, state or federal legislation or regulations. 
(c)  The funds collected pursuant to this article shall be deposited into a special account of the capital fund of the city and used solely for the purposes specified in section 7-126(a). 
(d)  The license tax shall be due and payable as follows: 
(1)  Residential development. The license tax shall be due and payable prior to the issuance of a building permit for residential development. 
(2)  Non-residential development. 
a.  Shell buildings. For non-residential development structures that are shell buildings constructed for the purpose of speculative development (hereinafter, "shell buildings"), the license tax may be due and payable at the time of issuance of any certificate of occupancy for a tenant finish building permit, upon written request of the applicant to the license tax administrator. The applicant shall make the written request to the license tax administrator to exercise the provisions of this section at the time of application for a building permit for the shell building. 
b.  Other than shell buildings. For non-residential development structures other than shell buildings, the license tax shall be due and payable prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01) 
Sec. 7-131. - Calculation of the license tax. 
    The city shall calculate the license tax as follows: 
(1)  The city council shall by resolution establish the license tax rates used to calculate the license tax to be imposed upon building contractors. 
(2)  The license tax administrator shall calculate the license tax due by: 
a.  Verifying the number and type of dwelling units or square footage of non-residential structures that are proposed to be constructed as shown on the building permit application. 
b.  Determining the license tax that shall be applied to each dwelling unit or square footage of non-residential structure pursuant to the roadway development tax schedule. For all land use categories not specified in the roadway development tax schedule established by resolution of the council, the license tax administrator shall classify the property in accordance with the procedures specified in the resolution of the council. 
c.  Multiplying the number of dwelling units or square footage of non-residential structures, stated in terms of thousand (1,000) square feet of gross floor area, or other applicable development unit by the applicable license tax rate. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01) 
Sec. 7-132. - Administration of this article. 
(a)  The license tax administrator shall perform all duties imposed by this article unless otherwise provided. 
(b)  The license tax administrator shall have the authority to create administrative guidelines necessary to effectuate and carry out the intent and purposes of this article. No administrative guidelines shall take effect until authorized by resolution by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01) 
Sec. 7-133. - Appeals. 
(a)  Appeal to the license tax administrator. 
(1)  A building contractor (hereinafter "appellant") may appeal the assessment of a license tax to the license tax administrator by filing a notice of appeal with the license tax administrator within thirty (30) days following the assessment of the license tax by the license tax administrator. If an appellant fails to appeal the assessment of the license tax within thirty (30) days as set forth in this subsection, the assessment of the license tax shall be final and no appeal shall be heard. If the appellant pays the license tax without protest, the appellant shall have waived the right to appeal the assessment of the license tax. 
(2)  If an appellant desires to process the building permit application during the appeal process, the building contractor shall be required to pay the license tax under protest. If the license tax is paid under protest by the building contractor, an appeal from a final decision of the license tax administrator shall not delay processing of the building permit and shall not delay any other permit, license or approval issued by the city. 
(3)  An appellant may appeal the following decisions to the license tax administrator: 
a.  The land use category of the development; 
b.  The number of vehicle trips generated by the proposed development; 
c.  Any credit determination made pursuant to section 7-129(c). 
(4)  Within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice of appeal, or by a date agreed upon in writing between the appellant and the city, the appellant shall submit to the license tax administrator copies of all studies, calculations and other evidence relevant to the appeal. If a specified basis for the appeal is to challenge the license tax administrator's determination of the number of vehicle trips generated by the proposed development, the appellant may be required by the license tax administrator to submit a traffic study prepared by a certified traffic engineer or traffic engineering firm, paid for by the appellant, which sets forth the appellant's proposed trip generation calculations for the development. If the basis for the appeal is a credit determination pursuant to section 7-129(c), the appellant must submit to the license tax administrator proof that it is eligible for a credit and the extent of the credit. 
(5)  The notice of appeal shall specify the grounds for the appeal. The license tax administrator shall consider the appeal. The burden of proof shall be on the appellant to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that (i) the land use category of the development is incorrect; (ii) the number of vehicle trips generated by the development, used in the calculation by the license tax administrator, does not accurately reflect the number of vehicle trips that are reasonably expected to be generated by the development; or (iii) the credit determination under section 7-129(c) of this article is incorrect. 
(6)  Within thirty (30) days after filing of the notice of appeal, the license tax administrator shall render a final decision and shall give written notice of that decision to the appellant. 
(b)  Appeal to the city council. 
(1)  An appeal under this subsection may be heard only after the license tax administrator has made a final decision pursuant to section 7-133(a)(6). 
(2)  An appellant may appeal the final decision of the license tax administrator to the city council by filing a notice of appeal with the city clerk within fifteen (15) days following issuance of the final written decision of the license tax administrator as specified in section 7-133(a)(6). If an appellant fails to appeal the final decision of the license tax administrator within fifteen (15) days, as set forth in this subsection, the assessment of the license tax shall be final and no appeal shall be heard. 
(3)  If an appellant desires to process the building permit application after appeal is taken from the final decision of the license tax administrator, the building contractor shall pay the license tax "under protest." If the license tax is paid under protest by the building contractor, an appeal from a final decision of the license tax administrator shall not delay processing of the building permit and shall not delay any other permit, license or approval issued by the city. 
(4)  An appellant may appeal the following decisions of the license tax administrator to the city council: 
a.  The land use category of the development; 
b.  The number of vehicle trips generated by the proposed development; or 
c.  Any credit determination made pursuant to section 7-129(c). 
(5)  Within thirty (30) days of receipt of the notice of appeal, or by a date agreed upon in writing between the appellant and the city, the appellant shall submit to the city council copies of all studies, calculations and other evidence relevant to the appeal. If a specified basis for the appeal is to challenge the license tax administrator's determination of the number of vehicle trips generated by the proposed development, the appellant may be required by the city council to submit to the city council a traffic study prepared by a certified traffic engineer or traffic engineering firm, paid for by the appellant, which sets forth the appellant's proposed trip generation calculations for the development. If the basis for the appeal is a credit determination pursuant to section 7-129(c), the appellant must submit to the city council proof that it is eligible for a credit and the extent of the credit. 
(6)  The notice of appeal shall specify the grounds for the appeal, and no argument shall be heard by the city council that is not set forth in the notice of appeal. The notice of appeal shall be forwarded to the city council along with a recommendation from the license tax administrator and the city council shall conduct a hearing to consider the appeal. The appellant shall be given notice of the hearing by certified mail at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. The burden of proof shall be on the appellant to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that (i) the land use category of the development is incorrect; (ii) the number of vehicle trips generated by the development, used in the calculation by the license tax administrator, does not accurately reflect the number of vehicle trips that are reasonably expected to be generated by the development; or (iii) the credit determination under section 7-129(c) of this article is incorrect. 
(7)  Within thirty (30) days after the city council's final decision, appellant shall be given written notice of the city council's decision. 
(c)  Calculation of days. The number of days specified in section 7-133 of this article shall include weekend days and holidays. The last day of the period shall be included in the computation, unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, and if it is, the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday. A half-holiday shall be considered as other days and not as a holiday. "Legal holiday" includes any day designated as a holiday by the Congress of the United States, Missouri legislature or the city council. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01) 
Sec. 7-134. - License tax review committee annual review. 
(a)  A license tax review committee shall be established to monitor the license tax and to make recommendations annually to the city council regarding any amendments to this article, the license tax rates, administrative guidelines, the roadways to be constructed as specified in the roadway development capital improvements plan, and any other matters related to the imposition, collection and use of the license tax revenues. 
(b)  The mayor shall appoint, upon the advice and consent of a majority of the city council, the members of the license tax review committee. The license tax review committee shall be composed of five (5) residents of the city, who shall serve without compensation, and at the pleasure of the city council. The committee shall have at least one representative from each of the following groups or organizations: the city council; the planning and zoning commission; the development community (a person who develops land); the business community and citizens of the city. The chair of the license tax review committee shall be elected by the members of the committee. The members of the license tax review committee shall serve two-year terms. 
(c)  To assist the license tax review committee in performing its annual review, beginning in the calendar year 2002 and annually thereafter, the city administrator, with the assistance of the directors of the finance and public works/development services departments, shall prepare and submit, to the license tax review committee a report on the subject of the license tax, which report shall include: 
(1)  Recommendations regarding appropriate amendments to this article; 
(2)  Any proposed changes in the license tax rates, including but not limited to any change to the maximum rate of the tax, based on an increase or decrease in the Construction Cost Index published by the Engineering News Record; 
(3)  Proposed changes to the license tax calculation method, including the trip generation estimates and the land use categories, if appropriate; 
(4)  Analysis of costs and revenues resulting from the license tax imposed pursuant to this article; 
(5)  Analysis of the impact of the license tax, if any, on growth and development in the city in each market segment during the preceding year; 
(6)  The status of the implementation and administration of this article; 
(7)  A summary of the appeals taken pursuant to this article; 
(8)  Any proposed changes in the roadway development capital improvements plan based on changes in development patterns in the city or other relevant factors. 
(d)  The city administrator, in preparing the annual report, shall, at a minimum, obtain and review the following information: 
(1)  A statement from the finance director summarizing the revenue collected through the license tax and disbursed during the preceding year; 
(2)  A statement from the director of planning and community development summarizing the applications for building permits approved during the preceding year which were subject to the license tax; 
(3)  A statement from the director of planning and community development regarding all roadway improvements funded with license tax proceeds and initiated, advanced or completed during the preceding year; 
(4)  A statement from the director of planning and community development regarding any change in the Construction Cost Index as published by the Engineering News Record and the effect of any such change on the maximum rate of the license tax, and 
(5)  A statement from the Building Official of the City of Liberty of the amount of investment made from those businesses subject to [subsection] 7-129.c.ii credit. 
(6)  The license tax review committee's annual review shall be completed by the first Monday of December of each year. 
(7)  Based on the annual review by, and recommendations of, the license tax review committee, the annual report of the city administrator and other factors that the council deems relevant and appropriate the council may amend this article. 
(Ord. No. 8260,  I, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 8633,  I, 1-26-04; Ord. No. 9798,  IV, 10-24-2011) 
Secs. 7-135-7-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - VIDEO SERVICES PROVIDERS 

Sec. 7-151. - Definitions. 
    The words and phrases used in this article shall have the meaning as set forth in RSMo 67.2677 or, if not defined therein, shall have such meanings as established by City Code. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 7-152. - Franchise fee. 
    Pursuant to RSMo 67.2689, and as partial compensation for use of the city's public rights-of-way, each video service provider or other person providing cable services or video services within the city shall, to the extent permitted by law, pay to the city a fee of five (5) percent of the gross revenues from such video services provider in the geographic area of the city. Such payment shall be made as required by RSMo 67.2689. The city shall have the right to audit any video service provider as authorized by RSMo 67.2691. Late payments shall accrue interest due to the city compounded monthly at one and one-half (1.5) percent or such other maximum rate as may be established by law. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 7-153. - Customer service requirements. 
    All video service providers providing service within the city shall adopt and comply with the minimum customer service requirements set forth in RSMo 67.2692. Notice or receipt of the ordinance from which this article derives by the video service provider shall be deemed notice of the city invoking such customer service requirements. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 7-154. - Rights-of-way regulation; indemnification; permits and compliance with other laws. 
    Video service providers shall comply with the requirements of RSMo 67.2707, 67.2709 and all applicable ordinances and regulations consistent with RSMo 67.1830 to 67.1846 relating to use of the city rights-of-way. Each video service provider shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and its officers, employees and agents from any loss or damage, including, but not limited to attorneys' fees, as provided in such ordinances or regulations, but in no event less than the obligation on video service providers set forth in RSMo 67.2695. The city may require documentation of such indemnification by written agreement or other instrument to the extent permitted by law. In addition, video service providers shall be subject to and comply with such supplementary provisions relating to placement, screening and location of facilities as provided in Chapter 30, Article IV of the Liberty Code of Ordinances whether on public or private property, and such other applicable laws of the city, except as may be otherwise validly preempted. Notwithstanding any other ordinance to the contrary, no facilities to be used for video services shall be installed without obtaining a permit from the city authorizing the location and plans for such facilities; provided that this provision shall not apply to installation of otherwise lawful and authorized poles or wires. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 7-155. - Public, educational and governmental channels. 
    Each video service provider shall designate a number of channels for public, educational and governmental programming consistent with RSMo 67.2703; provided that any greater number of channels, as may be required in the incumbent cable franchise or franchise ordinance, shall be required pursuant to RSMo 67.2703.2. The city shall bear no cost relating to the transmission, availability or maintenance of such channels unless expressly authorized by the city in writing and approved by the governing body. Incumbent cable operators and other video service providers shall provide support for such public, educational and governmental channels consistent with RSMo 67.2703.8. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 7-156. - Continued obligations. 
    The obligations of a cable service provider or video service provider as set forth in any existing cable services or video services franchise or ordinance shall also continue to apply to the full extent permitted by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 7-157. - Reservation of rights. 
    The city retains all rights in RSMo 67.2675 through 67.2714 RSMo., inclusive, and may take any and all actions permitted by law to exercise such rights or to enforce such obligations on providers of video service. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 7-158. - Notice. 
    A copy of the ordinance from which this article derives shall be delivered to each video service provider operating in the city after notice to the city that such provider is authorized to provide service within the city; provided that the provisions of this article shall, to the extent permitted by law, not be affected by any claimed or actual failure of a service provider to have received delivery of a copy of the ordinance from which this article derives. 
(Ord. No. 9183,  I, 8-27-07) 
ARTICLE XVI. - TRANSIENT GUEST TAX 

Sec. 7-159. - Definitions generally. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hotel or motel means any structure or any portion of any structure that is occupied or intended or designed for occupancy by transients for dwelling, lodging or sleeping purposes and includes, but is not limited to, any hotel, inn, tourist home or house, motel, studio hotel, bachelor hotel, lodging house, bed and breakfast, rooming house, or public or private club. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession or the right to the use or possession of any room or rooms or portion thereof in any hotel or motel for dwelling, lodging or sleeping purposes. 
    Operator means the proprietor, manager or other person having principal charge of a hotel or motel. Where the operator performs functions through a managing agent of any type other than an employee the managing agent shall also be deemed an operator for the purposes of this chapter and shall have the same duties and liabilities as the principal. Compliance with the provisions of this chapter by either the principal or the managing agent shall be compliance by both. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit. 
    Rent means the consideration charged for the occupancy of space in a hotel. 
    Tenant means any person who exercises occupancy or is entitled to occupancy by reason of concession, permit, right of access, license or other agreement. 
    Transient means any tenant who exercises occupancy or is entitled to occupancy by reason of concession, permit, right of access, license or other agreement for a period of thirty-one (31) days or less during a calendar quarter, counting portions of days as full days. Any such tenant so occupying space in a hotel shall be deemed to be a transient until the period of thirty-one (31) days during a calendar quarter has expired unless there is an agreement in writing between the operator and the occupant providing for a longer period of occupancy. In determining whether a person is a transient, uninterrupted periods of time extending both prior and subsequent to the effective date of this chapter may be considered. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-160. - Tax imposed-Gross daily rent. 
    There is hereby established and levied a tax on the charges for all sleeping rooms paid by the transient guests of all hotels or motels situated in the city, or a portion thereof, at the rate of five (5) percent per occupied room per night. Unless otherwise provided in this chapter or by law, the city finance director shall be responsible for the administration and collection of this tax. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-161. - Tax in addition to other taxes and fees. 
    The tax established under this chapter shall be in addition to any other tax or fee imposed pursuant to statute or ordinance or resolution by any governmental entity upon the occupancy of a hotel or motel room including the occupation/business license fee levied in article I, chapter 18, "licenses". The tax established in this chapter shall be in addition to the charge for the sleeping room and all other taxes imposed by law, and shall be stated separately from all other charges and taxes. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-162. - Reporting and remitting transient guest tax. 
    Each operator shall on or before the twentieth (20th) day of the month following the close of each month make a return to the city finance director on forms provided of total rents charged for sleeping rooms paid by transients and the amount of tax collected for transient occupancy. At the time the return is filed, the full amount of the tax collected shall be remitted to the city finance director. The city finance director may establish shorter reporting periods for any license holder that has established a record of being delinquent in reporting and/or remitting taxes accruing hereunder. The city finance director may also establish shorter or longer reporting periods to insure the efficient and effective collection of the tax. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-163. - Penalties and interest. 
A.  Any operator who fails to remit any tax imposed by this chapter within the time required shall pay a penalty of one percent and interest of two (2) percent per month, not to exceed twenty-five (25) percent per annum, of the amount of the tax in addition to the amount of the tax, all in accordance with law. 
B.  Every penalty imposed and such interest as accrues under the provisions of this section shall become a part of the tax herein required to be paid. Any penalty may for good cause be waived by the collector provided that a report thereof be made in writing to the city council. 
C.  Any unpaid taxes shall be considered delinquent thirty (30) days after the last day of each quarter. Taxes delinquent under this chapter shall be grounds for revocation by the city council of an occupation/business license after notice and hearing. Revocation under this section shall be in addition to all other penalties provided under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-164. - Failure to collect and report tax-Determination of tax by finance director. 
    If any operator shall fail or refuse to collect any tax or portion thereof or to submit within the time provided in this chapter any report and/or remittance of any tax or any portion thereof required, the city finance director shall proceed to obtain facts and information on which to base an estimate of the tax due. As soon as the city finance director procures such facts and information upon which to base such an estimate or assessment against the operator of all tax, interest and penalties provided for by this chapter, the city finance director shall give notice of the amount so assessed by serving such notice personally or by depositing such notice in the United States mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the operator at the operator's business address. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-165. - Right to hearing. 
    Such operator may within ten (10) days after the serving or mailing of any notice make application in writing to the city finance director for a hearing on the amount assessed as transient guest tax. If such application for a hearing is not made within the time prescribed, the tax, interest and penalties, shall become final and conclusive and immediately due and payable by such operator. If an application is received for a hearing, the time and place of such hearing shall be fixed within five days of receipt of the request. The notice for request of a hearing should show cause why the amount, specifying tax, interest and penalties should not be fixed as specified in the assessment. After such hearing, the city finance director shall determine the proper tax to be remitted and shall thereafter give written notice to the operator of such determination and the amount of such tax, interest and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-166. - Retention of records for taxing purposes. 
    It shall be the duty of every operator liable for the collection and payment to the city of any tax imposed by this chapter to keep and preserve for a period of three (3) years all records which may be necessary to determine the amount of such taxes as may have accrued to the city and for the collection or payment of which such operator is responsible. The city finance director shall have the right to inspect and/or audit such records at all reasonable times, but shall hold the same in confidence and utilize the same only for the purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-167. - Refunds-Overpayment of taxes. 
A.  Whenever the amount of any tax, interest or penalty has been overpaid or paid more than once or has been erroneously collected or received by the city under this chapter, such overpayment may be refunded as provided in subsections B and C of this section. A claim in writing shall be presented stating, under penalty of perjury, the specific grounds upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be on forms provided by the city finance director. 
B.  An operator may claim a refund or take as a credit against taxes to be remitted the amount previously overpaid, the amount paid more than once, or the amount paid after being erroneously collected or received when it is established in a manner prescribed by the city finance director that the tax was paid on charges imposed upon a person who was not a transient. 
    No refund shall be paid under the provisions of this section unless the operator establishes a right thereto by written records. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-168. - Actions to collect taxes owed to the city. 
    Any tax required to be paid by any operator under the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a lien upon the premises to which such tax applies and shall be recoverable by the city in any action provided at law for the recovery of delinquent taxes. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 7-169. - Unlawful acts-Hotel operator. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator to fail or refuse to register a hotel or motel, to fail or refuse to register or make other record of any transient occupant of the premises to which the tax imposed by this chapter applies, to fail or refuse to submit any tax return or other financial records or to refuse to permit any necessary inspection of hotel or motel records upon reasonable request by the city finance director, or to willfully render a false or fraudulent tax return or claim as required by this chapter. Each such occurrence shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10328,  I, 1-26-15) 
Chapter 8 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10283,  I, adopted Oct. 27, 2014, amended Ch. 8 in its entirety. Former Ch. 8,  8-3.2-8-25, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from R.O. 1931,  340, 502-511, 515-517; 1950,  1; 2294,  2; 2434,  1; 2475; 2520,  3; 3192,  1; 3662; 3805; 3882,  1, adopted Nov. 14, 1977; Ord. No. 4103,  1, adopted April 9, 1979; Ord. No. 4801,  1, adopted May 28, 1984; Ord. No. 8625,  I, II, adopted Dec. 15, 2003; Ord. No. 10117,  I, adopted Oct. 28, 2013. 

Sec. 8-1. - Composition and appointment. 
    The cemetery advisory committee shall be composed of nine (9) members, all of whom shall be residents of the city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-2. - Terms of office; vacancies. 
    The members of the cemetery advisory committee shall hold office as follows: The terms of the nine (9) persons to be appointed by the mayor shall be three (3) years. Each member shall serve until his successor is duly appointed and qualified, and shall receive no compensation. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as regular appointments, and any person so appointed shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-3. - Duties, generally. 
    The cemetery advisory committee is to act in an advisory capacity to the city council in connection with preservation, beautification, and enhancement of the city's cemeteries. The cemetery advisory committee will work with the city government in security matters at the cemeteries to lessen damage to monuments, cornerstones, and fences. 
    The cemetery advisory committee, when requested by the city council, shall study, investigate, advise, report, or develop any plan or program which is determined to be necessary or advisable for the care, operation, or disposition of the cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I(8-3.2), 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-4. - Supervisor of cemeteries. 
    The director of parks and recreation of the city or his designee shall serve the board in the capacity of "supervisor of cemeteries" with authority to coordinate and direct all of the administrative and maintenance affairs of the cemeteries under the policies of the cemetery advisory committee. The committee shall act through the chief administrative officer as a unit in administering its policies. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I(8-3.2), 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-5. - Injury to fences, etc. 
    No person shall injure the fences enclosing city-owned cemetery grounds in the city, or the gates, locks or other fastenings thereto. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-6. - Defacing cemetery property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully and maliciously destroy, disfigure, or injure any wall, fence, hedge, monument, tombstone, tree, shrubbery, or any part thereof, around or in any cemetery, graveyard, or burial ground. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-7. - City cemetery designated. 
    The tract, piece or parcel of land heretofore, on the first day of March, 1858, conveyed to the mayor, councilmen and citizens of the city, by William H. Roush and wife, by deed recorded in "Book S," on page 455 of the records of deeds for the county, lying north of and contiguous to the fairgrounds in the city, is set apart and dedicated for a cemetery, to be known and designated as the "Fairview and New Hope Cemetery of the City of Liberty." 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-8. - Plat of city cemetery. 
    An accurate plat of the city cemetery shall be made by order and under the direction of the city council, setting forth: 
(1)  The blocks and lots, by number, and the dimensions thereof; 
(2)  The streets and alleys, corresponding as near as may be, in width and direction with those heretofore laid off. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-9. - Keeping plat of cemetery, conveyances. 
    The plat referred to in section 8-8 shall be filed in the office of the city and all conveyances of cemetery lots shall be made by block and lot as numbered on such plat. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-10. - Permit for burial. 
    No person shall be buried in the city cemetery, unless some relative, friend or other person shall first obtain a burial permit from the city. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-11. - Sexton. 
    The city shall employ a sexton who shall be responsible for the care and maintenance of the cemetery, the sale of grave sites, provide for grave openings and related arrangements, promote contributions to the perpetual care cemetery fund, and such other duties in connection therewith as may be assigned from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-12. - Specifications, head and foot markers. 
    All head markers and foot markers erected in city-owned cemeteries shall be installed in accordance with the City of Liberty rules and regulations for city-owned cemeteries technical specifications, design criteria, and policies currently in full force and effect, having been approved by resolution of the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-13. - Monuments in city-owned cemeteries. 
    All monuments erected in city-owned cemeteries shall be installed in accordance with the City of Liberty rules and regulations for city-owned cemeteries technical specifications, design criteria, and policies currently in full force and effect, having been approved by resolution of the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-14. - Cornerstones. 
    All cornerstones erected in city-owned cemeteries shall be installed in accordance with the City of Liberty rules and regulations for city-owned cemeteries technical specifications, design criteria, and policies currently in full force and effect, having been approved by resolution of the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk and shall be placed with the top level with the ground. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-15. - Bases. 
    All bases shall be erected in accordance with the City of Liberty rules and regulations for city-owned cemeteries technical specifications, design criteria, and policies currently in full force and effect, having been approved by resolution of the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk and approved in advance by the director of parks and recreation or his authorized agent. No base shall be erected until a permit for such base shall be secured from the cemetery records clerk. All bases shall be inspected during construction by the director of parks and recreation or his authorized agent. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-16. - Installation of monuments; city approval. 
    All monuments shall be inspected during installation; and if the same shall not conform to the specifications, the city reserves the right to prohibit the erection of the monument, marker or cornerstone. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-17. - Planting, generally. 
    No lot shall be decorated with any tree, shrub, nor shall the lot be disturbed in any way without first obtaining the consent of the director. Memorial shrubs, trees and bushes may be planted in designated areas under the direction of the director. The city reserves the right to trim or remove any shrubbery or tree on any lot in any of the cemeteries. Flowers are permitted to be planted in portions of the plot not affecting the routine maintenance of the cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-18. - Decorations, generally. 
(a)  From March 15 to October 15 of each year, fresh-cut flowers or small artificial bouquets will be permitted as grave decorations. No glass shall be permitted. 
(b)  From October 15 to March 15, any appropriate winter decoration may be used, such as wreaths, floral or evergreen blankets and artificial flowers. Decorations other than those permitted between March 15 and October 15 will be removed and discarded at the beginning of the mowing season commencing March 15. 
(c)  Glass shall not be permitted. 
(d)  Exceptions: On Easter, Mother's Day, Memorial Day and Father's Day, other appropriate decorations such as boxes, metal containers, potted plants and wreaths may be used for one week only. No glass will be permitted. Any decoration which is to be retained by the owner must be picked up within seven (7) days after each of the above days or it will be removed and discarded. 
(e)  Neither the cemetery advisory committee, the city council nor the maintenance staff will be responsible for unauthorized removal or destruction of grave decorations. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-19. - Trust for care, etc. 
    The mayor, council members and citizens of the city consent and agree to accept and hold in trust free of charge any fund or property of any description, donated or willed to it, in trust for the care and maintenance of city-owned cemeteries. 
    Any money so donated or willed, with directions that only the interest thereon shall be used, shall be loaned by the city council on unencumbered real estate situated in the county, and not exceeding two-thirds the fair value thereof or invested in bonds issued by the United States, the state, the city or the county, and only the interest received thereon shall be used in maintaining the cemeteries; and all trust monies shall be kept separate from funds derived from the sale of cemetery lots and in a fund known as the "cemetery trust fund." 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-20. - Disposition of proceeds from sales of lots. 
    There shall be placed in the cemetery trust fund twenty-five (25) per cent of the proceeds of the sale of all cemetery lots owned by the city, and such twenty-five (25) per cent shall be and become a part of the permanent trust fund provided for by section 8-19, and the interest only derived from such funds shall be used for the maintenance of city-owned cemeteries. All such funds so placed in the cemetery trust fund shall be handled and disposed of according to the terms of section 8-19. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-21. - Gifts and bequests. 
    All money and property derived from gifts, bequests and devises to the city for cemetery purposes, unless otherwise provided in the instrument granting the same, shall be deposited in and become a part of the cemetery trust fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-22. - Trespassing. 
    It shall be unlawful to knowingly enter or remain on the grounds of any cemetery after 9:00 p.m. or before 6:00 a.m. local time. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-23. - Vaults. 
    Two-piece concrete boxes and vaults shall be optional. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-24. - Cemetery, schedule of fees. 
    Fees for purchase of spaces, openings and closings and foundations are based on the schedule of fees in full force and effect, having been approved by the city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-25. - Removal of remains. 
    Note: If a vault was not used, the person asking for such removal must furnish own labor for removal of box. 
    Necessary forms for removal of remains: 
(1)  Request for removal (notarized). 
(2)  Permit from county board of health for removal of grave remains. 
(3)  County permit not necessary for removal of cremated remains. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-26. - Repurchase of cemetery lots. 
    The city may repurchase unused cemetery lots. The city shall, within thirty (30) days after the lot is offered to the city, either purchase the lot for an amount not to exceed the price for which the lot was originally sold or reject the same. If the price for which a lot originally sold cannot be ascertained, the resale price shall be set in accordance with the city's schedule of fees. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 8-27. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate, fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any provisions, regulations, or requirements of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed in section 22-40 for each such offense. 
(Ord. No. 10283,  I, 10-27-2014) 
Chapter 9 - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS ORGANIZATION 

Sec. 9-1. - Organization created. 
    There is hereby created the City of Liberty emergency preparedness organization, which is responsible for the preparation and implementation of emergency functions required to prevent and minimize injury and damage due to disasters, to include emergency management of resources and administration of such economic controls as may be needed to provide for the welfare of the people, and emergency activities (excluding functions for which the military forces are primarily responsible) in accordance with "Civil Defense," Chapter 44, RSMo, 1976. 
(3333; Ord. No. 4619,  1, 3-14-83) 
Sec. 9-2. - State law adopted. 
    The City of Liberty hereby adopts the provisions and directions of RSMo 44.080, 44.090, 44.110, 44.112, 44.113 and 44.115 of "Civil Defense," RSMo ch. 44, as they apply to political subdivisions. 
(3333; Ord. No. 4619,  1, 3-14-83) 
Sec. 9-3. - Coordinator, responsibilities. 
    The coordinator is authorized to select and obtain federal government surplus property through the Lakes Country Regional Planning Commission, state disaster planning and operations office, and state department of education. The coordinator shall obtain the necessary approval to obligate the city for the handling charge imposed by the department of education-state agency for surplus property. The coordinator may delegate authority to obtain surplus property at the state agency for surplus property warehouse with the approval of the mayor and city council. The coordinator is authorized to submit all materials and sign all documents requested by the state disaster planning and operations office, to qualify the city for participation in federal contributions for personnel and administrative expense program under P.L. 85-606. 
(3333) 
Sec. 9-4. - Functions, cooperation. 
    The city organization shall perform emergency preparedness functions in cooperation with the County of Clay and shall conduct these functions in accordance with the provisions of "Civil Defense," RSMo ch. 44. 
(3333; Ord. No. 4619,  1, 3-14-83) 
Chapter 10 - COURTS, FINES AND IMPRISONMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Jury duty,  22-31, 22-32; duty of parent to appear if summoned for minor,  22-34; attorney and city prosecutor,  2-103.11-2-103.14; municipal judge,  2-103.21, 2-103.22; traffic violations bureau,  20-49-20-51. 

Sec. 10-1. - Court established. 
    There is hereby established in the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, a municipal court to be known as "Liberty Municipal Court, a Division of the Seventh Judicial Circuit Court of the State of Missouri." This court is a continuation of the municipal court of the city as previously established, and termed herein "the municipal court." 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-2. - Jurisdiction. 
    The jurisdiction of the municipal court shall extend to all cases involving alleged violations of the ordinances of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-3. - Superintending authority. 
    The municipal court of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, shall be subject to the rules of the Seventh Judicial Circuit Court of the State of Missouri, and to the rules of the supreme court. The judge and court personnel of the municipal court shall be subject to the general administrative authority of the presiding judge of Clay County. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-4. - Docket and court records. 
    The municipal judge shall be a conservator of the peace. He shall keep a docket, or cause such a docket to be kept, in which shall be entered every case commenced before him and the proceedings therein; and he shall keep such records as may be required. Such docket and records shall be records of the circuit court of Clay County. The municipal judge shall deliver, or cause to be delivered, the docket and records of the municipal court, and all books and papers pertaining to his office, to his successor in office or to the presiding judge of the circuit. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-5. - Municipal judge; powers and duties generally. 
    The municipal judge shall be, and is hereby authorized to: 
(a)  Establish a traffic violations bureau as provided for in the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts, and RSMo 479.050. 
(b)  Administer oaths and enforce due obedience to all orders, rules and judgment made by him, and may fine or imprison for contempt committed before him while he is holding court in the same manner and to the same extent as a circuit judge. 
(c)  Commute the term of any sentence, stay execution of any fine or sentence, suspend any fine or sentence, and make such other orders that may be proper in the municipal court. 
(d)  Make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to implement and carry out the provisions of this chapter, and make and adopt such rules of practice as are necessary to hear and decide matters pending before the municipal court and to implement and carry out the provisions of the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts. Any and all rules made or adopted hereunder may be annulled or amended by an ordinance limited to such purpose; provided that such ordinance does not violate, or conflict with, the provisions of the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts, or state statutes. 
    The municipal judge shall have such other powers, duties and privileges as are or may be prescribed by the laws of this state, this Code or other ordinances of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-6. - Traffic violations bureau. 
    Should the municipal judge determine that there shall be a traffic violations bureau, the city shall provide all expenses incident to the operations of the same. The municipal court clerk is hereby designated as the traffic violations clerk of said bureau, if established. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-7. - Issuance and execution of warrants. 
    All warrants issued by a municipal judge shall be directed to the chief of police, or any other police officer of the municipality, or to the sheriff of the county. The warrants shall be executed by the chief of police, police officer or sheriff any place within the limits of the county and not elsewhere unless the warrants are endorsed in the manner provided for warrants in criminal cases, and, when so endorsed, shall be served in other counties, as provided for in warrants in criminal cases. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-8. - Arrests without warrants. 
    The chief of police or other police officers of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, may, without a warrant, make arrest of any person who commits an offense in his presence, but such officer shall, before the trial, file a written complaint with the judge hearing violations of municipal ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-9. - Jury trials. 
    Any person charged with a violation of a municipal ordinance of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, shall be entitled to a trial by jury, as in prosecutions for misdemeanors before an associate circuit judge. Whenever a defendant accused of a violation of a municipal ordinance demands a trial by jury, the municipal court shall certify the case to the presiding judge of the circuit court for reassignment, as provided in subsection 2 of Section 517.520, Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-10. - Duties of the city prosecuting attorney. 
    It shall be the duty of an attorney designated by the municipality to prosecute the violations of the city's ordinances before the municipal judge or before any circuit judge hearing violations of the city ordinances. The salary or fees of the attorney and his necessary expenses incurred in such prosecutions shall be paid by the City of Liberty in such manner as provided by ordinance. The compensation of such attorney shall not be contingent upon the result in any case. The city attorney elected pursuant to Section 5, Article II of the Charter of the City, or selected to fill a vacancy in that office, if such should occur, is designated to prosecute violations of the city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-11. - Summoning of witnesses. 
    It shall be the duty of the municipal judge to summon all persons whose testimony may be deemed essential as witnesses at a trial, and to enforce their attendance by attachment, if necessary. The fees of witnesses shall be the same as those fixed for witnesses in trials before associate circuit judges and shall be taxed as other costs in the case. Where a trial shall be continued by a municipal judge, it shall not be necessary to summon any witnesses who may be present at the continuance; but the municipal judge or the municipal court clerk shall notify such witnesses as either party may require before him on the day set for trial to testify in the case, and to enter the names of such witnesses on his docket which such oral or written notice shall be valid as a summons. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-12. - Transfer of complaint to associate circuit judge. 
    If, in the progress of any trial before a municipal judge, it shall appear to the judge that the accused ought to be put upon trial for an offense against the criminal laws of the state and [the accused is] not cognizable before him as municipal judge, he shall immediately stop all further proceedings before him as municipal judge, and cause the complaint to be made before some associate circuit judge within the county. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-13. - Disqualification of municipal judge from hearing particular case. 
    A municipal judge shall be disqualified to hear any case in which he is in anywise interested, or, if before the trial is commenced, the defendant or the prosecutor files an affidavit that the defendant or the municipality, as the case may be, cannot have a fair and impartial trial by reason of the interest or prejudice of the judge. Neither the defendant nor the city shall be entitled to file more than one affidavit or disqualification in the same case. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-14. - Temporary municipal judge. 
    If a municipal judge be absent, sick or disqualified from acting, the mayor shall designate, with the advice and consent of the city council, some competent, eligible person to act as municipal judge until such absence or disqualification shall cease, or until such vacancy shall become permanent under any provision of section 2-103.22 of the Code of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, whichever shall first occur. The city council shall provide by ordinance for the compensation of any person designated to act as municipal judge under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78; Ord. No. 4060,  1, 1-8-79) 
Editor's note- The editor has inserted  2-103.22 into  10-14 in lieu of  2-40, which has been repealed. 
Sec. 10-15. - Clerk of the municipal court. 
    The clerk of the municipal court shall be a regular employee of the City of Liberty, shall at all times meet all the qualifications to be an employee of the City of Liberty, and shall be a notary public of the State of Missouri. Appointment to the position of municipal court clerk shall be made by the mayor by and with the approval of the city council. The appointment shall be based upon the skill and ability of the individual to competently carry out the day-to-day duties of the office of municipal court clerk as described in this chapter. The duties of the said clerk shall be as follows: 
(a)  To collect such fines for violations of the municipal ordinances of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, and for such other offenses as may be described, and the court costs thereof. 
(b)  To administer oaths and take affirmations. 
(c)  To accept signed complaints and allow the same to be signed and sworn to or affirmed before said clerk. 
(d)  To sign and issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses, and sign and issue subpoenas duces tecum. 
(e)  To accept the appearance, waiver of trial and plea of guilty and payment of fine and costs in traffic violation bureau cases, or, as directed by the municipal judge, generally act as violation clerk of the traffic violation bureau. 
(f)  To perform all duties as provided for by ordinance, by rules of practice and procedure adopted by the municipal judge and by the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts and by statute. 
(g)  To prepare and deliver or cause to be delivered dockets for all sessions of municipal court prior to the date of all such sessions, and prepare and deliver or cause to be delivered complete reports of the actions taken in all such sessions of the municipal court after each said session, and to keep and maintain a full and complete record thereof. 
(h)  To maintain a copy of the Code of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, and all amendments thereto, properly certified by the city clerk or the deputy city clerk, which shall constitute the prima facie evidence of such ordinances before the court. 
    The municipal court clerk shall be responsible for collecting all fines and costs as shall be assessed by the municipal court judge or provided for in the schedule of fines and costs of the traffic violations bureau and shall, immediately after collection of the same, pay to the director of finance the full amount of all fines collected pursuant to said court action of schedule of the traffic violations bureau. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-16. - Court costs-Generally. 
(a)  In addition to any fine which may be imposed by the municipal judge there shall be assessed as costs in all cases the following: 
(1)  Costs of the court in the amount of twelve dollars ($12.00). 
(2)  A fee of two dollars ($2.00) shall be assessed for the training of police officers as provided for in Ordinance No. 4000 of the City of Liberty, except in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court (RSMo 488.5336). 
(3)  A fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be assessed for the purpose of law enforcement training, as provided for in Ordinance 6676 of the City of Liberty, except in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court (RSMo 488.5336). 
(4)  A fee of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) for the crime victims' compensation fund established by the state, except in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court (RSMo 595.045.1). 
(5)  A fee of two dollars ($2.00) shall be assessed to be used for the inmate security fund. Funds deposited shall be used for the maintenance of a biometric verification system to properly identify and track inmates and to pay for any expenses related to custody and housing and other expenses for inmates, except in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court (RSMo 488.5026) 
(6)  A fee of three dollars ($3.00) shall be assessed for the sheriff's retirement fund established by the state, except in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court. 
(7)  A fee of four dollars ($4.00) shall be assessed for the domestic violence surcharge as established by the state (RSMo 488.607), except in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court. 
(8)  Actual costs assessed against the city by the county sheriff for housing prisoners in the county jail. 
(b)  Upon a plea of guilty, or a finding of guilty for any offense resulting from an arrest for violation of section 20-4, the court may, in addition to imposition of any penalties provided by law, order the convicted person to reimburse the city for costs associated with making such arrest. Such costs shall include the reasonable cost of making the arrest, including the cost of any chemical test made to determine the alcohol or drug content of the person's blood, and the costs of processing, charging, booking, and holding such person in custody. The city may establish a schedule of such costs; however, the court may order the costs reduced if it determines that the costs are excessive. Any costs assessed under this section shall be used solely for the training of police officers. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78; Ord. No. 5596,  1, 8-22-88; Ord. No. 6722,  1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. 7501,  I, 7-14-97; Ord. No. 8235,  I, 8-27-01; Ord. No. 9384,  I, 11-24-08; Ord. No. 10091,  I, 8-12-13; Ord. No. 10463,  I, 10-26-15; Ord. No. 10578,  I, 5-23-16) 
Sec. 10-17. - Same-Assessed against prosecuting witness. 
    When an action for violation of an ordinance is based upon an affidavit or complaint filed with the clerk of the municipal court, or delivered to the city prosecuting attorney, the person executing such affidavit or complaint shall be deemed the prosecuting witness; and in the event the defendant charged shall be acquitted, the costs of the action shall be assessed against the prosecuting witness who shall be liable therefor, but the city prosecuting attorney shall not be liable for such costs in any case. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-18. - Installment payment of fines. 
    When a fine is assessed for violating an ordinance, it should be within the discretion of the judge assessing the fine to provide for a payment of the fine under such terms and conditions as he may deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-19. - Penalties. 
    The municipal judge shall have the power to assess fines or jail sentences as provided in the Charter of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, or any and all applicable statutes of the State of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Charter reference- Punishment for misdemeanor, Art. VII,  26. 
Sec. 10-20. - Parole and probation. 
    Any judge hearing violations of municipal ordinances may, when in his judgment it shall seem advisable, grant a parole or probation to any person who shall plead guilty or who shall be convicted after trial before said judge. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-21. - Right of appeal. 
    The defendant shall have a right to a trial de novo, even from a plea of guilty, before a circuit judge or an associated circuit judge. Such application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten (10) days after the judgment and shall be in the form as provided by supreme court rules. 
Charter reference- Appeals to county court, Art. VII,  27, 28. 
Sec. 10-22. - Breach of recognizance. 
    In the case of a breach of any recognizance entered into before a municipal judge or an associate circuit judge hearing a municipal ordinance violation case, the same shall be deemed forfeited and the judge shall cause the same to be prosecuted against the principal and surety, or either of them, in the name of the municipality as plaintiff. Such action shall be prosecuted before a circuit judge or associate circuit judge, and in the event of cases cause to be prosecuted by a municipal judge, such shall be on the transcript of the proceedings before the municipal judge. All monies recovered in such action shall be paid over to the municipal treasury to the general revenue fund of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  2, 12-28-78) 
Sec. 10-23. - Failure to obey summons or to appear. 
    Any person who shall be duly served with a summons issued by the court or by any officer authorized to issue a summons and who shall fail or refuse to obey any of its terms and conditions, or who shall fail to appear at the place and at the time fixed therein, may be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and so punished. 
(Ord. No. 5230,  1, 10-27-86) 
Sec. 10-24. - Fee for plea of guilty or adjudicated as guilty. 
    An amount of one dollar ($1.00) per case for each municipal ordinance violation case filed in the City of Liberty municipal court and pled or adjudicated as guilty shall be collected according to RSMo 479.260 by the court clerk and shall be distributed to the city treasury. 
(Ord. No. 6941,  1, 11-28-94) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6941,  1, amended the Code by enacting provisions designated as  22-65. In order to keep related provisions together, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 6941 as  10-24. 
Chapter 11 - ELECTIONS[1]
