Sec. 11-1. - Ward boundaries. 
    The City of Liberty is hereby divided into four (4) wards as follows: 
    Ward 1: Beginning at the intersection of Mill Street and Harrison Avenue, thence east along Mill Street to its connection with the Richfield Road; thence southeast along Richfield Road to its intersection with the Rail Link Rail Road; thence southwest along the Rail Link Rail Road to its intersection with the prolongation of Richfield Road; thence east along Richfield Road to its intersection with the eastern city limits; thence northerly, westerly, and southerly along the city limits to its intersection with the prolongation of Nashua Road; thence southeasterly along the prolongation to Nashua Road and Nashua Road to its intersection with Morse Avenue; thence south along Morse Avenue to its intersection with Kansas Street; thence west along Kansas Street to its intersection with Harrison Avenue; thence southwest along Harrison Avenue to its intersection with Mill Street, point of beginning. 
    Ward 2: Beginning at the intersection of Mill Street & Harrison Avenue, thence easterly along Mill Street to its connection with Richfield Road; thence southeasterly along Richfield Road to its intersection with the I&M Rail Link, LLC Railroad; thence southwesterly along I&M Rail Link, LLC Railroad to its intersection with M-291 Highway; thence northwesterly along M-291 Highway to its intersection with West Liberty Drive; thence south and westerly on West Liberty Drive to its intersection with Kings Hwy; thence westerly along Kings Highway to its intersection with Dam Road; thence southwesterly along Dam Road to its intersection with Wilshire Boulevard; thence northwesterly along Wilshire Boulevard to South Stewart Road; thence northerly along South Stewart Road to the intersection of Kings Highway; thence westerly to the intersection of the westerly city limits; thence northerly and easterly along the city limits to its intersection with the northwesterly prolongation of Nashua Road; thence southeasterly along the northwesterly prolongation of Nashua Road to Nashua Road; thence southeasterly along Nashua Road to its intersection with Morse Avenue; thence southerly along Morse Avenue to its intersection with Kansas Street; thence westerly along Kansas Street to its intersection with Harrison Avenue; thence southwesterly along Harrison Avenue to its intersection with Mill Street, point of beginning. 
    Ward 3: Beginning at the intersection of M-291 Highway and Skyline Drive; thence northwesterly along M-291 Highway to its intersection with West Liberty Drive; thence south and westerly on West Liberty Drive to its intersection with Kings Hwy; thence westerly along Kings Highway to its intersection with Dam Road; thence southwesterly along Dam Road to its intersection with Wilshire Boulevard; thence northwesterly along Wilshire Boulevard to South Stewart Road; thence northerly along South Stewart Road to the intersection of Kings Highway; thence westerly to the intersection of the westerly city limits; thence southerly, easterly and northerly along the city limits to Birmingham Road; thence northerly along Birmingham Road to its intersection with Skyline Drive; thence northerly along Skyline Drive to its intersection with M-291 Highway, point of beginning. 
    Ward 4: Beginning at the intersection of 291 Highway and Skyline Drive, thence east along 291 Highway to its intersection with the Rail Link Rail Road; thence northeasterly along the Rail Link Rail Road to its intersection with Richfield Road; thence east along Richfield Road to its intersection the easterly city limits; thence southerly, westerly, northerly, and westerly along the city limits to its intersection with Birmingham Road; thence north along Birmingham Road to its intersection with Skyline Drive; thence north along Skyline Drive to its intersection with 291 Highway, point of beginning. 
(Ord. No. 2554,  3; Ord. No. 3160,  2; Ord. No. 4466,  1, 2, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 8297,  I, 1-7-02; Ord. No. 9283,  I, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 9894,  I, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 11-2. - Form of ballot, generally. 
    In all city elections, the Clay County Board of Election Commissioners shall print the official ballot, and be responsible for all absentee ballots, as provided for in Chapter 115, Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 2230,  1; Ord. No. 4062,  1, 1-8-79) 
Secs. 11-3, 11-4. - Reserved.

Sec. 11-5. - Procedure for swearing in newly elected officials. 
    At the first regularly scheduled meeting after each general city election, all city officials elected at such general city election shall assume their duties at that point in the city council proceedings or agenda immediately after approval of the previous council minutes, approval of the appropriations ordinance and certification of the results of the general city election. The outgoing city council shall transact no other items of business at such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2231,  2; Ord. No. 2665,  3; Ord. No. 3064,  2) 
Cross reference- Affidavits prerequisite to taking office,  2-27. 
Sec. 11-6. - General elections. 
    A general election for all elective offices of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri, shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April in each odd-numbered year, the same to be known as "municipal election day," at which election the qualified voters of the city shall elect a mayor, one council member from each ward, a city clerk, a city auditor, a city treasurer, and a constable, who shall hold their offices for a term of two (2) years and until their successors are elected and qualified; except that council members shall hold office for a term of four (4) years, as provided by Revised Statutes of Missouri, and the Code of the City of Liberty, Clay County, Missouri. All elections shall be conducted and returned as provided in RSMo Ch. 115 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, as amended. 
(R.O. 1931,  166; Ord. No. 4062,  3, 1-8-79; Ord. No. 7631, 4-13-98) 
Sec. 11-7. - Tie, etc., elections. 
    Whenever there shall be a tie vote in the election of members of the city council, or of clerk, treasurer, auditor or constable, the Clay County Board of Election Commissioners shall certify the same to the mayor, or person exercising the duties of mayor, who shall immediately thereupon issue his proclamation stating such facts and ordering a new election to be held on some day specified, which election shall be conducted and returned according to the provisions of Chapter 115, Revised Statutes of Missouri; and if such tie shall occur upon any election for mayor, said Clay County Board of Election Commissioners shall certify the same to the city council, and such council, after qualification, shall elect between such candidates having an equal number of votes; and, in the further event that neither of such candidates for mayor shall receive a majority of the votes of the council, a new election shall be conducted and returned according to the provisions of said Chapter 115 Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(R.O. 1931,  167; Ord. No. 4062,  4, 1-8-79) 
Sec. 11-8. - Vacancies in council, clerk, etc. 
    Whenever a vacancy shall occur in the city council or office of clerk, treasurer, auditor or constable of the city, by death, written resignation or otherwise, the same shall be filled by appointment by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, for the remainder of the unexpired term, except that should any such vacancy occur on the city council, or notice be given by an incumbent member of the city council that such vacancy shall occur in such office, not more than ninety (90) days prior to any regular city general election and not less than sixty (60) days prior to such regular city general election, candidates to fill such vacancy shall be placed on the ballot at said regular city general election and filled by such election for the remainder of the term, upon the occurrence of such vacancy or the date of such election, whichever shall last occur, and the same shall not be filled by such appointment. 
(3778; Ord. No. 4062,  5, 1-8-79) 
Sec. 11-9. - Procedure for filling vacancy in office of mayor. 
    When any vacancy shall happen in the office of mayor, by death, resignation or removal from the city, removal from office, refusal to qualify, or otherwise, the president pro tempore of the council shall, for the time being, perform the duties of mayor until such vacancy is filled; and in case of the temporary absence of the mayor or disability to perform the duties of his office, the president pro tempore of the council shall perform the duties of mayor until the mayor shall return or the disability is removed; and during the time the president pro tempore shall act as mayor, he shall receive the same compensation that the mayor would be entitled to. In case of a vacancy other than a temporary absence or disability, the person exercising the office of mayor shall cause a new election to be held, giving ten (10) days' notice thereof by proclamation published in some newspaper published in the city; provided, that when a vacancy occurs within six (6) months of a general city election, no election shall be called to fill such vacancy, and the president pro tempore of the council shall perform all the duties of the mayor until the successor is duly elected and qualified. 
(R.O. 1931,  169) 
Sec. 11-10. - Procedure for special elections. 
    When any special election shall be held or called for any purpose of the City of Liberty, such election shall be conducted and returned according to the provisions of RSMo Ch. 115. 
(1549; Ord. No. 4062,  6, 1-8-79) 
Sec. 11-11. - Vacancies arising from refusal to qualify or enter upon office. 
    If any person who may be elected to fill any city office shall fail, neglect or refuse to qualify or enter upon the discharge of his official duty within thirty (30) days after his election, the city council, at their first meeting next succeeding the expiration of such period or at any subsequent meeting, may declare such office vacant; and thereupon such vacancy shall be filled in the same way as vacancies arising from other causes. 
(R.O. 1931,  170) 
Sec. 11-12. - Filing period for candidates for municipal office. 
    The filing period for declarations of candidacy for municipal elections shall open at 8:00 a.m. on the fifteenth Tuesday prior to the date of the general election, and shall close at 5:00 p.m. on the eleventh Tuesday prior to the date of the general election. 
(Ord. No. 5597,  1, 8-22-88; Ord. No. 5805,  1, 9-11-89; Ord. No. 7298,  1, 8-12-96) 
Note- See the editor's note to  11-13-11-19. 
Secs. 11-13-11-19. - Reserved.

No. 4062,  7, adopted Jan. 8, 1979, repealed former  11-12-11-19, pertaining to polling places, judges, declaration of results, compensation for judges, procedure for placing names on ballots, conduct of election officers, voting by nonqualified voters and voting more than once. Said elections derived from R.O. 1931,  171-174, 177, 343, 344; Ord. No. 2229,  1; Ord. No. 2801,  2; Ord. No. 2805,  1, 2; Ord. No. 2806,  1. 
Chapter 12A - FAIR HOUSING 

Sec. 12A-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Chairman: The chairman of the fair housing and rehabilitation committee. 
    Committee: The fair housing and rehabilitation committee established as hereinafter provided. 
    Discriminatory housing practice: An act that is unlawful under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Dwelling: Any building, structure or portion thereof, located within the territorial limits of the city, which is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residence by one or more families, and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon of any such building, structure, or portion thereof. 
    Family: Includes a single individual. 
    Familial status: One or more individuals (who have not attained the age of eighteen (18) years) being domiciled with: 
(1)  A parent or another person having legal custody of such individual or individuals; or 
(2)  The designee of such parent or other person having such custody, with the written permission of such parent or other person. 
    Handicap: Means with respect to a person: 
(1)  A physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or more of such person's major life activities; 
(2)  A record of having such an impairment; or 
(3)  Being regarded as having such an impairment, but such term does not include current, illegal use of or addiction to a controlled substance (as defined in Section 102 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 802)). 
    Person: Includes one or more individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, labor organizations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint stock companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers and fiduciaries. 
    Rehabilitation: The refurbishing, repair, structural repair, renovation, painting, reworking, improving or otherwise bringing a dwelling as herein defined to a minimum average and acceptable quality or state of repair necessary to protect the health and safety of those dwelling within. 
    To rent: Includes to lease, sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
    To sell: Includes the transfer of deed of ownership of any dwelling for a consideration, subject to the exceptions in section 12A-3 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3680,  2; Ord. No. 6148,  I, 5-28-91) 
Sec. 12A-2. - Discrimination in sale or rental of housing. 
    Except as exempted by section 12A-3, it shall be unlawful for any person: 
(a)  To refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make available or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, sex, religion, national origin, familial status or handicap. 
(b)  To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provisions of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, sex, religion, national origin, familial status or handicap. 
(c)  To make, print, or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published any notice, statement, or advertisement, with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation, or discrimination based on race, color, sex, religion, national origin, familial status or handicap, or an intention to make any such preference, limitation, or discrimination. 
(d)  To represent to any person because of race, color, sex, religion, national origin, familial status or handicap that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale, or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available. 
(e)  For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a particular race, color, sex, religion, national origin, familial status or handicap. 
(Ord. No. 3680,  3; Ord. No. 6148,  II, 5-28-91) 
Sec. 12A-3. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Nothing in section 12A-2 (other than subsection (c)) shall apply to: 
(1)  Any single-family house sold or rented by an owner; provided that such house is sold or rented (a) without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent, or salesman, or of such facilities or services of any person in the business of selling or renting dwellings, or of any employee or agent of any such broker, agent, salesman, or person and (b) without the publication, posting or mailing, after notice, of any advertisement or written notice in violation of section 12A-2(c); but nothing in this proviso shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies, and other such professional assistance as necessary to perfect or transfer the title; provided further, that such private individual owner does not own more than three (3) such single-family houses at any one time; or 
(2)  Rooms or units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four (4) families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of such living quarters as his residence. 
(b)  For the purposes of subsection (a) a person shall be deemed to be in the business of selling or renting dwellings if: 
(1)  He has, within the preceding twelve (12) months participated as principal in three (3) or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any dwelling or any interest therein; or 
(2)  He has, within the preceding twelve (12) months, participated as agent, other than in the sale of his own personal residence in providing sales or rental facilities or sales or rental services in two (2) or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any dwelling or any interest therein; or 
(3)  He is the owner of any dwelling designed or intended for occupancy by, or occupied by, five (5) or more families. 
(c)  Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a religious organization, association, or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association, or society, from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, sex, national origin, familial status or handicap. Nor shall anything in this chapter prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or purposes provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members. 
(3680,  4; Ord. No. 6148,  III, 5-28-91) 
Sec. 12A-4. - Discrimination in financing of housing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise whose business consists in whole or in part in the making of commercial real estate loans, to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing, or maintaining a dwelling, or to discriminate against him in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration, or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance, because of the race, color, sex, religion, national origin, familial status or handicap of such person or of any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants, or occupants of the dwelling or dwellings in relation to such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given; provided that nothing contained in this section shall impair the scope or effectiveness of the exemptions contained in section 12A-3. 
(3680,  4; Ord. No. 6148,  IV, 5-28-91) 
Sec. 12A-5. - Discrimination in providing brokerage services. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple-listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization, or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate against him in the terms or conditions of such access, membership, or participation, on account of race, color, sex, religion, national origin, familial status or handicap. 
(3680,  6; Ord. No. 6148,  V, 5-28-91) 
Sec. 12A-6. - Fair housing and rehabilitation committee; establishment; terms of members; qualifications of members; quorum; special advisors. 
(a)  There is hereby established a fair housing and rehabilitation committee of nine (9) members, to be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the city council. 
(b)  All appointments shall be for terms of three (3) years, with not more than three (3) members' terms expiring in any one year, provided however that all members shall continue in office until their successors shall have been appointed, and provided also that the first fair housing and rehabilitation committee shall consist of the existing committee known previously as the human relations and minority group housing committee with existing expiration of terms. All vacancies on the committee, arising from death or resignation, shall be filled in the manner prescribed for new members. 
(c)  Members must possess the following qualifications: They shall be freeholders of the city and citizens of the United States, and have resided in this city for more than five (5) years, and shall be persons who have demonstrated an interest in the civic affairs of the community and in the preservation of peace, safety, health and welfare thereof. 
(d)  A quorum of five (5) members of the committee may perform its duty and may keep minutes and execute its reports in the name of the committee. At least five (5) votes must be cast in the majority for approval of any motion. 
The committee may, from time to time, invite special experience and knowledge to advise with them on specific questions. 
(3680,  7) 
Sec. 12A-6.1. - Purpose, powers, and duties of committee. 
    The purposes of the fair housing and rehabilitation committee shall be to promote, foster, encourage and stimulate understanding, harmonious relationship, a program of practical cooperation among all groups and individuals to the end that the city may grow and advance in peace and wholesome collective achievement, and in the field of individual opportunity. 
    The fair housing and rehabilitation committee is further authorized to: 
(a)  Devise and recommend to the mayor and city council ways and means of discouraging and combating prejudice, intolerance and bigotry in all groups and in their relations with one another. 
(b)  Discover all practices and policies which may create conflicts and tensions and recommend ways and means for their elimination. 
(c)  Report and recommend means of eliminating any unfair or unjust discrimination against any person or group. 
(d)  Inform and warn the public of false and sinister propaganda subversive to the public interest. As a part of its continuing program, it shall be the duty of the fair housing and rehabilitation committee to: 
1.  Enlist the cooperation of all racial, religious, educational, community, civic, labor, fraternal and benevolent associations and societies and all constructive community forces and talents that would be helpful in discharging its duties. 
2.  Cooperate with federal, state and city agencies, citizens' organizations, the board of education and parochial and private schools in formulating and developing courses of education to stimulate the interest of the entire population in accomplishing the objectives of the committee. 
3.  Receive and investigate complaints and initiate and conduct voluntary surveys; assemble pertinent data; confer with any and all groups; hold hearings; and, for expediting the work of the committee, to make investigations and surveys through subcommittees. 
4.  Receive and investigate applications under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 for rehabilitation of housing for low-income families as defined in the act. 
5.  Make recommendations for funding of rehabilitation for those dwellings which the committee, in its discretion, believes to be eligible for and in need of such funding. 
6.  From time to time make a report of its activities, together with recommendations, to the mayor and city council for the approval of the council. 
7.  Adopt rules for the transaction of business and keep a record of its activities and minutes of all meetings. 
(3680,  8) 
Sec. 12A-7. - Procedure after complaint of unfair housing practice. 
(a)  Any person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice, or who believes that he will be irrevocably injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur (hereafter "person aggrieved"), may file a complaint with the chairman. Complaints shall be in writing and shall contain such information and be in such form as the chairman requires. Upon receipt of such complaint the chairman shall furnish a copy of the same to the person or persons who allegedly committed or are about to commit the alleged discriminatory housing practice. Within thirty (30) days after receiving a complaint, the chairman shall cause the complaint to be investigated and give notice in writing to the person aggrieved whether he intends to resolve it. If the chairman decides to resolve the complaint, he shall proceed to try to eliminate or correct the alleged discriminatory housing practice by informal methods of conference, conciliation, and persuasion. Nothing said or done in the course of such informal endeavors may be made public or used as evidence in a subsequent proceeding under this chapter without the written consent of the persons concerned. Any member of the committee who shall make public any information in violation of this provision shall be deemed guilty of a violation and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70. 
(b)  A complaint under subsection (a) shall be filed within one hundred and eighty (180) days after alleged discriminatory housing practice occurred. Complaints shall be in writing and shall state the facts upon which the allegations of a discriminatory housing practice is based. Complaints may be reasonably and fairly amended at any time. A respondent may file an answer to the complaint against him and with the leave of the chairman, which shall be granted whenever it would be reasonable and fair to do so, may amend his answer at any time. Both complaints and answers shall be verified. 
(c)  After chairman's investigation and attempted conciliation, but within fifteen (15) days of the filing of the complaints, if, in the judgement of the complainant, the complaint is substantial and conciliation has not occurred, the chairman shall refer the complaint, together with a full report of his activities in connection therewith, to the committee. 
(d)  Upon referral of a complaint from the chairman, the committee shall promptly set a date for hearing of the matters alleged in such complaint and subsequent occurring related matters; such hearings shall occur in a designated location not more than thirty (30) days after the date on which the chairman shall have so referred such complaint, but only after giving at least five (5) days prior written notice to the person or persons who allegedly committed or are about to commit the alleged unfair housing practice. 
(e)  For purposes of such hearing the committee shall have the power, at the request of the person aggrieved, or the person or persons who allegedly committed or are about to commit the alleged unfair housing practice, or upon its own motion to issue process and compel the attendance of any person or witness, together with books, papers and other documents; such process shall be executed by the chief of police and shall be enforced as in all cases of city ordinance violations; such hearings shall be conducted in a fair and impartial manner according to the rules adopted by the committee; the proof of the matters contained within the complaint may be presented by the city attorney at the hearing, upon request of the committee; the person aggrieved and the person or persons who allegedly committed or are about to commit the alleged unfair housing practice may appear with legal counsel and shall have the right to present proof and cross-examine witnesses in all matters relating to the complaint and subsequent related occurrences. A complete account to these hearings must be preserved but may not be made public. 
(f)  After such hearing, if a majority of the committee shall be convinced by the evidence upon the hearing that the complaint is well-founded, the committee shall forthwith, by persuasion, education and entreaty diligently attempt to secure with a reasonable time, voluntary discontinuance of the violation complained of. 
(g)  The committee, as it appears to the best interest of discovery of the truth of the complaint and effectuating a conciliation, may at its discretion, conduct the hearing and conciliation discussions in private or public. 
(h)  The committee, upon either the request of the person aggrieved or the person or persons who allegedly committed or are about to commit the alleged unfair housing practice, and upon the posting of reasonable security for the payment of costs thereof, or upon its own motion, shall secure the attendance of a proceedings reporter at the hearing for the purpose of recording the proceedings at the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2793,  9) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4956, adopted April 22, 1985, provided that the penalty set out in  22-70 was to supersede and amend all previously enacted ordinances for which the penalty was a fine not exceeding $90.00. Therefore, the section above has been changed to provide a reference to  22-70. 
Sec. 12A-8. - Enforcement by city attorney. 
(a)  The committee, in the event of failure to secure voluntary compliance with the requirements of this chapter, shall cause the chairman thereof to certify, in writing, to the city attorney that all reasonable efforts of the committee to secure conciliation are concluded in the matter, and the committee shall, with such certification transmit the committee file, the transcript of the hearing, if any, and in all other respects cooperate with the city attorney. 
(b)  Upon certification by the committee, the city attorney may, if in his judgment the violation appears clear and the proof thereof available, institute a charge in the police [municipal] court against the alleged violator and prosecute the same to final conclusion. 
(Ord. No. 2793,  10) 
Sec. 12A-9. - Penalty-Contemptuous conduct. 
    Any person who willfully fails to attend a committee hearing and testify or to answer any lawful inquiry at such hearing, or there to produce records, documents or other evidence, if in his power to do so in obedience to the subpoena or lawful order of the committee, shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70. 
(Ord. No. 2793,  11)

Therefore, the section above has been changed to provide a reference to  22-70. 
Sec. 12A-10. - Same-Falsifying statements or documents. 
    Any person who, with intent thereby to mislead the committee shall make or cause to be made any false entry or statement of fact in any report, account, record or other document submitted to the committee pursuant to its subpoena or lawful order, or shall willfully neglect or fail to make or cause to be made full, true and correct entries in such reports, accounts, records, or other documents, or shall willfully mutilate, alter, or by any other means falsify any documentary evidence, or shall willfully make a false complaint or give false testimony at any hearing of the committee, shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70. 
(Ord. No. 2793,  12)

Sec. 12A-11. - Same-Violation of section 12A-2, 12A-4 or 12A-5. 
    Any person who shall commit a discriminatory housing practice in violation of section 12A-2, 12A-4 or 12A-5 shall, upon conviction therefor, be punished for each such violation as prescribed in section 22-70. 
    Upon conviction of any violation of the provisions of section 12A-2, 12A-4 or 12A-5, in addition to the penalties provided above, the license of such person to do business in this city shall be suspended for thirty (30) days, and upon a third conviction of any violation of such sections, the license of such person to do business in this city shall be revoked.

Chapter 13 - FINANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6867,  1, adopted July 25, 1994, amended Ch. 13,  13-1-13-18, to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance,  13-1-13-7 pertained to similar provisions and derived from Revised Ordinances of 1931,  14-16; Ord. No. 2125; Ord. No. 2410; Ord. No. 2889; and Ord. 2898. 
Charter reference- Bonded indebtedness, Art. III,  2; payment of current expenses, Art. III,  3; annual financial statement, Art. VII,  1. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; city treasurer,  2-46 et seq.; taxation, Ch. 27. 

Sec. 13-1. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the City of Liberty shall be from January 1 to December 31. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-2. - Policy statement. 
    It is the policy of the city to invest public funds in a manner which insures maximum security of principal; produces optimal investment returns; meets daily cash flow requirements; and conforms to all state and city ordinances governing the investment of public funds. 
    The city will concentrate its investment efforts in local banks, primary dealers or state investment pools located within the State of Missouri, which are under the Missouri statutes for public funds. 
    In order to maximize funds available for investment, all funds received by the finance department are to be deposited at least once each day as such funds are received. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-3. - Scope. 
    This investment policy applies to all financial assets of the city. These funds are accounted for in the city comprehensive annual financial report and include: 
(1)  General funds. 
(2)  Special revenue funds. 
(3)  Debt service funds. 
(4)  Capital projects funds. 
(5)  Trust and agency funds. 
(6)  Enterprise funds. 
(7)  Internal service funds. 
    Funds will be invested and collateralized in compliance with the provisions of RSMo 110.010 and 110.020. Investments will be in accordance with written policies and administrative procedures. Investment of all funds will comply with federal legislation and regulations governing reinvestment of proceeds and arbitrage. Earnings from investments will be used in a manner that will best serve the interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-4. - Prudence. 
    The standards of prudence to be used by investment officials is the "prudent person" and will be applied in the context of managing an overall portfolio. This standard states that investments shall be made with judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs, not for speculation, but for investment, considering the probable safety of their capital as well as the probable income to be derived. 
    The investment officer and staff, acting in accordance with written procedures and exercising due diligence will be relieved of personal responsibility for an individual security's credit risk or market price changes, provided deviations from expectations are reported timely and appropriate action is taken to control adverse developments. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-5. - Objectives. 
    The city's investment objectives are: 
(1)  Safety: As custodians of the public trust, preservation of capital and the protection of investment principal shall be the primary objective. In order to maintain this objective, diversification is required to avoid incurring unreasonable risks regarding specific security types and individual financial institutions. Investments shall be made in conformance with federal, state and other legal requirements. 
(2)  Liquidity: Maintenance of sufficient liquidity to meet operating requirements. 
(3)  Yield: Attainment of a market rate of return throughout budgetary and economic cycles, acknowledging the city's investment risk constraints and the cash flow characteristics of the portfolio. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-6. - Delegation of authority. 
    The director of finance is designated as the investment officer of the city, and will be responsible for managing and establishing written procedures consistent with this investment policy. Such procedures shall include explicit delegation of authority to persons responsible for investment transactions, including requirements for safekeeping; repurchase agreements; wire transfer agreements; collateral/depository agreements and banking service contracts. No person may engage in an investment transaction except as provided under the terms of this policy and the procedures established by the director of finance. The director of finance shall be responsible for all transactions undertaken and shall establish a system of controls to regulate the activities of subordinate officials. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-7. - Ethics and conflicts of interest. 
    Employees of the finance department shall refrain from personal business activity that could conflict with the proper execution of the investment program or would impair their ability to make impartial investment decisions. Personal investment transactions shall be subordinate to those of the city and a full disclosure to the city council is required for any personal investments related to the performance of the city's portfolio. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-8. - Authorized financial dealers and institutions. 
    Financial dealers will be selected, based on the credit-worthiness of the institutions, after a comprehensive review of the prospective dealers' characteristics and financial history. Dealers shall be selected from primary dealers or regional banks, located within the Kansas City metropolitan area, who will be asked to provide their more recent statement of financial condition at the request of the city. The director of finance will maintain a list of qualified bidders which will be reviewed and evaluated, at minimum, on a quarterly basis. 
    The selection of a primary depository shall be made in compliance with section 95.355, Revised Statutes of Missouri. In order to maximize investment capabilities and minimize banking costs, centralization of deposits in a primary banking institution will be maintained. At the direction of the city council, the investment officer shall prepare a request for proposal and solicit competitive bids for banking services. The city council will select a depository upon recommendation by the investment officer. 
    Any contract or banking services shall not exceed five (5) years and must be reviewed annually. The city council shall adopt an ordinance designating a bank as the primary depository and authorizing the investment staff to do business with that institution during the contract period. Special banking needs may be contracted for by the city, outside this policy, if approved by the investment officer. If a depositor does not meet the city's standards of financial stability by maintaining a Sheshunoff bank rating of at least a "B", the bank will be required to come into compliance within six (6) months or lose the depository contract. 
    The city shall limit trading to organizations that require a written agreement for their records of individuals authorized to transact business for the city. The city trading authorization will designate the assistant to the director of finance or designated investment staff as authorized to invest for the city. The investment officer, city administrator or assistant city administrator are authorized to sign all investment related agreements on behalf of the city. 
    Before accepting city funds, all financial institutions/dealers must agree to undertake reasonable efforts to preclude imprudent transactions and certify compliance with this investment policy and pertinent state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 7577,  I, 12-8-97) 
Sec. 13-9. - Authorized and suitable investments. 
    Assets of funds of the city may be invested in: 
(1)  U.S. Treasury bills. Short-term obligations of the United States government, issued and sold at a discount. 
(2)  U.S. Treasury notes and bonds. Obligations of the United States government issued with a fixed coupon rate. 
(3)  Collateralized public deposits (negotiable certificates of deposit). Instruments issued by financial institutions (banks) that state specified sums have been deposited for specified periods of time and at specified rates of interest. The certificates of deposit are to be backed by acceptable collateral securities as dictated by state and local law. The right of substitution of collateral may be granted to the financial institution upon approval by the investment officer. Interest will be calculated on a three hundred sixty-five-day year/actual-day month basis, or another method approved by the investment officer in writing. 
(4)  Federal home loan bank discount notes. Consolidated obligations of the twelve (12) district banks, issued on a discount basis. 
(5)  Federal national mortgage association discount notes. Obligations of the association, issued on a discount basis. 
(6)  Federal home loan mortgage corporation discount notes. Obligations of the corporation, issued on a discount basis. 
(7)  Repurchase agreements. Contractual agreements, authorized by a signed master repurchase agreement, with primary dealers and nationally supervised commercial banks, collateralized by U.S. Treasury securities or U.S. government agency instrumentality securities which are marked-to market. 
(8)  Government investment pools. Repurchase and reverse repurchase agreements, authorized by a signed master repurchase agreement, collateralized by the investment instruments listed above. 
(9)  Other securities. Securities not specifically mentioned, but which are listed in RSMo 30.270 and other enabling state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-10. - Collateral requirements. 
    Collateral will be required on all city investments and funds on deposit with the depository bank, other than investments which are obligations of the United States government and its agencies, in compliance with RSMo 110.010. The city considers repurchase/reverse repurchase agreements as simultaneous sales and purchases of securities rather than as collateralized loans. The purchases of securities underlying repurchase agreements will be referred to as "collateral" in this investment policy. 
    The financial institution/dealer will be required to provide delivery of securities pledged as collateral to the city in bearer form, book entry form, or fully-registered certificates in a third party nominee name, marked as "pledged to the City of Liberty." 
    In compliance with RSMo 110.020, the city's depository bank shall be required to ensure there is one hundred (100) per cent collateral on all city funds at the time of delivery to the institution. The depository is required to pledge collateral securities with a market value of at least one hundred (100) per cent of the amount deposited plus any accrued interest, less the amount which is an insured deposit pursuant to the Federal Deposit Insurance Act of 1950 (64 Stat. 873) as heretofore or hereafter amended. The banking institution may choose to collateralize the prior day's balance of deposits plus any accrued interest with securities whose market value is at least one hundred ten (110) per cent of those amounts. 
    Repurchase agreement collateral must be maintained at a market value with a minimum of one hundred (100) per cent of the par value plus any accrued interest. 
    The following securities are hereby designated as acceptable collateral for city funds: 
(1)  Marketable treasury securities of the United States. 
(2)  General obligation debt securities issued by the State of Missouri. 
(3)  General obligation bonds of any city in this state having a population of not less than two thousand (2,000). 
(4)  General obligation bonds of any county in this state. 
(5)  General obligation bonds approved and registered, of any school district situated in this state. 
(6)  General obligation bonds approved and registered, of any special road or hospital district situated in this state. 
(7)  General obligation state bonds of any of the fifty (50) states. 
(8)  Debt securities of federal agencies allowed by RSMo 30.270, and other enabling state statutes. 
    Note: No revenue bonds of any kind will be accepted under sections 13-1 to 13-10. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-11. - Safekeeping and custody. 
    All securities pledged as collateral to the city shall be deemed purchased securities and will be held by the city in the finance department or a designated independent third-party custodian with whom the city has a current custodial agreement. 
    The third-party custodian will hold securities pledged to the city in an account in the city's name. A clearly marked evidence of ownership (safekeeping receipt) must be supplied to the city. Purchase or sale of a security will be on a delivery versus payment basis, with title to the security passing to the city when funds are transferred to the banker/dealer. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-12. - Diversification. 
    It is the policy of the city to diversify its investment portfolios by security type, institution/dealer and maturity. Assets held in the cash fund and other investment funds shall be diversified to eliminate the risk of loss resulting from over-concentration of assets in a specific maturity, a specific issuer or a specific class of securities. 
    With the exception of U.S. Treasury securities, government pools collateralized by U.S. Treasury securities and repurchase agreements, no more than fifty (50) per cent of the entity's total investment portfolio will be deposited with a single financial institution/primary dealer. Repurchase agreements shall not exceed twenty-five (25) per cent of the city's total portfolio on any one day, unless the director of finance makes an exception. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-13. - Maximum maturities. 
    Maturity limitations will depend upon whether the funds being invested are considered short-term to meet cash flow requirements or long-term funds reserved for capital projects (i.e., bond sale proceeds). Investments shall be limited to maturities not exceeding three (3) years, except for special situations as directed by the director of finance. This policy limits principal risk caused by changes in interest rates or longer maturities. 
    The city must collateralize repurchase agreements using securities with maturities which do not exceed three (3) years. Funds may be invested in longer maturities, and other secured instruments upon adoption of a motion of authorization by the majority of the city council at a regular or special public meeting. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-14. - Internal control. 
    The director of finance will establish a system of internal controls, documented in writing, to assure compliance with state laws, policies, and procedures. 
    In order to protect against collusion, the director of finance will assign separate responsibility for operational functions from those of financial record keeping. The director of finance, as investment officer, will have authority to approve all decisions relating to investment of idle funds but will not have access to those assets, or be responsible for recording transactions in the general ledger. It will be the director of finance's responsibility to test actual results against budgeted expectations and the results of other governmental entities. Detection controls will include monthly bank account reconciliation, reconciliation of securities held by the city, and an independent test of performance with a segregation of duties assigned to accounting personnel. 
    These controls shall be designed to prevent loss of public funds due to fraud, employee error, misrepresentation by third parties, unanticipated changes in financial markets, or imprudent actions by employees and officers of the city. Internal controls will be reviewed for effectiveness annually by an independent auditor. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-15. - Performance standards. 
    The investment portfolio will be designed to obtain a market average rate of return during budgetary and economic cycles, taking into account the city's investment risk constraints and cash flow needs. Performance statistics will include comparison of yields to average ninety-day and one hundred eighty-day treasury bill rates. Results of the comparisons will be weighted against cash flow requirements during the investment period. Interest income shall be evaluated using these indices and the overall investment objectives as outlined in this investment policy and adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-16. - Reporting. 
    Quarterly reports will be prepared by the investment staff for council review. In addition, the director of finance will be provided monthly reports which will include data on investments being held in the portfolio and returns on the investments. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-17. - Investment policy adoption. 
    The city's investment policy shall be adopted by resolution of the city council. The policy shall be reviewed on an annual basis by the director of finance and any modifications made thereto must be approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Sec. 13-18. - Award of bids. 
    The city council hereafter reserves the right to reject any bid received by them or defer action on awarding any bid of any kind received by them until the next regularly scheduled city council meeting or any special city council meeting called by the mayor. 
    The intent of this section shall be included in whole or part in any proposed invitation for bids prepared by the city. 
(Ord. No. 6867,  1, 7-25-94) 
Chapter 14 - FIRE PROTECTION[1]

ARTICLE I. - INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10021,  I, adopted Feb. 11, 2013, amended the provisions of former Art. I,  14-1-14-8, in their entirety which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the following:

Sec. 14-1. - Adopted. 
    The provisions of the International Fire Code, 2012 edition, including appendix as reference, is for all intents and purposes incorporated in this chapter as though more fully set out herein, except as stated below, and is hereby adopted as the official fire code of the city, and all provisions thereof shall be in full force and effect in this city in the form of that particular and specific printed volume to be permanently retained as a part of the official records of this city on file in the office of the deputy city clerk and to be construed, applied and enforced, as modified and supplemented as follows: 
(1)  As modified by other provisions of chapter 14, article I of the Liberty City Code. 
(2)  All portions of said International Fire Code identified in section 14-3 as exclusions below are not so included herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 10021,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 14-2. - Revisions. 
    The following shall be included as a revision to the fire code adopted in section 14-1: 
(1)  Section 510. All new buildings shall have approved radio coverage for emergency responders within the building based upon existing coverage levels of the public safety communication system. 
(Ord. No. 10021,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 14-3. - Exclusions. 
    The following shall be excluded from the fire code adopted in section 14-1: 
(1)  Section 1103.2 Emergency Responder Radio Coverage; 
(2)  Section 1103.9 Carbon Monoxide Detectors; 
(3)  Section 1104.24 Egress Path Markings. 
(Ord. No. 10021,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 14-4. - Board of appeals. 
    Unless an appeal procedure is otherwise specifically provided, appeals shall be to the board of appeals. In order to determine the suitability of alternate materials and type of construction and to provide for reasonable interpretations of the provisions of the codes herein, appeals may be taken to the board of appeals established under chapter 6, section 6-38, of the Liberty City Code. 
(Ord. No. 10021,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 14-5. - Penalties. 
    It is a misdemeanor for any person, firm, corporation, public utility, or government agency to violate, omit, neglect, or refuse to comply with, or resist enforcement of, any provisions of the fire code or chapter 14 of the Liberty City Code. Any such person, firm, corporation, public utility, or government agency found in violation of the fire code of chapter 14 of the Liberty City Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70 of the Liberty City Code for each violation. Each day in which such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10021,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 14-6. - Obstruction of fire hydrants. 
    It shall be unlawful to place or park or allow to be placed or parked any vehicle within an area of five (5) feet on each side of a fire hydrant or any other fire protection system control valve. 
(Ord. No. 10021,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 14-7. - Crossing or driving over fire hose. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive or allow to be driven any vehicle over any unprotected hose of any fire department when laid down on any street, alley, or private way to be used at any fire, or alarm of fire, or other emergency, without the consent of the fire department official in charge. 
(Ord. No. 10021,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 14-8. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 14-9. - Annual inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department or his authorized agent to inspect or examine all places of business for fire hazards and life safety hazards annually and to notify the owner or occupant of any building wherein any such dangerous conditions exist to correct said conditions within a specified time as shall be determined by the chief of the fire department or his said authorized agent. Should such conditions not be corrected within the specified time, any such owner or occupant shall be subject to summons into municipal court and the payment of fines or penalties for maintaining a public hazard. Every day that any such hazard shall continue, beyond the time limit specified, shall be considered a new violation. 
(Ord. No. 5086,  2, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 14-10. - Authority to enter buildings for purpose of inspection. 
    The chief of the fire department or his authorized agent shall be permitted by the owner, lessee, manager or operator of any building or premises at all reasonable hours for the purpose of making any inspection or investigation provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 5086,  2, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 14-11. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPEN BURNING 

Sec. 14-12. - Open burning. 
    Except for the exceptions provided in Section 14-13, no person, firm or corporation may conduct, cause, permit or allow open burning or refuse, a salvage operation by open burning, or the disposal of trade wastes by open burning. Violation hereof shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 5086,  3, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 14-13. - Open burning permitted. 
    There is hereby excepted from the application of Section 14-12 the following, and none other: 
(a)  The opening burning of trade wastes and vegetation may be permitted only upon prior application to and approval by the executive secretary of the state air conservation commission, as required and provided by state law and valid regulations thereunder. 
(b)  The open burning of tree trunks, tree limbs, vegetation or untreated waste lumber shall be permitted when such burning takes place at the site of a disposal area license for that purpose under the provision of RSMo 64.470, or at any other site approved by the executive secretary of the state air conservation commission. 
(c)  Burning by fires set in connection with agricultural operations relating to the growing or harvesting of crops, and for this purpose only. Botanical nursery operations shall not be considered agricultural operations. 
(d)  The burning of gaseous trade wastes, refinery or industrial chemical safety flares and full smokeless-tip combustion, steam addition or other flare smoke control methods approved by the executive secretary of the state air conservation commission, such approval having been first obtained and used, and the emissions to be not of a shade or density in violation of applicable state law and valid regulations. 
(e)  Fires used for recreational purposes, or fires used for noncommercial preparation of food such as by barbecuing. 
(f)  Fires set for the purpose of instruction and training fire-fighters in methods of fighting fires shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 5086,  3, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 14-14. - Attending open fires. 
    Any burning permitted within the meaning of the exceptions in Section 14-13 shall be constantly attended by competent persons until completely extinguished. 
(Ord. No. 5086,  3, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 14-15. - Orders prohibiting fires. 
    The chief of the fire department may prohibit any or all bonfires and outdoor rubbish fire when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous. 
(Ord. No. 5086,  3, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 14-16. - Penalties. 
    Any person determined to be in any way in violation of any provisions of this chapter shall be subject to penalties as provided in the Charter of the City of Liberty. 
(Ord. No. 5086,  3, 12-23-85) 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC ACCESS DEFIBRILLATOR PROGRAM 

Sec. 14-17. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Public Access Defibrillator Program Code." 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-18. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this code to create the public access defibrillator program and establish guidelines for use, training, and data collection, as well as requirements and procedures for implementing and using automated external defibrillators (AED's) within this program. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-19. - Definitions. 
(a)  Authorized user means any person who has met the training standards of this code, and is authorized to use the Automated External Defibrillators (AED's) by the medical director and program manager. 
(b)  Automated external defibrillator or AED means an external defibrillator capable of cardiac rhythm analysis that will charge and, with or without further operator action, deliver a shock after electronically detecting that a "shockable rhythm" is present. 
(c)  Director means the EMS director of the Liberty Fire Department or persons to whom the director has delegated duties imposed by this code. 
(d)  Health care facility means a hospital, nursing home, physician's office or other fixed location at which medical and health care services are performed. 
(e)  Medical director means a physician authorized by the State of Missouri to permit individuals to operate an AED and who develops, implements and maintains the medical control provisions of this code and the regulations promulgated pursuant to this code. 
(f)  Program manager means a person who works with the medical director to oversee the administration of the Public Access Defibrillation (PAD) program at specific sites within Liberty. 
(g)  Public access defibrillation or PAD means the utilization of AEDs by rescuers to treat victims of cardiac arrest in public or private places, including first aid providers at public events not associated with the pre-hospital emergency medical services provider for the city, staff of nursing homes not otherwise exempt by this code, and similar activities. 
(h)  PAD site means the agency, business, organization, or other entity that sponsors a PAD program and allows placement of an AED on its premises. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-20. - Exceptions. 
    The following entities or persons are exempt from the provisions of this code: 
(1)  Hospitals. Hospitals licensed by the State of Missouri. 
(2)  Physicians. Persons licensed by the state of Missouri as a physician pursuant to Chapter 334, RSMo. 
(3)  Nurses. Persons licensed by the state of Missouri as a nurse pursuant to Chapter 335, RSMo. 
(4)  Mutual aid providers. Persons working for ambulance services, fire departments or other EMS agencies that are called into the city to provide mutual aid to the city's pre-hospital emergency medical services. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-21. - Use of AEDs. 
    No entity or person shall begin a public access defibrillator program after October 31, 2002, unless the EMS director certifies the program. Public access defibrillator programs operating on October 31, 2002, may operate for one year from that date without being certified by the director. Thereafter, the director shall certify all public access defibrillator programs. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-22. - EMS director duties. 
(a)  Adopt regulations. The director shall adopt regulations necessary to implement a public access defibrillator program within the authorization of this code, Missouri law and regulations, and current medical standards for the use of AEDs and prompt treatment of people suffering cardiac arrest. 
(b)  Authorized programs. The director shall maintain a list of authorized programs reflecting their intent to operate a PAD program pursuant to this code. 
(c)  Public access defibrillation programs. The director shall maintain a list of PAD program sites. 
(d)  Audit. The director shall have the right to audit any use of an AED. The director may review maintenance and repair records, training records, medical director agreements, reports of cardiopulmonary resuscitation or AED use, and any other records necessary to determine compliance with the terms of the PAD program. An audit, or quality assurance review, may include gathering clinical data and information from the person who used the AED, and from the AED itself. 
(e)  Delegation. The director may delegate duties to appropriate personnel, including the medical director of the pre-hospital emergency medical services system working through the director's office, the emergency physicians advisory board, or other persons or entities determined by the director to be qualified to oversee the operations of PAD programs. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-23. - PAD program duties. 
(a)  Training. Any person, business or institution acquiring an AED will authorize the use of the AED only by persons who have received training by the American Heart Association or American Red Cross, or an equivalent nationally recognized course approved by the director including the identification of cardiac arrest, administration of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, and the use of AEDs. 
(b)  Maintenance and testing. Any person, business or institution acquiring an AED will maintain and test the unit according to the manufacturer's operational guidelines. Records of maintenance and testing will be made available to the director upon request. 
(c)  Notification of use of the AED. Any person, business or institution that renders emergency care or treatment on a person by using an AED must notify the EMS system through proper use of the 9-1-1 system or other means to seek pre-hospital emergency medical services. 
(d)  Medical control. Any person, business or institution acquiring an AED for use outside a health care facility shall have an authorized physician provide the medical protocol for the use of the device. Protocols will be made available to the director upon request. 
(e)  Cooperation with the director. A person, business or institution acquiring an AED and the user of an AED will fully cooperate with the director in any audit or other quality assurance review, including the retrieval of clinical data from the device itself by the director. 
(f)  List of authorized users. A PAD program will maintain a list of the persons participating in the program reflecting the persons' training and qualifications. This list will subject to audit by the director. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-24. - Certification of participants in a PAD program. 
(a)  EMS director duties. The director shall establish criteria for the certification of AED programs. 
(b)  Periodic certification. The director is authorized to require recertification of the program at intervals established by regulation. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-25. - Violations. 
    It is unlawful to: 
(1)  Fail to cooperate with the director in the investigation, audit or other review of the use of an AED; or 
(2)  Fail to make the AED available to the director for the recovery of data; or 
(3)  Fail to properly maintain and test an AED made available for use; or 
(4)  Fail to relinquish control of patient care to appropriately licensed members of the City of Liberty pre-hospital emergency medical services system upon their arrival. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 14-26. - Severability. 
    Should any portion of this code [article] be held invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions of this code shall remain in effect. 
(Ord. No. 8430,  I, 5-14-02) 
Chapter 15 - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses and occupations generally, Ch. 7; Unsanitary conditions as nuisances,  21-2; commercial and industrial wastewater,  29-66 et seq. 
State Law reference- Sanitation in food-handling establishments, RSMo 196.190 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Close. A suspension of business. 
    Food. All articles used for food, drink, confectionery condiment, whether simple, mixed or compound, and all substances or ingredients used in the preparation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  1, 12) 
Sec. 15-2. - Storing, exhibiting, selling, etc., food from trucks, etc., prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall store, exhibit or sell any food on or from a truck or any vehicle, or on or from any open stand, basket or on the ground; except, that a person may sell produce raised by him on his own property for a period of thirty days after such food is ready for human consumption. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  13) 
Sec. 15-3. - Sanitary requirements-Generally. 
    Every building, room, basement or cellar occupied or used as a bakery, confectionery, cannery, packinghouse, slaughterhouse, restaurant, hotel, dining car, grocery, meat market, dairy, creamery, butter factory, cheese factory, or other place or apartment used for the preparation for manufacture, packing, storage, sale or distribution of any food, shall be properly lighted, drained, plumbed and ventilated and conducted with strict regard to the influence of such condition upon the health of the operatives, employees, clerks or other persons therein employed, and the purity and wholesomeness of the food therein produced. 
    The premises around any building under control of the operator or his lessor, where food is stored or prepared for sale or sold shall be kept free and clear of all trash, debris, garbage, filth, boxes and paper. No animals shall be kept on such premises. The premises shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  1, 14) 
Sec. 15-4. - Same-Ceilings of bakeries, etc. 
    The ceilings of every bakery, confectionery, hotel and restaurant kitchen shall be well plastered, wainscoted or ceiled with metal or lumber and shall be oil painted or kept well limed washed, and all interior woodwork in every bakery, confectionery, hotel, dining car and restaurant kitchen shall be kept well oiled or painted with oil paints, and be kept washed clean with soap and water, and every building, room, basement or cellar, occupied or used for the preparation, manufacture, packing, storage, sale or distribution of food shall have an impermeable floor made of cement or tile laid in cement, brick, wood or other suitable nonabsorbent material which can be flushed and washed clean with water. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  3) 
Sec. 15-5. - Same-Fly screen required. 
    The doors, windows and other openings of every food producing or distributing establishment, during the fly season, shall be fitted with self-closing screen doors and wire window screens of not coarser than 14-mesh wire gauge. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  4) 
Sec. 15-6. - Same-Toilet rooms. 
    Every building, room, basement or cellar, occupied or used for the preparation, manufacture, packing, canning, sale or distribution of food, shall have convenient toilet or toilet rooms, separate and apart from the room where the process of production, manufacture, packing, canning, selling or distributing is conducted. 
    The floors of such toilet rooms shall be of cement, tile, wood, brick or other nonabsorbent material and shall be furnished with separate ventilating flush or pipes, discharging into soil pipes, or on outside of the building in which they are situated. 
    Lavatories and washrooms shall be adjacent to toilet rooms, and shall be supplied with soap, running water and towels, and shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
    Operatives, employees, clerks and all other persons who handle the material from which food is prepared, or the finished product, before beginning work or after visiting toilets, shall wash their hands and arms thoroughly with soap and clean water. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  5) 
Sec. 15-7. - Unsanitary conditions enumerated. 
    The floors, sidewalks, ceilings, lockers, closets, furniture, receptacles, implements and machinery of every establishment or place where food is manufactured, packed, stored, sold or distributed, and all cars, trucks and vehicles used in the transportation of food products, shall at no time be kept in an unclean, unhealthy or insanitary condition, and for the purpose of this article, unclean, unhealthful and insanitary conditions shall be deemed to exist: 
(a)  If food in the process of manufacture, preparation, packing, storing, sale, distribution or transportation is not securely protected from flies, dust, dirt and, as far as may be necessary, by all reasonable means from all other foreign or injurious contamination; and, 
(b)  If the refuse, dirt and waste products, subject to decomposition and fermentation, incident to the manufacture, preparation, packing, storing, selling, distributing and transporting of food, are not removed daily; and, 
(c)  If all trucks, trays, boxes, baskets, buckets and other receptacles, chutes, platforms, racks, tables, troughs, shelves and all knives, saws, cleavers and other utensils and machinery used in moving, handling, cutting, chopping, mixing, canning and all other processes are not fairly cleaned daily; and, 
(d)  If the clothing of operatives, employees, clerks or other persons therein employed is unclean. 
    The placing of vinegar or other liquid, used as food or drink, in open vessels without covering the same is forbidden. The use of secondhand bottles for vinegar or other liquids, used as food or drink, is forbidden unless the same are first sterilized with live steam. 
    The sidewalk display of food products is prohibited unless such products are enclosed in a showcase or similar device, which will protect the same from flies, dust or other contamination. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  2) 
Sec. 15-8. - Use of bake shops, etc., for sleeping purposes prohibited. 
    No person shall be allowed to live or sleep in any room of a bakeshop, kitchen, dining room, confectionery or place where food is prepared, served or sold. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  6) 
Sec. 15-9. - Employing personnel suffering from certain diseases prohibited. 
    No employer shall require, permit or suffer any person to work, nor shall any person work, in a building, room, basement, cellar or vehicle occupied or used for the production, preparation, manufacture, packing, storage, sale, distribution and transportation of food, who is affected with any venereal disease, smallpox, diphtheria, scarlet fever, yellow fever, tuberculosis or consumption, bubonic plague, Asiatic cholera, eczema or other skin diseases, leprosy, eye disease, typhoid fever (epidemic), epidemic dysentery, measles, mumps, German measles (Rothein), whooping cough, chicken pox or any other infectious disease. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  7) 
Sec. 15-10. - Health officer-Right of entry for purpose of examination or inspection. 
    The city health officer shall have full power at any time to enter and inspect every building, room, basement or cellar, occupied or used, or suspected of being used, for the production for sale, manufacture for sale, storage, sale, distribution or transportation of food and all utensils, fixtures, furniture and machinery used as described in this article, and if upon inspection any food producing or distribution establishment, conveyance, employer, operative, employee, clerk, driver or other person is found to be violating any of the provisions of this article, or if the production, cooking, preparation, manufacture, packing, storing, sale, distribution or transportation of food is being conducted in a manner detrimental to the health of the employees and operatives and the character or quality of the food being produced, manufactured, packed, stored, sold, distributed or conveyed, the officer or inspector, making the examination or inspection, shall furnish evidence of such violation to the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 196.230. 
Sec. 15-11. - Same-Right to close establishments under certain conditions. 
    It shall be the duty of the city health officer and he is authorized and empowered to close any market place, grocery store, general store, baker, confectionery, butcher shop, slaughterhouse, dining car, refrigerator car, cold storage plant or warehouse, hotel dining room or kitchen, cafe, restaurant, lunch counter, drugstore, or any other place where articles or commodities intended for human food or for human consumption as medicine are manufactured, sold, stored or prepared for sale, or wherever food and drink is served, where such places shall, in the judgment of such officer, constitute a menace to the public health, by reason of dirt, filth or other insanitary cause. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  10) 
Sec. 15-12. - Same-Same-Suspension of order to close upon correction of deficiency. 
    Any order issued by the city health officer [director of community development] for the closing of any place mentioned in section 15-11 shall specify the cause for which such order was issued, and the time during which same shall be in effect. The health officer [director of community development] shall revoke such order before the time specified therein for its expiration; provided, that the cause for which such order was issued is removed, and if the health officer [director of community development] is satisfied that such place may be reopened without endangering the public health. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  11) 
Sec. 15-13. - Penalty for violating article. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, on conviction, shall be punished as prescribed in section 22-70. 
(Ord. No. 2056,  9) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4956, adopted April 22, 1985, provided that the penalty set out in  22-70 was to supersede and amend all previously enacted ordinances for which the penalty was a fine not exceeding $90.00. Therefore, the section above has been changed to provide a reference to  22-70. 
Chapter 16 - PLACES OF RECREATION AND AMUSEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Inspections of amusements rides,  6-4; amusements,  7-7 et seq.; public dances,  7-57 et seq.; licenses, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate places of recreation, RSMo. 81.190; authority to regulate amusements, RSMo 94.360. 

ARTICLE I. - ARCADES 

Sec. 16-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Arcade: Any establishment or place of business offering for the recreation and amusement of customers or users eight (8) or more amusement devices, as defined below, for the use of its customers or patrons, upon payment of valuable consideration. 
(b)  Amusement device: Any table upon which balls and cues are used, or any device, mechanical or electronic, which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, plate or disc, or by control of a person or operator to use the device as a game, contest of skill or amusement, whether or not registering a score, which may cause a person using the same to secure some amusement, recreation, enjoyment or entertainment. Such amusement devices shall include, but not be limited to, such devices as pool tables, electronic or mechanical game machines, or any other mechanical or electrical games or operations similar thereto under whatever name they may be indicated. This definition shall not include telephone devices or machines that sell merchandise. 
(c)  Operator: The proprietor, lessee, manager or employee then in control of any arcade at time of use. 
(d)  Premises: A building or part of a building where amusement devices are located, under the ownership or control of the operator. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84; Ord. No. 5706,  2, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 16-2. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or to permit to be operated on any premises in the city owned or controlled by such person an arcade without first securing a permit duly issued by the deputy city clerk of Liberty, Missouri, as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-3. - Application for permit; investigations and reports by police chief and director of community development. 
(a)  An application for permit for the operation of an arcade in the city shall be obtained from the deputy city clerk. 
(b)  Each such application shall be verified and shall contain the name of the proposed operation (if a partnership, the names of all partners, and if a corporation, the names of all officers, directors and stockholders), the proposed location of the arcade, and the number and type of amusement devices to be provided. Such application shall be accompanied by accurately scaled and dimensioned plans of the premises, showing the proposed location of the amusement devices. 
(c)  Each such application shall be referred to the chief of police who shall investigate the character and fitness of the proposed operator as well as any persons listed as having an interest in the proposed license. 
(d)  The plans submitted with this application shall be submitted to the director of community development, who shall determine whether such proposed operation would comply with the applicable zoning ordinances and with all applicable fire ordinances. The police chief and director of community development shall, within forty-five (45) days, file written reports with the deputy city clerk for reference to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 16-4. - Grounds for denial of permit. 
    A permit for the operation of an arcade may be approved by the city council, unless city council finds one or more of the following:
