(a)  False or untrue statement in the application. 
(b)  The proposed operation would not comply with all applicable provisions of this article or any other city ordinance. 
(c)  Any of parties interested in the operation of the arcade have been convicted of any violation of any statute or ordinance involving moral turpitude, or have previously had a business license or permit suspended or revoked for violation of law, provided that if the city council shall find that such person's fitness to operate a business has not been affected by suspension or revocation and that permitting such applicant to conduct such an operation would not be contrary to the public interest, the city council may approve the issuance of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-5. - Notification of issuance or denial of permit. 
    Each applicant for a permit under this article shall be notified by regular mail to the address listed on the application, or by hand delivery, of the approval or nonapproval of a license by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-6. - Duration of permit. 
    All permits issued pursuant to this article shall be for a term of one year from date of issuance. The first permit issued to any establishment shall be subject to review six (6) months from its date of issuance, pursuant to the conditions of section 16-17. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-7. - Display of permit. 
    Every permit granted pursuant to this article shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business authorized to be conducted by such permit. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-8. - Location of arcade. 
    No arcade shall be located or situated at less distance than five hundred (500) feet from any school, church or place of worship or hospital. 
    If a proposed arcade is to be located within a structure wherein alcoholic beverages and/or nonintoxicating beer are sold for consumption on the premises, a separate entrance to the arcade must be provided, and there must be no direct access by patrons, physical or visual, from the arcade to the liquor-serving establishment. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 16-9. - Restroom requirements. 
(a)  Every arcade within the city shall have two (2) separate restrooms, one for male patrons and/or employees and one for female patrons and/or employees. 
(b)  Restroom facilities must be provided within the arcade itself, separate and distinct from those required for the liquor-serving establishment by any other statute, ordinance or code. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-10. - Minors on premises. 
    No person under the age of fourteen (14) years of age shall be permitted on the premises of an arcade unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. No person aged fourteen (14), fifteen (15) or sixteen (16) years shall be permitted on the premises of an arcade without having on his person an identification card supplied by the operator and containing that person's name, age, home address, telephone number, date of birth, personal photograph and signature of the recipient and the issuer. No such identification card shall be issued by the operator unless the operator has received the written permission of the parent or legal guardian acknowledged before a notary public with notary's certificate. The operator shall maintain a permanent record of the names of the parents or legal guardians who have granted such permission. Such record shall be available for inspection at all times by the director of community development and the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-11. - Alcoholic beverages, nonintoxicating beer, controlled substances, or explosives on the premises. 
    Unless there is in effect a lawful license for dispensation of alcoholic beverages on the premises, no alcoholic beverages, non-intoxicating beer, drugs or other controlled substances shall be permitted anywhere on the premises of any arcade. 
    No firearms, knives or other legal weapons or explosives shall be permitted on the premises of any arcade. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; explosives,  6-5; firearms,  22-16.1, 22-16.2. 
Sec. 16-12. - Gambling devices; use of amusement devices for gambling prohibited. 
    No permit shall be issued for any amusement device which is so constructed as to make possible, either directly or by the use of any adjustment, the return of cash, tickets, discs or other tokens or certificates of any kind to a player operating the same, whether or not such tokens or certificates have a value of any kind. Only machines operated exclusively for the amusement provided by the operation thereof shall be permitted, and no amusement devices shall return, and no licensee shall offer or give, any reward or thing of value as reward for the making of any score or accomplishing any result in the playing of any such device; except, that as a reward for his skill the player may be given plays on the device, but the free plays shall not be converted, commuted or exchanged in any way. Any device which is capable of being played, used or operated in a single time by the insertion therein of more than one coin, disc, or other insertion piece and for the operator thereof winning free plays or free games thereon or for the purpose of increasing the number of free plays or free games which may be won thereby is not permitted. If the chief of police of his designated representative shall have reasonable cause to believe that any amusement device is used or being used as a gambling device, such device may be seized by the chief of police and impounded. 
    Gambling on the premises is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-13. - Employees and supervisory personnel. 
    No person shall be employed in a supervisory position in an arcade who is under the age of twenty-one (21) or who has been convicted of any violation of any statute or any provision of this Code or other ordinance involving moral turpitude or any felony. 
    Prior to employing any person in a supervisory position, the operator shall submit the name of such person, and such other information as may be required, to the chief of police who shall determine whether such person has been so convicted and shall notify the operator thereof. 
    At least one supervisor of at least twenty-one (21) years of age, employed by the operator, shall be on duty at all times the premises are open to the public and be present on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-14. - Maximum occupancy; fire regulations. 
    Occupancy of an arcade shall not exceed at any time the number of persons established by the fire department or local fire regulations. The owner shall conform to all fire regulations covering exit requirements, signs, etc., as established by the fire department and as covered in this Code and other local ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 16-15. - Hours of operation. 
    No arcade shall operate between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. of the following day, except on Fridays, when they shall not operate between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 9:00 a.m. of the following day, and except on Saturdays, when they may not operate between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 1:00 p.m. the next day, all times official county time. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-16. - Maintenance of place of business and devices; order and decorum. 
    Each arcade shall be maintained in any orderly manner, and shall have at least eighty (80) per cent of the amusement devices in good repair and operating at all times. 
    The licensee, business owner, manager and supervisory personnel of the arcade shall be obligated to maintain and keep order and proper decorum at all times and shall be obligated, on order of the chief of police, to provide security personnel for the maintenance of order and proper decorum on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Cross reference- Disorderly house,  22-12. 
Sec. 16-17. - Renewal of permit. 
(a)  Not more than sixty (60) days nor less than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the permit, a permittee may apply to the city council for renewal therefor, on such application forms as may be provided by the deputy city clerk. Further investigation under section 16-2 shall be required only as to personnel not listed in last previous application for permit. 
(b)  Renewal application shall contain the number of the permittee's operation, and the permittee shall indicate any changes from the information furnished to the city council at the time of the original application. 
(c)  The city council shall renew such permit if the city council shall find that such operation has been conducted in accordance with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-18. - Inspections. 
    All amusement devices and all premises on which such devices are maintained or exhibited shall be open to inspection by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-19. - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
    The city council may suspend or revoke a permit theretofore issued if it finds one or more of the following: 
(a)  False or untrue statements of a substantial fact in the application, not discovered at the time of issuance of such permit. 
(b)  Permitting conduct on the premises which would constitute a violation of any state statues or provision of this article or any other city ordinance, including conduct constituting a breach of the peace which would have the propensity of resulting in violence; damage to property; or injury to any person. 
(c)  Violation of or the failure to comply with any of the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Alcoholic beverages (except when dispensation is licensed), drugs or other controlled substances being found upon the premises; drug or controlled substance trafficking and sales upon the premises. 
    In the event the director of community development recommends the suspension or revocation of a permit to the city council, the permittee shall have a period of ten (10) days following notice of the stated violation and recommendation by director of community development to request a hearing before the city council. The director of community development's recommendation shall include the charges against the permittee and shall be in writing and shall be deemed served upon the permittee by deposit in United States mail, certified, first class postage prepaid to the permittee's last known address. The permittee must request by delivery to the deputy city clerk at City Hall, Liberty, Missouri, the hearing provided for in this section. If the permittee requests a hearing, such hearing shall be held no later than thirty (30) days following receipt of the request for such hearing. 
    The first permit issued to any establishment may be reviewed by the city council six (6) months after its issuance. Should the city council deem necessary the suspension or revocation of the license, the above stated hearing and notice procedures shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-20. - Severability. 
    Should any part, section, or provision of this article be held invalid by a court of [competent] jurisdiction, the remaining parts, sections and provisions shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Sec. 16-21. - Penalties. 
    Any person or corporation charged with any duty or obligation hereunder who shall fail to discharge the same; or shall do or perform any act in violation hereof; or shall aid or abet any such failure or commission of such act by another, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided in the Liberty City Code. Continuation of any such offense or violation as to each day shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4866,  2, 11-12-84) 
Chapter 17 - REGULATING SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the following terms shall be deemed to have the meaning indicated below: 
    Approved incinerator: An incinerator which complies with all current regulations of the Missouri Air Conservation Commission. 
    Bulky rubbish: Non-putrescible solid waste consisting of combustible and/or non-combustible waste materials from dwelling units, commercial, industrial, institutional, or agricultural establishments which are either too large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste collection vehicles by solid waste collectors, with the equipment available therefor. 
    City: The City of Liberty, Missouri. 
    Collection: Removal and transportation of solid waste from its place of storage to its place of processing or disposal. 
    Demolition and construction waste: Waste materials from the construction or destruction of residential, industrial or commercial structures. 
    Director: The city administrator of the City of Liberty, or his authorized representative. 
    Disposable solid waste container: Disposable plastic or paper sacks with a capacity of 20 to 35 gallons specifically designed for storage of solid waste. 
    Dwelling unit: Any room or group of rooms located within a structure and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used, or are intended to be used, for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Garbage: Putrescible animal or vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food. 
    Hazardous wastes: Including but not limited to: pathological wastes, explosive wastes, pesticides, pesticide containers, toxic or radioactive materials. 
    Multiple housing facility: A housing facility containing more than one dwelling unit under one roof. 
    Occupant: Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others shall be in actual possession of any dwelling unit or of any other improved real property, either as owner or as a tenant. 
    Person: Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or organization of any kind, or their legal representative, agent or assigns. 
    Processing: Incinerating, composting, baling, shredding, salvaging, compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced. 
    Refuse: Solid waste. 
    Solid waste: Unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semi-solid state, including but not limited to garbage, ashes, street refuse, rubbish, animal and agricultural wastes, yard wastes, discarded appliances, special wastes, industrial wastes, and demolition and construction wastes. 
(a)  Commercial solid waste: Solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishment, and multiple housing facilities with more than 4 dwelling units. 
(b)  Residential solid waste: Solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units, excluding multiple housing facilities with more than 4 dwelling units. 
    Solid waste container: Receptacle used by any person to store solid waste during the interval between solid waste collections. 
    Solid waste disposal: The process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material. In particular the final deposition of solid waste by men. 
    Solid waste management: The entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage: Keeping, maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Yard wastes: Grass clippings, leaves, tree trimmings. 
Sec. 17-2. - Solid waste storage. 
(a)  The occupant of every dwelling unit of every institutional, commercial or business, industrial or agricultural establishment producing solid waste within the corporate limits of the city, shall provide sufficient and adequate containers for the storage of all solid waste except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste to serve each such dwelling unit and/or establishment; and to maintain such solid waste containers at all times in good repair. 
(b)  The occupant of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial, industrial, agricultural or business establishment shall place all solid waste to be collected in proper solid waste containers, except as otherwise provided herein, and shall maintain such solid waste containers and the area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
(c)  Residential solid waste shall be stored in containers of not more than thirty-five (35) gallons and not less than twenty (20) gallons in nominal capacity. Containers shall be leakproof, waterproof, and fitted with a fly-tight lid and shall be properly covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof. The containers shall have handles, balls or other suitable lifting devices or features. Containers shall be of a type originally manufactured for residential solid waste with tapered sides for easy emptying. They shall be of light weight and shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds when full. Galvanized metal containers, rubber or fiberglass, and plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather, may be used. Disposable solid waste containers with suitable frames, regular containers used in garbage compactors of standard manufacture, or containers as approved by the city may also be used for storage of residential solid waste. The council may by resolution specify more precisely the container to be authorized. 
(d)  Commercial solid waste shall be stored in solid waste containers as approved by the city. The containers shall be waterproof, leakproof, and shall be covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof; and shall meet all requirements as set forth by section 17-6. 
(e)  Tree limbs less than four (4) inches in diameter and brush shall be securely tied in bundles not larger than forty-eight (48) inches long and eighteen (18) inches in diameter when not placed in storage containers. The weight of any individual bundle shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds. 
(f)  Yard wastes shall be stored in containers so constructed and maintained as to prevent the dispersal of wastes placed therein upon the premises served, upon adjacent premises, or upon adjacent public rights-of-way. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds. 
(g)  Solid waste material shall not be collected by the contractor for the city unless contained in approved containers. 
Sec. 17-3. - Collection of solid waste. 
    [Regulations pertaining to the collection of solid waste are set out in sections 17-3.1-17.3.9.] 
Sec. 17-3.1. - City collection of solid waste. 
(a)  Collection of residential solid waste. The city shall provide for the collection of all residential solid waste in the city, provided, however, that the city may provide the collection service by contracting with a person, county, or other city or a combination thereof, for the entire city or portions thereof, as deemed to be in the best interests of the city. 
(b)  Other collections. The city may, at its discretion, provide commercial solid waste collection services. However, in the event that such services are not provided by the city, it shall be the duty of such establishment to provide for collection and proper disposal of all solid waste produced upon any such premises. The failure of any person to provide for proper collection and disposal shall be cause for action by the city under the terms of this chapter. 
Sec. 17-3.2. - Bulky rubbish collection. 
    All solid waste from premises to which collection services are provided by the city shall be collected, except bulky rubbish as defined herein, provided, however, that bulky rubbish will be collected if tied securely in bundles not exceeding reasonable limitations of weight and bulk to be fixed by regulations to be made and promulgated by the city as hereinafter provided. All solid waste collected shall, upon being loaded into collection equipment, become the property of the collection agency. 
Sec. 17-3.3. - Collection of yard wastes and tree limbs. 
    Tree limbs and yard wastes, as described in section 7-2 (e) and (f) respectively, shall be placed at the curb or alley for collection. Solid waste containers are required by this chapter for the storage of other residential solid waste and shall be placed at the curbside or roadside in the front or side yard for collection, with the exception of any specific deviations for hardship reasons as may be approved by the city. Any solid waste containers, tree limbs, yard wastes, or other solid waste permitted by this chapter to be placed at the authorized collection point shall not be so placed until the regularly scheduled collection day. 
Sec. 17-3.4. - Authorization for collectors to enter upon private property. 
    Solid waste collectors, employed by the city or a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city, are hereby authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting solid waste therefrom as required by this chapter. Solid waste collectors shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings for the purpose of collecting residential solid waste unless authorized by the occupant. Commercial solid waste may be removed from within commercial establishments upon written approval of the occupant. 
Sec. 17-3.5. - Frequency of collection. 
    The following collection frequencies shall apply to collections of solid waste within the city: 
    All residential solid waste, other than bulky rubbish, shall be collected at least once weekly. At least one hundred twenty (120) hours shall intervene between collections. All commercial solid waste shall be collected once weekly, and shall be collected at such lesser intervals upon determination by the city that such lesser intervals are necessary for the preservation of the health and/or safety of the public. 
Sec. 17-3.6. - Storage of containers. 
    Residential solid waste containers shall be stored upon the residential premises. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon private property, unless the occupant shall have been granted written permission from the city to use public property for such purposes. The storage site shall be well drained, fully accessible to collection equipment, public health personnel and fire inspection personnel. Commercial solid waste containers shall be located behind the front line of the main building, which excludes the front porch, on all days except the day of collection. Commercial solid waste containers shall not be located in the side yard on the street side of a corner lot. 
(Ord. No. 10016,  I, 2-11-2013) 
Sec. 17-3.7. - Collection vehicles. 
    All collection vehicles shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom. All vehicles to be used for collection of solid waste shall be constructed with water-tight bodies and with covers which shall be an integral part of the vehicle or shall be a separate cover of suitable material with fasteners designed to secure all sides of the cover to the vehicle and shall be secured whenever the vehicle is transporting solid waste, or, as an alternate, the entire bodies thereof shall be enclosed, with only loading hoppers exposed. No solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers. 
Sec. 17-3.8. - Earth materials. 
    Permits shall not be required for the removal, hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities; however, all such materials shall be conveyed in tight vehicles, trucks or receptacles, so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public right-of-way. 
Sec. 17-3.9. - Demolition and construction wastes. 
    Transportation and disposal of demolition and construction wastes shall be in accordance with sections 17-4 and 17-5. 
Sec. 17-4. - Disposal of solid wastes. 
    [Regulations pertaining to the disposal of solid wastes are set out on sections 17-4.1 and 17-4.2.] 
Sec. 17-4.1. - Disposal requirements of Missouri Division of Health. 
    Solid wastes shall be disposed of at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the city and complying with all requirements of the Missouri Division of Health. 
Sec. 17-4.2. - Disposal of hazardous wastes. 
    The city may classify certain wastes as hazardous wastes which will require special handling and shall be disposed of only in a manner acceptable to the city and which will meet all local, state and federal regulations. 
Sec. 17-5. - Permits. 
    [Regulations pertaining to the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid wastes are set out in sections 17-5.1-17.5.9] 
Sec. 17-5.1. - Permit to engage in business. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transportation, processing or disposal of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining an annual permit therefor from the city; provided, however that this provision shall not be deemed to apply to employees of the holder of any such permit. 
Sec. 17-5.2. - Requirements for permit. 
    No such permit shall be issued until and unless the applicant therefor in addition to all other requirements set forth, shall file and maintain with the city evidence of a satisfactory public liability insurance policy with the city named as co-insured, covering all operations of such applicant pertaining to such business and all vehicles to be operated in the conduct thereof in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person injured or killed, and in the amount of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) in the event of injury or death of two or more persons in any single accident and in the amount of not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for damage to property. Should any such policy be cancelled, the city shall be notified of such cancellation by the insurance carrier in writing not less than thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of such cancellation, and provisions to that effect shall be incorporated in such policy, which shall also place upon the company writing such policy the duty to give such notice. 
Sec. 17-5.3. - Application for permit. 
    Each applicant for any such permit shall state in his application therefor: 
(a)  The nature of the permit desired, as to collect, transport, process, or dispose of solid waste or any combination thereof; 
(b)  The characteristics of solid waste to be collected, transported, processed or disposed; 
(c)  The number of solid waste vehicles to be operated thereunder; 
(d)  The precise location or locations of solid waste processing or disposal facilities to be used; 
(e)  Boundaries of the collection area; and 
(f)  Such other information as required by the director. 
Sec. 17-5.4. - Issuance of permit; term. 
    If the application shows that the applicant will collect, transport, process or dispose of solid wastes without hazard to the public health or damage to the environment and in conformity with the laws of the State of Missouri and this chapter, the director shall issue the permit authorized by this chapter. The permit shall be issued for a period of one year, and each applicant shall pay therefor a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00.) If in the opinion of the director modification can be made to the application regarding service, equipment, or mode of operation, so as to bring the applicant within the intent of this chapter, the director shall notify the applicant in writing setting forth the modification to be made and the time in which it shall be done. 
Sec. 17-5.5. - Denial of application for permit. 
    If the applicant does not make the modifications pursuant to the notice in section 17-5.4 within the time limit specified therein, or if the application does not clearly show that the collection, transportation, processing or disposal of solid wastes will create no public health hazard or be without harmful effects on the environment, the application shall be denied and the applicant notified by the director, in writing, stating the reason for such denial. Nothing in this section shall prejudice the right of the applicant to reapply after the rejection of his application provided that all aspects of the reapplication comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
Sec. 17-5.6. - Renewal of permit. 
    The annual permit may be renewed simply upon payment of the fee or fees as designated herein, if the business has not been modified. If modifications have been made, the applicant shall reapply for a permit as set forth in sections 7-5.2 and 7-5.3. No permits authorized by this chapter shall be transferable from person to person. 
Sec. 17-5.7. - Inspections. 
    In order to insure compliance with the laws of this state, this chapter and the rules and regulations authorized herein, the director is authorized to inspect all phases of solid waste management within the City of Liberty. No inspection shall be made in any residential unit unless authorized by the occupant or by due process of law. In all instances where such inspections reveal violation of this chapter, the rules and regulations authorized herein for the storage, collection, transportation, processing or disposal of solid waste or the laws of the State of Missouri, the director shall issue notice for each such violation stating therein the violation or violations found, the time and date and the corrective measures to be taken, together with the time in which such corrections shall be made. 
Sec. 17-5.8. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    In all cases, when the corrective measures have not been taken within the time specified, the director shall suspend or revoke the permit or permits involved in the violation; however, in those cases where an extension of time will permit correction and there is no public health hazard created by the delay, one extension of time not to exceed the original time period may be given. 
Sec. 17-5.9. - Numbering of vehicles. 
    All motor vehicles operating under any permit required by this chapter shall display the number or numbers on each side in colors which contrast with that of the vehicle, such numbers to be clearly legible and not less than three (3) inches high. Each permit for processing or disposal facilities shall be prominently displayed at the facility. 
Sec. 17-6. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city shall make, and the director shall enforce, reasonable and necessary rules and regulations, governing, but not limited to: 
(a)  Preparation, drainage and wrapping of garbage, deposited in solid waste containers. 
(b)  Specifications for solid waste containers including the type, composition, equipment, size and shape thereof. 
(c)  Identification of solid waste containers, and of the covers thereof, and of equipment thereto appertaining, if any. 
(d)  Weight limitations on the combined weight of solid waste containers and the contents thereof, and weight and size limitations on bundles of solid waste too large for solid waste containers. 
(e)  Storage of solid waste in solid waste containers. 
(f)  Sanitation of solid waste in solid waste containers. 
(g)  Schedules of and routes for collection of solid waste. 
(h)  Collection points of solid waste containers. 
(i)  Collection and disposal of solid waste. 
(j)  Processing facilities and fees for the use thereof. 
(k)  Disposal facilities and fees for the use thereof. 
(l)  Records of quantity and type of wastes received at processing and/or disposal facility. 
(m)  Handling of special wastes such as toxic wastes, sludges, ashes, agriculture, construction, bulky items, tires, automobiles, oils, greases, etc. 
    The director is hereby authorized to make and promulgate reasonable and necessary rules and regulations for the billing and collection of solid waste collection and/or disposal service charges, as hereinafter provided for. 
    A copy of any and all rules and regulations made and promulgated under the provisions hereof shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3563, 8-11-75) 
Sec. 17-7. - Prohibited practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own, without the written consent of the owner of such container and/or with the intent of avoiding payment of the service charge hereinafter provided for solid waste collection and disposal; 
(2)  Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection equipment, or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such whether such equipment or collectors shall be those of the city or those of a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city; 
(3)  Burn solid waste unless an approved incinerator is provided or unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control agency; 
(4)  Dispose of solid waste at any facility or location which is not approved by the city and the Missouri division of health; 
(5)  Engage in the business of collection, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without a permit from the city, or operate under an expired permit, or operate after a permit has been suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 3563, 8-11-75) 
Cross reference- Open burning,  14-12 et seq. 
Sec. 17-8. - Service charges. 
    A service charge may be imposed for the collection and disposal of solid waste for each dwelling unit and each commercial establishment to which such service is provided under the provisions of this chapter. A resident who is sixty-five (65) years or older, or who is physically handicapped, may, upon application to the city, receive a partial credit towards the service charge. The service charge, service charge credit and method of collection of residential and commercial solid waste shall be set forth in resolution form and attached hereto; said rates shall be subject to change by resolution of the city council of the City of Liberty. An applicant for physical handicap exemption must provide a licensed physician's certification and give evidence that no resident member of the applicant's household is able to carry refuse to the authorized collection point. 
    The service charge shall be terminated upon presentation of satisfactory proof to the director that any such dwelling unit or establishment is unoccupied and shall be commenced upon renewed occupancy thereof. 
    The system of services established by the provisions of this chapter hereof is designed as an integral part of the city's system for providing potable water and the city's system for providing sewage disposal. The city may enforce collection of such charges by bringing proper legal action against the occupant of any premises which has received such services, to recover any sums due for such services plus a reasonable attorney's fee to be fixed by the court. 
(Ord. No. 3563, 8-11-75; Ord. No. 8351,  I, 4-22-02) 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, Ch. 29. 
Sec. 17-9. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, or any lawful rules or regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, upon conviction, shall be punished as prescribed by section 22-70; provided that each day's violation thereof shall be a separate offense for the purpose hereof. 
(Ord. No. 3563, 8-11-75) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4956, adopted April 22, 1985, provided that the penalty set out in  22-70 was to supersede and amend all previously enacted ordinances for which the penalty was a fine not exceeding ninety dollars ($90.00). Therefore, the section above has been editorially changed to provide a reference to  22-70. 
Sec. 17-10. - Bonds. 
    Bond requirements (performance and/or payment) may be required as set in contractual arrangements with private collectors. 
(Ord. No. 3563, 8-11-75) 
Sec. 17-11. - Severability clause. 
    The provisions of this chapter are severable and, if any provisions or part hereof shall be held invalid or unconstitutional or inapplicable to any person or circumstance, such invalidity, unconstitutionality or inapplicability shall not affect or impair the remaining provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3563, 8-11-75) 
Chapter 18 - LICENSES 
ARTICLE I. - ADMINISTRATION OF LICENSES IN GENERAL, AND REQUIREMENTS THEREOF[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9704,  I, adopted April 25, 2011, repealed Art. I in its entirety and enacted a new Art. I to read as set out herein. Former Art. I,  18-1-18-17, pertained to merchants and derived from Ord. No. 1877,  2; Ord. No. 2129,  2, 3, 7-12, 14-28; Ord. No. 2731,  3; Ord. No. 2904,  1; Ord. No. 2994,  1; Ord. No. 4302,  2, adopted Oct. 27, 1980; Ord. No. 4437,  1, adopted Nov. 9, 1981; Ord. No. 6866,  1, adopted July 25, 1994; Ord. No. 8486,  I, adopted Jan. 27, 2003. 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Agency means the legal relation which arises when one party, called the agent, is authorized to represent and act for another party, called the principal, in bringing or to aid in bringing such principal in contractual relation with a third person, however such authority may be conferred. It includes every relation in which one person acts for or represents another by his authority. The term is also defined as one who by authority performs an act for another. 
    Applicant means a duly authorized officer or person (owner) of a business applying for an occupation license, either new or renewal. 
    Business means all kinds of vocations, occupations, professions, enterprises, establishments and all other kinds of activities and matters together with all devices, machines, vehicles used therein, any of which are conducted for private profit, non-profit or benefit, either directly or indirectly, on any premises in this city, or anywhere within its jurisdiction, unless specified as a non-business through state or city charter exemption. 
    Home-based business means any enterprise for which the principal administrative and managerial activities take place within an individual's personal residence. 
    License or licensee means a certificate holder of an occupation license or permit, or the holder for any use or period of time of any similar privilege, wherever relevant to any provision of this chapter or other law or ordinance. 
    License year means the twelve-month period beginning the first day of the month in which a license is issued for or renewed. 
    Maintaining a business office means conducting the activities of one's occupation at a given place, phone or address within the physical boundaries of the City of Liberty. Activities supporting the operation of a business or occupation include, but are not limited to: Sending and receiving correspondence, telephone calls, or electronic communications; paying employees, scheduling, directing and managing; making deposits, paying bills or invoices, receiving payments; submitting reports, payments and forms to governmental entities; distributing product or where orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or a service are taken. 
    Mercantile agent/canvasser means any person having a place of business in the city where orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise are taken. Any person who shall go from place to place within the city and take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise for future delivery, either by himself or some other person. 
    Merchant means one whose occupation is the wholesale purchase and/or retail sale of any goods, wares and merchandise or services at a stand, store or place occupied for that purpose within this city, except as may be otherwise provided by this chapter. Some examples include, but are not limited to: Clothing stores, convenience stores, dry goods stores, drugstores, furniture stores, feed/grain stores, grocery stores; gas, water & plumbing fixture stores; hardware stores, jewelry stores, meat markets, millinery/fabric stores, monument dealers, novelty stores, news agencies, steam fixture stores, tire shops, wallpaper stores, paint stores, shoe stores, department stores, general merchandise stores, electronic stores, appliance stores and automobile supply stores. 
    Occupation license, also referred to as a business license, means a document required in order to conduct business within the city. 
    Pawnbroker means any person who shall engage in the business of loaning money on deposit of personal property or purchasing personal property on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price. 
    Real estate agent means any person who shall be employed to negotiate loans on real estate, shall be considered to be a real estate agent and such term shall include any person who shall sell or aid in the sale of any real or personal property not belonging to such person and receiving a commission or compensation for making or aiding in the making of such sale. 
    Traveling/special event, auction stores means any person, any agent or employee of any person who shall temporarily engage in the selling or offering for sale within the city, any goods, wares or merchandise, from any stock placed temporarily in any building, room or structure or other place within the city shall be considered as conducting a business as a traveling store, and if he shall sell or offer to sell or cause to be sold therein, any goods, wares and merchandise at auction, it shall be deemed as conducting business as an auction sale. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-2. - License-Required generally; exception. 
(a)  Every person (owner), whether or not located in the city, desiring to engage in any business, profession or occupation in the city shall be required to obtain an occupation license before engaging in such activity as specified in this chapter. Occupation licenses are not transferable. 
(b)  Every agent, general contractor, sub-contractor, or representative of any person desiring to engage in or to continue to engage in any business, profession or occupation shall be responsible for the compliance of such person in acquiring an occupation license as required by this chapter. 
(c)  No religious, benevolent or educational society located in this city shall be required to pay any license to conduct any kind of entertainment or to serve refreshments of any kind in any public building in this city. 
(d)  No license shall be required of any person for any delivery in the city of any property purchased or acquired in good faith from any person at any regular place of business outside the city where no intent by such person is shown to exist to evade the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-2.1. - Exempted occupations. 
(a)  In accordance with Section 71.620(1) R.S.Mo., as amended, the following professional occupations are exempt from the licensing and fee provisions of this article: 
(1)  Minister of the gospel; 
(2)  Teacher; 
(3)  Professor in a college; 
(4)  Priest; 
(5)  Lawyer; 
(6)  Certified public accountant; 
(7)  Dentist; 
(8)  Chiropractor; 
(9)  Optometrist; 
(10)  Chiropodist; 
(11)  Physician or surgeon. 
(b)  In accordance with Section 71.630 R.S.Mo., as amended, farmers are exempt from the licensing and fee provisions of this article when selling agricultural products and produce from a wagon, cart or vehicle that such farmers have themselves raised or produced. 
(c)  In accordance with Section 71.620(2) R.S.Mo., as amended, the following professional occupations are exempt from the licensing and fee provisions of this article unless that person maintains a business office within the City of Liberty: 
(1)  Architect; 
(2)  Professional engineer; 
(3)  Land surveyor; 
(4)  Auctioneer; 
(5)  Real estate broker or real estate salesperson; 
(6)  Insurance agent or brokers. 
(d)  In accordance with Section 148.620 R.S.Mo., as amended, credit unions and associations, including savings and loan associations, are exempt from the licensing and fee provisions of this article. 
(e)  In accordance with Section 340.214 R.S.Mo, as amended, veterinarians (for veterinary services only), are exempt from the licensing and fee provisions of this article. 
(f)  In accordance with Section 345.055 R.S.Mo., as amended, clinical audiologist and speech-language pathologist (for services only), are exempt from the licensing and fee provisions of this article. 
(g)  In accordance with Section 324.1114 R.S.Mo., as amended, private investigators are exempt from the licensing fee and provisions of this article. 
(h)  Any business, home-based business or occupation, with annual gross receipts less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), are exempt from the licensee fee and provisions of this article. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this Code and except where contrary to state or federal law, all occupations, pursuit, professions, trades, businesses, maintaining a business office, avocation office or agencies within the city shall hereby procure a license and pay a license fee computed as determined in section 18-13. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-3. - Same-Form; payment of fee pre-requisite to issuance. 
    All licenses required by section 18-2 shall be signed by the mayor, attested and countersigned by the [deputy] city clerk, and the corporate seal shall be affixed thereto. No license shall be issued until the amount prescribed therefore and levied thereon shall have been paid to the [deputy] city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-4. - Payment of taxes condition for license. 
    No license or permit provided for or required under this Code or any ordinance of the city shall be issued to any person until all city taxes owed by the business or owner of the business are paid in full. Such tax to be paid prior to issuance of any license or permit includes all real and personal property taxes, all business property taxes, all transient guest tax and all after adopted taxes and fees as levied by the city. The [deputy] city clerk may require the applicant to show his tax receipt. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011; Ord. No. 10844,  I, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 18-5. - License year, when fees are paid, expiration. 
(a)  All licenses, except where otherwise provided, shall be in effect for one year from the date of issuance, and renewed annually thereafter. There is no proration of fees. 
(b)  Any person applying for an occupation license whose fiscal year does not coincide with its license year under this article, shall be permitted to report and pay the license fee based upon such fiscal year. 
(c)  License fees for renewals shall be due and payable on or before the last day of the month in which it is to be renewed. 
(d)  All licenses, except as otherwise specifically provided for in this chapter, shall expire if the renewal fee is not paid in full within the period provided for in paragraph (c) above. A license which is not paid in full by such date is delinquent and such business or occupation will be deemed unlicensed and fall under the strict enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-5.1. - License fees-Delinquent and unpaid; increase of fee. 
    Any license fee which is not paid within thirty (30) days of the due date shall be increased by ten (10) per cent of the basic license fee. If such fee is not paid within sixty (60) days of the due date, an additional increase of three (3) per cent shall be added for each month in which such license fee is not paid, and any fraction of a month shall be counted as a whole month. The penalty provided for in this section shall be in addition to any other penalty prescribed by ordinance. 
    Any person engaging in any business, profession, or occupation as herein specified without first having paid the license fee required herein and having secured a license for the conduct of such business, profession, or occupation shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day of such violation. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
    Payment of such increased fees shall not relieve licensee of liability to prosecution and fine on conviction for failure to pay when due. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-6. - Nontransferability. 
    No license issued under this chapter shall in any case be assigned or transferred. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-7. - Compliance with zoning requirements. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the licensee's compliance with all zoning requirements. The [deputy] city clerk shall have the power to revoke any license for failure to comply with the zoning requirements and, upon application, may refund the unused portion of the annual license fee paid for such revoked license. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-8. - Separate license each place of business. 
    A separate license shall be obtained for each place of conducted, operated, maintained or carried on by every person engaged in any occupation, calling, trade or enterprise, for which a license is required by this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-8.1. - Duplicate license, change in location. 
    Any licensee shall have the right to change the location of a licensed business provided that: 
(1)  The licensee submits an application form provided by the [deputy] city clerk for such change in location of the licensed business prior to making such change in location. 
(2)  The proposed location meets the requirements of all health, zoning, fire, building and other codes of the City of Liberty. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-9. - Multiple occupations. 
    Whenever any applicant for an occupation license, required by this chapter, is engaged in more than one occupation or business at the same address, such applicant may, at his option, in lieu of making application and paying for a separate occupation or business license for each such occupation or business, make application and pay for the occupation or business license for only the major or principal business or occupation of the applicant at such address; however, the license fee for all such occupations or businesses shall be computed on the basis of the total annual gross receipts of the applicant derived from all of the occupations or businesses in which the applicant is engaged at such address, and the only minimum license fee required to be paid shall be the one for occupation or business license for which application is made. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-10. - Records of city clerk. 
    The [deputy] city clerk shall keep a complete and perfect record of all licenses issued under this chapter, showing the nature of the license, its date, expiration and to whom issued. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-11. - Display. 
    All licenses granted by the city under this chapter shall be carefully preserved and be displayed in a conspicuous place in the places of business authorized to be conducted by such licensee. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-12. - Effect of false statements on application. 
    Any person found making a statement in his application for an occupation license, under this chapter, showing gross annual business or annual gross receipts or gross annual commissions, fees, charges or compensation in an amount less than the true amount thereof, or knowingly making a false statement as to any other condition or factor upon which the license fee is or shall be based, the effect of which would be to reduce the amount of such fee, shall pay to the city treasurer [director of finance] upon demand therefore, the additional amount of license fee found to be due, plus a penalty of twenty-five (25) per cent of such additional amount, with interest on the additional license fee of one per cent for each month, or major fraction thereof, after the date when the demand for the additional amount was made. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-13. - Manner of calculating fees based on gross receipts, generally. 
    Each applicant for an occupation license required by this chapter shall be based on gross annual business or annual gross receipts, shall include in his application the true amount of the gross annual business or annual gross receipts of his business or occupation for the preceding calendar year, using as the basis for such computation the same figures shown by his books and records, by his federal and state income tax returns, by his state sales tax returns or by any other records or copies thereof, which correctly and accurately show such gross annual business or annual gross receipts of the applicant for such period. Each applicant for such license, in all cases where the fee for such license is or shall be based on conditions or factors other than gross annual business or annual gross receipts shall include in his application a true and accurate statement of such conditions or factors upon which such license fee is or shall be based. 
    The [deputy] city clerk, or any [deputy] or agent, or certified public accountant employed thereby, based upon reasonable suspicion, shall have the right at all reasonable times during regular business hours to audit or examine the books and records of the applicant or licensee for the purpose of determining the truthfulness and accuracy of any statements made by the applicant or licensee in an application for a current or preceding year's occupation license. All applications accepted by the [deputy] city clerk shall be accepted subject to audit. No license shall be issued to any applicant so long as the applicant refuses to permit such audit or examination to be made on all prior years licensed. 
    For businesses located outside the city limits of Liberty, gross receipts, gross business activity or gross commissions shall be reported for business activities which occur within the city limits. 
    For residential and commercial builders, gross receipts means all monies received from construction or sale of a residential or commercial structure. Therefore, the sales price or contract price of the residential or commercial structure is the "gross receipts", not the profit from the sale. This applies to both contract or speculative construction. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-13.1. - Disclosure by officials of the amount of gross receipts or amount of tax paid, unlawful. 
    No officer or employee of the city shall disclose to anyone other than an officer, employee or agent of the city, and then only in the performance of his duty, the amount of gross receipts from sales as set out in any report made under this chapter, or the amount of tax paid by any licensee under this chapter, except as may be required in a court proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-14. - Manner of calculating fees based on commissions, etc. 
    Every person for whom a license is provided in this chapter, the amount of which license is to be computed upon the gross annual business or gross annual commissions of such person, may be required to furnish the city with a certified statement in writing showing the amount of such gross annual business or gross annual commissions done or received, which statement shall not be made public or used by the city except for the purpose of establishing a correct basis for fixing and collecting the amount of the license provided. All books of account showing the amount of such gross annual business or gross annual commissions shall be opened to the inspection of city officials charged with the duty of issuing the license provided and collecting for the same. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-15. - Application. 
(a)  Every person required to obtain a license under the provisions of this chapter shall submit an application to the [deputy] city clerk upon forms to be furnished by the [deputy] city clerk for the license required in this chapter, such forms shall give the name of the business, the owner thereof, the person actually in charge of the conduct of such business within this city, the location of such business, nature of the business or occupation, whether or not personal taxes due the city from the owner or manager of such business and all preceding merchants taxes for such business have been paid. In addition thereto, the applicant shall furnish the sworn statement giving the annual gross receipts or commission derived from such business as required in section 18-14. 
(b)  At the time the application is submitted, the [deputy] city clerk shall issue a receipt to the applicant for the money paid in advance. Such receipt shall not be construed as the approval of the [deputy] city clerk for the issuance of a license, nor shall it entitle or authorize the applicant to open or maintain any business contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  The applicant shall submit application for renewal of the license annually at the time specified in section 18-5 of this chapter. Such application for renewal shall include a written statement upon forms provided that the information submitted on the application form is true and correct. 
(d)  When the [deputy] city clerk upon considering and applying the general standards set out in this chapter determines that an applicant for a license, or for a renewal of a license, is not qualified under such provisions, the application shall be denied. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-15.1. - Missouri retail sales license required prior to issuance of license. 
(a)  Every applicant for an occupation license relating to a business which involves the retail sale of goods shall exhibit a valid and current retail sales license issued by the State of Missouri. 
(b)  The revocation of such retail sales license by the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri shall render the occupation license issued hereunder null and void provided, however, that the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri or any duly authorized representative must inform the [deputy] city clerk in writing of such revocation of a retailers license before such city license shall be revoked under section. 18-7.1 
(c)  The [deputy] city clerk may upon presentment of proof of issuance or re-issuance of a Missouri Retail Sales License reinstate the city occupation license that any business may have had in effect at the time of revocation under the provisions of subsection (b) above. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-16. - Schedule of fees. 
    As authorized by state law and except as otherwise provided in this Code and except where contrary to state or federal law every corporation, company, association, joint stock company or association, partnership and person, their lessees, trustees or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, engaged in any business, occupation, pursuit, profession or trade, or in the keeping or maintaining of any institution, establishment, article, utility, or commodity specified in this section, but not limited to, shall procure and pay for a license therefore from the city; and such license fees shall be based on the annual gross receipts, business, commission, fees, charges and compensation for the preceding current year or fiscal year, as provided in section 18-5, according to the following table; provided, however, each licensee shall pay at least the minimum fee indicated and, provided further, shall pay the amount indicated for such occupation in place of the fee based on this table if a different fee be provided. Non-profit organizations are required to obtain a license but shall be exempt from the license fee. 
Fee Table 
Annual gross receipts     Fee per year 
$2,500.00 to $100,000.00 ..... $50.00 
$100,001.00 to 500,000.00 ..... 150.00 
$500,001.00 to 1,000,000.00 ..... 300.00 
$1,000,001.00 to 2,000,000.00 ..... 450.00 
$2,000,001.00 to 3,000,000.00 ..... 600.00 
$3,000,001.00 to 5,000,000.00 ..... 750.00 
Over 5,000,001.00 ..... 1,200.00 
Gross commission, salary, fees, and compensation: 
$00.00 to 25,000.00, per year ..... $50.00 
$25,001.00 to 50,000.00, per year ..... 160.00 
$50,001.00 to 100,000.00, per year ..... 320.00 
Over 100,001.00, per year ..... 480.00 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-17. - Enforcement of this chapter-Penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to exercise, carry on or engage in within the city for pay or profit, any of the occupations, pursuit, professions, trades, businesses, maintaining a business office, avocations office or agencies, without first obtaining a license to do so as required by this chapter. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be punished, where no other penalty is provided in this chapter by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such separate violation. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-17.1. - Authority of [deputy] city clerk to suspend licenses; hearings on suspensions. 
    The [deputy] city clerk shall have the power to issue subpoenas and all necessary processes and to require the production of papers, to administer oaths and to take testimony and to make findings thereon. He shall have the power to suspend or revoke any license granted under the terms of this chapter, pursuant to the provisions hereof, whenever it shall be shown or whenever he has knowledge of any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license. 
(2)  Any violation of the terms or provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Conduct of the business licensed under the provisions of this chapter in an unlawful manner. 
(4)  Failure to obtain, and maintain in good standing, a Missouri Retail Sales License referred to section 18-5.1. 
(5)  Refusal to allow the examination of the books and records of the licensee as provided in section 18-13. 
(6)  Failure to collect and remit all applicable taxes. 
    The licensee shall have five (5) days' notice of the intention to suspend or revoke the license, prior to the hearing on such suspension or revocation, with full right to have counsel, to produce witnesses on his behalf in such hearing and to be advised in writing of the grounds upon which his license is sought to be suspended or revoked. Such notice shall be mailed to the licensee at the last known address, at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. In the alternative, such notice of hearing may be delivered to the licensee by personal service. 
    Upon revocation or suspension, no refund of any portion of the license fee shall be made to the licensee, and the licensee shall immediately cease all business operations at each place found to be in violation of the provisions of this chapter or any other law or ordinance. 
    Any person violating any order of the [deputy] city clerk dealing with the suspension or revocation of any license made pursuant to this section continuing to engage in any business, profession or occupation during the term of such suspension or revocation shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day of such violation. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011; Ord. No. 10844,  II, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 18-17.2. - General duties of the police. 
    The chief of police and the police department shall cooperate with the [deputy] city clerk, finance director and other city officials for the strict enforcement of this chapter and all license ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 18-17.3 - Appeal-Procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the [deputy] city clerk in regard to the denial of an application for or revocation of a license as provided in this chapter or with the renewal of a license as provided in this chapter, shall have the right to appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal with the [deputy] city clerk for transmittal to the city council within fourteen (14) days after notice of the decision has been mailed to such person's last known address. The city council shall set the time and place for the hearing of such appeal. A notice of such hearing shall be mailed to the appellant at the last known address at least five (5) days prior to the date set forth for the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 9704,  I, 4-25-2011) 
Cross reference- City clerk,  2-41-2-45; deputy city clerk,  2-88-2-92. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING FOR FARMERS' MARKET 

Sec. 18-18. - Purpose. 
    The City of Liberty hereby authorizes the streets and parking lots in the vicinity of downtown Liberty to be used for the weekend farmers market. Any weekend farmers market shall be restricted to the downtown area. 
(Ord. No. 5287,  1, 2-9-87; Ord. No. 6853,  1, 7-11-94; Ord. No. 9099,  I, 2-26-07; Ord. No. 9276,  I, 3-3-08) 
Sec. 18-19. - Permit required. 
    Any farmers market within the City of Liberty shall obtain a temporary use permit from the department of development, and shall comply with all city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 5287,  1, 2-9-87; Ord. No. 6853,  1, 7-11-94; Ord. No. 9099,  II, 2-26-07; Ord. No. 9276,  II, 3-3-08) 
Sec. 18-20. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-21. - Enforcement. 
    The enforcement and administration of this article shall be the responsibility of the director of development or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 5287,  1, 2-9-87; Ord. No. 6853,  1, 7-11-94; Ord. No. 9276,  II, III, 3-3-08)

No. 7818,  I, 6-14-99; Ord. No. 9099,  III, 2-26-07.

    It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to violate, disobey, omit, neglect or refuse to comply with, or to resist enforcement of any of the provisions of this Code or chapter; and any such person, firm or corporation shall, upon conviction, be punished as described in section 22-70. 
(Ord. No. 5287,  1, 2-9-87; Ord. No. 6853,  1, 7-11-94; Ord. No. 9276,  I, 3-3-08)

ARTICLE VI. - LIGHT AND POWER COMPANIES 

Sec. 18-39. - License tax. 
    There is hereby levied, and the city accounting supervisor [director of finance], as ex officio collector of the city revenue, shall hereafter collect license taxes as provided in this article from light companies and power companies engaged in business in the city; and it shall be unlawful for any such light company or power company as herein defined to engage in such business without first having obtained a license therefor and having made all reports and paid all license taxes due in accordance with the terms of this article. Such license shall issue upon application and payment of tax for the initial quarter and continue in effect as long as there is no default in the payments of tax required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3282,  1) 
Sec. 18-40. - License tax rate, computation. 
    Such license tax shall be computed upon a monthly basis to be due and payable to the city on or before thirty (30) days following the close of the period for which the payment is due. The amount of such monthly license tax shall be a sum equal to six (6) percent of the gross receipts derived from the business of the company within present or future boundaries of the city during each calendar month, exclusive of electrical energy sold to the city. In the event it becomes impossible and impracticable for a licensee to compute and include in any monthly payment of tax all of such gross receipts for month for which the payment is due, such licensees shall pay the estimated amount of the tax and include the correct amount by adjusting the next succeeding monthly tax payment to the city without penalty. 
(Ord. No. 3282,  1; Ord. No. 10325,  I, 1-26-15) 
Sec. 18-41. - Financial reports required; inspection of books. 
    Each company licensed under this article shall make true and faithful reports, under oath by an officer thereof, to the city accounting supervisor [director of finance] in such form as contains such information as may be necessary to determine the amounts to which the license tax shall apply on or before the due date of each such license tax payment above provided. Acceptance of such tax shall not prejudice the right of the city to collect any additional taxes thereafter found to be due. The city accounting supervisor [director of finance], or any accountant selected by the city council, shall have the right, at all reasonable times, during business hours, to make such examinations and inspections of the books of the companies licensed under this article as may be necessary to determine the correctness of such reports. The city shall have the right, at its own expense, to employ the same accountants who make regular annual audits of the books, records and accounts of the business of the licensee to audit at the same time, its accounts and records, and certify as to the correctness of any payment due and payable by the licensee to the city. 
(Ord. No. 3282,  1) 
Sec. 18-42. - Penalty for unpaid tax. 
    For each and every month or part thereof any such license tax required by this article remains unpaid after the same becomes due and payable, there shall be added to such license tax, as a penalty for such delayed payment, ten (10) per cent of the amount of such license tax for the first month or part thereof the same is unpaid, and for each and every month thereafter two (2) per cent of the amount of such license tax, until the same is fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 3282,  1) 
Sec. 18-43. - Recovery of tax, etc., by legal action. 
    The city may maintain an action at law as a means of collecting such tax, and in the event of such action, and upon judgment for recovery if entered, the city shall recover, in addition to such tax and penalty, its reasonable costs and expenses, including attorney's fees as determined by the court having jurisdiction of such action. 
(Ord. No. 3282,  1) 
Sec. 18-44. - Applicability of article. 
    There are included in the terms of this article all light companies and power companies within the meaning of RSMo 94.360, except and excluding therefrom any light company or power company obligated to pay an equal amount and rate under franchise ordinances or franchise contracts between such company and the city. 
(Ord. No. 3282,  1) 
Sec. 18-45. - No exclusive privileges. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as giving a company licensed hereunder any exclusive privileges. 
(Ord. No. 3282,  1) 
Chapter 19 - MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Food establishments, Ch. 15; licenses, Ch. 18. 

Sec. 19-1. - Milk ordinance adopted. 
    The proposed milk ordinance promulgated by the state department of public health and welfare, division of health, veterinary public health unit, is hereby adopted and incorporated into this chapter as if fully set out herein; except, that in lieu of section 16, violation of any of the provisions herein shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2781,  2) 
Sec. 19-2. - Payment of license, etc., fees-Prerequisite to sale of milk, etc., within city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale within the city any milk or milk products unless all license fees and inspection fees required shall have been paid by all producers and distributors of the milk or milk products so sold or offered for sale. 
(Ord. No. 1681,  1) 
Sec. 19-3. - Same-Fees applicable to distributors. 
    All distributors of milk or milk products in the city at either wholesale or retail shall pay an annual license fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per annum plus an additional fee of one dollar ($1.00) for each inspection of such distributors' facilities by an authorized representative of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1681,  2) 
Sec. 19-4. - Same-Fees applicable to producers. 
    All producers of milk or milk products sold within the city by such producers or by any other person shall pay a fee of one dollar ($1.00) for each inspection of such producers' facilities by an authorized representative of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1681,  3) 
Sec. 19-5. - Enforcement of chapter; interpretation. 
    This chapter shall be enforced by the health officer in accordance with the 1965 Edition of the United States Public Health Service Milk Code, a certified copy of which is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 2781,  15) 
Chapter 20 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 25; taxicabs and other vehicles for hire, Ch. 28; open containers in motor vehicles,  3-24. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic generally, RSMo 300 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Alley: Any street with a roadway of less than twenty (20) feet in width. 
    Bicycle: Every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels, either of which is over twenty (20) inches in diameter and including any device generally recognized as a bicycle through equipped with two (2) front or two (2) rear wheels. 
    Bus: Every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten (10) passengers and used for the transportation of persons, and designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Business district: The territory contiguous to a street when fifty (50) per cent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business. 
    Child booster seat: A seating system which meets the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards set forth in 49 C.F.R. 571.213, as amended, that is designed to elevate a child to properly sit in a federally approved safety belt system. 
    Child passenger restraint system: A seating system which meets the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards set forth in 49 C.F.R. 571.213, as amended, and which is either permanently affixed to a motor vehicle or is affixed to such vehicle by a safety belt or a universal attachment system. 
    Commercial vehicle: Every vehicle designed, maintained and used primarily for the routine conduct of business, and clearly marked as such. 
    Construction/work zone: The term construction zone or work zone means any area upon or around any highway as defined in RSMO section 302.010 which is visibly marked by the City of Liberty or the Missouri Department of Transportation, or a contractor or subcontractor performing work for the City of Liberty or Missouri Department of Transportation as an area where construction, maintenance, incident removal, or other work is temporarily occurring. The term work zone or construction zone also includes the lanes of highway leading up to the area upon which an activity described in this subsection is being performed, beginning at the point where appropriate signs or traffic control devices are posted or placed. 
    Crosswalk: That portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or connection of curb and property lines at intersections or any other portion of a roadway clearly indicated for pedestrians crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Curb loading zone: A space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Driver: A person who is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle. 
    Emergency vehicles: Those vehicles which are clearly identified by flashing or rotating red, blue, amber, or red and white lights mounted on the roof or dashboard behind the front windshield of said vehicle and clearly visible at all times. Such identification may also consist of an insignia affixed by means of paint, decal, or other permanent device to the exterior of the vehicle, and clearly visible. Said vehicles shall also be equipped with an audible siren. 
    Freight curb loading zone: A space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight or passengers. 
    Intersection: The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines; or if none, then of the lateral boundary lines of two (2) or more streets which join one another at an angle, whether or not one such street crosses the other. 
    Laned roadway: A roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Legal holidays: (1) The first day of January (New Year's Day); (2) the third Monday of January (Martin Luther King's Birthday); (3) the twelfth day of February (Lincoln's Birthday); (4) the third Monday in February (Washington's Birthday); (5) the eighth day of May (Truman's Birthday); (6) the last Monday in May (Memorial Day); (7) the fourth day of July (Independence Day); (8) the first Monday in September (Labor Day); (9) the second Monday in October (Columbus Day); (10) the eleventh day of November (Veteran's Day); (11) the fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving); (12) the fourth Friday in November; and (13) the twenty-fifth day of December (Christmas). 
    When any such holidays fall on Saturday, the Friday preceding shall be considered the holiday. 
    When any such holidays fall on Sunday, the Monday next shall be considered the holiday. 
    Motor scooter, moped, or motorized bicycle: Any two-wheeled device having an automatic transmission and a motor with a cylinder capacity of not more than fifty (50) cubic centimeters. 
    Motor vehicle: Every vehicle which is self-propelled. 
    Motorcycle: Every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Official government vehicle: A vehicle publicly owned and operated by the state highway patrol, police or fire department, or sheriff's department. 
    Official traffic-control devices: All signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of the city council for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    One-way streets or alleys: A one-way street or alley is any street or alley upon which all vehicular and bicycle traffic is restricted to movement in one direction only. 
    Park: When prohibited, means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading.
