(Ord. No. 1901, art. 4,  10) 
Sec. 20-72. - Designation of crosswalks, safety zones, etc. 
    The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized; 
(a)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrian crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(b)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(c)  To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with this chapter or other traffic ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 4,  11) 
Sec. 20-73. - Designation of emergency snow routes. 
    Emergency snow routes may be designated to expedite the flow of traffic. Such streets comprising emergency snow routes are listed in schedule I, section 20-171. 
(Ord. No. 2202,  1) 
ARTICLE VI. - SPEED LIMITS 

Sec. 20-74. - Restrictions generally. 
    No person shall drive or operate a vehicle upon a street at a greater speed than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard to the traffic, surface and width of the street and the hazard at intersections and any other condition then existing. Every driver or operator of a vehicle shall exercise the highest degree of care, particularly in driving at a rate of speed so as not to endanger the life, limb or property of any person. 
    No person shall drive or operate at a speed which is greater than will permit the driver or operator to exercise proper control of the vehicle and to decrease speed or stop, as may be necessary, to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance upon or entering the street in compliance with the legal requirements and with the duty of drivers and operators and other persons using the street and to exercise due care; provided, that this provision shall not be construed to relieve the plaintiff in any civil action from the burden of proving negligence upon the part of the defendant and that such negligence is the proximate cause of an accident. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 6,  1) 
Sec. 20-75. - Regulation of speed. 
    It is hereby determined upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that those streets or portions of streets described in schedule II is necessary for safe operation of vehicles thereon and it is hereby declared that the prima facie speed limit upon those streets or portions thereof described in such schedule II, section 20-172 shall be therein stated, which speeds so declared shall be effective at the time specified therein when signs are erected giving notice thereof. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of the posted maximum limit within a construction or work zone. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 6,  2; Ord. No. 10920,  I, II, 5-14-18) 
Sec. 20-76. - Slow speed prohibited under certain conditions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person unnecessarily to drive at such slow speed as to impede traffic, except when reduced speed is necessary for safe operation or because upon a grade or when the vehicle is a truck or truck and trailer necessarily or in compliance with the law proceeding at reduced speed. 
    Traffic and police officers are hereby authorized to enforce this provision by directions to the drivers, and in the event of apparent willful disobedience to the provisions and refusal to comply with the directions of an officer in accordance herewith, the continued slow operation by a driver shall be unlawful and constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 6,  3) 
ARTICLE VII. - TURNING MOVEMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Turns at intersections, RSMo 304.341. 

Sec. 20-77. - Turning at intersections. 
    The drivers of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall do so as follows: 
(a)  Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made close as practical to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway; 
(b)  Approach for a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the center line thereof and after entering the intersection, the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection to the right of the center line of the roadway being entered; 
(c)  Approach for a left turn from a two-way street into a one-way street shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the center line thereof and by passing at the right of such center line where it enters the intersection. A left turn from a one-way street into a two-way street shall be made by passing to the right of the center line of the street entered, upon leaving the intersection; 
(d)  Where both streets or roadways are one way, both the approach for a left turn and a left turn shall be made as close as practicable to the left-hand curb or edge of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 8,  1) 
Sec. 20-78. - Turning markers. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized to place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections, and such course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as prescribed by law, this chapter or other ordinance. 
    When authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 8,  2) 
Sec. 20-79. - Restricted turn signs. 
    The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left or "U" turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event, the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs or they may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 8,  3) 
Sec. 20-80. - Obedience to turn signs. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left or "U" turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 8,  4) 
Sec. 20-81. - Limitations on turning around. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district and shall not upon any other street so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(1901, art. 8,  5) 
Sec. 20-81.1. - Right turn on red signal prohibited or restricted. 
    Right turns on red signals are prohibited at all intersections so designated in section 20-174, schedule IV, and no driver of any vehicle shall make any turn from those intersections except upon a green signal unless otherwise permitted as posted. 
(Ord. No. 4236,  1, 5-12-80; Ord. No. 9126,  I, 4-23-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4236,  1, adopted May 12, 1980, repealed  20-81.1 and 20-81.2, pertaining to right turns at all times and right turns on red signals prohibited, respectively. Said sections derived from Ord. No. 2365,  1; Ord. No. 2536,  2; and Ord. No. 3397. Ord. No. 4236 enacted a new  20-81.1 as set out above. 
Sec. 20-81.2. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note for  20-81.1. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS 

Sec. 20-82. - Signs. 
    Whenever this chapter or any other ordinance of the city designates any one-way street or alley, the city traffic engineer [director of community development] shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(1901, art. 9,  1) 
Sec. 20-83. - Designated. 
    Upon those streets and parts of streets and in those alleys described in Schedule III, section 20-173, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(1901, art. 9,  2) 
ARTICLE IX. - SPECIAL STOPS 

Sec. 20-84. - "Throughway" defined. 
    Within the meaning of this article, not less than twenty-two (22) feet in width shall constitute an unobstructed freeway, travelway or throughway on all state and federal marked highways in this municipality. 
(1913,  2) 
Sec. 20-85. - Off-street parking lots. 
    Every motor vehicle shall stop before entering any street from any off-street parking lot in the city. 
(2297,  1) 
Sec. 20-86. - Street classification system. 
    Those streets and parts of streets shown on Figure I are hereby declared and classified as express, freeway, arterial or collector streets for the purpose of this section and that such Figure I shall be maintained on file in the office of the [deputy] city clerk and city engineer [director of community development] and shall be updated from time to time with the approval of the city council. 
(3393) 
Sec. 20-87. - Authority to erect stop signs. 
    Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of the city designates and describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer [director of community development] to place and maintain a stop sign on each street intersecting such through street or intersecting that portion thereon designated as such by this chapter or any ordinance of the city. 
(1901, art. 10,  8) 
Sec. 20-88. - Stop intersections. 
    The city traffic engineer [director of community development] is hereby authorized to determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist upon other than through streets and to determine whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such stop intersection, and shall erect a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required. Such stop sign locations are hereby declared to be those specified in Schedule V, Section 20-175. 
(1901, art. 10,  9) 
Sec. 20-89. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3841 repealed  20-89. 
Sec. 20-90. - Yield right-of-way intersections. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle into a through street without first bringing such vehicle to a stop and yielding the right-of-way to crossing traffic when necessary at a yield right-of-way sign erected on those streets listed in Schedule VII, Section 20-177. 
(2799,  1) 
Sec. 20-91. - Signalized intersections. 
    The city traffic engineer [director of community development] shall be responsible for placing and maintaining traffic control signals at these intersections which shall be designated by ordinance. Such intersections are described in Section 20-184, Schedule XIV, of this chapter. 
(1901, art. 10,  9; Ord. No. 4236,  2, 5-12-80) 
Sec. 20-92. - Specifications for stop signs. 
    Every sign erected pursuant to this article shall bear the word "stop" in letters not less than six (6) inches in height and such sign shall at nighttime be rendered luminous by efficient reflecting elements on the face of the sign. 
(1901, art. 10,  10) 
Sec. 20-93. - Vehicles required to stop at stop signs. 
    When stop signs are erected as provided at or near the entrance to any intersection, every driver of a vehicle shall stop such vehicle at such sign or at a clearly marked stop line before entering the intersection, except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic-control signal. 
(1901, art. 10,  11) 
Sec. 20-94. - Emerging from alley or private driveway. 
    The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or onto sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yielding the right-of-way to any pedestrian as may be necessary to avoid collision, and upon entering the roadway, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway. 
(1901, art. 10,  12) 
Sec. 20-95. - Obstructing intersections. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. 
(1901, art. 10,  13) 
Sec. 20-96. - Stopping at school stop signs. 
    Every person operating a motor vehicle on the streets of the city shall, when approaching a school stop sign located in the roadway, bring such vehicle to a stop before entering the nearest crosswalk. 
(1901, art. 10,  14) 
Sec. 20-96.1. - Stopping for school bus; equipment for school buses. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle upon any public roadway, when meeting or overtaking from either direction any school bus which has stopped on the roadway for the purpose of receiving or discharging any school children, and whose driver has, in the manner prescribed by law, given the signal to stop, shall stop the vehicle before reaching such school bus and shall not proceed until such school bus resumes motion, or until signaled by its driver to proceed. 
(b)  Every bus used for the transportation of school children shall bear, upon the front and rear thereon, a plainly visible sign containing the words, "SCHOOL BUS" in letters not less than eight (8) inches in height. Each bus shall have lettered on the rear, in plain and distinctive type, the following: "STATE LAW: STOP WHILE BUS IS LOADING AND UNLOADING." Each school bus shall be equipped with a mechanical and electrical signalling device, which will display a signal plainly visible from the front and rear indicating intention to stop as required by state statute. 
(c)  No driver of a school bus shall take on or discharge passengers at any location upon a public roadway consisting of four (4) or more lanes of traffic, whether or not divided by a median or barrier, in such manner as to require the passengers to cross more than two (2) lanes of traffic; nor shall he take on or discharge passengers while the vehicle is upon the road or roadway proper unless the vehicle so stopped is plainly visible for at least three hundred (300) feet in each direction to drivers of other vehicles upon the roadway and then only for such time as is actually necessary to take on and discharge passengers. 
(d)  The driver of a vehicle upon a public roadway with separate roadways need not stop upon meeting or overtaking a school bus which is on a different roadway, or which is stopped in a loading zone constituting a part of, or adjacent to, a limited or controlled access roadway at a point where pedestrians are not permitted to cross the roadway. 
(e)  If any vehicle is witnessed by a police officer or the driver of a school bus to have violated the provisions of this section and the identity of the operator is not otherwise apparent, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that the person in whose name the vehicle is registered committed the violation. In the event that charges are filed against multiple owners of a motor vehicle, only one of the owners may be convicted and court costs may be assessed against only one of the owners. If the vehicle which is involved in the violation in registered in the name of a rental or leasing company and the vehicle is rented or leased to another person at the time of the violation, the rental or leasing company may rebut the presumption by providing the police officer or prosecuting authority with a copy of the rental or lease agreement in effect at the time of the violation. No prosecuting authority may bring any legal proceedings against any rental or leasing company under this section unless prior written notice has been given to that rental or leasing company by registered mail at the address appearing on the registration and the rental or leasing company has failed to provide the rental or lease agreement copy within fifteen (15) days of receipt of such notice. 
(f)  Every person who is convicted of a violation of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 2840,  1-4; Ord. No. 5229,  1, 10-27-86) 
ARTICLE X. - RESERVED[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) ---

Secs. 20-97-20-107. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 20-108. - Duties at controlled intersections. 
    On streets where traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals or by police officers, pedestrians shall not cross a roadway against a red signal and shall not cross at any place except in a marked or unmarked crosswalk. A pedestrian shall not cross the roadway at any point other than at a marked or unmarked crosswalk in the business district. 
(1901, art. 12,  1) 
Sec. 20-109. - Right-of-way in crosswalks. 
    When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger, but no pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle, which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(1901, art. 12,  2) 
Sec. 20-110. - Keeping to the right side of crosswalks. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of the crosswalk. 
(1901, art. 12,  3) 
Sec. 20-111. - Pedestrian travel on roadways. 
    By definition "pedestrian travel" shall include all travel on foot, whether by ordinary foot travel, or upon roller skates or skateboards. 
    It shall be unlawful, and constitute a misdemeanor, for any person to do, perform or commit any of the following acts: 
(1)  To proceed by pedestrian travel on or along or upon and adjacent to the roadway regularly used by vehicular traffic where sidewalks are available. 
(2)  Where sidewalks are not available, to fail to proceed by pedestrian travel upon any portion of a roadway on the left half thereof and as near the left-hand side of said roadway as practicable, including any shoulder, so that the pedestrian faces traffic approaching from the opposite direction. 
(3)  To proceed by pedestrian travel on any roadway at any time from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise, or at any other time when there is not sufficient light to render clearly discernible persons upon the roadway at a distance of five hundred (500) feet, without displaying upon the person of the pedestrian, so as to be clearly visible, both on the front and on the back, a reflective surface of sufficient area to be seen at a distance of not less than five hundred (500) feet, excepting herefrom pedestrians walking (as distinguished from jogging, running or other pace) upon such roadway. 
(4)  To stand upon the traveled portion of any street or roadway which carries motor vehicular traffic, or upon any median divider of the same, except as follows: 
(a)  To give warning of a hazardous condition, or for reporting the occurrence of or seeking assistance in the event of accident or casualty on or near the street or roadway. 
(b)  As to those whose presence is necessary on account of street or road construction or repair. 
(c)  As to those standing on the median strip at an intersection to await clearing traffic while proceeding by pedestrian travel across. 
All of the prohibitions set out in this section are found and declared to be necessary for the safety of the traveling public and to avoid disconcerting and distracting, or otherwise diverting the attention of the operators of motor vehicles who are required, by law, to exercise the highest degree of care. 
(5)  Pursuant to Section 24-15 (Solicitation on Public Streets), individuals or organizations may be permitted to solicit on public streets under the conditions and stipulations set forth in said Code. 
(Ord. No. 4780,  3, 5-14-84; Ord. No. 5009,  1, 7-22-85; Ord. No. 9480,  I, 8-10-09) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4780, adopted May 14, 1984, repealed  20-111, "Walking along roadways," as derived from Ord. No. 1901, Art. 12,  4. Section 3 enacted a new  20-111. 
Cross reference- Use of roller skates, skateboards, coasters, etc.,  20-55. 
Sec. 20-112. - Soliciting rides. 
    No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. 
(1901, art. 12,  4) 
Sec. 20-113. - Care to be exercised by drivers. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this article, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(1901, art. 12,  5) 
ARTICLE XII. - MOTOR SCOOTERS; MOTOR BIKES AND ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES 

Sec. 20-114. - Limitations on operation. 
    No person shall operate any motor vehicle, commonly referred to as a "go-kart," which makes a loud noise and which disturbs the peace and quietude of any neighborhood within the city, except on a legally established track designed specifically for the racing of such vehicles. 
(2232,  1) 
Sec. 20-115. - Speed limits; equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate upon any street, boulevard, parkway or any public park in the city a motor scooter or motor bike, except under the following conditions: 
(a)  Brakes. It shall be equipped with brakes sufficient to stop the same within thirty (30) feet at a speed of twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(b)  Driver's license. He shall first procure a state driver's license to operate the same. 
(c)  Speed. The speed thereof shall never exceed twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(d)  Speedometer, horn, lights, etc. It shall be equipped with a speedometer, if available, adequate springs, and shock absorbers, a horn or other warning device, at least one and not more than two (2) approved head lamps, at least one red approved rear light. For the purpose of revealing its position and direction, a motor scooter or motor bike, while on the highway, whether in operation or at rest during the period when the street lights are turned on, and in any event from thirty (30) minutes after sunset to thirty (30) minutes before sunrise, and all times when fog or other atmospheric conditions render the operation of motor vehicles dangerous on the highway, shall carry lighted signal lamps as herein required. 
(1901, art. 13,  1) 
Sec. 20-115.1. - All-terrain vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall operate an unlicensed all-terrain vehicle, as described below, in the parks, upon the sidewalks, streets, alleys and public ways of this city. All-terrain vehicles may be used on private property on tracts of land three acres or larger, between the hours of 6 a.m. and 10 p.m. 
(b)  An all-terrain vehicle is defined as any motorized vehicle manufactured exclusively for off-roadway use which is fifty (50) inches or less in width, with an unladen dry weight of six hundred (600) pounds or less, traveling on three (3), four (4) or more low-pressure tires, with a seat designed to be straddled by the operator, and handlebars for steering control. 
(Ord. No. 5371,  1, 8-17-87; Ord. No. 9044,  I, 10-23-06) 
ARTICLE XIII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Parking for the physically handicapped,  20-220 et seq. 

Sec. 20-116. - Parking in municipal parking lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any motor vehicle of a width greater than eight (8) feet, or a length greater than twenty-one (21) feet to allow or permit such motor vehicle to be parked on any municipal parking lot between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-117. - Taxicab stands, bus zones, and special restricted parking zones. 
(a)  The city engineer is hereby authorized and required to establish bus stop, taxicab stands, stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles, and special restricted parking zones on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every bus stop, taxicab stand, other stand or special restricted parking zone shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
    Special restricted parking zones shall be established on a temporary basis to accommodate special uses of areas of public streets, at the discretion of the city engineer. 
(b)  Every duly licensed taxicab business owning or leasing a regular place of business within the city may, upon application to and approval of the city council, have the privilege of marking off and reserving on the street in front of such business a space required for the parking of two (2) taxicabs and, upon such approval by the city council, shall have the sole and exclusive right to reserve the same for the vehicles used in their business and no other person shall have the right to use the space so marked and reserved; provided that any taxicab business which is licensed to operate but a single car shall only have the right to mark off and reserve space required for such car. 
    The space reserved as provided by this section shall not extend beyond the property which such business owns or leases, unless the written consent of the owner of the adjoining property affected shall be obtained and filed with the [deputy] city clerk. 
(c)  The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus zone or taxicab stand, respectively; except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. Bus zones are hereby designated as those specified in Schedule IX, section 20-179. 
(d)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed; except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(e)  No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle other than a bona fide emergency vehicle or an official government vehicle in any zone clearly marked as a restricted parking zone, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in unloading or loading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any such vehicles as defined in this chapter waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(3378; 3841,  4; Ord. No. 8076,  I, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 20-117.1. - Exclusive parking spaces for city-owned vehicles in the public parking lot located at Missouri and Kansas Streets. 
    The city engineer is hereby authorized to erect signs designating certain parking spaces in the city hall/police facility parking lot, at Kansas and Missouri Streets, for the exclusive use of city-owned motor vehicles. 
(1)  The parking spaces on the west side of the city lot, north of the pedestrian crosswalk, will be designated exclusively for marked police vehicles and the animal control vehicle of the City of Liberty, Missouri. 
(2)  The parking spaces on the west side of the city lot, south of the pedestrian crosswalk, will be designated exclusively for city-owned vehicles of the City of Liberty, Missouri and will be limited to thirty-minute parking. 
(3)  The parking spaces on the south side of the city lot, from a point twenty-four (24) feet east of the west property line of the City lot, will be designated exclusively for city-owned vehicles of the City of Liberty, Missouri. 
    Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punishable as prescribed in section 20-167 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6142,  1, 5-13-91; Ord. No. 7268,  3, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 20-117.2. - Residential parking permits. 
(1)  Residential parking permit area. The city council authorizes the city engineer and chief of police to designate areas within the City of Liberty consisting of streets or portions of streets where parking is restricted to those vehicles bearing a valid parking permit issued through the department of public works. Such designated areas shall be maintained in a schedule in the official files of the city engineer, which are available for review as required by law. 
(2)  Designation of residential parking permit areas. A residential area shall be eligible for designation as a residential parking permit area after residents submit a petition and studies are conducted by the department of public works to determine if the area is significantly impacted by vehicles owned by nonresidents. In arriving at such findings staff shall consider the following factors: 
(a)  The number of parked vehicles approaches the legal on-street parking capacity of the area; 
(b)  The number of parked vehicles in the area is comprised of vehicles not registered to residents of the area; 
(c)  Where parking by vehicles owned by nonresidents puts an undue burden on area residents attempting to gain access to their residences and where such area residents are willing to bear the administrative costs associated with the establishment of a residential parking permit area. 
(d)  Where creating a parking permit area will promote the health, safety and welfare of the residence of the city by reducing personal motor vehicle travel, noise, pollution, litter, crime and hazardous traffic conditions and will promote protection of children and other pedestrians from bodily injury and the free flow of emergency vehicles in the area and will protect residence from unreasonable burdens in gaining access to their property, preserve neighborhood living within the city, maintain the convenience and attractiveness of residential living and preserve the residential character of the area. 
(3)  Parking within residential parking permit areas. 
(a)  The city engineer shall provide parking permits to the residents in each residential parking permit area and erect parking signs in the area, indicating the times and conditions under which parking shall be by permit only; 
(b)  Upon submission of an application and payment of a five-dollar ($5.00) processing fee, any single-family residence adjacent to the street within a residential parking permit area shall be entitled to up to two (2) permits. Any multi-family residence within such an area shall be entitled to one permit for each unit. An additional permit may be granted to certain residences where the property owner can demonstrate that unique conditions exist that warrant such consideration. Proof of residency shall be required prior to the issuance of each permit. 
(4)  Fines. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punishable as prescribed in section 20-167 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 9165,  I, 7-23-07; Ord. No. 9194,  I, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 20-118. - Obstructing traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle on the public streets of the city in such a manner that will interfere with the free and unencumbered passage of other motor vehicles over and along the public streets of the city or in such a position that will interfere with the movement of emergency vehicles such as fire trucks, police cars and ambulances. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-119. - Obstructing traffic by parking. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon a street, or within an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-120. - Declaration of emergency snow conditions. 
(a)  Notification of declaration of traffic snow emergency: Upon the declaration of a traffic snow emergency by the director of public works, there shall be placed upon the front window at the Liberty City Hall a notice that a traffic snow emergency has been declared and said notice shall remain posted on said front window until said traffic emergency is abated. In addition, the city shall post a notice on its web site and use whatever practical means are at its disposal, including social media, to broadcast the fact that a traffic snow emergency has been declared by the City of Liberty and that the provisions of this chapter are in effect during said traffic emergency. 
(1)  Phase I, "Driving Emergency." When snow, sleet or freezing rain is causing slippery or hazardous conditions which might lead to serious traffic congestion, the mayor or designee may declare a traffic emergency; and until such emergency is terminated no person shall operate a motor vehicle on any street in such manner or in such condition as to allow or permit such vehicle to become stalled by reason of the fact that the driving wheels of such vehicles are not equipped with tire chains or snow tires. 
(2)  Phase II, "Snow Routes Parking Emergency." Whenever snow has accumulated, or it is probable that snow will accumulate to such a depth that snow removal operations will be required, the mayor or designee may declare a snow routes parking emergency; and until such emergency is terminated, no vehicles shall be parked on streets designated by appropriate signs as snow routes. All vehicles parked on such streets must be removed within two (2) hours after declaration of emergency or be considered in violation of this section. 
(3)  Phase III, "Central Business District Parking Emergency." Whenever snow has accumulated, or it is probable that snow will accumulate to such a depth that snow removal operations will be required, the mayor or designee may declare a central business district parking emergency; and until such an emergency is terminated no vehicles shall be parked on the following streets in the central business district: Kansas, Gallatin to Leonard; Franklin, Gallatin to Missouri; Water, Mill or two hundred twenty-six (226) feet north of Franklin; Main, Mill to Mississippi; and Missouri, Mill to Franklin. All vehicles parked on such streets must be removed within two (2) hours after declaration of emergency or be considered in violation of this section. 
(b)  Termination of traffic snow emergency: After the declaration of a traffic snow emergency as set forth herein the prohibition against parking or impeding the free flow of traffic or removal of snow, sleet and ice conditions upon said emergency snow routes shall remain in effect until terminated by the announcement of the director of public works. Said termination shall also be evidenced by a notice of said termination upon the public bulletin board in the Liberty City Hall and public service announcements by a radio or television stations whose broadcasts are normally received in the Liberty area. 
    Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punishable as prescribed in section 20-167 of this Code. 
(3359; Ord. No. 4495,  1, 4-12-82; Ord. No. 4924,  1, 2-11-85; Ord. No. 7268,  4, 6-24-96; Ord. No. 10998,  I, 11-26-18) 
Sec. 20-121. - Parking prohibited at all times at certain places. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(a)  On a sidewalk, except motor scooters, mopeds, or motorized bicycles, when the motor is not running and parked in a manner so as not to impede pedestrian traffic; 
(b)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(c)  Within an intersection; 
(d)  Within an area eight (8) feet on each side of a fire hydrant or any other fire protection system control valve; 
(e)  On a crosswalk; 
(f)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(g)  On the roadside of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street, except in an emergency (double park); 
(h)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel; 
(i)  At any place where an official sign or yellow curb markings prohibit parking; 
(j)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from curb such distance as is unlawful; 
(k)  At any point along the edge or curb of each street measured from each intersection as follows: Beginning at the nearest property line and extending away from such intersection a distance of twenty (20) feet; 
(l)  On the travelled portion of any roadway where parking is prohibited under section 20-180, "Schedule X, parking prohibited at all times;" 
(m)  At any place where an official sign or paint markings shall designate an official fire lane or fire zone as established by the fire chief or his designated representative. 
(3378; Ord. No. 3956,  1, 5-23-78; Ord. No. 4006,  2, 9-11-78; Ord. No. 4266,  3, 7-14-80; Ord. No. 4744,  1, 2-13-84; Ord. No. 9452,  II, 5-11-09) 
Cross reference- Obstructing fire hydrants,  14-6; parking in residential front yard a nuisance,  21-3. 
Sec. 20-121.1. - Truck parking prohibited in residential areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver, owner or operator of any bus, recreational vehicle, truck of one ton or more, truck tractor, trailer, tractor trailer, or truck trailer combination to park or cause to be parked such vehicle for longer than two (2) hours at any one time on any street in a residential district as described in the zoning ordinances of the city, being district R-1A through R-7 inclusive; provided, however, that said vehicles may be parked in conjunction with the conduct of business in such district during normal business hours of said business, but subject to all other ordinances regulating parking at said location. No notice or sign reflecting said prohibition shall be required to be posted. 
(3498; Ord. No. 6338,  1, 4-13-92; Ord. No. 6369,  1, 11-9-92) 
Sec. 20-122. - All-night parking. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle on any street in the business district for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. of any day, except physicians on emergency calls. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful within a residential district as described in the zoning ordinance of the city, being districts R-1A through R-7 inclusive, for any driver, owner or operator of any bus, truck, truck tractor or trailer to park and leave said vehicle unattended with the engine, auxiliary engines or motors running, whether on a public street, public roadway or private property during the hours from sunset to the next following sunrise. 
(3378; Ord. No. 5180,  1, 7-28-86) 
Sec. 20-123. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(a)  Displaying the vehicle for sale; 
(b)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
(c)  Trucks or other vehicles carrying merchandise or freight shall not park at the front curb of any retail store for the purpose of discharging or picking up such merchandise or freight to or from such retail store when there is available at the back or side of such store an alley or private right-of-way which may be used for the purpose of such parking. 
(3378) 
Cross reference- Parking vehicle for purpose of sale prohibited,  20-28; repairing vehicles on street prohibited except in emergencies,  20-30; parking of nonoperating vehicles in residential zones,  22-36.1. 
Sec. 20-124. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
    The city engineer [director of community development] is hereby authorized to erect signs or provide yellow curb markings indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
    When official signs or yellow curb markings are provided indicating no parking upon that side of the street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-125. - Parking on posted school property; removal of vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver, operator or owner of any motor vehicle to enter onto, stop, stand or park such vehicle on any posted school property without the consent of the superintendent, principal or a delegated agent. 
    "Posted" shall mean the displaying of a sign not smaller than six (6) inches in height and eighteen (18) inches in width exposed to the public view, and located at some prominent location on the school property bearing the following information: 
SCHOOL PROPERTY-NO PARKING WITHOUT THE CONSENT OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OR PRINCIPAL: 
ORDINANCE _______ OF THE CITY OF LIBERTY, MISSOURI. CARS IN VIOLATION WILL BE TOWED AWAY AND VIOLATORS WILL BE PROSECUTED. 
    If at any time a vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of this section, the police department, upon complaint of the superintendent or principal or a delegated agent, may remove or cause to be removed the vehicle, keeping it in its custody or control until redeemed by the owner thereof. 
    Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punishable as prescribed in section 20-167 of this Code, and in addition thereto shall be assessed the costs and all charges incurred by the city in causing such vehicles to be removed and/or stored until redeemed by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 3378; Ord. No. 7268,  5, 6-24-96)

Sec. 20-126. - Parking prohibited on narrow streets. 
    The city engineer [director of community development] is hereby authorized to erect signs or provide yellow curb markings indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty (20) feet, or upon one side of a street as indicated by such signs or yellow curb markings when the width of the roadway does not exceed thirty (30) feet. 
    When official signs or yellow curb markings have been placed upon narrow streets, as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of such sign or markings. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-127. - Standing or parking on one-way streets. 
    The city engineer [director of community development] is authorized to place signs or yellow curb markings upon the left-hand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles, and when such signs or markings are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such left-hand side in violation of any such sign or curb marking. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-128. - Hazardous or congested places. 
    The city engineer [director of community development] is hereby authorized to determine and designate by proper signs or yellow curb markings places not exceeding one hundred (100) feet in length in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
    When official signs or curb markings are placed at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-129. - Loading zones. 
(a)  General restrictions. When signs are erected, and yellow spaces are marked, giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to stop, stand or park such vehicle for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes, and only then for the explicit purpose of loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
(b)  Exception. Any delivery vehicle, owned by a business located in the Central Business District, which is clearly and permanently marked as being a delivery vehicle for said business may park in a marked loading zone during normal business hours. 
(c)  Loading zones enumerated. Spaces so designated and marked shall be set forth in Schedule XXIII, Section 20-193. 
(3378; 3750; Ord. No. 5146,  1, 5-27-86) 
Sec. 20-130. - Parking on right-hand side of street required; exception. 
    All motor vehicles shall be parked on the right-hand side of the street, except on one-way streets where parking is permitted on both sides of the street. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-131. - Manner of parking. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way roadway where parking is permitted shall be so stopped or parked that the right-hand wheels of the vehicle are parallel to and within eighteen (18) inches of the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway. Parking of motor vehicles on streets within the city limits shall be parallel to the curb line, except where angle parking is specifically authorized. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way street or roadway where parking is permitted shall be so stopped or parked that the right-hand wheels of the vehicle are parallel to and within eighteen (18) inches of the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway, or the left-hand wheels of said vehicle within eighteen (18) inches of the left-hand curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction of authorized traffic movement. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, when angle parking or perpendicular parking is required, the front wheel, or wheels, of every vehicle so parked shall be within six (6) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway. 
(d)  No vehicle shall park in any designated parking space so as to occupy more than one parking space. 
(3378; Ord. No. 4006,  3, 9-11-78; Ord. No. 4214,  1, 3-10-80; Ord. No. 4631,  1, 4-11-83) 
Sec. 20-132. - Parking prohibited at all times on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected, or yellow curb markings provided, giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets specified in Schedule X, section 20-180. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-133. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited during certain hours on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected, or yellow curb markings provided, in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle between the hours specified in Schedule XI, section 20-181 on any day except Sundays and public holidays within the district or upon any of the streets described in such schedule. 
(3378) 
Sec. 20-134. - Parking time limited on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected, or yellow curb markings provided, in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the time permitted by such signs within the district or upon any of the streets specified in Schedule XII, section 20-182. Changing the position of a vehicle from one point to another within the Central Business District shall be deemed one continuous parking period. 
(3378; Ord. No. 4568,  2, 11-22-82; Ord. No. 9039,  I, 10-9-06; Ord. No. 9039,  I, 10-9-06)

Franklin Street, from Water Street to Main Street and on the north side only from Main Street to Missouri Street;

Main Street, from Franklin Street to Kansas Street;

(3378) 
Sec. 20-137. - Parking trucks on certain streets or parts of streets.

(3378) 
Sec. 20-138. - Parking on posted private property.

    "Posted' shall mean the displaying, in plain view at all entrances to the property, a sign not less than seventeen (17) by twenty-two (22) inches in size, with lettering not less than one inch in height, prohibiting public parking and indicating that unauthorized abandoned property or property parked in a restricted or assigned area will be removed at the owner's expense, disclosing the maximum fee for all charges related to towing and storage, and containing the telephone number of the Liberty Police Department (816.439.4702). 
(Ord. No. 10578,  II, 5-23-16)

(3378)

    Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of section 20-138 shall be punished as prescribed in section 20-167 and, in addition thereto, shall be assessed the costs all charges incurred by the city in causing such vehicles to be removed and/or stored until redeemed by owner. 
(Ord. No. 3378; Ord. No. 7268,  6, 6-24-96)

Sec. 20-141. - Parking adjacent to certain state highways restricted.

Sec. 20-144. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 20-145. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle or other personal property: An automobile or personal property which remains upon the streets or other public property for a period longer than forty-eight (48) hours, the owner of which cannot be located or the owner refuses to remove the same. 
    Unidentified motor vehicle or other personal property: Motor vehicle or other personal property where ownership thereof cannot be ascertained. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 17,  1) 
Sec. 20-146. - Unidentified, abandoned vehicles. 
    The police department is hereby authorized in its discretion, in addition to any penalty that may be provided therefor, to remove any unidentified, stolen, wrecked or abandoned motor vehicle or other personal property found upon any public street or other public property of the city and shall keep the same in its custody and control at such place as may be designated by such police department until redeemed by the owner thereof, as provided in this article. All such unidentified, stolen, wrecked or abandoned motor vehicles or other personal property which now is in the possession and custody of the police department or which may come into its possession shall be subject to the actual cost of removal or tow-in from the public place and a reasonable storage charge for as long as the same is in possession and custody of such department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 17,  1) 
Sec. 20-146.1. - Towing of vehicles-Emergency snow conditions. 
    Vehicles in violation of subsections (a), (b), or (c) of section 20-120, may be towed and stored upon the authority of the police department, by any tow service licensed to operate within the city as provided in section 20-146, and may be recovered only on payment for such cost of tow-in and storage. 
(Ord. No. 3359) 
Sec. 20-147. - Leaving or abandoning vehicles, etc., prohibited. 
    It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any owner or any person in charge of a motor vehicle or other personal property to leave or abandon the same upon the streets or public places. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 17,  1) 
Sec. 20-148. - Disposal of unredeemed vehicles, etc.; disposition of proceeds. 
    All motor vehicles and other personal property impounded by the police department pursuant to the provisions of this article, and unredeemed by the owner thereof for a period of sixty (60) days, shall thereafter be subject to sale by the assistant chief of police or the city clerk to the highest bidder for cash or at public auction, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied first, to all removal and storage charges accumulated against each article, which shall be deposited with the city treasurer and credited to the general fund of the city; and the balance of such sum, if any, shall be deposited with the city treasurer and shall be kept in a separate fund for a period of one year from the date of receipt, and if at the end of such year the former owner of such property has not made satisfactory proof of claim as provided, then the balance of such proceeds of sale shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 17,  2) 
Sec. 20-149. - Redeeming impounded vehicles. 
    Any person claiming to be the owner of any impounded property as in this article provided, shall make written application therefor to the police department and shall furnish to such department such additional proof as may be required to establish such ownership. If he shall present to such department proof of his ownership of such impounded property prior to the date of actual sale thereof pursuant to the provisions of this article, then the property itself shall be delivered to such owner under the conditions herein provided; but, if such property has been sold, then such department shall endorse its findings of ownership with a copy of the written application addressed to the city clerk, and such owner may present such application and findings to the city clerk and if presented within one year after sale, then such balance of the proceeds of sale, after deductions as in this article provided, shall be paid to the owner. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 17,  3) 
Sec. 20-150. - Notice of storage and sale of impounded vehicles. 
    On the first day of each month the police department shall forward to the city clerk a copy of its office description and all other pertinent information which may be required by the city clerk concerning each motor vehicle impounded under the provisions of this article, and held for a period of sixty (60) days unredeemed by its owner, and thereafter required. Immediately before the actual making of any sale, the city clerk shall submit his list to the police department of properties to be sold, for the elimination of any impounded articles redeemed and returned to their owners, but included within the published advertisement for sale. Immediately after such sale the city clerk shall report to the police department a complete list of all the properties sold, including the sale price, all charges as herein provided and balance, if any, available to the owner. 
(1901, art. 17,  4) 
Sec. 20-151. - Advertisement and sale of unredeemed vehicles. 
    Whenever the city clerk or assistant chief of police shall decide to offer impounded properties for sale, he shall publish such sale at least once in a newspaper published in the city, at least 5 days before such sale. Such publication shall briefly describe the property, and where motor vehicles are to be sold, shall give the manufacturer's name, model and motor number. 
(1901, art. 17,  5) 
ARTICLE XV. - MECHANICAL CONDITION 

Sec. 20-152. - Mechanically defective vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive on any street within the city, a motor vehicle which is in such defective mechanical condition as to be reasonably likely, because of such defective mechanical condition, to cause damage to persons or property while being driven. 
(1901, art. 18,  1; 3497) 
Sec. 20-152.1. - Tinted windows. 
    Any person may operate a motor vehicle with front side wing vents or windows located immediately to the left and right of the driver that have a sun screening device, in conjunction with safety glazing material, that has a light transmission of thirty-five (35) percent or less plus or minus three (3) percent. The operation of a motor vehicle with a sun screen device applied to front side wing vents or windows located immediately to the left and right of the driver in excess of the requirements of this subsection shall be prohibited without a permit issued by the state department of public safety in accordance with RSMO 307.173, and the rules adopted thereunder. The permit, if issued shall allow operation of the motor vehicle by any titleholder or close relative or a relationship by marriage which shall mean a spouse, grandparent, parent, brother, sister, niece, nephew, aunt, uncle, child and grandchild of a person who resides in the household. 
(a)  All sunscreen devices applied to the windshield of a motor vehicle are prohibited except as specifically provided in this subsection. This section shall not prohibit labels, stickers, decalcomania, or informational signs on motor vehicles or the application of solar screening material to recreational vehicles as defined in RSMO 700.010, provided that such material does not interfere with the driver's normal view of the road. This section shall not prohibit factory installed tinted glass, the equivalent replacement thereof or tinting material applied on the upper portion of the motor vehicle's windshield which is normally tinted by the manufacturer of motor vehicle safety glass. 
(b)  Any vehicle licensed with historical license plates shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, may be punished as prescribed in section 22-70 of this Code and pay court costs. 
(Ord. No. 9895,  I, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 20-153. - Lights. 
    For the purpose of revealing its position and direction, a motor vehicle, while on the highway, whether in operation or at rest during the period when the street lights are turned on, and in any event from thirty (30) minutes after sunset to thirty (30) minutes before sunrise, and all times when atmospheric conditions render the operation of motor vehicles dangerous on the highway, shall carry lighted signal lamps as required. Motor vehicles and motor tricycles shall display at least two white lamps mounted at the front and directed forward and one red light mounted at the back and directed toward the rear. Trailers being towed shall display one red light mounted at the back and directed toward the rear. No person shall drive or move a vehicle or equipment upon any street with any lamp device thereon displaying a red light visible from directly in front, except as required by state statute or interstate commerce regulation. This shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. Flashing lights are prohibited on motor vehicles except as a means of indicating right or left turn. No vehicle shall display at the back, or project toward the rear, any other than a red light, excepting on motor vehicles and trailers which are required to carry number plates on the rear; the rear lamp shall be so constructed, mounted and adjusted as to project from its sides, top, bottom, or front, sufficient white light upon such plate to make the number plainly visible from a distance of 25 feet; provided however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the use of additional red rear lights carried for added safety or such white lights of low intensity as may be required in the operation of mechanical rear signalling devices, but no motor vehicle shall have mounted at its back any lamp projecting toward the rear a light of sufficient intensity to conceal the number or to interfere with the vision of anyone following. 
(1901, art. 18,  2) 
Sec. 20-154. - Head lamps. 
    Except as provided, the head lamps or the auxiliary driving lamps or combinations thereof, on motor vehicles shall be so arranged that the driver may select at will between distributions of light projecting to different elevations, subject to the following requirements and limitations: 
(a)  There shall be an uppermost distribution of light, or composite beam, so aimed and of such intensity as to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least three hundred fifty (350) feet ahead for all conditions of loading. The maximum intensity of this uppermost distribution of light or composite beam one degree of arc or more above the horizontal level of the lamps when the vehicle is not loaded shall not exceed eight thousand (8,000) apparent candlepower, nor at composite beam shall there be an intensity of more than seventy-five thousand (75,000) apparent candlepower in both head lamps at the lens nor shall there be less than fifteen thousand (15,000) apparent candlepower in both head lamps at the lens. 
(b)  When the vehicle is loaded none of the high intensity portion of light which is directed forward shall at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet ahead, project higher than the level of the center lamps from which it comes. 
(c)  There shall be a lowermost distribution of light or composite beam so aimed that when the vehicle is not loaded, none of the high intensity portion of light which is directed to the left of the prolongation of the extreme left side of the vehicle shall at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet ahead, project higher than a level of five (5) inches below the level of the center of the lamp from which it comes. When the vehicle is not loaded, none of the high intensity portion of the light which is directed to the right of the prolongation of the extreme left side of the vehicle, shall at a distance of twenty (20) feet ahead, project higher than a level of five (5) inches below the level of the center of such lowermost distribution of light or composite beam, project higher than the level of forty-two (42) inches above the level on which the vehicles stand at a distance of seventy-five (75) feet ahead. All road-lighting beams shall be so aimed and of sufficient intensity to reveal a person or vehicle at a distance of at least one hundred (100) feet ahead. 
(1901, art. 18,  3) 
Sec. 20-155. - Multiple-beam lighting equipment. 
    Whenever a motor vehicle is being operated on any street during the time specified in section 20-153, the driver shall use a distribution of light or composite beam directed high enough and of sufficient intensity to reveal persons and vehicles at a safe distance in advance of the vehicle; provided, however, that whenever the driver of a vehicle approaches an oncoming vehicle within five hundred (500) feet, such driver shall use a distribution of light or composite beam so aimed that the glaring rays are not projected into the eyes of the oncoming driver, and in no case shall the high intensity portion, which is projected to the left of the prolongation of the extreme left side of the vehicle be aimed higher than the center of the lamp from which it comes at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet ahead, and in no case higher than a level of forty-two (42) inches above the level upon which the vehicle stands at a distance of seventy-five (75) feet ahead. The lowermost distribution of light shall avoid glare at all times, regardless of the road contour and loading. 
(1901, art. 18,  4) 
Sec. 20-156. - Single-beam road lighting equipment. 
    Head lamps arranged to provide a single distribution of light not supplemented by auxiliary driving lamps shall be permitted on motor vehicles manufactured and sold prior to one year after February 3, 1956, in lieu of multiple-beam road lighting equipment herein specified if the single distribution of light complies with the following requirements and limitations; the head lamps shall be so aimed that when the vehicle is not loaded none of the high intensity portion of the light shall at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet ahead, project higher than a level of five (5) inches below the level of the center of the lamp from which it comes, and in no case higher than forty-two (42) inches above the level on which the vehicle stands at a distance of seventy-five (75) feet ahead. The intensity shall be sufficient to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least two hundred (200) feet. 
(1901, art. 18,  5) 
Sec. 20-157. - Special restrictions on lamps. 
    Any lighted lamp or illuminating devices upon a motor vehicle other than head lamps, spot lamps or auxiliary driving lamps which project a beam of light of an intensity greater than three hundred (300) candlepower shall be so directed that no part of the beam will strike the level of the roadway on which the vehicle is traveling at a distance of more than seventy-five (75) feet from the vehicle. 
(1901, art. 18,  6) 
Sec. 20-158. - Spotlights. 
    No search light or spotlight shall be equipped with a bulb stronger than twenty-one (21) candlepower and shall not be used on the public highway except in emergency, or when the headlights are inadequate owing to rain, fog, or similar condition and then only; provided, that their shaft of condensed light is directed well downward below the level of the lamp and at no time into the eyes of other persons. No person shall operate within the city a motor vehicle unless such lamps comply with the provisions herein. 
(1901, art. 18,  7) 
Sec. 20-159. - Mufflers; cutouts. 
    Muffler cutouts shall not be used, and no vehicle shall be driven in such manner or condition that excessive and unnecessary noises shall be made by its machinery, motor, signaling device or other parts or by an improperly loaded cargo. The motors of all motor vehicles shall be fitted with properly attached mufflers of such capacity or construction as to quiet the maximum possible exhaust noise as completely as is done in modern gas engine passenger motor vehicles. Any cutout or opening in the exhaust pipe between the motor and the muffler on any motor vehicle shall be completely closed and disconnected from its operating lever and shall be so arranged that is cannot automatically open or be opened or operated while such vehicle is in motion. 
(2431,  1) 
Sec. 20-160. - Lights on projecting objects. 
    All vehicles carrying poles or other objects which project more than five (5) feet from the rear of such vehicles shall, during the period when lights are required, carry a red light, at or near to the end of the pole or object projecting. At other times, a red flag or cloth not less than sixteen (16) inches square shall be displayed at the end of such projection. 
(1901, art. 18,  9) 
Sec. 20-161. - Towed cars. 
    When one vehicle is being towed by another, they shall be coupled by a line so that the two vehicles will be separated by no more than fifteen (15) feet and there shall be displayed on the towline a white cloth or paper so that the same will be clearly visible to the other users of the highway. During the time lights are required, the required lights shall be displayed by both vehicles. 
(1901, art. 18,  10) 
Sec. 20-162. - Brakes. 
    Every motor vehicle operated on any street within the city shall be provided with at least two adequate brakes, each of which shall work independently of the other, except motorcycles and animal-drawn vehicles which shall be provided with not less than one adequate brake. 
(1901, art. 18,  11; 3497) 
Sec. 20-163. - Brakes-performance ability. 
    The service of brakes upon any motor vehicle or combination of vehicles shall be adequate to stop such vehicle or vehicles when traveling twenty (20) miles per hour within a distance of thirty (30) feet when upon dry asphalt or concrete pavement surface free from loose material where the grade does not exceed one percent. 
(1901, art. 18,  11) 
Sec. 20-164. - Mirrors. 
    Any motor vehicle which is so constructed or loaded that the operator of such vehicle cannot see the road behind any such vehicle by looking back or around the side of such vehicle shall be equipped with a mirror so adjusted as to reveal the road behind and be visible from the operator's seat. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 18,  12) 
Sec. 20-165. - Injury to pavement. 
    No person shall drive or operate any vehicle, tractor, or trailer on any paved street in the city when such vehicle, tractor or trailer has tires or wheels so constructed or in such condition as to injure the pavement; and no person shall so operate such vehicle, tractor or trailer, if the rubber or other material on such tires or wheels has been worn or otherwise damaged as to cause pounding or injury to the pavement; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be deemed to prohibit the use of ordinary anti-skid chains or rubber tires attached to the wheels of such motor vehicles, tractors or trailers on the public streets or alleys of the city, when the wheels of such tractor or trailer are equipped with blocks, studs, cleats, ribs, ridges, lugs, spikes, beads or other protuberances other than the anti-skid chains mentioned above. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 18,  13) 
Sec. 20-166. - Weight of vehicles. 
    No vehicle or combination of vehicles shall be moved or operated on any highway, street or alley in this municipality having a greater weight than that described under section 304.180 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. The local official and state highway commission or their legal agents for their respective jurisdiction, whenever by thawing of frost, rains or soft conditions due to construction, reconstruction and maintenance, adverse critical weather conditions, or other causes detrimental to the surface or physical condition of such highways, streets and alleys in this municipality, are hereby authorized to limit such weights described under such section to such an amount and in such manner as will preserve their economical use by the general public. When posted or marked it shall be unlawful to transport any gross load in excess of the posted notice. 
(Ord. No. 1901, art. 18,  14; Ord. No. 1913,  1) 
Secs. 20-166.1, 20-166.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9685,  I, II, adopted March 28, 2011, repealed  20-166.1 and 20-166.2 in their entirety. Former  20-166.1 and 20-166.2 pertained to truck routes and posting of signs, respectively, and derived from Ord. No. 3498; Ord. No. 6786,  1, adopted March 21, 1994. 
ARTICLE XVI. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 20-167. - Fines for parking. 
    Notwithstanding section 22-70 of this Code, any person found guilty of having committed a parking offense, being unlawful or prohibited, shall be assessed a parking fine according to the following fine schedule:

(Ord. No. 7268,  1, 6-24-96; Ord. No. 9039,  II, 10-9-06; Ord. No. 10578,  V, 5-23-16) 
Secs. 20-167.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 5260, adopted Jan. 12, 1987, amended Ch. 20 by deleting  20-167 and 20-167.1, which set out the schedules of fines for offenses under this chapter and were derived from Ord. No. 1901, art. 20, and Ord. No. 2841,  2. 
Sec. 20-168. - Traffic tickets. 
    Whenever any person is arrested for violating any provision of this chapter, the arresting officer may take the violator's name, address and registration number of the motor vehicle involved, and issue to him, in writing, upon a form provided by the clerk of the municipal court, a notice to answer at the office of said clerk, the charge against him by the date shown on the form. The officer shall thereupon, and on the giving of the violator of his written promise to answer as specified in the notice, release him from custody. The arresting officer shall send his copy of such notice to the clerk of the municipal court. Any person who willfully violates his written promise to appear, given in accordance with this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which he was originally arrested. 
(1901, art. 20,  2; Ord. No. 4881,  1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 20-169. - Parking tickets. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked in violation of any of the parking regulations of this chapter, the officer finding such vehicle shall take the registration number and any other information displayed on the same which may identify its user and affix conspicuously to such vehicle a notice in writing on a form provided by the clerk of the police court for the driver to answer to the charge against him within ten (10) working days from the date of violation, excepting Sundays and legal holidays, at the office of the clerk of the police court. The officer shall send one copy of such notice to the clerk of the police [municipal] court. 
    Any driver of a motor vehicle who willfully neglects to answer to the charges set forth in the notice affixed by the police officer in accordance with this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, regardless of the disposition of the charge for which the notice was originally issued. 
    If any vehicle is found upon a street in violation of any provision of this chapter regulating stopping, standing or parking, and the identity of the operator cannot be determined, the owner or person in whose name such vehicle is registered, shall be held prima facie responsible for such violation. 
(1901, art. 20,  3) 
Sec. 20-170. - Payment of satisfaction fine. 
(a)  Persons who have received notices as provided in section 20-168 may, within the time specified in the notice, answer at the office of the clerk of the municipal court to the charges set forth in such notice, and may, on appearance, pay to such clerk the full satisfaction fine for such charge, a sum in accordance with section 10-16, court costs-generally. 
(b)  Persons who have received notice as provided in section 20-169 may, within ten (10) days from the date of violation, answer to the office of the municipal court to the charges set forth in such notice, and may, on appearance, pay to such clerk the full satisfaction fine for such charges. In the event such violator fails to pay within such ten-day limit, then an additional court cost will be assessed in accordance with section 10-16, court costs-generally. 
(c)  The accused, if he so elects, may refuse to pay any such satisfaction fine, whereupon he will be booked for appearance in the case docketed for trial before the municipal judge. 
(d)  Complaints shall be made and filed by the police officer issuing the notice provided for in Sections 20-168 and 20-169 and warrants issued by the municipal judge against all persons charged with violations of this chapter who do not pay such satisfaction fines within the specified time limits, or appeal the case to court, and cases shall be prosecuted and tried before the municipal judge. 
(1901, art. 20,  4; Ord. No. 5260,  3, 1-12-87; Ord. No. 7501,  II, 7-14-97; Ord. No. 10578,  III, 5-23-16)

The speed limit of twenty (20) miles per hour shall apply when yellow school zone warning lights are flashing or, if no flashing lights are present, during any time periods between 6:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. as specifically posted by the official school zone signs:

Sec. 20-178. - Schedule VIII, parking lots. 
    No vehicle shall park outside of designated parking spaces in any city or county parking lot or otherwise impede ingress or egress to such parking facilities. 
(1)  No parking shall be allowed in the twenty (20) center parking spaces in Clay County Lot #1 except for those vehicles displaying a visible permit. 
(2)  No parking shall be allowed in the fourteen (14) reserved parking spaces on the west side of Clay County Lot #2 except for those vehicles displaying a visible permit. 
(3)  No parking shall be allowed in the 124 North Main parking lot Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. except for those vehicles displaying a visible permit. 
(4)  Pursuant to the provisions of section 20-146, the police department is authorized to remove any unidentified, stolen, wrecked, or abandoned motor vehicle found upon any public parking lot within the city. 
(Ord. No. 6208,  1, 9-9-91; Ord. No. 6234,  1, 10-28-91; Ord. No. 6336,  1, 4-13-92; Ord. No. 7829,  I, 6-28-99)

Secs. 20-196-20-219. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - PARKING FACILITIES FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking,  20-116 et seq. 

Sec. 20-220. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and terms as used are defined to mean the following: 
(a)  Physically disabled means any natural person who has temporarily or permanently lost the use of one or both legs or arms, any person who is so severely disabled as to be unable to move freely without the aid of crutches, braces, walker, canes, leg prosthesis or wheelchair or any person who suffers from lung disease to such an extent that his forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV) when measured by spirometry is less than one liter, or his arterial oxygen tension (Po2) is less than 60 mm/Hg on room air at rest, or any person who has a cardiovascular disease measuring between 3 and 4 on the New York Heart Classification Scale. 
(b)  Properly marked as reserved for disabled parking only shall mean any parking space which is indicated by a sign upon which shall be inscribed the international symbol of accessibility in white on a blue background. 
(Ord. No. 4577,  1, 12-13-82; Ord. No. 4657,  1, 6-27-83) 
Sec. 20-221. - Parking spaces to be designated. 
    The city engineer is hereby authorized to designate and establish parking spaces on public and private property for exclusive use of vehicles which display a disabled license plate, placard or sticker. The city engineer is responsible for placement and maintenance of appropriate disabled parking signs on public right-of-way. On private property, the owner or lessee is responsible for installing and maintaining signage as prescribed in section 20-220(b). 
(Ord. No. 4577,  1, 12-13-82; Ord. No. 4657,  1, 6-27-83; Ord. No. 6605,  1, 2, 5-24-93) 
Sec. 20-222. - Violations; parking prohibited without display of permit; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or permit any vehicle to remain in any parking space properly marked as reserved for disabled parking only, unless such vehicle shall display a disabled license plate, placard or sticker. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a vehicle which displays the disabled license plate, placard or sticker to use and occupy such established parking spaces upon any occasion when not actually used for the transportation of such physically disabled and handicapped person. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any vehicle to block access to any parking space properly marked as reserved for disabled parking or block access in any manner to any ramp, entrance or stile designed for disabled access or use. 
(d)  The registered owner of any motor vehicle found to be illegally parked in violation of subsection (a) of this provision or blocking access in violation of subsection (b) shall be deemed to be responsible for said violation. This presumption shall be rebuttable. 
(e)  The violations detailed in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be applicable whether said violations occur on private or public property so long as the public or private spaces are properly marked in the manner set forth herein, and so long as the ramp, entrance or stile is clearly marked in a manner readily visible to the public at large. 
(f)  While it shall be prima facie proof of violation for a vehicle not displaying a disabled license plate, placard or sticker to occupy a space reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles which so display the same, it shall be an adequate defense to prosecution for such offense if the defendant shall establish, by any lawful proof, that the vehicle was, upon the particular occasion, actually used for the transportation of a physically disabled and handicapped person. The burden of proof of such defense shall rest upon the defendant if such defense is offered. 
(g)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall be punishable as prescribed in section 20-167 of this cable. 
(Ord. No. 4577,  1, 12-13-82; Ord. No. 4657,  1, 6-27-83; Ord. No. 7268,  2, 6-24-96)
