(e)  Vending machines prohibited. It shall be unlawful for a retailer to sell tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or vapor products unless it is a direct, face-to face exchange between the retailer and the consumer. 
    Self-service displays, mail-order sales and other 'impersonal' modes of sales are prohibited. 
(f)  Restrictions on sale and distribution of tobacco paraphernalia. Retail businesses in operation as of September 26, 2016, and selling tobacco paraphernalia that do not meet the definition of retail tobacco store, are exempt to this restriction and may continue to legally sell tobacco paraphernalia. 
(g)  Enforcement. The City of Liberty or its authorized designee may conduct random, unannounced inspections at locations where tobacco products are distributed to test and ensure compliance with this ordinance. 
(h)  Penalties. 
(1)  In General. Any person found to have violated this ordinance shall be subject to a fine of no less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the second offense, and no less than five hundred dollars ($500.0) for each offense thereafter. Each violation, and every day in which a violation occurs, shall constitute a separate violation. 
(i)  Exceptions and defenses. The penalties in this ordinance do not apply to a person younger than twenty-one (21) years old who purchases or attempts to purchase tobacco products while under the direct supervision of City of Liberty staff for training, education, research, or enforcement purposes. 
    Nothing in this ordinance prohibits an underage person from handling tobacco products in the course of lawful employment. 
    It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation of this ordinance for a person to have reasonably relied on proof of age as described by state law. 
(Ord. No. 10626,  I, 9-26-16; Ord. No. 10640,  I, 10-24-16) 
Sec. 22-70. - Fine for offenses, misdemeanors, unlawful or prohibited acts. 
    Any person found guilty of having committed any act defined by the Liberty City Code or an ordinance of said city as constituting an offense, being unlawful, prohibited, or stated to constitute a misdemeanor, shall be assessed a penalty of a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment for not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, except as to those offenses in which the ordinance providing for and defining the same specifically limiting the penalty to one less than the maximum available at the time of its enactment. 
(Ord. No. 4521,  1, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 4953,  1, 4-9-85; Ord. No. 4956,  1, 4-22-85) 
Editor's note- At the request of the city, former  22-50, a general penalty, has been transferred to the end of the chapter and assigned section number 22-70. 
Chapter 22A - PARKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 5196,  1, adopted Aug. 25, 1986, amended Ch. 22A, Parks, in its entirety to read as herein set out. The substantive provisions of former Ch. 22A,  22A-1-22A-10, were derived from Ord. No. 2980,  1-10. 
Cross reference- Director of parks and recreation,  2-103.1 et seq.; cemeteries, Ch. 8; places of recreation and amusement, Ch. 16; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 22A-1. - Hours. 
    City parks and property under the stewardship of the Liberty parks and recreation department, excluding the Liberty Community Center, shall be open from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. daily. Persons or groups issued a facility reservation permit under section 22A-2 of this chapter shall be exempt from these daily hours, limited to the terms of the issued permit. Entering a park at a time other than scheduled hours of operation is prohibited. Overnight camping permits under section 22A-4 of this chapter are exempt from these daily hours. All parks, or parts thereof, may be closed temporarily in case of emergency, adverse weather conditions, needed repairs or unusual circumstances as determined by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 6942,  1, 11-28-94) 
Sec. 22A-2. - Reservation of facilities. 
    Special areas and facilities, such as shelterhouses, sportsfields, meeting rooms and other facilities may be reserved upon application to the director of parks and recreation and payment of the applicable fee, if any. No person shall occupy any shelterhouse, sportsfield or other park facility which has been reserved by another individual or group. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 22A-3. - Regulation of trash and fires. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any city park. Trash containers are to be used for trash only. The use of refuse containers in city parks for the dumping of household or commercial trash or litter brought onto park property is prohibited. Grills provided in city parks shall be used for cooking or warming purposes only. Fires are not permitted in any city park except in the grills provided by the city or in household barbecue grills. The director of parks and recreation may authorize bonfires for certain group functions. No fire shall be left unattended and must be extinguished prior to departure. Fires may be prohibited in city parks during dry seasons as necessary as a protective measure by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Cross reference- Open burning,  14-12 etc.; regulating solid waste management, Ch. 17; littering,  22-50. 
Sec. 22A-4. - Overnight camping. 
    Overnight camping shall be authorized only by written permit issued by the director of parks and recreation and shall be permitted only in those areas designated for camping by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 22A-5. - Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages, illegal drugs, etc. 
    Possession or consumption of illegal narcotic drugs or barbiturates upon any park property is prohibited. Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages upon any park property is prohibited except as may be permitted by city policy, in full force and effect, having been approved by resolution of city council and on file in the office of the deputy city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 9603,  I, 7-12-10) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; possession of alcoholic beverage in open container in motor vehicle,  3-24; drugs prohibited in arcades,  16-11. 
Sec. 22A-6. - Solicitation. 
    Solicitation by any individual or organization is strictly prohibited. No person shall offer or advertise merchandise or other goods for sale or hire, or maintain any concession or use any park facilities or park property for commercial purposes except as authorized by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Cross reference- Solicitors and canvassers, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 22A-7. - Hunting prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall catch, kill, pursue, hunt or harm wildlife in any manner at any time or place in any city park; except, as may be directed by the director of parks and recreation to preserve the safety of the citizens. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 22A-8. - Possession of firearms. 
    The possession of firearms including air rifles, BB guns, pellet guns, and slingshots in city parks at any time is prohibited. The possession of a firearm shall be considered prima facie evidence of violation of this regulation. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Cross reference- Use of firearms prohibited,  22-16.1; discharge of air guns,  22-22. 
Sec. 22A-9. - Animals and pets. 
    No dog, cat or other domesticated animal shall be permitted within city parks at any time without a leash not to exceed six (6) feet in length. Any dog, cat or domesticated animal running at large may be apprehended by the animal control officer of the city. Horses and/or horseback riding are not permitted in any city park. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 22A-10. - Disorderly conduct or property damage prohibited. 
    Disorderly conduct, bad behavior, vulgar language or cursing, indecent exposure or climbing in any building or on any structure or fence, or causing damage or destruction to any park property or playing areas, is prohibited. 
    The use of sound amplifying equipment in parks is prohibited to exceed four (4) hours in duration except as authorized by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 9951,  I, 8-27-2012) 
Cross reference- Disorderly conduct,  22-11.1; obscene language, indecent exposure, etc.,  22-37. 
Sec. 22A-11. - Operation of motor vehicles. 
    No motor vehicle, other than those operated by city employees conducting city business in city parks, may be driven or parked within any city park except upon designated roadways and parking lots unless authorized by the director of parks and recreation. Motorized vehicles shall not be operated or parked in the paved and unpaved trails or on any grass area in any city park. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 20. 
Sec. 22A-12. - Speed limit. 
    The speed limit upon any roadway or parking lot within a city park shall be ten (10) miles per hour unless otherwise posted. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 22A-13. - Hinderance of parks and recreation department employees. 
    No person shall prevent, interfere with, or in any manner hinder any city parks and recreation department employee in the performance of his or her official duties. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 22A-14. - Certain recreation activities prohibited. 
    Any activity in any city park which endangers the lives of others or causes harm to city parks or facilities is prohibited. The operation of any noise-producing device shall not disturb the peace. Tennis courts are to be used for the purpose of playing tennis only. Playing golf, archery and flying model airplanes is permitted only in areas designated for those purposes by the director of parks and recreation. The director of parks and recreation may allow certain activities, such as horseback riding, as part of any city festival or other special event. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 22A-15. - Destroying park property. 
    No person shall destroy, deface, injure, remove or relocate any natural or man-made park property. The cutting of trees or vegetation for firewood or any other purpose is prohibited except as authorized by written permit by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 22A-16. - Fireworks. 
    The possession and use of fireworks in city parks is prohibited unless authorized by the Liberty City Council. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Cross reference- Explosives and blasting agents,  22-15.2; fireworks,  22-17-22-20. 
Sec. 22A-17. - Penalties. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of Sections 22A-1 through 22A-16 of the Liberty City Code constitutes an offense, is unlawful and constitutes a misdemeanor, and any person found guilty of violating these provisions shall be assessed a penalty of a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 5196,  1, 8-25-86) 
Cross reference- Fines for offenses, misdemeanors, unlawful or prohibited acts,  22-70. 
Chapter 23A - PUBLIC WORKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Board of public works,  29-13-29-15. 

ARTICLE I. - PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Sec. I of Ord. No. 10940, adopted July 30, 2018, amended art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. I pertained to the same subject matter, consisted of  23A-1, 23A-2, and derived from Ord. 2941. 

Sec. 23A-1. - Design criteria and construction specifications and standard details. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Design criteria and construction specifications and standard details. A city manual for use by land developers in the design and construction of roadways, waterlines, sanitary sewer, and storm drainage systems. 
(b)  Incorporation by reference. The design criteria and construction specifications and standard details are hereby incorporated by reference into the Liberty Municipal Code for the purpose of providing certain design specifications and construction specifications and standard details and for enforcing compliance with same. No fewer than three (3) copies of said design criteria and construction specifications and standard details shall be marked official copy and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable business hours. 
(c)  Design criteria and construction specifications and standard details. Unless otherwise specified and approved, all public improvements shall be designed, constructed, and inspected in accordance with the current requirements for public improvements contained within the design criteria and construction specifications and standard details. 
(d)  Adoption of and amendments to design criteria and construction specifications and standard details. 
(1)  The requirements for public improvements contained within the design criteria and construction specifications and standard details shall be adopted and amended by the city engineer following a public input process. The public input process shall include the following minimum steps: 
a.  Posting on the city website the proposed design criteria and construction specifications and standard details in draft form a minimum of thirty (30) days prior to the city engineer holding a public informational meeting; and 
b.  Extending a written comment period for a minimum of thirty (30) days after the public informational meeting. 
A new public input process is not required for revisions to the proposed draft design criteria and construction specifications and standard details if the same is adopted by the city engineer within one hundred eighty (180) days of the public informational meeting. 
(Ord. No. 10940,  I, 7-30-18) 
Sec. 23A-2. - Title. 
    This article shall be known by the title "Liberty, Missouri Ordinance Regulating the Private Construction of Public Works Projects." 
(Ord. No. 10940,  I, 7-30-18) 
Sec. 23A-3. - Rules and regulations; permits. 
    Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, co-partnership or trust, prior to commencing any private work on public works projects in the city, shall comply with the following regulations and provisions: 
(1)  Plans and specifications for the private construction of public works projects, including, but not limited to, streets, sidewalks, drainage systems, sewers or thoroughfares to be dedicated to and maintained by the city or to be maintained by the city, shall be submitted to the city engineer for approval. 
(2)  A permit shall be obtained from the city engineer authorizing the construction mentioned and set forth in the plans and specifications submitted. 
(3)  Following the issuance of the permit provided for herein, construction shall not be started until the city engineer has been notified as to the time, location and scope of the construction. 
(4)  ) No construction shall be accomplished and the permit provided for herein shall not be issued until a performance and maintenance bond in an amount equal to the cost of construction and satisfactory to the city attorney [counselor] shall be posted with the city engineer guaranteeing against defects in construction for a period of two (2) years and guaranteeing against defects in the construction of streets for a period of two (2) years, as well as guaranteeing the complete performance of the contemplated construction for which the permit herein provided for is issued, and further guaranteeing and insuring that such construction shall be accomplished in a workmanlike manner, and further protecting the city and insuring the city from any loss or damage. 
(5)  No construction work shall be commenced until the permit provided for has been issued and a written notice to proceed shall have been issued by the city engineer. 
(6)  All construction work may be stopped at any time by the city engineer or his agent, when in the opinion of the city engineer the workmanship, materials used, or procedures of work do not meet the requirements or comply with the city codes, ordinances, specifications and procedures for such work. 
(7)  All work, accomplished by means of a permit issued under this article, shall be subject to final inspection for city maintenance by the city engineer and his/her recommendation shall be made to and action taken thereon by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 10940,  I, 7-30-18) 
Sec. 23A-4. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 23A-5. - Design-build services. 
(a)  Definitions. Definitions as used in this article unless the context specifically requires otherwise: 
    Design-build means any project for the design, construction, alteration, remodeling or improvement of any buildings, facilities or other public improvements for which the design and construction services are furnished under one contract. 
    Design-build team is comprised of the design-builder, the design consultant, and key subcontractors identified by the design-builder. 
    Design-builder is any individual, partnership, corporation, associates or other legal entity providing both design and construction services to the city for a design-build project. 
    Design consultant is a qualified, licensed design professional who is not an employee of design-builder, but is retained by design-builder, or employed or retained by any firm under contract with design-builder, to furnish design services required under the contract documents. A design sub-consultant is a qualified, licensed design professional who is not an employee of the design consultant, but is retained by the design consultant or employed or retained by any firm under contract to design consultant, to furnish design services required under the contract documents. Design services include architectural, engineering and land surveying services. 
    Architectural services means any service as defined in Section 327.091, RSMo. 
    Engineering services means any services as defined in Section 327.181, RSMo. 
    Land surveying services means any service as defined in Section 327.272, RSMo. 
    Design-build contract shall be a contract between the city and a design-builder to furnish the architecture, engineering, and related services as required for a given public project, and to furnish the labor, materials and other construction services for the same public project. A design-build contract may be conditional upon subsequent refinements in scope and price, and may permit the department to make changes in the scope of the project without invalidating the design-build contract. 
    Firm means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, associates or other legal entity permitted by law to practice the profession of architecture, engineering or land surveying and provide said services. 
    Project means any capital improvement project or any study, plan, survey or program activity of the city, including development of new or existing programs. 
    Performance criteria shall be the requirements for the public project, including as appropriate, capacity, durability, production standards, ingress and egress requirements, or other criteria for the intended use of the public project, expressed in performance-oriented drawings and specifications suitable to allow the design-builder to make a proposal. 
    Proposal shall be an offer to enter into a design-build contract, as further defined in this article. 
    Request for proposals shall be the document or publication whereby a department solicits proposals for a design-build contract. 
(b)  Request for qualifications. Whenever design-build services are needed, the department director, or designated representative, shall prepare a request for qualifications (RFQ) designed to ascertain the qualifications of design-build teams that may be interested in providing services for the proposed project. Qualifications may include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  The specialized experience and technical competence of the team with respect to the types of services required including experience in design-build projects of similar function and scope; 
(2)  The capacity and capability of the firm to perform the work in question, including specialized services, within the time limitations fixed for the completion of the project; 
(3)  The past record of performance of the firm with respect to such factors as estimating accuracy and meeting project budgets, quality of work, and ability to meet schedules; 
(4)  List of people available to provide required design and construction services including the licensed professional engineer, architect and/or land surveyor, who will be responsible for professional services associated with this project. 
    A selection committee shall be established by the department director, or designated representative, to review the qualifications. Each committee member will rank each firm according to the criteria set forth in the RFQ. The composite rating of the committee will be used to determine the top rated teams, which may be interviewed at the discretion of the department director. 
(c)  Performance criteria. The department shall determine the scope and level of detail required for the performance criteria. The performance criteria should be detailed enough to permit qualified design-builders to submit proposals in accordance with the request for proposals, given the nature of the public project and the level of design to be provided in the proposal. 
(d)  Solicitation of proposals. Proposals shall be solicited, from prequalified bidders, as follows: 
1.  Request for proposals. A request for proposals shall be prepared for each design-build contract containing, at a minimum, the following elements: 
a.  The identity of the department which will award the design-build contract. 
b.  The procedures to be followed for submitting proposals, the criteria for evaluation of proposals and their relative weight, and the procedures and timing for making awards, including a reference to the requirements of this article and the regulations of the department. 
c.  The proposed terms and conditions for the design-build contract. 
d.  The performance criteria. 
e.  A description of the drawings, specifications, or other submittals to be submitted with the proposal, with guidance as to the form and level of completeness of the drawings, specifications, or submittals that will be acceptable. 
f.  A schedule for planned commencement and completion of the design-build contract. 
g.  Budget limits for the design-build contract, if any. 
h.  Affirmative action, disadvantaged business, or set-aside goals or requirements for the design-build contract, if any. 
i.  The qualifications that the design-builder will be required to have. 
j.  Requirements for performance bonds, payment bonds, and insurance. 
k.  Any stipend or honorarium to be paid to responsive bidders who are not awarded the design-build contract to help defray the expense of the proposal. 
l.  The request for proposals may include any other information that the department in its discretion chooses to supply, including without limitation, surveys, soils reports, drawings or models of existing structures, environmental studies, photographs, or references to public records. 
(2)  Advertisement. Notice of requests for proposals shall be advertised in the same manner in which bids generally are solicited for public projects for the city. 
(3)  Prequalification. The department may, to the extent generally allowed by the laws governing prequalification of bidders on public projects, prequalify potential design-builders for design-build contracts. If prequalification is utilized, the notice and advertisement of requests for proposals shall conform to the procedures generally applied when prequalification of bidders is utilized as outlined in subsection (b). 
(e)  Design-build contract. Contracts for preliminary and final design-build services shall be negotiated for the types of design and construction services required at fair and reasonable prices. 
    If the department director and/or designated representative is unable to negotiate a satisfactory preliminary contract with the selected team, negotiations with that team shall be terminated. Negotiations shall then commence with the second rated team until agreement has been reached or negotiations are terminated. This process will continue until an agreement has been reached with one of the teams or no selected teams remain. If no agreement is reached with any of the selected teams, the department director, or designated representative, shall reevaluate the scope of design-build services, project schedule, and other requirements outlined in the project solicitation, and make revisions if appropriate. The selection process may be initiated again based on the revised project parameters or other project delivery systems may be considered. 
(Ord. No. 10926,  I, 5-29-18) 
Chapter 24 - SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses and occupations generally, Ch. 7; licenses generally, Ch. 18; solicitation in parks,  22A-6. 

Sec. 24-1. - "Canvasser", "solicitor" defined. 
    A canvasser or solicitor is any person, whether resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such person has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not; provided, that this section shall include any person who, for himself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodging house, apartment, shop, or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  2) 
Sec. 24-2. - Permit and license-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or canvasser as defined in section 24-1 to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a permit and license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  1) 
Sec. 24-3. - Same-Contents of application. 
    Applicants for permit and license under this chapter shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing (in duplicate) on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(a)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(b)  Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; 
(c)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(d)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(e)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(f)  The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time such application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery. 
(g)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(h)  The fingerprints of the applicant and the names of at least two reliable property owners of the county, who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business respectability, or, in lieu of the names of references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to evaluate properly such character and business responsibility; 
(i)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of this Code or any other ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; and 
(j)  A statement by a reputable physician of the city, dated not more than ten days prior to submission of the application, certifying the applicant to be free of contagious, infectious, or communicable disease. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  3) 
Sec. 24-4. - Same-Same-Fee. 
    At the time of filing the application required by section 24-3, a fee of two dollars and fifty cents shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated in such application. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  3) 
Sec. 24-5. - Same-Same-Investigation by chief of police. 
    Upon receipt of such application required by section 24-3, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
    If as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character of business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his disapproval and his reasons for the same, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit and license will be issued. 
    If as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return such permit, along with the application to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed license fee, deliver to the applicant his permit and issue a license. Such license shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of such licensee, the class of license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such soliciting or canvassing. The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  4) 
Sec. 24-6. - License fee. 
    The license fee which shall be charged by the city clerk for such license required by section 24-2 shall be five dollars per day, fifteen dollars per week, twenty-five dollars per month, one hundred dollars per year. 
    The annual fees provided by section 24-4 shall be assessed on a year basis and on or after January first the amount of such fee for annual license shall be one-half the amount stipulated above for the remainder of the year. 
    None of the license fees provided for by this chapter shall be so applied as to occasion an undue burden upon interstate commerce. In any case where a license fee is believed by a licensee or applicant for license to place an undue burden upon such commerce, he may apply to the mayor for an adjustment of the fee so that it shall not be discriminatory, unreasonable, or unfair as to such commerce. Such application may be made before, at, or within six months after payment of the prescribed license fee. The applicant shall, by affidavit and supporting testimony, show his method of business and the gross volume or estimated gross volume of business and such other information as the mayor may deem necessary in order to determine the extent, if any, of such undue burden on such commerce. The mayor shall then conduct an investigation, comparing applicant's business with other businesses of like nature and shall make findings of fact from which he shall determine whether the fee fixed by this chapter is unfair, unreasonable or discriminatory as to applicant's business and shall fix as the license fee for the applicant, an amount that is fair, reasonable and nondiscriminatory, or, if the fee has already been paid, shall order a refund of the amount over and above the fee so fixed. In fixing the fee to be charged, the mayor shall have the power to base the fee upon a percentage of gross sales, or any other method which will assure that the fee assessed shall be uniform with that assessed on businesses of like nature, so long as the amount assessed does not exceed the fees as prescribed in section 24-4. Should the mayor determine the gross sales measure of the fee to be the fair basis, he may require the applicant to submit, either at the time of termination of applicant's business in the city or at the end of each three-month period, a sworn statement of the gross sales, and pay the amount of fee therefor; provided, that, no additional fee during any one calendar year shall be required after the licensee shall have paid an amount equal to the annual license as prescribed in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  5) 
Cross reference- Licenses generally,  18-16. 
Sec. 24-7. - Bond requirements of nonresidents. 
    Every applicant, not a resident of the city, or who being a resident of the city, represents a person whose principal place of business is located outside the state, shall file with the city clerk a surety bond, running to the city in the amount of one thousand dollars with surety acceptable to and approved by the mayor, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the business of solicitor and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the solicitor and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the city doing business with such solicitor, that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of such solicitor. Action on such bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  6) 
Sec. 24-8. - Badge. 
    The city clerk shall issue to each licensee under this chapter at the time of delivery of his license a badge which shall contain the words "Licensed Solicitor," the period for which the license is issued and the number of the license, in letters and figures easily discernible from a distance of ten feet. Such badge shall, during the time such licensee is engaged in soliciting, be worn constantly by the licensee on the front of his outer garment in such a way as to be conspicuous. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  7) 
Sec. 24-9. - Duty to show license. 
    Solicitors and canvassers are required to exhibit their licenses at the request of any citizen. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  8) 
Sec. 24-10. - Enforcement of chapter by police. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen soliciting or canvassing, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his solicitor's or canvasser's license and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  9) 
Sec. 24-11. - Report of convictions under chapter. 
    The chief of police shall report to the city clerk all convictions for the violation of this chapter and the city clerk shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of violation in such record. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  10) 
Sec. 24-12. - Procedure for revocation of licenses. 
    Permits and licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the city council after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statements contained in the application for license; 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as solicitor or as canvasser; 
(c)  Any violation of this chapter; 
(d)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(e)  Conducting the business of soliciting, or of canvassing, in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
    Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  11) 
Sec. 24-13. - Appeals to city council by persons aggrieved under chapter. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the city clerk in the denial of a permit or license as provided in section 24-5, or in the action of the mayor in the assessing of the fee as provided in section 24-6, shall have the right of appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the council, within fourteen days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The council shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in section 24-12 for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  12) 
Sec. 24-14. - Expiration of licenses. 
    All annual licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on the thirtieth day of June, next. Other than annual licenses shall expire on the date specified in the license. 
(Ord. No. 2052,  13) 
Sec. 24-15. - Solicitation on public streets. 
(a)  Purpose. For purposes of this section, the term "solicit" shall mean and include the act of standing on, in the median of, or in the right-of-way of any city street, or entering on the same, for the purpose of soliciting contributions or selling, offering for sale or advertising any product, property or service of any kind from persons in vehicles on behalf of any organization or person. 
(b)  Permit required. 
(1)  Application. 
a.  Organizations or persons desiring to solicit contributions, sell, collect money or items from persons in vehicles on city streets by standing in, or beside, city streets must apply for a permit at least eleven (11) days prior to the collection event. 
b.  A permit is required of any individual or organization soliciting as defined in this chapter. 
c.  The application and permit shall be developed by the police department, but shall include: 
1.  The date and time the solicitation is to occur; 
2.  The location of the solicitation; 
3.  The number of solicitors to be involved at each location of the solicitation; 
4.  The name, address, and date of birth of each solicitor shall be provided in writing; 
5.  The permit authorizes a maximum of four (4) days of consecutive or nonconsecutive solicitation per calendar year; and 
6.  Confirmation of satisfaction of the qualifications herein. 
(2)  Qualifications. 
a.  The organization seeking a permit to solicit must provide services/benefits as anticipated by its charitable purpose. 
b.  The organization receiving a benefit from the collection must be qualified by the Internal Revenue Service under IRS Code Section 501(c). 
c.  At the time of application for permit, the organization must provide proof of insurance in the amount of at least two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate for any liability arising out of solicitation activities and agree to indemnify the city for any damages the city may suffer arising out of the fund raising activities. The city requires that they shall be listed as a certificate holder and not an additional insured. Additionally, there is a minimum notification of thirty (30) days for policy cancellation. 
d.  The insurance shall provide coverage against claims against the applicant and claims against the city, its elected and appointed officials and its employees. 
(c)  Conduct. 
(1)  It is unlawful for an individual who is less than seventeen (17) years of age to solicit as described herein. 
(2)  It is unlawful for more than ten (10) persons to solicit at one intersection at one time. 
(3)  It is unlawful to solicit at an intersection on I-35 Highway or on a ramp to or from I-35, and Kansas Street from the west city limits at I-35 Highway eastbound, up to and including the intersection with M-291 Highway. 
(4)  It is unlawful to solicit the occupant of a vehicle, unless the vehicle has come to a complete stop. 
(5)  It is unlawful to solicit unless the solicitor is wearing at all times a brightly colored safety vest, which meets ANSI/ISEA 107-2004, Class 2, Level 2 standards to help insure solicitor safety. 
(6)  It is unlawful to solicit except during daylight hours between thirty (30) minutes after sunrise and thirty (30) minutes before sunset. 
(7)  It is unlawful to permit any person on the registry of the federal government or any state listing for sex offenders to solicit under this section. 
(8)  It is unlawful to engage in solicitation using any bullhorn, sound amplification device or any sign or poster larger than two (2) feet by two (2) feet in size. 
(9)  It is unlawful for any solicitor to block the free flow of traffic or to have or attempt to exercise exclusive right or right-of-way over any location in the public streets. 
(d)  Penalties. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to solicit on any public street within the city without first obtaining a valid permit. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to solicit in a manner that fails to comply with any provision contained in subsection (c). 
(3)  A violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or such imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each person violating any provision of this section shall constitute a separate offense. Each day there is any violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(4)  A violation of any provision of the section shall be cause for the revocation of the permit. The applicant shall be notified either by telephone, in person, or in writing stating the reason for the denial or revocation. 
(e)  Exceptions. The foregoing notwithstanding, this section shall not apply to any situation, and no solicitation will occur where the city has, through the use of barricades or other traffic control measures, taken affirmative action or actions to control traffic flow to protect individuals in an area. 
(Ord. No. 9479,  I, 8-10-09) 
Chapter 25 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Director of public works,  2-68 et seq.; open containers,  3-24; signs, Ch. 5; buildings, Ch. 6; house moving,  6-19 et seq.; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 20; water and sewers, Ch. 29. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Injury; driving horses or vehicles across sidewalks. 
    No person shall in any way injure or damage any sidewalk, curbstone, gutter or sewer nor shall any person drive a horse or team of horses, or any vehicle, across any sidewalk. 
(R.O. 1931,  453) 
Sec. 25-2. - Trimming trees in and along streets and sidewalks. 
    Every owner, agent or occupant of any house, building lot or premises in the city, shall keep the shade and ornamental trees, bushes, flowers and vegetation, in the street, avenue or sidewalk in front and alongside of such house, building, lot or premises trimmed so that the branches shall not be lower than twelve (12) feet from the surface of such street, avenue or sidewalk nor extend more than one-fourth (1/4) of the distance from the base of such tree over or across such street, avenue or sidewalk. 
(R.O. 1931,  366; Ord. No. 8046,  I, 7-10-00) 
Cross reference- Injuring trees on city property,  22-30; removing dangerous trees,  22-51, 22-52. 
Sec. 25-3. - Keeping sidewalks, etc., free from filth, etc. 
    All owners and occupiers, or their agents, of any property fronting on any sidewalk, curbstone or gutter, shall keep such sidewalk, curbstone and gutter free and clear of all filth and obstructions of whatsoever kind. 
(R.O. 1931,  452) 
Sec. 25-4. - Removal of ice, snow, etc., from sidewalks, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons owning or occupying any real property, fronting upon any street to keep the sidewalks and curbing and guttering in front and alongside of such property and on the same side of the street, in good repair and order and clean the same and remove from any such sidewalk and curbing all ice, snow, earth or other substance that in anywise obstructs or renders the same dangerous, inconvenient or annoying to any person. 
(R.O. 1931,  457) 
Charter reference- Requirement that sidewalks be kept clean, clear, etc., Art. III,  1(27). 
Sec. 25-5. - Obstructions prohibited; exceptions for merchants, etc. 
    No person shall place or throw, or cause to be placed or thrown, any article, substance, or obstruction of any kind whatsoever upon the street, alley, avenue, public square, pavement or sidewalk or the paved part of any sidewalk or pavement, within the city, whether declared a public sidewalk or not, without the consent of the owner. Nothing in this section shall be so construed as to prevent any merchant or other person from placing any articles or boxes on the sidewalks while receiving or delivering goods, or forwarding the same, or receiving fuel, not to remain in the street more than one day; or building materials, during the erection of any building, or improvement; provided, that such materials shall not occupy more than one-half (1/2) of the street. 
(R.O. 1931,  307) 
Secs. 25-5.1, 25-5.2. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25-5.3. - Street specifications and standards adopted by reference. 
    Any street hereinafter constructed, or on which construction is hereinafter begun, shall be constructed according to the City of Liberty Technical Specifications and Design Criteria Manual for Public Improvement Projects (latest revision), copies of which are on file in the offices of the deputy city clerk and city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2829,  2, 3; Ord. No. 6004,  1, 8-27-90) 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Article II formerly pertained to street oiling. Section 25-6 was repealed by Ord. No. 2677;  25-7-25-10 were repealed by Ord. No. 2315. 

Secs. 25-6-25-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREET ALTERATION OR ABOLITION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Streets in subdivisions,  26-14 et seq. 

Sec. 25-11. - Purpose of article. 
    It is deemed proper and necessary that as a proper incident to the exercise of powers granted the city by paragraph 8, section one, article three of the city charter, and to provide due process of law, that provision should be made for the giving of a public notice and for the procedure incident to the exercise of such power, the same being the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1726,  2) 
Editor's note- The powers referred to by this section permit the city to create, open, abolish, alter, widen, extend, establish, grade, pave, etc., streets and include a procedure for so doing. 
Sec. 25-12. - Petition to alter or abolish-Generally. 
    Any person owning any interest in land running or abutting upon any street, avenue, lane, or alley within the city desiring that the same shall be abolished or altered, may petition the city council of the city to abolish or alter all or part of the same by petition in writing, giving a correct legal description of the land within such street, avenue, lane, or alley to be affected thereby, together with the names of the persons known to be owning or claiming the land running or abutting the portion of such street, avenue, lane, or alley so sought to be abolished or altered, and setting forth the alteration desired or the request for the abolishment thereof, which petition shall be verified by affidavit. Such petition shall be filed with the clerk of the city council of the city, and a notice of the pendency of such petition shall be given by publication in a weekly newspaper, printed and published in the city, for two (2) consecutive insertions in such newspaper, the last insertion thereof to be not more than one week prior to the date on which the city council will consider such petition; such notice shall be given by the clerk of the city council and shall contain a description of the street, avenue, lane, or alley within the city sought to be abolished or altered, and shall state the day and time at which the city council will consider such petition. 
(Ord. No. 1726,  3) 
Sec. 25-13. - Same-Fees. 
    The petitioners upon filing the petition required by section 25-12 shall deposit with the city clerk the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00), to apply to the payment of costs and proceedings which may be heard by the city by reason of such proceedings, and if the same shall exceed such deposit the petitioner shall pay all such additional costs and expenses so incurred, upon demand. 
(Ord. No. 1726,  4) 
Sec. 25-14. - Same-Action by city council. 
    Upon the meeting at the date and time set forth in such notice under section 25-12, the city council shall proceed to hear and determine the same and may enact an ordinance to abolish or alter such street, avenue, lane, or alley to such degree and upon such terms or conditions and in such manner as it, in its discretion may determine; provided, however, that, no such vacation of a street, avenue, lane, or alley shall take place, unless the consent of the persons owning two-thirds of the front feet immediately adjoining thereto is obtained therefor in writing, which consent shall be duly acknowledged and filed with the city clerk prior to the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1726,  5) 
Sec. 25-15. - Reversion of ownership to streets abolished. 
    Whenever any such street, avenue, lane or alley or any part thereof, shall be abolished, as provided in this article, the same shall revert as to ownership according to law. 
(Ord. No. 1726,  6) 
Sec. 25-16. - Acquisition of land in connection with alteration, etc. 
    If such alteration as permitted by this article, shall involve or require the incorporation within any street, avenue, lane, or alley of any land not then located within the same, the acquisition of such additional land shall be made according to law, and it may be a condition thereof that the petitioner shall first deposit the cost of such acquisition with the clerk of the city council before further proceedings are had relative thereto, or the same may be otherwise provided for as provided by law and determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1726,  7) 
Sec. 25-17. - Ordinances abolishing, etc., streets, etc., to be filed with recorder of deeds. 
    Upon the passage, and approval as required by law, of any ordinance to abolish or alter any street, avenue, lane, or alley within the city, the clerk of the city council shall approve and acknowledge a true copy of the same as required by law and file the same for record in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county, and the costs of such recording shall be paid by the petitioners as other costs and expenses incurred with respect thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1726,  9) 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Water from eaves prohibited from spreading over sidewalks,  22-55; private construction of public works, Ch. 23A. 

Sec. 25-18. - Specifications. 
    All sidewalks hereafter constructed shall be constructed according to specifications prepared by the city engineer [director of community development] at the time the sidewalk is ordered to be built. 
(R.O. 1931,  446) 
Sec. 25-19. - Establishment of grades for private construction. 
    Where any property owner desires to build sidewalks or curbing he shall notify the city engineer [director of community development] who shall immediately designate the grade at which the sidewalks or curbing shall be built and location thereof and the same shall be built under his supervision. 
(R.O. 1931,  454) 
Sec. 25-20. - Notification to property owner, etc., of intent of city to construct sidewalks. 
    It shall be the duty of the [deputy] city clerk to prepare the requisite notices, which notices shall be signed by the [deputy] city clerk and be issued under the seal of the city, to be served upon the owners and other persons having any interest in any lot or tract or land within the city along which the city council has by ordinance ordered the construction of sidewalks or curbing, which notices shall contain a description of the property and character of the sidewalk ordered to be constructed. Such notice shall be served as subpoenas are served. 
(R.O. 1931,  451) 
Sec. 25-21. - Inspections by director of community development; notice to repair 
    It shall be the duty of the director of community development to cause all sidewalks in the city to be inspected by himself or his deputy or assistant, at least once each calendar year, and to cause any sidewalk to be inspected when requested by the mayor, the city administrator, or a member of the city council. Upon any finding that any such sidewalk is in need of repair (three-fourths-inch or more out of vertical alignment, or in a badly deteriorated condition), the director of community development shall proceed as follows: 
(a)  To cause a written notice to be served upon or delivered to the owner(s) of all lots or tracts of land fronting or abutting on the part of said lot of said sidewalk found on inspection to be in need of repair setting forth the following: 
(1)  A description of the location of such portion needing repair including reference to the abutting lots or tracts of land. 
(2)  A description of the nature and extent of the repair needed. 
(3)  A statement that if such owner does not cause said portion of said sidewalk to be repaired at such location and to correct the condition described, within thirty (30) days after service or delivery of said notice, that written report will be made by said director of community development to the city council of said city for further proceedings, including repair thereof to be done by the city or its contractor, and to recover the costs thereof by having a special assessment on the particular lot or tract of land fronting or abutting the part to be repaired. 
(b)  If, at the expiration of thirty (30) days after service or delivery of said notice, said sidewalk shall not be repaired at the location and to the extent required to repair the same as so described, said director of community development shall make written report to the city council of said city of the continuing state of deficiency with respect to repair for its consideration and such further proceedings as may be authorized pursuant to Chapter 88, Revised Statutes of the State of Missouri. 
(R.O. 1931,  455, 456; Ord. No. 3616,  2, 12-22-75) 
Sec. 25-21.1. - Installation of brick sidewalks in commercially zoned areas upon special permission from council. 
    The city council may grant special permission in commercially zoned areas for the installation of brick sidewalks where sidewalk installations are required. 
    An application for such sidewalk installation must first have been submitted along with construction plans and an exact site location to the city engineer [director of community development]. The city engineer [director of community development] must submit the application to the city council before approval can be granted. The sidewalks must conform to construction standards as specified by the city engineer [director of community development]. 
(Ord. No. 2833,  1-4) 
ARTICLE V. - HOUSE NUMBERING 

Sec. 25-22. - System established. 
    All houses fronting on public streets, avenues and highways in the city, shall be numbered in conformity with the following provisions: 
(a)  Odd numbers shall be given to houses on the east and south sides of the streets, avenues and highways and even numbers to those on the north and west sides of same. 
(b)  On streets, avenues and highways running northwardly and southwardly in the city, numbering shall commence with number one on Kansas street, and increase one hundred (100) numbers for each block or approximate block. 
(c)  On streets, avenues and highways running eastwardly and westwardly in the city, numbering shall commence with number one on Main Street and increase one hundred (100) numbers for each block or approximate block. 
(R.O. 1931,  459) 
Sec. 25-23. - Assignment of numbers. 
    The city engineer [director of community development] shall designate the numbers of all houses, in conformity with the preceding provisions, and shall furnish the owner of each house, now or hereafter built, with its proper number. When any house is not correctly numbered, or not numbered at all, the engineer [director of community development] shall give such house its proper number and require that same be put on such house in a conspicuous place next to the street. 
(R.O. 1931,  460) 
ARTICLE VI. - MANAGING THE USE AND OCCUPANCY OF PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY FOR THE CITY OF LIBERTY, MISSOURI[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10831,  IV(Exh. A), adopted Dec. 11, 2017, amended Art. VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. VI,  25-24-25-45, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 9545,  1, adopted Jan. 25, 2010; and Ord. No. 10014,  I, adopted Jan. 28, 2013. 

Sec. 25-24. - Policy. 
    It shall be the policy of the city to authorize use of the rights-of-way in a manner that minimizes interference to the public use and minimizes the burden on the rights-of-way physically and aesthetically to the full extent permitted by law. Any use of the rights-of-way by any person shall be subject to the terms and conditions hereof, in addition to all applicable federal, state, or local requirements. 
    The right granted to a person to use the rights-of-way is limited to the use that the person has filed with the city and approved in accordance with this article. These rights shall grant nonexclusive use only to that person except where otherwise provided herein or when expressly authorized by the city. 
    No provision of this article shall apply to any circumstance in which such application shall be unlawful under superseding federal or state law and furthermore, if any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this article is now or in the future superseded or preempted by state or federal law or found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unauthorized, such provision shall be automatically interpreted and applied as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 10831,  IV(Exh. A), 12-11-17) 
Sec. 25-25. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to this article, except that where the definitions set forth in RSMo  67.1830 (Supp. 2001), as may be amended, are required by law to apply to specific uses of the rights-of-way, such definitions shall apply to such circumstances. 
    Abandoned facilities means those facilities owned by a ROW user that are not in use or cannot be utilized by the owner in the future and as otherwise defined by applicable law. 
    Administrative fee means that fee charged by the city to administer all aspects of rights-of-way management to recover its cost of this management in accordance with applicable law. 
    Applicant means any person required to apply for a rights-of-way permit. 
    City means the City of Liberty, Missouri, a municipal corporation and any duly authorized representative. 
    City specifications means the City of Liberty Technical Specifications and Design Criteria for public improvement projects on file with the deputy city clerk as of the date of this article, and incorporated herein, and as may be amended from time to time by the authority of the public works director establishing such specifications and procedures consistent with the requirements and purposes of this article. 
    Communications service means the transmission via facilities, in whole or in part, of any writing, signs, signals, pictures, sounds or other forms of intelligence through wire, wireless, or other means, including, but not limited to, any telecommunications service, enhanced service, information service, or internet service, as such terms are now, or may in the future be, defined under applicable law, and including all instrumentalities, facilities, apparatus (communications facilities), and services (among other things, the receipt, forwarding, and delivery of telecommunications) incidental to such transmission or designed to directly or indirectly facilitate or accept such transmission and shall also include "video services" as defined in  67.2677 RSMo. The term "communications service" does not include the rental of conduit or physical facilities. 
    Construct means and includes construct, install, erect, build, affix or otherwise place any fixed structure or object in, on, under, through or above the rights-of-way. 
    Director or public works director means the public works director, Liberty, Missouri, or his or her authorized representative. 
    Emergency means any incident that requires immediate intrusion and work within the rights-of-way to restore service to a user or otherwise protect the general welfare and safety. 
    Excavate means any act by which earth, asphalt, concrete, sand, gravel, rock or any other material in or on the ground is cut into, dug, uncovered, removed, or otherwise displaced by means of any tools, equipment, or explosives, except as excluded by applicable law. 
    Excess capacity means the remaining volume or capacity in any existing or future duct, conduit, manhole, handhold, or other facility, including dark fiber, in the ROW that is used, or authorized by the ROW user to be used, by others. 
    Embedded means to surround tightly or incorporate. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. 
    Facility means all/any lines, pipes, irrigation systems, wires, cables, conduit facilities, poles, towers, vaults, pedestals, boxes, or other equipment owned or controlled by an entity other than the city. 
    Facility-based service provider means a service provider owning or possessing facilities in the rights-of-way. 
    Franchise means the rights and obligations extended by the city to certain ROW users to occupy the rights-of-way for the purpose of providing, transporting, or distributing electricity, gas, water, steam, lighting, energy, or sewer service to any person or area within the city's limits and boundaries. 
    Governing body means the mayor and the city council of the City of Liberty, Missouri. 
    Governmental entity means any subdivision of the governments within the United States of America. 
    License means the rights and obligations extended by the city to a person to use and occupy the rights-of-way for the purpose of installing temporary facilities in the rights-of-way or incidental uses such as ingress and egress facilities, lateral utility lines, mailboxes, or driveway aprons. 
    PSC means the Missouri Public Service Commission. 
    Pavement means the improved surface of the public way with concrete, asphalt, aggregate, or other treated materials. 
    Person means an individual, person, or body natural or corporate. 
    Public easement means any easement for utilities, access, or other use dedicated to the city or in the name of the city irrespective of whether the easement is held in trust by the city for private and public users and regardless of whether private utilities or others in addition to or other than the city are actually using the easements. 
    Public improvement means any public project undertaken by the city for the public good or when such is required by public necessity, or public convenience and security require it, or such other findings in the public interest that may require relocation, adjustment, or removal at the cost of the ROW user. 
    Public lands means any real property owned by the city not used as rights-of-way or considered to be rights-of-way. 
    Restoration means returning the rights-of-way surface to its original condition, or better. 
    Reseller service provider means a person providing service within the city that does not have its own facilities in the rights-of-way, but instead uses the rights-of-way by interconnecting with or using the network elements of another ROW user utilizing the rights-of-way, and/or by leasing excess capacity from an entity having facilities in the ROW with no right to physically access the facilities or ROW. 
    Rights-of-way or ROW means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street or alleyway in which the city has an ownership interest, and including such adjacent area of such public ways within such ownership interest as made available by the city for rights-of-way use herein, but not including: 
(1)  Easements obtained by utilities or private easements in platted subdivisions or tracts; 
(2)  Railroad rights-of-way and ground utilized or acquired for railroad facilities; 
(3)  Poles, pipes, cables, conduits, wires, optical cables, or other means of transmission, collection or exchange of communications, information, substances, data, or electronic or electrical current or impulses utilized by a utility owned or operated by a governmental entity pursuant to RSMo ch. 91 or pursuant to a charter form of government; or 
(4)  The airwaves above a public rights-of-way with regard to cellular or other nonwire telecommunications or broadcast services. 
    Rights-of-way permit means the authorization to make excavations or perform work for the construction, installation, repair, or maintenance of any type of facility within the rights-of-way. 
    Rights-of-way use agreement or ROW use agreement means the rights and obligations extended by the city to a person to occupy the ROW for the purpose of providing any form of communications service to any person or area within the city's limits and boundaries, or any other person desiring to use the ROW for which a franchise or license is not applicable, subject to the regulations and requirements herein. 
    Rights-of-way user or ROW user means such persons and entities, whether a PSC registered utility or otherwise, owning, controlling, leasing maintaining, using or installing facilities in the rights-of-way of the city unless otherwise exempted by law. The term shall not include the city; provided that the city shall nevertheless comply with all such requirements applicable to ROW users to the extent such compliance is otherwise required by state or federal law. The term shall also not include lawful vehicular parking or pedestrian use. 
    Work means construction, alteration, maintenance, installation, storage, or location of facilities installed below, on, or above ground in the rights-of-way, other than excavation that also: 
(1)  Causes or threatens to cause any obstruction or interference to any vehicular or pedestrian traffic or traffic lane in the rights-of-way; 
(2)  Involves temporary or permanent storage of materials or equipment on rights-of-way; 
(3)  Causes or reasonably may cause damage to any public improvement within the rights-of-way; or 
(4)  Removal, replacement, or alteration to any safety feature or requirement within the rights-of-way, including but not limited to removal of manhole covers, altering lighting, traffic signage or signals, placement, or removal of traffic barricades, etc. 
    Work shall not include routine or other maintenance on poles, boxes, or other facilities that does not result in one or more of the circumstances described in subparagraphs (1) through (4) herein. 
(Ord. No. 10831,  IV(Exh. A), 12-11-17) 
Sec. 25-26. - Administration. 
    The public works director is the principal city official responsible for administration of rights-of-way permits for work and excavations made in the rights-of-way. The public works director may delegate any or all of the duties hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 10831,  IV(Exh. A), 12-11-17) 
Sec. 25-27. - Franchise or rights-of-way use agreement required. 
(a)  Agreement or franchise required. Except when otherwise authorized by applicable law, no ROW user may construct, maintain, own, control, or use facilities in the rights-of-way without a franchise or ROW use agreement with the city as provided herein. All such franchises and agreements shall be approved by ordinance of the governing body on a nondiscriminatory basis provided that the applicant is in compliance with all applicable requirements. Unless otherwise required by applicable law, no rights-of-way permit may be issued unless or until such person has a valid franchise, license, or ROW use agreement with the city. Such franchises and agreements shall be deemed to incorporate the terms of this article and other applicable laws of the city, except as may be expressly stated in such agreements and franchises. Reseller service providers shall not be required to obtain a franchise or agreement but shall be required to register with the city prior to providing service on forms provided by the city. 
(1)  Franchise. A franchise shall be required from the city in conformance with all applicable franchise procedures for any ROW user seeking to use the rights-of-way for purposes of providing or distribution of electricity, gas, water, steam, lighting, or sewer public utility service in the city, except where otherwise provided by law. Such franchise may be granted only after satisfaction of all applicable procedural or substantive requirements established by charter or other law. 
(2)  ROW use agreement. A ROW use agreement with the city shall be required for all ROW users not set forth in subsection (1), irrespective of any state licensing, franchise, or certificate that may also be held by the ROW user, except as otherwise required herein or by law. Such agreements shall conform to all applicable law, but shall not be subject to procedures applicable to franchises and the city may, if appropriate, approve form agreements that may be executed by the mayor after approval by the city council. 
(3)  License. Incidental uses of the public rights-of-way may be permitted without a franchise or ROW use agreement pursuant to a license issued by the public works director. The public works director may establish such application, requirements, and conditions applicable to such uses consistent with the purposes of this article or as otherwise established by law. Any person granted a license hereunder shall be subject to the applicable requirements of this article. 
(b)  Franchises and agreements nonexclusive. The authority granted by the city in any agreement or franchise shall be for nonexclusive use of the rights-of-way. Such grant does not in any way limit the continuing authority of the city through the proper exercise of its statutory powers to adopt and enforce ordinances necessary to provide for the health, safety, and welfare of the public. The city specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, such additional agreements or other rights to use the rights-of-way for any purpose and to any other person, including itself, as it deems appropriate, subject to all applicable law. The granting of an agreement or franchise shall not be deemed to create any property interest of any kind in favor of the ROW user nor shall it create any relationship of agency, partnership, joint venture, or employment between the parties. 
(c)  No warranty. The city makes no express or implied representation or warranty regarding its rights to authorize the installation or construction of facilities on any particular segment of rights-of-way and shall not be liable for any damage therefrom. The burden and responsibility for making all such determinations in advance of construction or installation shall be entirely upon the ROW user. The ROW user shall be solely liable for any damages to facilities or other property due to excavation or other ROW work performed prior to obtaining the location of all facilities. The ROW user shall not make or attempt to make repairs, relocation, or replacement of damaged or disturbed facilities without the approval of the owner of the facilities. 
(d)  Use of city or third-party facilities . No ROW use agreement, franchise, or license shall grant the right to use facilities owned or controlled by the city or a third party, and no such use shall occur, without the express written consent of such party (on file with the city and subject to other applicable requirements), nor shall any franchise, ROW use agreement, or license excuse such person from first obtaining a pole attachment agreement or other express consent for such right or use before locating on the facilities controlled or owned by the city or a third party. 
(e)  Lease required for public lands. Unless otherwise provided, use or installation of any facilities in, on, or over public lands of the city not constituting rights-of-way shall be permitted only if a lease agreement or other separate written approval has been negotiated and approved by the city with such reasonable terms and conditions as the city may require. 
(f)  Transferability. Except as provided in this article or as otherwise required by law, no franchise, agreement, license, other written authorization, or rights-of-way permit may be transferred without the written application to and consent of the city based on the requirements and policies of this article. The city shall not unreasonably withhold its consent to transfer as provided herein, but any costs incurred shall be paid by the applicant. 
(g)  Forfeiture of agreement and privilege. In case of failure on the part of the ROW user, including its successors and assigns to comply with any of the provisions of this article or a ROW use agreement, franchise, license, or other authorization, or if the ROW user, its successors and assigns should do or cause to be done any act or thing prohibited by or in violation of this article or the terms of the authorization of such use, or otherwise loses authority to provide its service in the city, the ROW user, its successors and assigns shall forfeit all rights and privileges permitted by this article and any ROW use agreement, franchise, license, or other authorization, and all rights hereunder shall cease, terminate, and become null and void, provided that said forfeiture shall not take effect until the city shall carry out the following proceedings: Before the city declares the forfeiture or revocation of a ROW use agreement, franchise, license, or other authorization, it shall first serve a written notice upon the person setting forth in detail the neglect or failure complained of, and the person shall have thirty (30) days thereafter, or such other reasonable period established by the city council, in which to cure the default by complying with the conditions of the ROW use agreement, franchise, license, or other authorization or requirement and fully remedying any default or violation. If at the end of such period the city determines that the conditions have not been complied with and that the person did not reasonably and in the public interest require more than thirty (30) days to cure the default, the city shall take action by an affirmative vote of the city council present at the meeting and voting to terminate the ROW use agreement, franchise, license, or other authorization, setting out the grounds upon which said agreement or other authorization is to be forfeited or revoked. Nothing herein shall prevent the city from invoking any other remedy or from declaring immediate forfeiture where the default is incapable of being cured by the ROW user, including where such defaults or violations have repeatedly occurred. 
(h)  Application for franchise or agreement required. 
(1)  Application. An application for franchise or ROW use agreement shall be presented to the public works director in writing and shall include all such information as is required by this section. The ROW user shall be responsible for accurately maintaining the information in the application during the term of any franchise or agreement and shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city due to the failure to provide or maintain as accurate any application information required herein. 
(2)  Application fee. An application deposit fee for review, documentation and approval of such agreement or franchise shall be established by the public works director to recover any actual costs anticipated and incurred by the city in reviewing, documenting, or negotiating such agreement or franchise, provided that no costs shall be included if such inclusion is prohibited by applicable law as to that applicant. If the actual costs are thereafter determined to be less than the application deposit fee, such amount shall be returned to the applicant after written request therefrom; if the actual costs reasonably exceed the application fee, applicant shall, after written notice from the city, pay such additional amount prior to issuance by the city of any final approval. The city may require compensation for use of the ROW or other public property as may be reasonably required by the city council, subject to applicable law. 
(3)  Application form. A ROW user shall submit a completed application for franchise or ROW use agreement on such form provided by the city, which shall include information necessary to determine compliance with this article, including but not limited to: 
a.  Identity and legal status of the ROW user; 
b.  Name, address, telephone number, and email address of each officer, agent, or employee responsible for the accuracy of the application. Each officer, agent, or employee shall be familiar with the local facilities of the ROW user, shall be the person(s) to whom notices shall be sent and shall be responsible for facilitating all necessary communications including, but not limited to, certification to the city of any material changes to the information provided in such completed application during the term of any franchise or ROW use agreement; 
c.  Name, address, telephone number, and email address of the local representative of the ROW user who shall be available at all times to act on behalf of the ROW user in the event of an emergency; 
d.  Proof of any necessary permit, license, certification, grant, registration, franchise, agreement or any other authorization required by any appropriate governmental entity including, but not limited to, the FCC or the PSC;
